column10: Crap on a stick.
Online co-op, as ALL RE'S SHOULD BE. Pretty solid.

Thank goodness I didn't buy the full version. This is dog shit! From the saves, to the enemies, to the design, to the story, to the lighting, to the controls, to everything. They put too much that they didn't even bother to make it at least decent. I had to force myself to enjoy this crap for 3 hours and not even a second I experience fun.

Not Recommended.

The game is just another vestige of Crapcom dark ages these days, with everything checking up: bad DLC practices, a badly directed John Mctiernan low tier mashup of action sequences, and a backward policy of appealing to the supposed West audience that appealed to an imaginary public instead.

Story was somewhat decent, the gunplay/combat was also really innovative to the series at the time of original release, and the characters also ended alright, but that basically ends there with a counter part to each of them: The story was destroyed by the terrible pacing and the huge amount of unnecessary action sequences and explosions, the gunplay and combat were ruined by enemies with huuuge mercy windows that would put grounded fighting game characters to shame, and the somewhat non bland characters were victims of mary sues and obvious plot armor.

On the topic of the Extra game modes, normal Mercenaries was trash, but the No Mercy version, the one that includes the L4Dead colab, man, that was a real blast, one which i'm seeing myself playing for a good while post 100%. 
The rest is not worth mentioning, Capcom to this day still didn't learn the basic concept of m.p. loop engagement and dedicated servers.

An overall safe and skippable chapter of Biohazard if you're not a big enjoyer of the series. One that may or may not warrant a remake.

[h1]
Story - 4
Gameplay - 4
Scenario - 1
Sync - 2
Sense - 3

Final - 2.8/5[/h1]

My only complaint about this game is often times during high action scenes, the camera will swap on you to an awkward angle. Other than that though, RE 6 is an AMAZING co-op entry in the series. Definitely recommend grabbing a friend to play this with.

Controversial Opinion... I'd rather play this game again than ever run through Resident Evil 7 and it's super Bullet Absorbing enemies known as the molded. My reasoning is because I think way too many people throw shade at this game for the wrong reasons, One of the reason's I can absolutely agree with is that it is too damn long for an RE Game, usually you are looking at about 8-12 hours of gameplay with a typical RE Game, Unless you are playing RE1 Classic or RE3 Classic those were quite short clocking in at maybe 3-5 hours. But RE6 is maybe 20-28 hours thanks too the fact that the stories are split into 4 different campaigns, that last maybe 5-7 hours each, It really does overstay it's welcome especially with there being a lot of quicktime events in the game, which is another big reason this game got hate. I think the people who bitch about the story are overreacting, Has there ever really been a Resident Evil game that has had a good story? None of them really had an amazing narrative, not even the newer ones and don't try lying to yourself. The gameplay can honestly be real stupid fun, not to mention with a friend in coop. And not to mention... Better Than Starfield.

As a Resident Evil game, it doesn't fit much with the rest of the games but by no means is it a bad game. There is a lot of content in this game and as a person who has bought this on multiple platforms, it is worth it. If you have a friend, it makes a really good co op game and there are a good amount of campaigns that are lengthy for each one which is pretty cool. I like the combat, the characters, and the gameplay just keeps me hooked surprisingly. There are other modes you can play like Mercenaries and Agent Hunt which adds to the game. If you are looking for a classic survival horror RE game, look elsewhere but a good game for just dumb fun and content....this is your game.

Duuude.. this game is a literal hate love(for me personally) and if there would be a third option to vote for reviews like a neutral(“—“) vote, I would do it because I cannot really down- or upvote this game.
Some situations/parts and certain things(which seem to be only bad programmed) I just hate in that game and don't even want to proceed further in the game and then there are some situations and certain things where I absolutely like that game.
And to be fully honest, I got so pissed off during a certain part in the game that I not only was about to rage quit, uninstall that game and never play it again, but also give that game definitely a thumbs down..
[h3]AI Character[/h3]
There’s one super annoying thing I really hate about the AI in this game and that’s the fact that you have to play babysitter but what does that mean?
If you are at a certain spot where you have to press “V”(on PC) to perform an action like opening doors or to boost the AI onto something and as soon as you pressed “V”, you’re stuck in this action until the AI is with you to perform this action but what makes this so annoying? 
It’s simply the fact that you cannot cancel this action by yourself which means that if the AI is miles away from you, it takes forever for the AI to come to you.
The only way this action will be cancelled is if you’re attacked by an enemy which is imo the most dumbest thing I have ever seen.
I mean there are other spots where you have to perform QTE(Quick-Time-Events) in the game where you have to spin a Valve Wheel by quickly pressing “WASD”(on PC) and this action you can cancel by pressing “Space”(on PC), why the hell isn’t that possible with the other actions where you have to wait for the AI?
[h3]Inventory[/h3]
I cannot tell how long it took me to understand and get used to this inventory system.
(This is a little “Guide” to demonstrate this “special” inventory system) 
Combining herbs and selecting any utility is so stupid weird..
For combining herbs you have to press “E” to open the main inventory, scroll to the green herb, press “Space” to select it, press again “Space” to select the second green or red herb and then press again “Space” to combine it – if you want to store the combined herb, you have press again “Space” to select the herb and then press again “Space to store it in the “tablet case”.
See, absolutely dumb and super laborious…
To select any utility you have to press “Shift” to open the “sub-inventory” and then you have all your utilities.
… just don’t ask me, why, ok x) 
I have never seen a more dumb and laborious inventory system in any other game!
[h3]Tutorial[/h3]
Yep, this Resident Evil Part does have a Tutorial which you have to play first before playing the actual game but spoiler alert; [spoiler]the entire tutorial is also a Part in the final Chapter of the Leon Campaign.[/spoiler]
[h3]Controls[/h3]
This game has a completely different controls compared to all other Resident Evil Part’s!
Usually you press and hold “Shift” to sprint in almost every game but in this game you have to press and hold “Space” to sprint..
For example; there was a Part in Chris' Campaign - Chapter 3, where I got so pissed off, that I not only was about to rage quit and uninstall the game, but also definitely would've given that game a thumbs down because there was a Part in this Chapter where I thought to be stuck(I died 44 times in this Part) and only a comment in a other f*cking Steam discussion(from 10 years ago) helped me to proceed because the game itself didn't tell me anything, during the entire play through and at first I thought it was a bug but it wasn't, it was only the very first time in the game where I had to use “Space” to sprint which I apparently didn’t needed before.
As I already have written in my Resident Evil 4 2005 Review, the QTE happen at least on PC sooo stupid fast where you have literally a time window of max 1 second to react with a weird combination of keys on the keyboard whereas you have all buttons on the controller directly ready to hand – as much as I have seen in videos on YouTube, you have a react time window of about 3 seconds with controller, like?? x)
[h3]Ada[/h3]
There’s nothing to complain about her, she’s the real boss in the entire Resident Evil Franchise(you can say what you want) and she knows exactly what she is doing – oh and her love for Leon(and vice versa of course) is so special, especially the scene of those two on the Quad Tower in Lanshiang!
[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The way the gameplay is in this Resident Evil Part is how I imagine it as a typical Resident Evil gameplay. 
But this game had also it’s few situations again where too much happen at ones - my biggest complaign especially in this game would be that it's quite unnecessary to fight besides the boss also the regular zombies as it was already in Resident Evil 3 Remake(penultimate Nemesis Boss fight).
[h3]Bosse[/h3]
A few bosses were really easy whereas other bosses where just annoying and kinda hard to beat.
Those who have played Resident Evil 7 before this Resident Evil here, will definitely recognize a certain boss fight again ;)
[h3]Game Length[/h3]
For my personal taste, this game has a wayyy too long story length and honestly it felt like I was playing 4 Resident Evil Parts because each Campaign took me about 9 hours to beat, only the Ada Campaign took me about 6 hours.
[h3]Graphics[/h3]
Honestly? For a Game which was released back in 2012, this game looks really good!
[h3]Rating[/h3]
As I have said at the beginning of this review, I was about to give this game definitely a thumbs down but later on I really began to enjoy and like this game. I'd give that game a 7/10!

[h1]Resident Evil's Lowest Point[/h1]
Resident Evil 6 is a 2012 third-person shooter video game developed and published by Capcom. A major installment in the Resident Evil series, Players control Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Jake Muller and Ada Wong as they confront the force behind a worldwide bio-terrorist attack. The story is centered around their four interwoven campaigns, and every campaign features a unique style in both tone and gameplay.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil 6 has such a mix set of graphics. First I have to say that the UI is actual torture. Whoever made the UI in this game hates you and wants you to truly suffer. Wanna pause the game and change settings? F*ck you, basically. You can pause the game with a big PAUSE in the middle of the screen, but changing audio settings or controls while playing is a nightmare. Having to navigate through your game phone “no joke” is comical at best. I guess it’s cool that every character’s story has a different style UI? It would have been better if the UI was easy to navigate. Also switching weapons is a huge pain too so have fun with that. The lighting is pretty good in some sections (especially Leon’s campaign), while others look so washed out and depressing. The world textures are disgusting if you get close to them. The character models and cinematics do look really good though.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Okay the gameplay is pretty average on a good day. Now the movement is the best in the franchise. Being able to roll and dive around during some cool dodges is pretty addicting. I really enjoyed the movement in this game. The shooting not so much. I can’t put my finger on it but the shooting feels so stiff and hard to aim. Playing RE4 and RE5 was day and night different in terms of gunplay compared to RE6. It’s not good here I will say, the gunplay is pretty awful. Speaking of awful, for a game that focuses on actions and a ton of enemies, sure hates giving you ammo. Breaking a grate or killing an enemy sometimes gives you ammo, but most of the time you will get skill points. The skills in this game don’t really make a huge deal here from my experience. Only a few are worth using, so most are just filler. The drop rates are horrible, most of the time you will get skill points and no ammo so good luck. I don’t see why they added the skills in this game, they don’t play a big role here. Honestly you can play without them and your gameplay will barely change at all. The map design is trash. Jakes snow mission is torture, chris’s helicopter chase section is a pain at best, and much more. Also this game feels like an action flick with a taste of michael bay. I swear they have a love for explosions here. It's pretty comical. Oh and if you enjoy QTE’s, this is the game for you. Literally you will be doing QTE’s for the most pointless reason, like finding keys in a car for example. It’s hard to find something good here. I guess the Co-op is fun, if you don’t crash a lot. Oh and the enemy design is heartbreaking (they have half human/half grasshopper enemies). That says enough.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story is actually pretty interesting I will say. Playing through it, not so much. I just didn’t have a good time with some sections of the game. Chris was fun, Leon was good, Jake was meh, and Ada’s was the worst. This game is canon so if you are wanting to dive deeper into the Resident Evil Universe, you will learn a lot here from the story. It just felt kinda weak and forgettable from my experience.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]In terms of co-op, it’s pretty fun. As fun as it gets for this game I guess. I would totally prefer company while playing this game since the co-op is actually really well implemented here (well kinda). I have experienced crashes on co-op and lost of connection sadly. It’s not rapid, but it can happen. The PVP is trash. Just get a friend and get the achievements since it’s so bland and a bore fest (also no one plays it).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]To beat all the stories it takes around 20+ hours (depending on difficulty). If you focused on getting 100% it will take you around 60-70+ hours.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]I will say that the voice acting is actually pretty good. I really enjoyed the cutscenes a lot here. The music is a no no sadly. The soundtrack feels like an afterthought. Prepare to hear a lot of generic action music, also has the weakest safe theme in the franchise (from my experience).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I didn’t notice any game breaking bugs or weird glitches from my experience. Besides the loss of connection while playing co-op at times.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]RE6 runs really well on my system. Being able to play max settings with a solid 60fps, it looked really smooth with no stutters or glitches.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Multiple campaigns
[*]Great voice acting
[*]Awesome mobility and movement
[*]UI is different and unique for every campaign
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Level design is bad
[*]Too many quick time events
[*]Textures can look awful
[*]So many on rail sections
[*]ALT+TAB can possibly crash the game
[*]Stories are forgettable and not interesting
[*]Phone menu idea is horrible (no pausing while going through settings)
[*]Random connection lost during co-op (not all the time, but it happens enough)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]4/10
Get this game on a huge sale for around 75% or more.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil 6 to me left a mark on the franchise and not for the good reasons. With the QTE spams, horrible pacing, confusing/forgettable story, horrible mechanics and game design, etc. So many issues this game possesses that it’s hard to give it a thumbs up. I didn’t follow the hate train mainly because I got into RE way after release (not counting my first experience with Outbreak on the PS2, amazing game btw). I came to this game with open arms and it spat me right in the face. I thought I would somewhat enjoy it, ignoring all the hate and bs, but my god was I wrong. This was the Franchise's worst time in its history, with RE7 saving the franchise and I can see why it did. I would skip this atrocity of a game. If you are wanting to learn the lore of RE or are collecting all the games, get this on a huge discount.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Sadly, the reason I really can't recommend this game is solely because Crapcom has decided to put in a Russian DRM that's so easily compromised, you'd be less exposed walking into a snowstorm in your underwear. This is to say nothing of Capcom openly banning certain mods across most of their games. Like a number of AAA gaming companies, both here and overseas, it has become anti-consumer, and seems like it may continue to be in the near future. With that, I cannot recommend for anyone to buy this game. Piracy or emulation is the way to go, now. Thank you for reading.

I played this game back when it first came out on the Xbox 360 and didn't think it was bad. Upon playing this game again on PC I feel nothing but sadness. I know Resident Evil 5 gets a lot of hate but I gotta say the game-play in that was like butter compared to what I have experienced in the few hours of playing Resident Evil 6. If you're looking at buying this game in the future do not unless its cheap. I am not happy playing this game again and do not recommend it. If you're looking to play this game for the story just watch someones play-through. 

To expand on my review I didn't like the dodge mechanics mixed with the camera view made it very hard to play. The fact that playing on normal even with all the ammo I had, enemies seem to take so much damage it made me wonder what is the point of head shots when it doesn't work. The melee system in the game is kinda cool but the range of it working is lacking, such as when you're close enough to damage an enemy it would miss the melee (haha). There would be zombies with weapons attached to them and you would have to damage the zombie enough to use the "insta kill" on it when it should just be the first option not 99 damage and then we get the "insta kill" . Would also like to add the skill system in the game is kinda of garbage. Adding skills to the game to make up for the lack of good game-play is just sad. I know this game came out in 2013 but comparing it to Resident Evil 4 and 5 which came out before why change the mechanics now.

Maybe playing this on controller is easier I'll try again later...

This game is so unbelievably boring. Played 2/4 campaigns and every single moment was so dull. After finishing Leon's one I decided to give a chance to Chris' one to see if it was better, but it was even worse.

RE5 story was the funny kind of bad, but this one is the boring kind of bad. Besides, there's basically no story at all, just excuses to change scenarios and keep killing zombies.

On the zombies topic, the physical combat is good, I liked that addition, but guns feel bad, there's little to no feedback when shooting. Am I hitting a weak point? Am I doing no damage at all? I have no idea.
Boss fights are eternal, and not the epic kind of long bosses you might be thinking of, they really drag on and are interrupted so much. 

Same with the campaign. 4 campaigns of (I assume) 5-6 hs of length, but they all revolve around the same (terrible) plot so once you finish one, the rest is the same from other perspectives. At around the 3hs mark it already starts dragging on, and out of boredom and wanting to finish them already, at the end of these campaigns I would just start running past all enemies and discovered that they literally don't attack you if you're running, even if you pass right by their side, I started ignoring all enemies and they wouldn't even pursue me most of the time.

Ambience is terrible as well, most generic soundtrack that almost seems to disappear at times, really doesn't help with immersion, same with the huge amount of scripted events, at times it makes you question if you should even shoot the enemies because it might as well be a scripted event

The worst Resident evil by far. That's not to say that everything about it is bad. They definitely had something going for themselves when they made this. For example, the ability to dodge and roll like Max Payne is pretty fun. However, the crappy textures, weak gunplay and just general way the game is constructed is sloppy. Play with friends for best experience.

Resident Evil 6 is a large departure from the survival horror established in the original trilogy. If you loved the action present in RE4 and RE5, then you'll likely feel at home with RE6. Just don't go into this game expecting a semblance of competent storytelling. The plot goes all over the place (literally with you trekking various countries as well as figuratively). It's just a game you play for its gameplay. Shooting is decent and fighting the zombies is mindless fun. Pretty much worth its price on sale because it goes for really steep discounts given its age.

Resident Evil 6 is a must-Play game in my opinion, but not for the reasons you would think. Or let me rephrase that: Not for the reasons you would hope for your game to be called a must-Play. It's common knowledge by now that this game is an absolute shit Show of different design choices and the prime example of what happens when a game diverges too far from its roots.
Resident Evil 1 was a slow, atmospheric and, for the time, terrifying experience (I think, I haven't actually played it myself). Even the over the top hack'n'slasher Devil May Cry, which was originally being developed as RE 4, showed some of those characteristics like the slow start before any action happend and at times very atmospheric levels. Well take that shit and throw it out the window, RE 6 is here leveling bridges and crashing helicopters into buildings in the fucking prologue.
Resident Evil 6 had the potential to be something great, but it isn't. And it's all the better for it, because this game is fucking hilarious. Grab a friend and play this with them and I guarantee you will have a great time.
What did you expect me to actually review this game? No, this game is so blood crazy it doesn't deserve a proper review. It has transcended normal games where reviews require metrics like gameplay and story. There is only one metric that applies to this game and that is how fucking insane is it and on a scale of 1 to 10 it's OVER 9000.
Some bad games or movies, etc. are often called, so bad it's good, but that doesn't apply to the game. I think a more fitting sentence would be such a clusterfuck it's hilarious. I encourage you to put down your hard earned cash for this game, just to experience the batshit insane nature of it and to subsequently question what kind of drugs Capcom's employees were on to think this was an acceptable mainline entry for Resident Evil.
My friend perfectly summed ip this game when he said "This game is a constant mix of 'That's pretty cool!', 'What the fuck?' and 'AAAAH'".

CONS:

-Too many QTE even with auto complete option.
-Unintuitive inventory interface.

PROS:
+okay third person shooter
+attractive characters.

I love RE games, but I usually just play them once and am done with them. Like most solo story base games.
This one though, despite being the fan least favorite, kept me hooked and I still play it regularly. Joining a random coop session or whatever.
If you are looking solely for a RE game, you'll be disappointed indeed, as it is far different from the holy trinity (RE1/2/3).
I think what I really like about the game is the rythm, and the balance between action/shooting/QTE/escape scenes, etc...
Maybe if you have an ADHD brain like mine, you'll like it, as you never linger too much in one thing and everything is so various and flashy. The game is also linear and straightforward, there is no frustrating labyrinth or anything to waste your time. Pure packed action, little time to get bored, nothing too difficult or nerve-wracking. A frustration free game.
The story is often criticized, however I did find it interesting. We always love to see the ever stoic Ada and her character being explored in more depth, Leon is still himself, altruistic with his peculiar sense of humor. Chris is also himself, and we can see some interesting character development in his campaign. Finally, it is nice to see grown up Sherry and her dynamic with Jake is interesting.
It is all very subjective of course, but RE6 became one of my favorite game, one that I can play multiple times without being bored.
PS: If you play it in the highest difficulty setting, you'll actually get that Survival Horror experience, lacking ammo and all that jazz...

I've played through several Resident Evil games and I really loved the earlier ones. I didn't know much about RE6 when I picked it up for 5€ on this Winter sale.
Resident Evil 6 lets you choose out of four available campaigns, each accompanied by a different pair of protagonists. The story was meant to intertwine between these campaigns, but sadly the result is pretty confusing. Apparently story isn't that important in RE6 - you find yourself in a city overrun by zombies and that's basically all you need to know.
In contrast to its survival horror predecessors, Resident Evil 6 is a full-bloodied shooter. You have unlimited inventory space, the game is automatically saved on checkpoints, there is no map and puzzles are reduced to zero. Along with these "improvements", the game is now insanely linear - most of the times you can't even return to the room you visited just moments ago. If that wasn't bad enough, real-time events are sure to put the nail in the coffin. Every now and then, the gameplay is chopped by a real-time event in which you are forced to press a certain button combination or do something quickly (otherwise you'll die in most cases). This literally happens around every other corner and it's really irritating. The only good thing about RE6 is the presentation. Despite the game being rather dark, the interiors are full of details and look very realistic. Zombies have been animated excellently and voice acting in cut-scenes is top-notch. Thanks to that, the creepy atmosphere characteristic to Resident Evil games is still present in RE6.

If you're thinking about buying Resident Evil 6, just don't. You won't miss out on anything, story-related or otherwise. This game is just another horror shooter and there are lots of better horror shooters out there.

Former positive review:
You know what? No. This game isn't ass. This game isn't ass at all, and I want to give a sincere "screw you" to everyone who told me it was and stopped me from playing this game earlier. This is one of the best third-person shooters I've ever played bar none. 

RE6's gameplay is very in-depth, though almost to a fault. Those who go in blind will likely struggle a lot with it, but after learning the game and how its mechanics work, I can say with full certainty that it has some of the smoothest, most understated gameplay I've seen in a game like this. Quick shots allow you to quickly put an enemy in a daze if they're getting a little too close, dash attacks allow you to quickly take a small group out, sliding allows you to get through large groups relatively unscathed, and diving basically replaces the QTEs of RE4 and 5 with a mechanic that makes you feel much more in control of what your player character does. The game didn't tell you "press X to dodge", you had to input the dodge [i]yourself[/i]. It makes for a game where you feel much more in control of what your player character is doing. If the game had explained these mechanics better, a lot of the "enemies don't react to my shots" comments would go away. They don't react to your shots because you're [i]not supposed to just be shooting them blindly[/i]. It puts great focus on choosing what method of attacking is best for the given situation, be it shooting, quick shooting, meleeing, sliding, whatever it may be, and once you get used to it, it's extremely fun to play with. 

My main issues with the game lie with other problems. Some smaller, like I'm not a big fan of Leon's VA around this time. Others larger; for example, the Nintendo Switch version added support for gyro aiming, while the PC version is still missing this feature. PC definitely has a rockier situation when it comes to implementation of features not found in the basic Xbox 360 controller, but given Capcom also made Okami, which has proper Steam Input integration (including support for gyro input), they totally know how to implement stuff like that properly, and it's disappointing that they don't. Also the bosses just kinda suck. I won't defend those. They may LOOK cool, a giant flech-mecha t-rex is metal as hell, but they're rarely fun to fight.

TL;DR, Capcom should make this gameplay into a spinoff series for Resident Evil. It's too good to just be left in one game. The RE series in general may have moved past its action phase, which is probably for the best, but that doesn't mean this needs to be completely forgotten. I will die on this hill: RE6 is NOT a bad game, I wouldn't even call it mediocre. While it has its bad moments, all and all I found the game extremely enjoyable once I got used to its unorthodox gameplay mechanics.. I recommend trying this game. Definitely not as an introduction to the series GOD no, but for those who are already experienced with the rest of the RE franchise, it's a fun change of pace, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

Resident Evil 6 is a divisive entry in the iconic survival horror franchise, and my experience with it has been nothing short of a rollercoaster ride. Capcom's ambitious attempt to blend various gameplay styles results in a game that's both exhilarating and occasionally bewildering.

From a technical standpoint, Resident Evil 6 is a visual spectacle. The environments are detailed, character models are lifelike, and the sound design is top-notch. The action sequences are intense, and the game's scope is undeniably grand. The variety of locales, ranging from urban landscapes to dark, eerie caverns, keeps the visuals engaging throughout.

However, the departure from the series' survival horror roots might leave purists feeling a bit disoriented. Resident Evil 6 leans heavily into the action genre, with fast-paced combat, spectacular set pieces, and a relentless onslaught of enemies. The inclusion of multiple playable characters (each with their own unique campaign) adds replay value but contributes to a somewhat disjointed narrative.

One standout feature is the cooperative gameplay, which allows you to team up with a friend for a more enjoyable experience. The synergy between characters can lead to some epic moments, and the shared sense of dread amplifies the horror elements.

The game's biggest flaw lies in its occasionally convoluted plot and an overabundance of quick-time events (QTEs). The narrative jumps between different characters and locations, making it challenging to fully immerse yourself in the unfolding story. The QTEs, while adding cinematic flair, can sometimes feel like a distraction from the core gameplay.

Despite its flaws, Resident Evil 6 delivers a satisfying action experience for those willing to embrace the departure from the series' roots. It's a game that's best enjoyed with a friend, where the chaos becomes part of the fun. If you can overlook the narrative hiccups and embrace the change in direction, Resident Evil 6 offers an intense and visually stunning journey through the darker corners of the Resident Evil universe.

I'm one of the yahoos that likes this game. RE 4 was okay if disappointing in how little connection anything had to the original titles. RE 5 was just painful for me and made worse by the early-woke demands that a game in [i]Africa[/i] was "racist" because the enemies were all African (with Capcom caving in and adding white enemies). But this one was enjoyable because it actually felt like a real [i]Resident Evil[/i] title with the dark environments and settings that hearkened back to the originals. Chris's story I didn't enjoy because, again, it didn't feel like a true RE entry. But the others certainly did, including Ada's.

My greatest complaint is how much grinding is involved in unlocking the Mastery skills even after you've unlocked the unlimited ammo skills. A lesser but still significant gripe is that some missions take place during the day; that's not scary. Finally, why is there another chainsaw enemy? It's just one but one that keeps coming back until it's smashed by a train. Those things aren't fun, just aggravating!

At first, putting the name Resident Evil right before "6" could lead to some wrong interpretation. I've always remembered the survival horror of Resident Evil games where the scarce bullets and herbs had to be properly managed if you wanted to survive.

I don't believe you will find the suvival feel in this one, however this is not exactly a bad thing. If you see this as an action packed game with plenty of explosions, quick time events and some bullet sponges bosses then you will enjoy Resident Evil 6. If you forgive (and forget) about what made Resident Evil past games so tense and unique, you can even grab a friend and play the entire game in co-op sharing all the action paced chapters. However, even if you get past all these nostalgia things you can't avoid to feel of how the little things that made these games what they are today are gone. You will miss the calming music when entering a safe room, you will miss the risk-reward in getting a slot in your inventory filled with herbs instead of more ammo. If you're just in for the action, then the game will deliver plenty to shoot, plenty ammo to find and plenty ways of how you want to upgrade yourself. Looking to find more items and ammo? Upgrade that skill. Faster reload? You got it. You want your AI co-op partner to not help you when you need the most? Well, you can upgrade it that way too. 

In 20 hours you will be done with all the chapters the game has to offer. More if you choose to go to higher difficulties or looking for every possible crate to smash or collectible to shoot. Then, of course, there's more game in the mercenaries mode that may feel similar if you played Resident Evil 5. In the end, you will get your moneys' worth if you adjust your Resident Evil sensitivity to a minimum and pretend this is an action game. 

Turn off your brain just like the ones you're fighting and the game will be fun. Expect a true Resident Evil game and be left with sadness. Nevertheless there's good content if action is what you're looking for in the series.

Resident Evil 6 was the last good Resident Evil game we got from Capcom, after this they rebooted the franchise and now we have an overall weaker story due to RE7 and RE8 which really should have been side stories like revelations. But back to the game, RE6 is a very fun action/"horror" game but it is not really horror when you play as three super soldiers who are Chris, Jake and Leon (also Helena is basically Wesker she dodges every single bullet that comes her way in survivors) story may be weak here with Simmons being a big let down from the previous instalment's villain Albert Wesker (although you cannot really top Wesker I still have no idea why Capcom decided to kill him off so early in the story. Capcom please clone Wesker for RE9).

The only good thing about the story is that the character writing is still pretty good here and dare I say better than RE5 in terms of Chris' development with Piers. Capcom did fumble the bag with this entry and they certainly could have written the game better for example Jill should have been in it, but we could have gotten a lot worse than what we got. The combat is by far the most fluid in the series leaning into full action but is a blast when you play in the online modes. 

It really baffles that we went from RE5 to RE6 then to RE7, the quality in overall game design has just nose dived, I think the only way to fix the Resident Evil Franchise now is to have some games be pure horror and some be action, you cannot do both anymore.

Did i liked the story ? ... meh... >_> would i prefer a more classic style resident evil ? yes . The game is good in its own rights , its just ridiculously action . Cheesy punch lines, too much action , the character are like they'v trained under master splinter , viruses has become ridiculously many , it barely feels like horror anymore . It takes away a LOT of stuff from the original source material and just adds what happened to previous game to make it look cool but it doesn't . I still enjoyed it though. Now is it worth buying ? in a discount yes

This game isn’t good. I do not recommend it. As someone who has played through the Resident Evil franchise in 2023 I found Resident Evil 6 to be the worst mainline entry.

I don’t like how it completely shreds its roots in the survival horror. The prior games were all fun to play. But starting with Resident Evil 5 the franchise was at a low point that relied on action over horror because it was during the “decline of survival horror”  that occurred towards the end of the Xbox 360/PS3 era.

This reliance on action, insane story events, and online co-op is not synonymous with Resident Evil. The strong environments, puzzles, and interesting characters associated with the prior games is not present in any way in Resident Evil 6, and the intertwining narratives it is trying to tell get lost in the terrible writing and story. We get a shell of its former self. One that tries to cater to broad appeal and one that tries to jump the shark in numerous ways, but it ends up being a game that doesn’t really excel in anything and one that doesn’t really appeal to anyone.

If its gameplay was good I could be a bit more positive but Resident Evil 6 is also a poorly designed game as well. I was thrown around during gameplay, the enemy AI is inconsistent, and your partner AI is awful (I often saw both my partner and enemies just chilling out together before shooting at each when I catch them). The cover based shooting is awful, there is an overreliance on unfair QTEs, and enemies soak up a lot of bullets. Every combat encounter was a joyless slog and combined with being thrown around, the overwhelming action set pieces, and QTEs it made me feel unwell whilst I was playing it. I really tried to finish it and I really tried to find the positives in it, but I can’t find anything good to say about it.

I don’t personally agree with the idea that this is a good game if you take away the fact that it’s a Resident Evil entry. That sounds like copium, because even if it wasn’t a Resident Evil game it would still be terrible and no-one would remember it. This game was a dead end and Capcom knew this as well. It would have killed the franchise if they didn’t reboot it with RE7. 

Resident Evil 6 is not Resident Evil in the slightest. It’s a game that chases trends and high levels of action, but also one that disregards its legacy and franchise history in the worst way possible. As such I do not recommend it, not even during a sale. Please play any of the other mainline games instead.

Resident Evil 6 assembles a crew of fan-favorite heroes for bombastic adventures across the globe. From Ivy League zombie slayer Leon Kennedy to boulder crusher Chris Redfield, this ultimate bioweapon-busting team packs a fun punch.

Fight zombies while enjoying various playground equipments after a long day preventing viral outbreaks. Action and absurdity make for an enjoyable, if cheesy romp through colorful locales from Tall Oaks to lush Chinese metropolis.

With four interconnected campaigns, you can laugh at the over-the-top antics with friends. Hop online for zany co-op and unleash combo attacks on the hordes.

While no horror masterpiece, RE6 is a popcorn flick that knows not to take itself too seriously. The plot jumps the shark more often than the zombies, but the tongue-in-cheek tone lets you enjoy the thrill ride.

So grab the gang and suit up with Leon & friends for delightful undead destroying fun across the world. With custom skillsets and unlockable costumes, you’ve got options galore to fight in style. Time to crack some wisecracks and zombie skulls - duty calls!

This game completely ditches the survival-horror genre. What a great way for developers to apply every single cliche full of random imaginations in your heads.

[h1]AI | Co-Op[/h1]
The partner AI in this game is the most detrimental and distress you can control than Sheva from RE5. First of all, they don't intend to help the player and always no tension to save you. In fact, they just stand anywhere and watch you die, no matter what weapon they carry, they had no intention of using it, so screw them.

[h1]Controls | Camera System[/h1]
The controls are fine and modifiable, but It feels so sluggish and awkward to get the hang of it. Not to mention the camera makes me sick and dizzy 'cause I cannot change its FOV which really infuriates me a lot.

[h1]Enemies | Boss Fights[/h1]
My god Capcom, this feels like the previous sequels which I want to smack my controller to you. Aren't you getting tired of these bullet-spongey thing when you hit an zombie? Normally, they'll be dead in one or two shots, even you let to have a button appear to counterattack them. It's laughable. Especially boss fights which this is the most extreme painful for me to defeat them one-by-one.

[h1]QTE: Quick-Time Events[/h1]
Jesus Christ Capcom! This is another death nail at the coffin to your RE franchise. Do you think it's a good idea to apply every QTE for every actions, especially at cutscenes? You'd probably like to insult your fans like "Hey let's add more hardcore challenges like QTE" thing to mash up every single buttons we have, ultimately result of giving us injuries to our fingers.

[h1]Unbelievable Crisis[/h1]
Wow! Do I need to explain it out what is "Resident Evil" to you Capcom, it's a zombie survival-horror game, not an hardcore zombie action-pack. Words cannot express what did I just witnessed inside while playing of this Resident Evil thingy. We could call this "Resident Duty" instead.


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
RE6 is a downright detrimental game! I don't want to explain more because I'm starting to hate this game more and I wish I could refund it, get my money back for buying this bullshit game!

Leon's Route: Fine route overall, but the ending felt pretty rushed. However, the story was engaging and there are different game mechanics each chapter.
Chris's Route: Easily the best route. An interesting story with a straightforward objective. The action scenes are the best in this route as well.

It's absolute toss.

Nonsensical story even by Resident Evil standard. Who the hell are half of these people? Don't tell me. I don't care.

 Abysmal inventory management. I feel it's pretty bad over Resident Evil games overall really, but this one takes the biscuit. It's this weird mess of basic scrolling, but it scrolls both ways and you can fast swap weapons, but when you have a lot of weapons it make it so you're back and forth. The game also decided to pack your inventory out by giving you way too many throwables, but makes them a chore to use. Every so often you're best off just stopping and clearing them from your inventory.

 Controls are garbage. It has this weird cover system that's a mix of something like Gears and Army of Two, but instead of copying one or the other and improving them, it takes the worst aspects from both of them. Dreadful.

Vehicle sections are uniformly terrible. They even know this themselves because when you die it gives you full health from the check point.

Game constantly has points where it wrestles the camera from you, or even anchors your view to something while you are in the action. The action doesn't pause. You will die because of this. It also has a weird habit of not letting you see what you need to see.

Some parts are impossible if you are playing as a specific character in some hosting situations. You can become soft locked.

When a player gets downed, the game takes control away from you while it stun grenades your eyes with a negative flash. You can receive damage during this time, just like when it does the cinematic pans or focuses your camera on whatever it's doing.

FOV feels like it's inside my eyeballs. Why does it have to be like this?

No auto reloads when a magazine is empty meaning that you're often caught with your pants down.

Terrible AI. Even in co-op you're stuck with AI doing stuff that will just get hung up and cause you fails.

 "Puzzles". Generally you're only going to get stuck because the geography of the level is horrendous in parts. In fact there's a part in every single campaign where you have to do three of whatever in an area and these parts suck so much.

Health system is garbage. Damaged received is inconsistent across the game. You can get stunlocked in certain areas of the game.

The item drop rates are skewed as to be a bit of a headache. This is tied to the bad inventory I think, because you can get 100's of pistol bullets and can't use them fast enough to negate more pistol bullets dropping, but not getting anything for other weapons or vice versa. My co-op partner regularly has run completely out of ammo, sometimes through her own gung-ho nature, but sometimes just because the game insist on giving you xp. I hate it.

XP is pointless. The perks are pointless. I feel like some of them might as well be a placebo effect they aid you so little. There's so many situational ones that provide so little value there's no point in them existing. So many of them require you to kill 1000 enemies or whatever with a specific weapon. No thanks. Only someone with brain damage would want to play this game more than once. 

It's never 100% clear what an area wants from you in some instances. Is it to survive? Is it to get the keys and escape? Do I need to do a puzzle to stop the waves? Is it a combination of all of the above?

In instances of where the players get split up and must do something to progress the parts, it's barely clear on what needs doing, especially when you are at a whim of the co-op partner. Like, do I just stand and defend? Do I have urgency to do the objective to get them out of trouble? Also these parts are utterly awful to play when its you waiting on them.

On said parts, holding to view what they are doing so you can see what they see only works part of the time. Why. Because they don't care about this awful game.

The characters are terrible. Leon and his sidekick are fine in isolation, but the rest of them are truly the worst of the worst. Jake in particular is to Resident Evil 6 as to what Poochie was to the Itchy and Scratchy show. They make the people on Love Island seem like fantastic filled out people with something to give the world.

The running away sections are a travesty. All of them. All of them are hampered with spinning the camera around and generally making them as unpleasant to experience as possible. 

Boss fights are atrocious. Boss fights in RE games have never been it strong suite, but they somehow managed to make them at best tedious and at worst agonising. Rubbish design throughout, such as bosses getting toppled out of reach where you cannot continue the attack that is needed to finish them.

Constant QTE's. All the time. I'm surprised I'm not asked to complete a QTE to post this review.

Ada campaign is for one player only, making it so that the co-op player is just there to be dragged along. Why make a game that's intended for 2 players and then do this? Baffling.

Instances of where you can be instakilled through no fault of your own by standing in the wrong position are too frequent. You could argue once is enough, but this game does it a lot. Ambulances, cars, trains, helicopters, floors collapsing, you name it, there's probably some nonsense there that will cause a kill screen before you even knew it was going to be there. Not even QTE failures, just BAM and you're looking at a you died screen.

This game was released in 2012, the same as Borderlands 2, Sleeping Dogs, Far Cry 3, Dishonoured, Journey, Hotline Miami, Dragons Dogma, Diablo 3, Fez, Mark of the Ninja, The Walking Dead, Super Hexagon, Okami HD, X-Com, Dear Esther, Binary Domain, Anomaly, Super Brothers, Sniper Elite 2, Plague Inc, LEGO Batman, Spec Ops: The Line, Spelunky, Orcs Must Die 2, CS:GO, FTL, Torchlight II, Euro Truck 2, Halo 4 and Thomas Was Alone. 

I played all of these way after release, with only some being played on or thereabouts on release, and without a doubt Resident Evil 6 is easily the worst game. By a country mile. There's so many issues it faces or just gets wrong.

I cannot think of any good things to say about Resident Evil 6. Maybe it made us laugh at how bad it is, but not in a kitschy way, just in a "This is absolutely shockingly terrible" way. It's a complete embarrassment from Capcom. It's absolute silage. There's not a single aspect from this game that I can go "You know what, it did x or y well". After playing through Chris' campaign i have made a very important and shocking discovery that has massively improved my enjoyment of this game. Resident Evil 6 is Puella Magi Madoka Magica. Chris' campaign revolves around a veteran BOW specialist (Chris) that is isolated until he meets a new recruit (Piers) that he thinks can take up his role. The first few episodes of Madoka Magica revolve around a veteran magical girl (Mami) that is isolated until she meets a new potential magical girl (Madoka) that she thinks can take up her role. Both end with one being killed on a mission after a powerful enemy that they thought had been defeated returns and catches them off guard. This revelation has changed my formerly sour opinion on this game to the belief that it is the greatest work of fiction ever made, because Madoka Magica is the greatest work of fiction ever made.

Final assessment after playing the whole thing:

I liked some campaigns more than others. For example this is my favourite portrayal of Ada in any of the RE Games. Chris's Campaign is the blandest i'd say. I like the story, even tough it is convoluted and confusing at parts. 

I liked the melee and movement that feels pretty dynamic and is pretty context sensitive which is cool.

I liked the idea of the 4 intertwined campaigns, but this was a bit diminished as it was used to be able to recycle assets. This did not hurt as much tough, because the set pieces were interesting like China and Eastern Europe.

The effects and models still look nice to date, but many textures are pretty low res (sadly). The color filters used over the whole thing suck ass, but this was pretty common at that time i think.

The Game is fun and all, but still keep in mind, that this is like the fast and furious of the RE Series and it tops even RE5 in the overblown action department.

Resident Evil 6 delivers a mixed bag of action-packed sequences and divisive design choices that veer away from the series' survival horror roots. The game features a vast ensemble of characters, each with their own campaigns, intertwining in a sprawling narrative that attempts to cater to diverse player preferences.

The characters showcase a range of gameplay styles and perspectives, offering variety but at the cost of a cohesive narrative. While series veterans like Leon S. Kennedy and Chris Redfield return, their arcs can feel disjointed, and the sheer number of protagonists may dilute the emotional impact. Newcomers like Jake Muller and Helena Harper bring fresh faces but may struggle to resonate with players as strongly as iconic characters from previous entries.

The game's focus on action and set pieces is evident, providing a fast-paced, cinematic experience. However, this shift in tone sacrifices the atmospheric tension and survival horror elements that defined earlier Resident Evil titles. The abundance of quick-time events and explosive action may polarize fans looking for a more restrained and suspenseful horror experience.

On a positive note, Resident Evil 6 does offer a robust cooperative experience, allowing players to team up and face the mutated horrors together. The varied gameplay styles across campaigns provide diversity but may also lead to inconsistency in pacing and quality.

In summary, Resident Evil 6 introduces an ambitious but divisive approach, emphasizing action over horror. The multitude of characters and campaigns adds variety but may sacrifice the tight storytelling and atmosphere the series is known for. While the cooperative gameplay and set pieces are engaging, the departure from the franchise's roots may leave fans yearning for the classic Resident Evil experience.

Back when the game came out I hated it for being so different. It was fast, had too much action and insane monster designs, now I love it for those exact reasons.

The story is split between 4 campaigns with 5 overlapping missions each. Every campaign has something different to offer:

The Reisdent Leon 2 campaign probably feels the most like Resident Evil games before 4. Especially the first mission feels very Resident Evil 2.

Chris of Duty: Zombie Warfare feels like playing a third person Call of Duty game for the most part.

The Jake Bandicoot campaign has a lot of plattforming straight out of Crash Bandicoot.

And the Ada Gear Solid campaign has a lot of stealthy bits and a grappling hook, but essentially it only fills in the missing gaps in the other storylines.

Throughout the campaign you also get to ride a wild variation of vehicles, from motorbikes, to humvees, to helicopters and even a fucking jet.

As you can see, the game offers a lot of different mechanics and action filled set pieces throughout the world. That makes it a crazy ride to the end.

Where it dropped the ball is removing that addictive weapon upgrading system. You can still unlock a lot of cool upgrades and infinite ammo, but it just felt way better to upgrade your guns slowly throughout your playthrough in the previous two games.

[The game runs mostly solid on Steam Deck. I only had some stuttering during cutscenes, during gameplay it was running very smooth the entire playthrough.]

Time to finish: Around 20 hours

I am a 53 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game.
I am a single father to my son, who is now 17.
My son recently downloaded Resident Evil 6 and in less than a week,
he had already played for over 28 hours. This was terrible for me,
as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son,
as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok.
So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him.
I loaded into the game, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do.
I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join.
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died.
This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.
This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything,
and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank You Capcom. ♥

Resident Evil 6 is a divisive entry in the Resident Evil franchise, offering a mixed bag of strengths and weaknesses. While its ambitious scope, high production values, and cooperative gameplay appeal to some, its disjointed narrative, inconsistent pacing, over-reliance on QTEs, and departure from survival horror roots have disappointed others.

For fans seeking a more action-oriented experience with cooperative multiplayer, Resident Evil 6 may provide some enjoyment. However, those who prefer the traditional survival horror elements of the franchise may find this installment to be less satisfying.

I can appreciate the game's ambitious scope and high production values, but I also acknowledge the criticisms regarding its narrative, pacing, and reliance on QTEs. Resident Evil 6 is a polarizing entry in the franchise, and its appeal will depend on individual preferences.

[b]Hey gamers, let's dive into Resident Evil 6, a game that's sparked its fair share of debates, but hey, I'm here to spill the beans on why it deserves some love.[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Mixed Bag of Criticisms: Look, I know this game divided the RE community, but hear me out. It's like that pizza with unconventional toppings - not everyone's taste, but it's got its unique charm.[/b]

[*][b]Action-Packed Thrill Ride: Forget the naysayers; RE 6 is a rollercoaster of action. It's like a heart-pounding blockbuster movie, with explosions, zombies, and adrenaline-pumping moments around every corner.[/b]

[*][b]Unique Storytelling: People say it's a jumbled mess, but I say it's a narrative marvel. The way the story unfolds from multiple character perspectives is like fitting together a twisted puzzle. Flawless? Maybe not, but definitely intriguing.[/b]

[*][b]Character-Centric Awesomeness: The different character storylines offer variety. It's like playing different genres within one game. From Leon's horror-style segments to Chris's all-out action, it keeps things fresh.[/b]

[*][b]Flawed Beauty: Some say it's flawed, but hey, that's part of its beauty. It's like those charmingly imperfect movies you love for their quirks.[/b]

[*][b]Multiplayer Madness: The co-op is where the fun skyrockets. Team up with a buddy, and the chaos becomes twice as enjoyable. It's like surviving a zombie apocalypse with your partner-in-crime.[/b]

[*][b]Hardcore RE Fan's Delight: I don't care what people say about this game. I LOVE IT! For hardcore RE fans, diving into RE 6 is like revisiting familiar places and characters while exploring new horizons.[/b]
[/list]
[b]In conclusion, Resident Evil 6 might not be everyone's cup of T-Virus, but for those who crave action-packed thrills and enjoy the different storytelling approaches, it's a hidden gem. So, if you're a hardcore RE fan who doesn't mind a little controversy, give this one a shot. It might surprise you![/b]

I usually don't insult people for opinions, but you genuinely have to be completely brain dead to think this game is good in anyway, as an RE game, or as an action game.

As an RE game, aside from some recurring characters and one specific enemy, it feels nothing like RE. All the horror or creepiness from the previous games (aside from RE5) is gone, the survival horror gameplay is gone. Now it's just a mindless shooting gallery with flashing lights and explosions every 5 seconds. And even the recurring characters are horrible. Leon is a complete fucking idiot. He lets a woman who has killed and infected thousands, if not millions go, just because he thought that she was Ada (not even gonna get into how much I hate Ada and the Leon and Ada love story in general). Chris is boring, and so is Sherry.

Edit: Forgot to mention Helena, Piers and Jake. Goes to show how forgettable all three of them are.

As an action game, it's a shitty clunky mess. Aiming feels like shit. Weapons feel like they shoot pebbles because their sound design is horrible and enemies are bullet sponges. Movement feels like shit. The inventory system is shit. The weapon upgrade systems from the previous two mainline games are gone, being replaced by skills that you can buy with skill points, but the skill point requirements to buy and upgrade them are so fucking insane that by the end of the 20+ hour game, you'll only have 3 skills at level 2 out of the 3 levels, and they're not even that useful in the first place, aside from the infinite ammo skills you can get after beating the game once, and what's worse is that if you plan on 100%ing the game, one of the achievement require you to buy and upgrade every single skill in the game. And don't get me started on the countless number of useless QTEs that are shoved in your faces every time the developers get a chance. Enemies are annoying. Bosses are even worse. I kid you not, there are two different villains in this game that get a fake out death at least five separate fucking times and each time they come back you have to have a long, boring, drawn out, worthless boss fight with them. One out of those two villains turn into a FUCKING DINOSAUR WITH A MACHINE GUN ON IT'S BACK.

In total, the game is 21 hours...

21 hours of pure brain numbing pain.

Playing with a friend didn't even save the experience. In fact, the friend I was playing with stopped mid way through because of how bad it was, and I had to push on through the rest of it by myself (on console).

If you haven't played this game yet, save yourself and don't waste ANY money on this game. It is not worth the money or time.

One of, if not, the worst game I've ever played in my life.

RE6 is often called the worst Resident Evil game and it's probably true. The story is really good and really fleshes out the characters, but a lot of the gameplay hasn't aged very well. 

It's a tad janky on PC with Mouse/Keyboard, but to be fair it's still miles better than the RE5 dumpster fire of a PC port (the original RE5, not a remake that is so desperately needed).

RE6 in 2023 still holds up visually and the story is top notch, but the gameplay veers too far away from what I expect in a resident evil game. Too many quick-time events and fail-able action scenes with janky camera angles and horrible "space bar does everything" controls. I lost count of the number of times I died trying to sprint but instead jumped backwards over an obstacle into danger. 90% of the challenge in this game is overcoming the bad controls. 

Leon, Jake and Ada Wong's stories are all worth playing. Chris Redfield's story is good but not really that fun to play unless you love being tortured. Just watch the cutscenes for Chris on Youtube, you'll be a lot happier.

It's a lousy game with a lot of problems - The story is very stupid, we have lots of Hollywood tropes & cliches; the camera is cancerous, you'll often lose track of where you are. But don't get me wrong here, despite all of these issues, I really had fun playing with my friend.

Both storyline and characters are very generic and you won't feel immersed or interested throughout the game. There'll be a lot of sections where you'll just want to rush through and be done with it due to the amount of retarded enemies (e.g., flying bugs with assault rifles, dilophosaurus, and so on.) But on the other hand, the combo system is very sick: watching Chris carrying enemies around as if they were made of cardboard and throwing them onto the floor was downright awesome. 

Me and my friend reached a consensus that this is not a Resident Evil game, so If you're coming into this game expecting this or anything else, don't.

Now, I'd recommend this game if you meet this criteria:
-You ran out of games (heavily recommend to play with a friend, otherwise you'll find yourself losing the will to continue)
-You're a masochist
-You want to see grown up Sherry
-Sherry.

As a long time Resident Evil fan, its disappointing to say this is the worse game of the franchise but there still reasonably good game here. Highly frustrated after playing the initial campaign, it grew on me as the whole plot line unfolded. There are some great cinematic events in here but the game is marred by some terrible game design decisions. These include unpredictable quick time events which you learn about through instant death, areas of limited ammo but unlimited enemies and THAT boat jumping scene (You'll know when you get there!). There 4 sizeable campaigns here which is impressive enough, each around 80% as long as RE5 in their own right, took me around 40 hours to complete. Frustratingly, Some of the best bits of the game (Leon's early jump scares and Ada's 1st stealth mission) are short lived in favour of lots of action shooter.

Metacritic scores RE6 in the 60% range.. I think that's harsh, it more like an 80% game but with a handful of really frustrating moments, usually caused by unavoidable death and your inability to predict the future.
The first 10 hours frustrated, but after all campaigns where complete, I'd had an enjoyable experience of sorts. There a lot to like, if you can turn to a blind eye to the frustrations.

Additionally: I frequently suffered a strange stuttering / freezing bug during both gameplay and cut scenes. Some reference to this online online, but no solution found - PC more than capable of handling the game [2013 Game Played in 2023] - Disabling Steam Overlay seemed to really reduce this.

I really enjoy this game (co-op included, especially back in the day) even though it is much different than the others in the series. It is a fun zombie shoot 'em up with an AI partner basically. If they remade this now with newer AI it could a very interesting game and would love to see what they change and keep about it. It is almost entirely an action based game which was very popular at the time it was made, same goes for co-op also very popular then. 

Controls for this game are extremely wacky, some of the weirdest I have played, but has a unique feel to them I suppose.

There are a couple mild and game crashing bugs though which is likely due to newer hardware, windows version, and gfx drivers over time and I wouldn't expect this to be fixed due to its age.

The game has bugs with alt-tabbing and wants to blackscreen the pc (can't even view task manager, that kind of bug) leaving me with no option but to manually shut down with the physical button. 

The Mouse cursor disappears basically every session making navigating the awkward ported menu and UI even worse.

Maybe once they remake the game in 2029 we can relive the glory days.

Unfortunately, the story of Resident Evil 6 is overshadowed by less-than-stellar game design, and Capcom's attempt to blend the excitement of Call of Duty into this game ultimately damages the experience. I'm not suggesting that a game should be all about fear and lack action, but where is the thrill in pressing a single keyboard or controller button repeatedly? Even the vehicle sections and snowmobile sequences are subpar compared to Call of Duty. The game's camera angle, in certain scenes, leads to multiple frustrating deaths, leaving you exasperated. What's the point of this frustration? Has the game director not even played the game once to see the problems with the camera angle that suddenly becomes a hindrance or the abrupt button mashing during gameplay?

However, I can't say the game is bad; it's not a great game either. Its strong point is the story, but it gets lost beneath helicopter rides, tank battles, and skiing down mountains. The DLC section, meant for online play, is virtually deserted, and I haven't come across a single player there, at least not in my experience. But within the game itself, you can still find people to team up with for co-op play.

In my opinion, I'd rate it a 7 out of 10.

I'll keep this one short:

Resident Evil 6 is a mediocre game with fantastic gameplay mechanics.

The combat is a lot of fun with mostly smooth character movements and controls and a lot of great animation work.

Sadly, everything else about the game sucks. Enemies are all designed with the 'swarm the player in as a many numbers as possible mentality', the game is super linear with next to zero exploration, all of the scripted sections are annoying QTE inputs for stuff like starting a bloody car or have fixed cameras which makes navigating them a nightmare, there's a lot of gimmicky vehicle sections with floaty controls, the game goes on for too long (after two campaigns, I wanted it to be over), boss fights don't take advantage of the combat mechanics and instead are just bullet sponges, and as a whole it's a game that you have to fight with to get any enjoyment out of.

Mercenaries is a lot of fun since it's just the combat mechanics, but even then there's still problems such as the sprint and action button being tied to the same key which causes your character to interact with objects you didn't intend.

Overall, I can only recommend this game if either:

A. You want a CO-OP game to play with a friend.

B. You want to play the mercenaries.

C. You hate yourself.

I don't think the game is complete garbage as some people say. A lot of work clearly went into making the game and as I said, you can still get fun out of it. But I also disagree with the mentality that the game is 'underappreciated' or 'hated too much'. Every problem that critics had with this game are all correct.

I personally enjoy Resident Evil 6 more than any of the other resident evil games. its great for what it is, a multiplayer game with 4 campaigns that you can play with your friends, you get the most stories in one game! dlc game modes are also fun!

This game is the most over hated game I've played in a long while. 

Much like RE4 and 5, 6 is an action game and not a survival horror like the older entries. Going in after enjoying 4 and 5, I was expecting a game that was "so bad it's good" and that's pretty much what I got. What I didn't get was a game so bad that it deserves the title of "a game that killed the franchise." Because honestly? 6 is the natural evolution of everything 4 and 5 had to offer, and I am baffled that people like those two games (or at least 4), but hate this one. And after the success of 4 and 5, I really don't know what people were expecting, and I say this as someone who very much prefers the classic RE titles. 

Now that I've played it, I can confirm people overreacted to this game an absurd amount. "It isn't survival horror!" Neither was 4 or 5, and 4 is practically worshiped as the best RE game to the point where its influence can be found in every subsequent RE title. "It has too much action and it can't be taken seriously." Again, such was the case with 4 and 5 - Leon roundhouse kicked BOWs in 4 and was a one man army, while in 5 Chris punches a boulder. Even in the older entries, RE always had an element of ridiculousness and being over the top, and this game is no exception. So in all honesty, I find the vast majority of complaints people have with this game to be, frankly, invalid.

That said, it does have some issues, but one glaring one in particular: Holding space bar is your run key and your "action" key most of the time. What this means is that you'll be running, and without meaning to, you'll vault over an object, which gets pretty annoying pretty quickly. This problem is further highlighted during the game's chase sequences, where you'll be running away from something, only to be slowed down because your character vaulted over an object unintentionally, and because of that, you fail the sequence and die. Changing the key won't make a difference either as you'll still encounter the same problems. Additionally, there's also a "skill system" with skill points, which is just...not needed and feels really out of place. Oh, and there's also QTEs and a bad cover system, but that's just peak early 2010s gaming, and for the QTEs in particular, again: 4 and 5 did that too.

Aside from all that though, this game is a fun time, especially if you bring a friend to sit back and laugh at it with. I personally find it fun and I'd say it has the smoother gameplay compared to the original RE4 and 5, although it still is a bit jank, mostly for what I just mentioned. I think at the very least, this game deserves praise for making knife/close quarters combat feel good, as you can now execute special moves after knifing enemies or just punch them a lot and doing the same. Close combat/the knife feels like an alternative to your guns, instead of something to fall back on as a last resort. It's definitely worth it on sale, even if you're just playing solo like I was. If you like 4 and 5, this game is more of the same, albeit turned up to 11.

RE6 is a classic in the gaming world and it is as entertaining and addictive as ever. The game features a wide variety of characters, each with their own special abilities adding to the variety of play. The storyline is engaging and exciting, with plenty of suspense-filled moments. The antagonists are truly menacing, the environment is eerie and the weapons are varied and upgraded over time. Mercenaries mode is still as adrenaline-pumping as ever. Whether you’re playing solo or with a fiend, Mercenaries mode is intense and requires coordination and planning in order to achieve the highest score. There's plenty to scavenge and collect throughout the various campaign missions. It's no wonder Resident Evil 6 has become a gaming classic and definitely one I would recommend to playing today.

[h1]The most disappointing entry, when it could've been among the best.[/h1]

I mainly intend to cover the individual campaigns with minimal spoilers but to give my general feelings for all the campaigns.
This is the most irritating mainline RE game, not necessarily the worst.
-Enemies feel cheap with how they can lunge at you, take literal chunks off your health no matter how big or small they might be, some can just straight up instakill you, some have guns which just feels boring, and with how some animations play out it just makes certain hits feel unearned.
-Skills are a terrible addition, as not only does it remove the merchant/upgrade system from 4 & 5, but it straight up affects loot drops, sometimes you'll be struggling on ammo just because the game keeps giving you absolutely worthless +50 skill point drops at random. And without buff skills, lowly enemies can take several headshots and just never die.
The fact that alot of enemies have second forms means that you're using far more ammo than any other RE game, and potentially you get no drops to compensate this despite the continued action gameplay.
-Bosses are kinda bad, I can never tell if I'm actually hurting them, or if I should save my bullets and wait for the scripted moments to happen so I can get to the part of the fight where I can ACTUALLY hurt the boss.
-Cutscenes are here with a vengeance, so much of this game feels scripted and sometimes that scripting messes with ya.
From having a large amount of hallways where you walk slowly with exposition that doesn't matter, to exiting a cutscene only to get hit, or being shot because the camera REALLY wants to focus on a setpiece, the cinematics get in the way of gameplay.
-Item management feels bad compared to basically any other RE game, since they have both removed item boxes and the option to sell excess ammo, with weapons being free to pick up, you'll naturally want to carry some ammo for all of them, but with no way to deposit excess ammo, chances are you'll end up leaving a lot of ammo laying around, never to be used.
-The controls are never really properly explained, for example, the game never teaches you how to crouch without a prompt. I think there's tips in the loading screens but if you have an SSD you will most likely be unable to get consistent information out of these, either way there's parts of this control scheme which are absolutely unconventional even if they work well under certain circumstances.

I do have other issues such as an excess of QTEs or absurd gun recoil, but overall these are my main issues.
To me, these ruin what could've been an otherwise cool action game, as I just kept coming into contact with irritations instead of a fun experience similar to RE4.

[h1]I will say that there are some major improvements from RE5.[/h1]
The environments are way more varied and despite some low resolution textures and high usage of bloom, look pretty great!
The AI is no longer a major hindrance, as they no longer need to share their ammo with you, and have unlimited health. They are debatably less deadly compared to what they're capable of in RE5, but they no longer require babysitting which is quite nice.
The multiplayer too has a bit more merit (outside of one of the campaigns) as players are split up more often with their specific paths. For the most part you stick together, but having actual specific content designed for ya is pretty alright, even if other times it can end up pretty dull.

The enemy variety if we look at everything the game has to offer, is pretty nice.
The enemies themselves are mostly separated to be used depending on the campaign, but it could be worse.

And lastly the return of four campaigns is something I appreciate, especially since they're pretty different from one another compared to the multiple campaigns in RE1/RE2.

Speaking of which, time to cover the campaign starting off with
[h1]Leon's Campaign[/h1]
This is the one that has the most effort, and definitely wants to feel as close as possible to a RE4.
It has the return of classic zombies and some of the games slower moments, aswell as the most broad story, but the problems I have are with how cinematic it is, and how little story there is.
Most of its story just feels like it's setup to make you want to play the other campaigns, it's OK but not great.

[h1]Chris's Campaign[/h1]
This campaign feels more like a standard shooter campaign, and narratively I think it's the least necessary.
Minor spoilers but mainly just a premise, [spoiler]Chris suffering from PTSD feels odd after how much he's lost from his journey starting off in RE1, all the way up to his closing statement in RE5.[/spoiler]
The enemies in this also just felt super dull as you're mostly just dealing with guys with guns, and usually they're pretty tanky, this was the campaign where I had the most issues with ammo depletion.
Honestly I think the game would be better without this campaign but taste is subjective, for co-op I can see this being fun in the same way RE5 was.

[h1]Jake's Campaign[/h1]
The gimmicky campaign, featuring more QTEs and vehicle segments than any other, and surprisingly I actually had fun with this one.
Featuring the return of Sherry from RE2, better melee and a good mix of high action spectacle, standard gunplay and some real absurd moments, excluding some cheap deaths this was pretty painless.
If the rest of the game was like this I'd say it would be more fun due to giving the player more control to go with the absurdity.

Finally, we have 
[h1]Ada's Campaign[/h1]
This was my least favourite one sadly, as it reveals NOTHING important about the main plot, and the gameplay was the lamest.
No partner to go with you in single player (though one will be introduced if you play co-op), and gameplay that just involves you waiting on protagonists from the other campaigns to do things for you to progress the plot, along with the shortest overall runtime out of all these campaigns.
This campaign just feels like wasted potential, nowhere near as good as Seperate Ways.

[h1]This could've been the fix to all my problems with RE5, but it's one step forward and who knows how many more back[/h1]
It's not the worst of the RE games, that goes to RE 0, but it should've been so much better than this.
I would only recommend this if you're desperate for a co-op game and liked RE5 already, or if you're too invested in the series and need to see everything it has to offer.
