[h1]Resident Evil 6: A Flawed Sequel, but Still Enjoyable[/h1]

[b]Resident Evil 6[/b] serves as a sequel to Resident Evil 5, arriving three years later. Much like its predecessor, [b]Resident Evil 6[/b] falls victim to some significant flaws in its gameplay. During development, Capcom had promised fans a return to the franchise's survival horror roots, and while this rings true for the one campaign, the other campaigns lean more towards action.

In [b]Resident Evil 6[/b], several major characters are both present and playable, thanks to the game's unique approach. Instead of featuring just one or two campaigns, [b]Resident Evil 6[/b] introduces four different campaigns that follow seven different characters. This concept adds an interesting layer to the game, with each campaign having its own storyline and goals while being interconnected at various points. The first campaign features Leon, a long-time fan favorite, and Helena as they attempt to unravel the murder of the US President. Chris and Piers' campaign focuses on capturing the mastermind behind a bioterrorist attack, while Sherry and Jake's campaign revolves around escorting Jake to create a cure for a new virus. The last campaign, Ada's, is best played last, as it ties up any remaining mysteries from the other campaigns. Overall, the story is enjoyable and fun to experience.

In terms of combat, [b]Resident Evil 6[/b] feels more fluid and dynamic, allowing players to engage in gun-fu and perform various moves such as rolling and aiming while lying on the ground. These moves, while making the game more action-oriented, come in handy when dealing with enemies that get too close or if you want to conserve ammo. The game offers a wide variety of weapons, and every type is available to the player, allowing for experimentation and personalization of gameplay.

Similar to Resident Evil 5, [b]Resident Evil 6[/b] can be played cooperatively with a friend. The co-op system has been improved in this installment, allowing players to drop in and out at any time, with no host system. If one player disconnects, the other can continue, with the partner being controlled by the CPU. This improvement makes cooperative play more engaging.

However, [b]Resident Evil 6[/b] is often considered the weakest entry in the mainline series, and there are valid reasons for this assessment. The game ditches the merchant system found in previous titles in favor of a skill and XP system. Players can earn XP from defeating zombies or destroying boxes and then spend it to purchase skills for their characters. This new system feels out of place in [b]Resident Evil 6[/b], and the skills are quite expensive, with limited slots (only three in total). This imbalance in XP gain and skill cost can make the system feel unrewarding.

The horror aspect of the game is virtually abandoned after Leon's campaign concludes. While Leon faces traditional zombies in eerie environments, other campaigns predominantly involve combat with human soldiers who have a mutating virus in their bodies. These enemies can use firearms and display basic intelligence, shifting the game's focus further towards action. When playing solo, your partner feels nearly invulnerable, as they have infinite ammo and health, diminishing the horror aspect even more. Additionally, you can't interact with your partner's inventory, and they won't pick up items on their own since they don't need them. While this setup can be beneficial in some ways, such as not worrying about ammo conservation or dying, it also has its drawbacks.

Despite its shortcomings, I don't consider [b]Resident Evil 6[/b] the worst game in the series. I believe it offers a degree of enjoyment and fun that surpasses Resident Evil 5. The co-op play, in particular, can be chaotic and immersive, as you and your partner may take different actions and routes.

Resident Evil 6, released in 2012, is a polarizing entry in the long-running survival horror franchise. The game departed significantly from the series' traditional roots, opting for a more action-oriented approach. Here's a review of Resident Evil 6, taking into account the game's strengths and weaknesses.

Resident Evil 6 offered a diverse gameplay experience, with four intertwining campaigns featuring different characters. These characters included series veterans like Leon S. Kennedy and Chris Redfield, each with their own unique style and gameplay mechanics. The game's controls and movement were more fluid than previous entries, allowing for better combat mechanics. However, the increased focus on action and fast-paced combat detracted from the series' survival horror origins, leaving fans divided on the direction Capcom took.

The story in Resident Evil 6 was complex and featured a convoluted plot with multiple perspectives and intertwining storylines. It expanded upon the series' lore but often felt disjointed, and some players found it difficult to follow. The game also struggled to maintain the tense atmosphere and horror elements that the earlier entries in the series were known for.

Resident Evil 6 featured impressive visuals and detailed environments. The character models were well-rendered, and the game's locations were varied and visually appealing. However, some criticized the overuse of quick-time events (QTEs) and cutscenes that took control away from the player, which disrupted the overall flow of the game.

While the sound design and voice acting were solid, Resident Evil 6 failed to capture the atmospheric and terrifying ambiance that the series was originally known for. The constant action sequences and explosions left little room for the quiet, suspenseful moments that made the earlier games in the series so iconic.

The game's multiple campaigns, each offering a distinct gameplay experience, added to its replayability. Co-op play was also a significant feature, allowing players to team up with a friend. This made the game more enjoyable when played in co-op mode, as it could be less frustrating and more enjoyable to tackle the challenging encounters with a partner.

Resident Evil 6 was a departure from the series' roots, with a greater emphasis on action and a more cinematic experience. It's a game that polarized the Resident Evil fan base; some appreciated the change, while others felt it strayed too far from what made the series great. If you're looking for a more action-oriented game with moments of horror and don't mind a convoluted story, Resident Evil 6 may provide an enjoyable experience. However, if you're a die-hard fan of the earlier, more survival horror-focused entries, you might find this one a bit of a departure from what you love about the franchise.
It's not a question, but a lesson learned in time.

[h1] Resident Evil 6: Better Than You Remember, Even Better If You Havent Played It. [/h1]

As a longtime Resident Evil fan, there's been one game in the series I've avoided for almost a decade: Resident Evil 6. Back when it was released, it garnered mixed reviews from both fans and critics. It was a dramatic shift from the series' survival horror roots, with multiple campaigns that often felt uneven, a co-op system that made solo play feel like an afterthought, and the abandonment of classic features like a merchant or inventory management. But this Halloween, I decided to finally give it a shot.

From the start, Resident Evil 6 doesn't inspire much confidence. Its sparse main menu feels like something out of an early 2000s multiplayer game. You soon realize that the only way to pause the game is by playing in offline mode, making you feel quite alone, despite having an AI partner always ready to revive you.

The fear factor takes a hit when the game encourages you to holster your gun and engage in frenetic Street Fighter-style melee attacks on the undead. Melee becomes your go-to strategy against hordes of enemies, further diminishing the horror elements.

Resident Evil 6 abandons the survival horror genre. It dabbles in creepiness during Leon's campaign, but the scares are largely absent. The new J'avo enemies, for instance, feel more like regular gun-toting foes with a zombie twist. While the game features some horror-themed missions in catacombs, sewers, and labs, it's primarily an action shooter with grotesque monsters. This departure from the series' roots is likely why Capcom veered back to pure horror with Resident Evil 7.

Looking back now, after Resident Evil's return to survival horror with Resident Evil 7 and Resident Evil Village, it's easier to appreciate Resident Evil 6 for what it truly is: a highly enjoyable action game. The enemy designs are inventive and challenging, and the game sometimes borrows a page from Dead Space by making headshots counterproductive, occasionally causing standard enemies to transform into far more powerful creatures. While it might lack survival horror, it retains Resident Evil's trademark outlandish puzzles.

The game's diverse encounters and settings are perhaps the most exciting in the series, ranging from rooftop chases through apocalyptic cityscapes to Ada Wong's dramatic escape from a sinking submarine. There's even a thrilling sequence where you sink an aircraft carrier using a fighter jet. While the four campaigns occasionally intersect, they mainly tell separate stories in vastly different locations. Admittedly, the narrative is a bit of a mess. I'm not invested in whatchamacallit's sister who's a plant or Ada Wong's murderous clone. It's unfocused, and the broader story strokes are forgettable, but there are enough memorable set pieces and wacky moments to keep you entertained.

So, is it worth revisiting Resident Evil 6 in the wake of Resident Evil Village or checking it out if you've never played it? Absolutely, but think of it as an action game. While it might not live up to its predecessors in terms of its original format, it's a fun Resident Evil game in its own right. The cinematic presentation, filled with action movie clichés, over-the-top dialogue, and tense Quick Time Events, creates an engaging experience during the campaign. However, it might not leave a lasting impression after the credits roll.

Resident Evil 6 is not a perfect game, but it's an enjoyable one, especially if you're looking for action-packed zombie mayhem. It may have divided fans, but it's worth giving it a try for its own unique take on the series.
Over the top and incredibly stupid and lame but simultaneously a great time

Even if not the best, RE6 is still a fun Resident Evil game to play and replay. If you're a fan of crazy zombie movies like Resident Evil's own action films or even other sci-fi franchises like "Underworld" or "Blade" you'll enjoy the vibes here.

EDIT: Meh. Finally finished it years later as I wanted a mindless action game to occupy my mind in-between hard mental work sessions. Since I have played the entire series before, it was somehow interesting to play these characters again, but gameplay-wise the game is quite a mess. 

My main problems with this game are the incoherent game design, the repetitive gameplay and the fixed (and very bad) camera during a lot of action sequences. 

The game has a complete lack of coherence when it comes to establishing and following its own gameplay rules. For example, a certain button is pressed for a certain type of action (i.e. opening a door) but half the time another button will have to be pressed instead. Or a certain height of objects can be jumped over, but half the time an object of exact same height cannot be jumped over. Or you should be able to add an Herb to your quick-button "Case", but you can't despite available room. These are a very few examples, but those kind of things happen ALL the time. Add to this the very poor controls of vehicle sections, and it's obvious game design was, at the very best, rushed without consideration. 

Repetitive gameplay is self-explanatory, and the camera has a very frustrating tendency to auto-lock on "important" things in the worst possible way, forcing you to avoid enemies you can't look at, or move to an interactive point without the ability to actually see the path you're walking. Things like that. I'm trying to keep this short, but suffice to say you need a lot of patience and detachment to enjoy this game!

Recommend with the caveat you get it on sale and co-op with someone; it's a fun game to play together and although certain things are frustrating (e.g. characters magnetise to ladders, ledges and vault-ables even if you're moving away from them), the combat is pretty good, there are many more movement options than previous RE titles and if nothing else, the jank can be hilarious.

If you can't play with a friend or find anyone online, AI cannot die and they're competent at events, but don't cover your back well.

Aiming is easier with keyboard & mouse, but the menus and rest of the controls are very much designed for controller. Some campaigns are better than others (Leon's being strongest) and there are some sections that are near-impossible to do without controller (e.g. Chris chapter 5-3), however the game lets you switch seamlessly.

While definitely not the strongest in the franchise, there's still something to enjoy here.

The title is extremely misleading ; this is NOT an RE game.

pros : Good stand-alone action packed and fun combat game. Cool characters, pretty colorful visuals (most of the time), eargasm inducing music, lots of achievements and collectibles.

cons : BEYOND ATROCIOUS "RESIDENT EVIL" GAME. 99% scripted events and QTE's, next to ZERO documents, terrible save mechanic, ridiculous plot armor (it's very known to exist in RE games but this...) An abomination of an interface ; extremely confusing inventory system, very disappointing graphics and sound effects for the guns, compared to RE5, it makes them sound like plastic toys. Cutscenes that are extremely long, boring and unskippable (such as the first person car scene in chapter 5 of Leon's campaign) Overall really, really bad story telling and writing. It's actually hilariously terrible. Will 100% give you a headache with the explosions and flashes 24/7. The boss fights are extremely boring and take an unnecessarily long amount of time. (Perhaps a skill issue...we shall never know.)

 I'd also like to add in these minor cons which still made me and other fans pretty pissed :
- There are no alternative costumes for the campaigns, which is a huge shame.
- Ada basically changed race lol. They used a white facemodel for an asian character...really? - Honestly no one really cares about this one, but i'd like to mention how weird Sherry's "sexy" school uniform mercenary outfit from RE2 is. I dont fw it
- No "RESIDENT EVIL....SIX!" voiceline when you launch the game. 

"But then, YOU, as an RE fan, why do you play this game?"

Because it's actually relatively fun! I believe this game was developed by a different team than the one that worked on RE 0-5, which might explain the sudden piece of shit released in the franchise.

Here are some points to consider in order to get the best possible experience with RE6:

* Watch a combat tutorial on Youtube, so you would get a better idea how combat works. The game has a awful tutorial (that you have to complete before starting the actual game) that only tells you very basics that anyone would understand, except maybe the healing which can be confusing for beginners. Basically, try to use melee, dodge and counter actions, and start experimenting. There is more to combat than just shooting and kicking.
* All characters have their own unique moves and starting loadouts. Your partner will have different attacks and guns at the beginning. 
* Skill system can be confusing but know this; you can only use one skill slot at the time (three skills each slot) but you can actually change them in-game at any point using your F1-F9 keys (slot 1 = F1, slot 2 for F2 and so on). You can buy skills between chapters, using skill points you acquired throughout the game
* Do not expect any horror. While this game has a few moments that could qualify as "horror" but there isn't anything that would really increase your anxiety levels compared to average horror game. And I'm saying this as someone who can get easily scared with any horror that has jumpscares.
* Leon's campaign has an awful opening, a walking simulator section, where game disables most of your abilities and forces you to walk slowly. But do not throw this game away that quickly, it's only for the first section of that chapter and the rest of the game isn't anything like that. It's annoying but it will be over quickly.
* RE6 has co-op, therefore you should absolutely play it with your friend. Like with RE5, it makes the experience so much more fun and hilarious. Also healing affects the other player too, if you are close to each other, so keep that in mind before using those sprays and herbs.
* Item and ammo drops are client-side, which means that players see different drops and do not have to worry about sharing ammo. Some item spawns are in fixed spots but it will show up for both players and each player can grab it on their end (if you see a first aid spray on a table, it could mean that there is another one for co-op partner). If you play alone however, you do not need to worry about AI partner wasting resources, they have infinite ammo. (those who played RE5 alone, you'll be relieved with RE6)
* There is no manual saving in RE6, instead there are two types of auto-saves; checkpoints (pin icon) and typewriter saves (typewriter icon). Checkpoint loads only when you fail or die, while typewriter one does that too AND saves your level progress. If you wish to take a break, only do so when you get the latter.
* There's two settings for aiming: crosshair and laser sight. Take your preferred choice.
* And if you happen to love combat of this game, like I do, check out "mercenaries". Can also be played in co-op.

Now indeed, Resident Evil 6 is a polarizing game for all the reasons that have been stated by others. For every weird/bad game design choice, there is one that is really good. Resident Evil 6 can be a lot of fun under the right circumstances, which is why I wanted to write this for anyone who has doubts about buying it.

If you have any questions, post them in the comments section. I should respond quickly :)

Title: Resident Evil 6 - A Mixed Bag of Survival Horror and Action-Packed Mayhem

Introduction:
Resident Evil 6, developed and published by Capcom, is the sixth main installment in the iconic survival horror game series. Released in 2012, this highly anticipated title aimed to continue the legacy of its predecessors while introducing some ambitious changes to the gameplay formula. With a bigger focus on action and a multi-layered storyline, Resident Evil 6 received both critical acclaim and some backlash from the fan base. In this review, we will explore the game's strengths, weaknesses, and overall gaming experience.

Gameplay:
One of the most noticeable aspects of Resident Evil 6 is its departure from the series' traditional survival horror roots. The game takes a more action-oriented approach, featuring fast-paced combat, abundant ammunition, and intense set pieces. The gameplay revolves around four distinct campaigns, each following a pair of characters, and their paths intertwine throughout the story.

The third-person shooter mechanics are solid and refined, making the gunplay feel smooth and satisfying. The controls have improved significantly compared to previous titles, allowing players to perform evasive maneuvers, rolling, and quick-time events seamlessly. However, some purist fans of the series were disappointed by the emphasis on action, which led to the sacrifice of the atmospheric tension that made the earlier Resident Evil games memorable.

Storyline:
Resident Evil 6 boasts an intricate narrative, intertwining the fates of iconic characters such as Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, and Ada Wong, among others. Each campaign offers a unique perspective on the global bio-terrorist threat plaguing the world. The plot is ambitious, with political intrigue, conspiracies, and global implications, but it can become convoluted and challenging to follow, particularly for newcomers to the series.

The attempt to blend different themes and storylines sometimes results in an inconsistent tone, making it difficult for players to immerse themselves fully in the game's universe. Nonetheless, the characters' individual arcs, especially Leon's campaign, manage to deliver compelling moments that will resonate with long-time fans of the franchise.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually, Resident Evil 6 delivers impressive graphics, character models, and environments. The game features highly detailed character designs, realistic animations, and a diverse range of locations, from urban settings to underground laboratories. However, despite these advancements, some areas feel lacking in detail and can appear bland or uninspired.

The sound design is a standout aspect of the game, with a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that enhances the overall experience. The game's audio effects, from the eerie ambiance to the spine-chilling roars of enemies, contribute to creating a tense atmosphere during intense moments.

Replay Value:
Resident Evil 6 offers significant replay value due to its multiple campaigns, each providing a different gameplay experience and perspective on the story. Additionally, there are various unlockable content, collectibles, and hidden secrets that encourage players to revisit the game. Moreover, the inclusion of co-op gameplay makes it a highly enjoyable experience to play with friends, adding to its longevity.

Conclusion:
Resident Evil 6 is undoubtedly a divisive entry in the Resident Evil series. While it strays from the traditional survival horror formula, it still manages to deliver an enjoyable and action-packed gaming experience. The improved gameplay mechanics and visually stunning graphics are commendable, but the convoluted storyline and departure from the series' roots received mixed reactions from fans.

If you are a fan of the series looking for an action-packed adventure with some engaging moments, Resident Evil 6 might be worth exploring. However, those seeking the classic survival horror experience might find it somewhat lacking in the atmospheric tension that characterized earlier installments. In the end, it boils down to personal preferences, and players should approach Resident Evil 6 with an open mind to appreciate its unique blend of action and horror elements.

Went in with extremely low expectations - I'm a huge fan of the survival horror elements of the Resident Evil franchise; in particular I love 2 and 7. I knew going into 6 that it had a bad rep as an over-the-top, action focused mess. I also had a very bad time attempting to play 5. All odds stacked against it then.

But for what it has turned out to be, it's actually a lot of fun. Don't get me wrong, this is nothing like the best that the series has to offer. The story-line is ... insane, the action elements totally undermine any hope of "survival horror" and half the game occurs in cut-scenes. 

However, it's just ... fun. Stupid, but fun. The mechanics are sufficiently tight, and not at odds with the rest of the gameplay like I found to be the case in 5. Quick time events are most unwelcome and are probably my biggest gripe with the game, but when it just lets you loose on a bunch of enemies it's a great time. Particularly if you're playing with a friend, as I am. The game is very easy unfortunately, but you can create some interesting and tense scenarios by being a bit creative and silly. For instance, at the start of Chris's chapter, I decided that we would crank the difficulty to max, and I'd attempt to play knife only. This created a fun dynamic with my friend having to conserve ammo to take down the enemies I couldn't overcome with the knife, and me trying to outmaneuver the enemies, getting in close enough to knife them down. Silly, but fun. 

Hence my conclusion: Take this game seriously and you'll be left with a bad taste in your mouth, particularly in comparison to the best of the series. Approach the game with a sense of "playfulness" and it's really quite enjoyable. Whether or not this warrants a recommendation of the game I leave up to the discretion of the reader, but for one, I can't help but tick the "thumbs up", because what is a game supposed to be if not fun?

Resident Evil 6 - A Thrilling and Immersive Action Experience

Review Date: July 26, 2023

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

As I delved into the world of Resident Evil 6, I found myself captivated by its heart-pounding gameplay, stunning visuals, and engaging storyline. Developed by Capcom, this action-packed survival horror game truly left a lasting impression during my 105-minute playthrough in my attempt to reach the Cathedral, I stopped after the bus crash before reaching the Cathedral to write this review, and I can confidently say that it stands as a must-play for any fan of the genre.

One of the standout features that impressed me was the seamless integration of partners into the story. Unlike some games where companions feel like mere NPCs, Resident Evil 6 focused on cooperative gameplay and camaraderie. With its three interconnected campaigns, the game allowed me to experience the enthralling narrative from different perspectives, each character showcasing their unique skills and playstyle. This emphasis on dynamic partnerships not only elevated the gameplay experience but also deepened the overall storytelling.

The graphics in Resident Evil 6 were nothing short of breathtaking awesome, even by today's standards. The attention to detail in character models, environments, and horrifying creatures was awe-inspiring, the fear of the monsters is palpable. Every dark corner and eerie alley felt masterfully crafted, immersing me in a hauntingly atmospheric world where danger lurked around every turn. The remastered version, offering a superb 1080p60 experience, took full advantage of current-gen systems and further heightened the visual spectacle. 

What truly set Resident Evil 6 apart for me was its unparalleled immersive nature and fighting side by side with a partner. From the very beginning, I was drawn into a gripping narrative that kept me on the edge of my seat and trembling fingers on the key board. The game's pacing struck a perfect balance between heart-pounding action sequences and suspenseful exploration, ensuring that I remained fully invested in the story and the characters throughout the entire journey.

An aspect I greatly appreciated was the game's lack of punishment for exploring and making choices. Resident Evil 6 embraced player agency and encouraged me to explore every nook and cranny of its world without fear of being penalized for choosing the wrong path. This level of freedom enhanced the overall enjoyment and immersive nature of the game, so, I could play the game with confidence and actually enjoy the story without too much frustration and it made the experience feel incredibly rewarding and player-centric; thank you. 

I've been a Resident evil fan form the start, to include the first and early games. Resident Evil 6 is a triumphant addition to the iconic series and it's come a long way, successfully blending action and horror elements into an immersive and unforgettable gaming experience. Its emphasis on cooperative gameplay, stunning graphics, and captivating storytelling make it a standout title that deserves the attention of both longtime fans and newcomers alike. For anyone seeking an intense, heart-pounding action with a touch of survival horror, Resident Evil 6 is an absolute must-play.

I really wanted to like this, but it dragged on for way too long and overstayed its welcome. There are 4 campaigns in Resident Evil 6, each 6-7 hours long and to get the full story you need to play them all. The problem is that there is so much repetition in these campaigns - You fight through a street and then have to kill a boss at the end from one character's POV, and then in another campaign you have to do the same thing from another character's POV. The first time this happened I thought it was cool, but then it kept happening again and again.. so much so that it just felt like filler. 

The HUD/GUI is so overly-stylised that it ends up not being stylish at all; It's loud, distracting, and antsy. The QTES are so flashy and they sometimes appear too quick to respond to. 

Saying all that, I liked that a lot of the famous RE characters were playable in this game, and I liked the newcomers too. I just wish the storylines were a bit more cohesive and easier to digest. 

FYI: If you want to be able to pause the game, you have to start your session in 'offline' mode. Otherwise, even if you're playing solo you can't pause.

Although RE 6 isn't a horror game at all it's still an excellent game and it's absolutely worth playing for anyone who is a fan of the franchise. Don't listen to people who say 5 is better. This game is understandably hated by the core resident evil audience, and for good reason. The series started as a slow, methodical, combat light, puzzle heavy series of games, and Resident Evil 6 is a fast paced, explosive game with classic RE puzzles being completely absent. This by no means makes it a bad game. People tend to group RE6 and RE5 as the worst in the series for being "non-horror" games. I have played 5, and while it really can't be called a horror game, anyone who says that 6 is not a horror game is dead wrong. I'd argue that 6's strongest moments of horror even rival RE1 Remake, though others will disagree. History lesson on how RE6 came to be: 1996, Resident Evil 1 literally establishes survival horror as a genre. 1998, RE2, another major hit. 1999 & the 2000s bring RE3 and Code Veronica, both really good games, but the formula was a little stale, so in 2005, Resident Evil 4 came along, considered one of the greatest games of all time. Capcom saw the love for the new over-the-shoulder style of gameplay, and from that came RE5, the best selling Resident Evil of all time. And thats how RE6 came along. RE5 had action, and Capcom took the sales as the fans wanting more action, which new fans loved, and old fans less so. I like this game not because I want more classic Resident Evil, I like this game for the characters. After playing 4 and 5, I was genuinely invested in the stories of Chris Redfeild, Ada Wong, and of course mah boi, Leon S. Kennedy. If you are a newcomer to the series, DO NOT START WITH THIS GAME. I cannot stress enough how fast this game throws you in. However, if you are someone who has played 1, 2, Code Veronica, 4, and/ or 5, and have not checked out this game, I would recommend it (I specifically left 3 out because Jill unfortunately is not in this game and I must say Capcom she totally should have been). Back to story elements, I think people who say that the game is too action packed miss a key detail: This series has always been about the characters becoming more experienced. Jill, for starters, is much more versatile in 3 than in 1. Leon is a rookie cop who can do some basic maneuvers in 2, and by 4 is able to do high kicks and roundhouse kicks. Chris in RE1 could do basic maneuvers. In CV, he had a bad encounter with Wesker, which is why he trained so much so that in 5 one punch knocked a majini out cold. RE6 is the next logical step in these evolutions. So, how does the game play? For starters, the inventory is completely different from 5, which is probably the biggest downside. Quickturn is absent, but considering how fast you can turn, it's not really needed. Most other gameplay bits are the same as 5. The best way I can describe this game in kind of like a playable version of the animated Resident Evil movies. This is a good game, but also an unfortunate reminder for Resident Evil fans that we most likely won't see a sequel that has RE7/ Village slow methodical horror starring Leon or Chris. The strengths they've acquired are too powerful for a game to be genuinely scary. Jill could be a good candidate, as we haven't seen as much development from her (Capcom, please make another game with Jill). Overall, Resident Evil 6 is not the Resident Evil experience we have come to expect, but it is a good game.

The goofiest and most stupidly fun Resident Evil, 6 is like playing the kind of "Bad Movie" that is too much to make fun of. The gameplay is unique from all other titles and, although weapons are imbalanced, is good if you don't play this like any other Resident Evil you had. Well, it's similar in concept combat wise but still has to be learned. If you went into this from OG 4, 5, or the 4 remake, you'll definitely find it feels dramatically different and what you learned combat wise definitely isn't the same. The story, writing, and voice directed writing, is all also hilarious. It takes itself way too seriously and also doesn't at the same time which was a breath of fresh air. Some might be mad at this as it's kind of the "conclusion" of the Resident Evil series after going down the wrong direction. However, if you play it just for the fun co-op or just it by itself, it's really fun. Don't judge this solely by the identity of them ruining the perfection of their atmosphere and narrative. This was a double-downed display of "We are stupid action silly hehe" which was much more enjoyable than RE 5 which held itself back from being way too serious and action in a enjoyably bad/dumb way.

This is fun, play and enjoy it for what it is. Not just because the co-op is extremely fun, not just because it's an over-the-top action packed comedy sketch, but also as a testament to one of the couple of Resident Evil games in the past that are shining examples as to what they should NEVER  do again if they want their rebooted series to continue being good. Resident Evil 4 was fantastic but also the harbinger of what terror was to come. Resident Evil 5 was the true face of being out of touch with both their audience as well as what made the series good. Resident Evil 6 was hilariously an understanding of how they messed up, realized their mistake, and decided to crank the action up by 10x while going back to the laughable campy and silly of oldschool. Yet, if we want to avoid a travesty like Raccoon City Operations again, we have to remember what EXACTLY went wrong. Acknowledge it. Do better. Let the goofy games stay stuck in the past, but remember them and study them.

There are a lot of problems.
It doesn't feel like a Resident Evil game, it feels more like a Call of Duty campaign with mutants.
You can't "corpse check" the guys on the ground by shooting them ahead of time, you have to walk up right next to them so that they basically are guaranteed to hit you.
Keyboard controls are complete trash, with 4 different dodge buttons for 4 directions instead of one button that dodges in the direction you're moving.
The story is really forced.
Everything is way too over the top. Usually in these games, you have a couple massive enemies, of course. But they have always been overgrown bugs or test-tube babies. The main bad guy is a HUMAN who turns into a giant DOG and then a T-REX and then a massive HOUSEFLY. It's too much. It's too over the top for a Resident Evil game.
Some parts of the story were cool, but for the most part I really just can't think of this as anything except a massive disappointment.

Still though, not as bad as Resident Evil 5.

4/10

It isn't your standard Resident Evil affair, yet it still stands head and shoulders above most action games of the 2010's. Capcom knocks it out of the park with crazy addictive action and fun set pieces while tying it off with a fun story spread across 4 campaigns. I could see some fatigue with completing all of the game, because of how long it is, but it is still great.

Listen. This is a bad game. It's a terrible game. That does not stop it from being extremely fun with the right company. It's a movie just begging to be riffed, the controls are frustrating and the mechanics are baffling at times, and the melodrama is just amazing. It looks god-awful in the modern day--not because the graphics don't hold up, I'd argue they do, but because the edgy, high-contrast lighting makes everything impossible to see. The sound quality is iffy (though the soundtrack is straight up fantastic) and the designs are boring and dated. Also this game is SUPER misogynist, that's important to know going in.
But with all of that, you can tell how much passion and hard work went into crafting this story and laying it out the way it is. The characters all intersect at different sections of the story and having live players that had nothing to do with me or my teammate show up across the map to play out a separate story--YEARS after this game's release and relevance--had me cheering. We exploded bug monsters, we made severed hand soup, we played on the slides and rode the panda. We died SO many times due to horrible lag issues. I had an amazing time and will play it again often.

This game is not resident evil, does not make you want to replay the campaigns, or encourage you to take an interest in its expansive game mechanics. The combat strays far from RE roots but none the less is an interesting system that stands seemingly out of place in a game filled to the brim with an insane amount of QTE insta-kill events and huge amounts of padding. Some of the most interesting enemy designs is hidden behind bland campaigns and filler content. There is so much good in this game that is absolutely covered in a shit-fest of poorly designed game flow. Too many cooks in the kitchen sums the entire game up well as many superfluous mechanics are introduced then never used again through out each campaign. I don't want to play this game again, unlike many other RE games, but what I want is a remake that aims to cut the immense amount of bloat that this game seems to gorge itself on.

Despite the lack of bingo, Resident Evil 6 is a more underrated title. Still not as good as Resident Evil 5 or 7 but still better than Resistance and Re:Verse.

[h1]The sequel to Resident Evil: Revelations 2.

Developed by the guy who made the original RE4 (2005) and tried to take a swing at making a new RE5 with RE6. What we got is an over-complicated control game with many different stories/campaigns (RE1x2).

Every level takes around 2-3 hours to complete. There are checkpoints, but unlike previous games those aren't save states. Those come very seldom, just to be able to quit and take a break to get back in later.

It's rough, and not the best game out there. But it's okay.

6/10[/h1]

RE6 is a weird game to explain. There's nothing inherently wrong with the game's [i]concept[/i], but it falls flat way, way more than it sticks the landing. It's big, bombastic, and action movie-y, even more so than RE4 and RE5. This is one of the most expensive and largest efforts for the RE franchise, which is why it's nearly inexcusable that RE6 feels the least polished and most jank out of the group. It feels more like the first game in a series than one of the later titles. The individual campaigns weaving together to tell a cohesive narrative is actually kind of fun...until you fight the same boss for the fourth time, in almost exactly the same way, with nearly identical cutscenes. The inventory is messy, and feels tacked-on only because players might riot if there wasn't an inventory system, even if there's no real need for it in such an action-focused title. It also has tons of nostalgia-bait and 'Oh look it's like that thing In that other RE game', for no other reason than to remind you that yes, you are still playing a Resident Evil game. This isn't bad, but it definitely means you should only check out RE6 if you have at least a passing understanding of the other games.

If you attempt to play the game like the RE4 and RE5, you will hate RE6 and think it’s a slog. I know I did as my first two playthroughs were a complete chore and I jumped on the hate bandwagon. It’s much more melee focused with the aiming for specific body parts downplayed in favor of various types of stuns as well as counters and dodges. Of course to discover this shift in focus you have to do the research yourself, since there is no advanced tutorial to speak of, and I don’t blame anyone for not understanding it and not going out of their way to watch/read combat guides. It is its biggest failure and borders on self-sabotage.

I can't help but be in awe at RE6's epic scope and ambition, with all of the campaigns and plot threads intertwining with each other, cutscenes shown from different perspectives depending on the campaign you are playing (one of the most epic cutscenes is the Tatchi missile attack). All of this effort for a plot that is bad even for Resident Evil standards. Each campaign is so long, it could've been its separate game. They even have unique looking UIs. I believe each of them had a completely separate team of developers whom communicated with each other whenever necessary. Must have cost a pretty penny to develop such a monster.

Each campaign tries to be different:[list]
[*]Leon’s is slower, more horror focused with a few minor puzzles… until it’s not, and turns into an escalating series of events which end in an increasingly ridiculous sequence of fights with the same constantly transforming boss. Ironically, it becomes more over the top than Chris’ campaign: Leon survives a car crash, bus crash, helicopter crash, airplane crash, basically a train crash, and jeep crash all in one game. Total identity crisis. Also has awful swimming section with a giant mutated shark. The “horror” parts restrict your movement and force you to walk in linear corridors. Adding zombies and trying to pretend that Tall Oaks is “Raccoon City all over again”, doesn’t make it good. What’s more, Leon seems superfluous to the story in his own campaign as it’s almost entirely centered around Helena. Good voice acting from Laura Bailey (Helena).
[*]Chris’ drops all pretenses and embraces being a full on action game. It makes the best use of the controls and mechanics, it’s the most consistent, and has the fewest QTEs (outside of combat Chris has fewer than 10 QTEs, dunno about Piers). The brief car chase does suck, however. As for the relationship between Chris and Piers, it’s the most developed. Chris’ PTSD and amnesia seem farfetched, but they’re not, if you take previous games into account. The ending is surprisingly touching for a Resident Evil game. Very good voice acting on Roger Craig Smith’s part (Chris).
[*]Jake’s is more like an adventure/Uncharted type game focused on cinematic set pieces with the most scripted sequences (and instant death chases), the most annoying QTEs, and the worst level in the game: it has running around in a snow storm, with possible ice sliding hindrance, snow mobile vehicle and several braindead stealth sections, and ends with an annoying series of QTEs. Additionally, Jake has a lot more to do at specific parts compared to Sherry, e.g. in the bike chase Jake has to weave and dodge vehicles and projectiles (with a few QTEs for good measure) while maintaining proper speed, meanwhile Sherry only has to shoot at some enemies from time to time. This bike chase is also the worst vehicle section in the game, as it feels and looks amateurish: the game force switches the direction your facing constantly to ready you up for upcoming obstacles and it looks very jarring. The final nail in the coffin is that the partner AI is at its worst here due to the nature of the scripted sequences... and Sherry’s sometimes shrill voice (JaAaAaAaAkEeeee…!!!). Even Jake’s melee focused build can’t save this campaign. Overall this one is very experimental, a mishmash of various mechanics, the chapters are much shorter, but at least it has the most variety. Voice acting wise Jake is played by Troy Baker, and Troy Baker is Troy Baker.
[*]Ada’s is supposed to be the piece that ties the whole puzzle together. Has a few poorly explained puzzles with obnoxious solutions. Fortunately, aside from that, it has the least bullcrap, some semi-decent stealth sections, and it’s blissfully short.
[*]Each campaign has a chapter with one of the most annoying enemies in Resident Evil history: Rasklapanje. Those parts the worst.[/list]

During your first playthrough you will most likely like Leon’s campaign the most with Chris’ the least. However, if you look at what the campaigns ARE, instead of what some wish they were, it’s obvious: Chris > Ada > Leon > Jake.

I haven’t tried the multiplayer modes, since none of them seems much fun. Might try them out with bots to get achievements for completionism sake. Agent Hunt appears to be there to purely troll people in their campaigns. Story Intersections are a good idea, but poorly implemented and almost never occurred with all characters being controlled by players as they have too many fixed requirements: two pairs of players at a specific section of their specific campaign in their specific region of the world they’re playing in at that specific time.

Mid mechanics that I couldn’t stand:[list]
[*]Default keybindings are awful, thankfully you can change them.
[*]New inventory system is a shadow of what it once was. Instead of the quick and snappy RE5 one, we have a new XMB (Playstation dashboard) one, which requires a lot of time getting used to.
[*]Brief cutscenes showing e.g. a door opening, do not stop enemies from moving. While you do not take damage during their duration, you will regularly find yourself on the receiving end of a zombie grab or melee attack once they’re finished.
[*]Sections where you cannot evoke any menu be it inventory, menu, or even pause.
[*]Chase sequences during which the camera is in front of you instead of behind you.[/list]

Minor mechanics that I couldn’t stand:[list]
[*]Tripping over corpses, which interrupts combat.
[*]Stumbling during “the place is falling apart” sections.
[*]Hitboxes for context sensitive traversals are way too big: you try to dash past a ladder - you climb the ladder, you try to dash past a chest high wall - you vault the wall etc.[/list]

Do not misconstrue me, this isn’t some misunderstood masterpiece: the complete lack of focus, scatterbrained design that goes everywhere and nowhere at the same time, way too ambitious, so much so that I don’t think more time in the oven would have helped etc. It has high highs and very low lows. Still, RE6 is fascinating to me: it’s a snapshot of the entire industry of the early 2010’s in a single game, with all of the trends of that time. I imagine someone writing an entire dissertation about each chapter of every campaign and analyzing all design decisions. It’s also really fun once you learn all of the combat mechanics and play Mercenaries... but I cannot recommend it with a clear conscience.

TL;DR: I genuinely tried, but I can't get behind any part of this mess of an entry to the Resident Evil franchise. In Capcom's attempt to simplify the already streamlined gameplay of the previous titles, they just failed to create a game worthy of your time.

Don't let the positive reviews fool you, people. Skip this one! It truly, absolutely sucks! 

...

Okay, so, for its time: it looks, sounds and feels good enough. But then you start to realize how the overall focus on multiplayer basically ruined the game design in this title. Not only that, but oftentimes combat encounters are just mindless farming, without any reason for a tactical approach. 

Also, reality check: there is nothing confusing about having a Use button and a Reload button. Capcom, however, in its infinite wisdom, decided that this is just too much. So it tried to make the Space button do all possible contextual actions.

And that, while not perfect, is functional. Until the moment it stops being true. Because Pick Up and Reload are a different, separate button just for these two functions. Then, this becomes even more complicated, because actions involving other players or NPCs require their own button too. 

Just when you start thinking that it can't possibly get any worse, you see how Evade is mapped -- by default -- to a numerical key. If this doesn't get you to question your motives for continuing to play, then you are one tough cookie.

Oh, wait: it can get worse too: there is literally no way to pause this game, even when playing alone. You are at the mercy of the autosave system and only after the game is done saving may you exit the game. RE6 basically assumes that you live on your own, in a cave.

So what, if my SO or my kid need something, I am to just ignore them, because Resident Evil 6 -- with its extremely strategic gameplay and deeply philosophical plot -- expects my full, undivided and absolute attention? 

This is absurdity incarnate. 

Then there are the little things like menu navigation being confusing or the XP system going against most of what we learned from the 90s, and all of this totals up to a complete mess of a package. And I, personally, value my time way too much to waste it on... Whatever attempt of inovation this is. 

I gave it an honest chance, though. I struggled for three hours and became absolutely fine with the idea of Resident Evil 6 being the only entry in the franchise that I haven't completed. Maybe I'll try again in a decade or two, but as of now -- not a chance in hell. 

Resident Evil 6 sucks. And no amount of new-age positive reviews should convince you otherwise. And that sucks! Because there are genuinely cool ideas here and... I'll end it off like this: if there was ever a game that needs a remake, it is this one.
It's like a good bad B movie with terrible one liners and bad plots. LOVE IT!

Resident Evil 6 takes place a few years after Resident Evil 5 and adds a rather chunky size of events and potentially interesting characters, but it falls short in the quality control department. It has big amount of attempts at doing things that no horror fan cares about, much less RE fans, which I'm supposing is the main reason this title is the red haired step child of the bunch. The mechanics of combat can be interesting if you learn to master them, but the rest of the game will feel awkward to matter how good you get.

Cons vary from melee parries (what) to constant QTEs (why), passing through car chases (unnecessary) and ridiculous and weirdly angled chases (is this really resident evil) where running away feels like you're running straight AT the camera or when the angle keeps flipping and the control becomes really unintuitive leaving the players feeling like they've no clue where you're going so you die a few times and then some, restarting that sequence over and over again can be frustrating.

Why am I recommending it? Co-op! I've really enjoyed 5 and 6, even though not many liked them. Same for Dead Space 3, even though it's considered to be the worst of the series. That's why. Sure, the game has flaws, not many people will enjoy the wonky feel of it of the game where you may die 5 or 6 times before you figure out ''that's where or what I'm supposed to do?!'', and then proceed to keep playing until the next ''wait, what?''. But it all becomes bearable with a bud. Do I think it saves them from being the worse in the series? Yeeeeaaaah, no. But do I think game with coop campaign need to stay alive? Yeah. 

So it got my 5$ when on sales (as an RE bundle) and me and me friend enjoyed it. Ain't the best, but it's still fun. 4 campaigns in one game is still a lot of content!

Resident Evil 6 marks a significant departure from its predecessors, this installment takes the series into uncharted territory by emphasizing action and a blockbuster-style narrative. While it undoubtedly has its flaws, Resident Evil 6 manages to deliver an intense and thrilling experience, albeit one that may not satisfy purists of the earlier games.

One of the most notable aspects of Resident Evil 6 is its ambitious scope. The game features four intertwined campaigns, each following a different set of characters and taking place in various locations around the world. This diversity injects a refreshing variety into the gameplay, showcasing different perspectives and intertwining storylines. Whether it's Leon S. Kennedy's traditional survival horror scenario, Chris Redfield's military-style action sequences, Jake Muller's intense chase sequences, or Ada Wong's stealth-focused missions, there's no shortage of content to explore.

The gameplay itself leans heavily towards an action-oriented approach, offering fast-paced gunfights, intense set pieces, and dynamic encounters with hordes of enemies. The controls have been refined, providing smooth movement and a wide range of combat options. However, the increased focus on action detracts from the survival horror elements that defined earlier entries in the series. The game relies heavily on quick-time events and scripted sequences, leaving little room for strategic planning or genuine tension.

Another divisive aspect of Resident Evil 6 is its convoluted and overstuffed narrative. The attempt to tell a grand-scale story spanning multiple campaigns is admirable, but the execution leaves much to be desired. The plot often feels disjointed and confusing, with a plethora of characters, twists, and conspiracies that can be difficult to follow. While it does offer some interesting moments and ties up loose ends from previous games, the storytelling lacks the cohesive and atmospheric charm that fans of the series have come to expect.

Visually, Resident Evil 6 is a mixed bag. The game boasts impressive graphics, detailed environments, and excellent character models. The different locations are beautifully rendered, and the attention to detail is commendable. However, the dark, brooding atmosphere of earlier entries is largely absent, replaced by a more action-oriented and explosive visual style. This departure may disappoint fans of the series' signature creepy and atmospheric settings.

Despite its flaws, Resident Evil 6 manages to deliver an entertaining and action-packed experience. It offers a substantial amount of content, providing hours of gameplay and variety. The cooperative multiplayer mode adds another layer of fun, allowing players to team up and face the challenges together. It may not be the traditional survival horror experience that fans expected, but as a standalone action game, it can be an enjoyable and thrilling ride.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 6 is a game that divides the fan base due to its departure from the series' roots. It sacrifices the atmospheric tension and strategic gameplay of its predecessors in favor of an action-oriented approach. While it falls short in capturing the essence of the earlier games, it still manages to provide an engaging experience, especially for those who enjoy fast-paced action and cooperative play. If you can embrace its differences and approach it with an open mind, Resident Evil 6 offers an exciting and adrenaline-fueled adventure.

Remember those god-awful Milla Jovovich Resident Evil movies? It's like that, but it lasts 20 painful hours instead of 2.

The devs went into the game with one real motive: make a game jam packed with as much fanservice as possible. Returning characters facing off against each other, badass kaiju sized bioweapons that can turn into anything based on pure Rule of Cool and level entire buildings. Unfortunately, they spent so much time wondering what they could do that they never considered if they should make such a game. So much danger, destruction and action setpieces are thrown at you, that you ironically don't feel like you are under any real threat. It's just a constant stream of "hey, remember when this happened in an older game? Well, here's more!"

It's not a poor game by any means, but anyone who isn't an RE fan would just comment, "why do people like Resident Evil? It's just a boring, mediocre third-person shooter with a strangely ludicrous production value". Looking back on it with the hindsight that they ultimately saved the series it's easier to accept it for what it is. Still, besides the fun movement tech, the gunplay's kinda bad.

It's hard to rate the game poorly when Leon's campaign is at the very least decent and worth the low sale price, and the game comes with an entire alternate Mercenaries arena mode. However, Chris and Jake's routes are beyond abysmal, with sections being entirely instant death QTE-fests and terrible driving sections that are little fun, and a story that is boring beyond belief.
The lowest point in RE history.

Firstly, I adore Resident Evil 5 despite it's quirks and controversies. Resident Evil 6 is like a clone of RE5, but Capcom dialed up the cheesiness and action up to 11 and cut the charisma and story to 0. The inventory, currency, skill/weapon upgrade systems are a MASSIVE step down from RE5 and the sheer volume of familiar Resident Evil characters and number of campaigns they include doesn't make up for a pretty hollow quasi-rail shooter with few horror elements. It's like they were still riding the high of Resident Evil 4 and doubled down on the least interesting parts.

On the flip side, the campaign design is great for co-op play as I've had the most fun playing with friends and making fun of the game. Playing with a friend also improves a familiar issue from RE5 around the friendly AI being more of a liability in combat. With the right attitude I'll admin the story can have a "so bad it's good" vibe and the combat can be satisfying once you figure out the awful menus and inventory screens. I'm glad I've played through it a few times and always keep it on the list because despite its flaws it's still a Resident Evil game with good graphics and at least an obvious attempt at telling a big story.
Unfortunately this Resident Evil is more action than survival horror, but it's still good.

now I won't get too much into the story because it's not that great. We have 4 Campaigns all with 5 Chapters, so 20 Chapters. The Campaigns are Leon/Helena, Chris/Piers, Jake/Sherry, and Ada/Random Guy.

Leon/Helena Campaign: I think this is with Ada's Campaign the Worst, it's Okay but I get the feeling this campaign doesn't know what it wants to be, a Horror game or Action game, that somehow really got on my Nerves. Helena is Alright but I think Claire or Jill would've been better here. Simmons was a cool Boss, and even tho this is the Horror Survival Campaign in this game (or it wants to be that) you don't have any Ammo Problems in this one. 

Chris/Piers: Chris is in a bar and just Drinking, Piers comes and says they all waiting for him, and Bam he is back, Doesn't seem to be that much of a problem that he has if just one Person has to come and say ''Come back'' so he does LMAO. 
Otherwise, I loved this Campaign it's With Jakes My Favorite, I loved that this Campaign just wants to be an Action game, and it works great, I loved the Characters that were Introduced and the Emotions from Chris to his Comrades, I like Piers and Finn. Well-made Boss and ammo Problems, even tho this is the ACTION campaign LMAO.

Jake/Sherry: This is my Favorite Campaign of the Game, I Like jake, I love the Stealth actions of this Campaign, and The Locations are Interesting, Like the Lab or the Snowy Open Area, This was just Great. also had Great Boss fight, but the end was A bit weird with the Fist Fight. For the longest of my life, I suffered from depression. It was a constant companion, always lurking in the shadows. I tried to ignore it, to push it away, but it always found a way back to me. It felt like a weight on my shoulders, dragging me down. 

I couldn't remember a time when I didn't feel this way. It was like I was born with a deep sadness inside of me. I tried to fill the void with all kinds of things - drugs, alcohol, relationships - but nothing ever worked. 

I felt like I was being dragged down into the bottomless pit, until I discovered Resident Evil 6. This game have shed a light into my sorrowful heart and directed me to the path that will solve my problems and put an end to my endless pain. I have decided to finally kill myself.

Many people would tell you that this game is horrible and a terrible addition to the Resident Evil franchise. Well, I'm here to tell you that they're wrong. I avoided both RE5 and RE6 for a long time because of their reputation, but RE6 ended up being a bit of a treat. The biggest understandable complaint is that this game completely ditches the survival horror aspect, but that's ok. With a great story of 4 separate campaigns that all ingeniously cross over into each other seamlessly and polished action gameplay, RE6 is a solid action game that I feel is worthy of being remembered and part of the RE universe. Although it certainly has a handful of flaws that must be addressed. The main one is the overabundance of QTEs which are anything but fun in any videogame especially this one, I also have some gripes with the awkward control schemes which has SPACE used for basically everything from sprinting to mantling. This is especially awkward when attempting to sprint near any interact-able object which will most definitely cause you to either slide across a car or drop down from a ledge you probably don't want to, also reload and pickup are the same as well which isn't super annoying but using R to pickup items is super weird. I also felt Jake's campaign has by the far the most frustrating sections with most of them being attributed to Ustanak. Anyway, yeah, I was pleasantly surprised. Give it a go if you're unsure.

I can't recommend Resident Evil 6 as it is not really a good game. There are some good ideas here but almost all of them are poorly executed. Overlapping campaigns between characters and players potentially resulting in boss fights with 4 people is a cool idea but poorly executed as the fights and objectives are somewhat confusing in some cases.

I like the idea of the 4 campaigns where some of it is supposed to overlap. However in reality it results in a lot of re-used maps and sections and even video sequences where there isn't really any surprise anymore after you've finished 2 campaigns as you already know the intersections and where you will encounter the various characters. So you will know where the journey goes in campaign 3 and 4.

In addition the campaigns are all the same in structure regarding the various chapters. Each campaign has 5 chapters. Each  chapter on first playthrough will be about 1 hour long resulting in an overall campaign of around 20 hours. Each chapter is basically structured with some videosequences, sections where you fight some normal enemies, then you fight some harder enemies and then the chapter will have a boss as a finale and another small section afterwards to go to the next chapter.

Some of the bosses will re-appear multiple times throughout the campaigns which results in these "will you finally die?" moments because it just feels like groundhog day. You fight a boss in chapter one and then again in chapter 3 to then have him again in chapter 4 or 5. And when that boss that chases you doesn't even have any backstory or explanation on where it is coming from that makes the whole thing just really boring and obnoxious.

The story in terms of writing is also really weak. The character of Leon has been completely changed compared to RE2 and RE4. He still sometimes gets a cool oneliner. But overall he feels like a different character and a side kick in his own campaign. He also apparently has forgotten how the whole zombie stuff works. I can't explain his stupid decisions otherwise. In terms of the other characters and campaigns nothing really stood out in a positive way. I somewhat liked Jake at the start as he's closer to what Leon was in the previous games. But he also gets annoying in the later chapters of his campaign.

Let also mention the constant shark jumping the game does. This game is packed with heavily cliched over the top stupid dialogue and video sequences. Something like can be fun. Unfortunately the game takes itself way to serious which results in it not really being fun.

From a technical perspective the game looks good but it has way to many loading screens. Especially the Chris Redfield campaign often has situations where after a loading screen you go down a corridor, open a door, go another corridor without any fights just to then open another door and have another loading screen. Whoever thought this was good design has lost their mind. The character controls are sometimes okay and sometimes really make me rage. When you have multiple functions on the same key and they interfere with each other then I just want to strangle the designer who did this. Spacebare for example is used for running as well as climbing and various other actions. When I run along a corridor and then have to climb on a box I might actually turn around and climb down the box again if I immediately try to run again after climbin up. This can also result in deaths in high pressure situations.

The multiplayer functions seem to be fine from what I've seen but the game is mostly dead online. If you do not have a friend to play in co-op you're unlikely to get partners past Leon's campaign. The agent hunt mode can be fun but the creatures are extremely difficult to control.

Something else to finish this review off. The game still has an obnoxiously high number of QTEs and I HATE THEM!

You're not playing resident evil for the plot. Admit it.
If you're coming here, to RE6, you should be looking for a fun time with a friend, not necessarily a good one. As bad as the plot is, it's *funny* to poke fun at. The gameplay is polarizing. Either pretty fun (my opinion, due to being able to dodge, being able to just hit them with melee combat to stagger, and it feels like the character is actually remotely competent at fighting hordes of B.O.W's, knowing how to dodge, melee with anything and not exclusively a knife, escape grapples without using a knife or grenade, and perform finishing moves without exclusively using a knife. You know, stomp head into mush).
Or you hate it with the fury of a thousand stars. And you're a hypocrite because you like the original RE4 in which Leon is unable to avoid a chainsaw because he needs to slowly turn around and *then* begin hopping away.
RE2make had the elevator with a flaming tyrant and a minigun. Survival horror game btw.
RE3make had nemesis with a flamethrower, running over nemesis, a rocket shot at nemesis, many explosions, nemesis turning into a giant fish dog and running in circles, nemesis turning into half a room and you used a gigantic minigun. Survival horror game btw.
RE4make had the kid with the wig, shooting during a monologue, and throw a gold egg at a boss to kneecap his health. You shoot one dude in a foot and only then can you do any form of melee attack other than a knife, such as a roundhouse kick throwing five separate spaniards twirling through the air. "Best survival horror game ever" btw.
RE5 had chris punch a boulder. Survival horror franchise btw.
RE7 was more survival horror than any of the remakes so far.
RE8 had a tank mech with a chainsaw that you used to parry the megazord of a dude whose parasite gave him magneto powers and lifted you up into a tornado of magnetism. Survival horror franchise btw.
RE6 isn't RE4 part 3. It's a clusterfuck. It's a game that's been titled with the words Resident Evil.
Don't go into RE6 looking for running around spain without being able to strafe even a little bit. Go into RE6 expecting it to be a action B-movie with far too high a budget for its own good. Take a shot every time someone points a gun threateningly at something that clearly doesn't care about a pistol that shoots 9mil bullets. Take a shot every time the characters *should* die in a cutscene, or every time they get injured by something with the kinetic energy limited to the capabilities of a toddler.

It's very RE in grand schemes (bioweapons, lots of slow zombies, shoot leg, weakspot, important characters become supermutants instead of basic zombies, finding random stuff in random places, no common sense), but the minutae of the plot is not even close to the structure of other entries which is probably why it's so jarring and thus hated. It's so over-the-top.
The gameplay itself, after you make sure your bindings are yours (if you don't look at keybindings when you play a game you deserve to have misery with controlling it), can work well.
The dodge mechanic works great for just hitting a button and naturally avoiding a lunge, or acid, or a thrown shovel.
You can actually just hit zombies with a kick or your gun, instead of *having* to pull out a knife which might have durability.
Or you can quick shot to just *hit* them and stagger. And you regain stamina faster when laying on the ground.
RE6 will be a very polarizing game to play with your hands on the control inputs. You either hate the animation based tank-like movement when just walking around (you liked it in RE4 so shut up), or you figure out how to push the X button on your keyboard and nullify almost every single direct basic attack each enemy can deal. Or just use one of the sideways rolls to avoid even more.

Don't expect grand machinations of writing. Expect something as stupid as RE4. Great with a buddy. I just like being able to run around, shoot the enemies, dodge some attacks, laugh at how dumb the plot is.
Also, play it with a friend. It's much more palatable when you can laugh at it with somebody instead of just at a stream chat or a webcam or your own empty room. It's probably so fucking bad without anybody.
Any game is more fun with a friend. Investment in the decisions made is probably misery, just invest in the action-movie gameplay.
This is one of the worst games I've ever seen. It's so bad, it's offensive. You don't have to waste your time on this, try ANY other RE game.

This game will most likely suck if you play it with a bot and not a real partner. Only 2 of the 4 stories are really worth playing. Which is Leon and Ada.

Leon's story is by far the best story where it's the closest to classic RE you will get in this game. Classic zombies and large boss fights. Player 1 is Leon and player 2 is Helena who is really only there for co-op purposes and to fill Leon's story out longer. 

Chris' story is the worst by far game-play wise. Every enemy is incredibly tanky even on normal mode. The bosses were lame in Chris' story and most of it feels like filler. The best part of Chris' story is Chris and Piers I won't spoil anything about them but its a very interesting story between the both of them.

Jake's story is filler. It is only there just to fill the gaps between parts of the story that the above mentioned story's don't explain. Jake's story is worth playing however since Sherry and Jake are both fun to watch develop ,and the game-play is really good for Jake's story.

Ada's Story is very good but not meant for co-op. The option is there for co-op but you're friend will be playing as a nameless nobody who will not be able to interact with any puzzles or doors and will vanish in cut-scenes/teleport in and out of the game. However Ada's part of the game is important to the story and understanding it if you really care about this games story. She is very fun to play as with stealth,puzzles,and combat. 

Overall its a pretty tedious game with tanky enemies that wont die and for the most part bad boss fights, Puzzles for the most part that is just you searching for 3 items to unlock a door. These segments of collecting 3 of something all play the same where they send an immortal monster after you (that makes really annoying sounds) follows you until the game allows you to kill them.

Maybe I'm getting old. But I love RE6. Don't get me wrong. I'm well aware of all its faults technically, storywise (the Ada plotline is just a damn headache) and it feels like they hardly learned a lesson from RE5's mistakes. But hey, if there is anything I admire in a company like Capcom is its willingness to experiment with different styles of gameplay, coop, take on the backlash for doing so and eventually learn (RE7) . But that's just me, I don't mind sticking your guns to your OG style but RE6 took some chances.

The coop, which is why I recommend this mostly, is good fun and its heartwarming to know there are people who are interested in experiencing this action packed Hollywood adventure that is best experienced in the medium that is videogames. I don't know why but I love to help random people power through the campaign so they can see the badassery of all our favorite characters.

Hot take: RE6 is a great introduction to the series because it allows normies to be introduced to the universe through a more exciting perspective and those who want more of the story might actually be happy to find out the older games are not as cinematic, but rather more narrative driven. I think this viewpoint is forgotten by most oldschool gamers like me. We forget not everyone played the series from RE1 and have the luxury of playing it now in the modern day. Exciting!

Anyway, this is just something I wanted to throw out there. Get a buddy to play coop play, have fun playing as Jake and punching the shit out of BOWs.

I know this game gets quite a bit of flack for not been a good Resident Evil game but in all honesty I love it. Yes their are 4 different story campaigns to choose from and the story can get a bit convoluted and messy but it's one big roller-coaster of action and that's why I love Resident Evil 6 so much. I've just about completed Sherry and Jake's campaign and it's been one action set piece after another. I have played Resident Evil 6 before and completed Leon's, Chris's and Jake's campaigns but i never got round to doing Ada's campaign back in the Xbox 360 days. I forgot just how action packed this game is. So like I say if you prefer a more action orientated horror game rather than the usual survival horror game then your going to enjoy this. To say this game is around 11 years old now, some of the environments look spectacular. There is one thing I should bring to attention about this port of Resident Evil 6 on Steam and that is the stuttering. I'm playing on a Steam Deck and for some reason when a cut scene plays it starts to go choppy and stutters. I have tried numerous graphical options to see if I can sort the problem out and I've had no look so far. So if you like your games fast paced, action packed, with a grand story, then i highly recommend this game to you. Also if you've got a friend to play? You can either play Resident Evil 6 in local split screen co-op or in online co-op and this is where the game really shines in my opinion being able to play in co-op with a friend. I give this game a 8/10.

I know this is going to tick a lot of people off but Resident Evil 6 is actually my favorite RE title, with 4 close behind.  This game is a vast improvement over its predecessor, Resident Evil 5, with better controls, smoother gameplay, smarter AI, wider enemy variety and enough content to make its rather steep price, shared with RE7, worth it.

This is the most maligned RE game out there but I think most of the hate is unwarranted.  Is it a bad game?  Absolutely not.  Is it a bad survival horror game?  Yes, but so are 4 and 5, 4 less so but still not great.  Is it a bad Resident Evil game?  Yes, but only by old Resident Evil rules.  The thing is, those rules don't apply to all Resident Evil games forever.  RE4 did not jump the shark by going for action over horror: it evolved the series into something new for the new generation.  RE6 is the culmination of that evolution, the ultimate outbreak/disaster that every player of the original Resident Evil envisioned when they saw the horrific monstrosities infesting the Spencer mansion.

I played through all four campaigns without being too frustrated or quitting for ages at a time as I did with the previous game.  And, I have to say, they're all good in their own ways.  Leon's reeks of classic Resident Evil horror, Chris' feels more like a typical action monster movie, Jake's brings back the terror of having Mr. X hunting you in RE2 with the fearsome Ustanak on your tail, and Ada's campaign, while the least fun, does tie all of them together quite nicely.

The AI is much smarter and more useful than Sheva was in RE5 and is less of a liability.  I've had my skin saved far more times by Piers, Helena or Sherry than I ever was by Sheva.  Weapons and commands are better and the AI just seems more coordinated.  However, this game is also a blast with a friend.

The story is a little confusing, but it's not hard to piece together if you've played the game enough.  The J'avo seen here are far more threatening than the Ganado of RE4 or the Majini of RE5 with their ability to spontaneously mutate into terrifying new forms, and the C-Virus Zombies, while slower and less intelligent, are no joke either.  The only reason they're not as dangerous in-game is because you're stronger, with the ability to melee without shooting enemies and perform dodges and dives.

And the Mercenaries mode... OH MY GOD, the Mercenaries mode... easily the best in the series, tied with the RE4 Remake of 2023.  I have almost 100 hours in this game from this mode alone with how astoundingly entertaining it is.  I never thought just cracking zombie skulls and disintegrating J'avo for a few minutes could be so damn fun!  Not to mention, RE5's Mercenaries has to be unlocked by playing the main game through to the end, while the Mercenaries mode in this game is unlocked from the get-go.

People say RE6 is bad, but I say nay nay, not unless you were looking for an old-school Resident Evil game, because this is new school Resident Evil and that honestly makes it more fun.  I played this after playing RE5 for a while, and had so much fun with it that I actually beat it before coming back to RE5.  Would I recommend it?  Yes, definitely.  For a game that's over 10 years old, it's still quite fresh and a helluva good time!

Edit:  I think the story could have been a little better if Albert Wesker had survived RE5 and been the villain again, then he could have faced off against Jake in his campaign and have Jake call him out for being a bad father and an all-round psycho.  I also think the QTEs are a little excessive but at least the game added a counterattack option, which this series has needed for a while.  I really love how each encounter with the enemies is like its own mini-puzzle and how each B.O.W. you face has their own way of taking them down, which is pretty good for pretty much all of them.  Except the Lepoticas.  (Le-Poh-Tits-Ah)  Those things can just f*** right off.

I also understand the lack of an upgrade screen or Merchant and just starting with fully upgraded weapons because the campaigns take place over multiple countries in a short span of time, so I think Capcom can get a bit of leeway there.  I really love that this game has a sprint mechanic that actually lets you sprint, instead of the lame-as-hell jogging from Resident Evil 5, and even lets you perform some kick-ass sprinting melees so you can pull off devastating combos.

I think most of this game's horror comes not from how the B.O.W.s seen in it affect you, the protagonist, but knowing how they must be affecting the populace, who aren't trained or equipped to deal with them at all.  This is a horror game if you think about it, just not in the direct or traditional sense.
