People who say this game is awful? I legitimately don't know what game they're playing. It's honestly one of the best 3rd person shooters I've probably ever played. There's a lot of cutscenes sure but with the QTEs disabled they're pretty enjoyable with some great direction and cinematography.

Easily the worst mainline Resident Evil game and one of the worst Triple-A titles I've ever experienced. One could argue that it's "so bad that it's actually good" and I would agree to a certain degree, at least in regards to the story and characters.
The problem is though: it's fundamentaly broken gameplay-wise as it's trying to stuff the combat of a character-action game (think of Devil May Cry, etc.) into a cover-shooter with corridor-like areas that don't allow the combat to "breathe". It also features quite unresponsive controls and clunky movement which make the experience even more frustrating. 
It's an ambitious game for sure, but one that failed in too many ways to be actually good or genuinely enjoyable.

New Review:

So after more time with the game I still feel it is awful, but it can be quite fun at times. The combat system can definitely be quite entertaining with all the options in mobility and melee combat, but the game communicates so many mechanics so poorly that learning all the ins and outs of it that it somehow makes all the gameplay feel half baked. The game has some of the worst scripted sequences I’ve ever played in a game, they somehow feel more akin to a low budget game, there is one in particular when you drive on some snowmobile and my god is just awful. Also, the amount of QTEs are horrid, most of them with terrible timing and foreshadowing, but thankfully, you can turn them off, which I highly recommend. Also, while the game doesn’t look bad for its age, the quality of the assets, geometry, texture and lighting is inferior to the one in Resident Evil 5, the main character models look decent, but the environments can be incredibly dull and on close up just straight up ugly. 

I will now say some more positive things. As previously stated, combat can be fun, and there are some places where this element shines and as a consequence of this, there are some truly fun boss fights here and there. The game also runs smoothly as hell, aside from a weird bug that would tab out of the game, I had no problem with running the game. The story is also a highlight, it’s insane and stupid in all the right ways and I loved it. Also, if you have a friend who is willing to turn off their brain a little and not take the game too seriously it can be a blast in certain parts and you can laugh at everything wrong and dumb about the game.

In general is a game with ups and downs, but the issue is that the downs are by far the worst the mainline series has seen. If you have someone to play it with and go with the mentality that you will play a dump game and then turn off the QTEs, maybe I would be able to recommend it, otherwise, just don’t. While fun at times it’s a miserable experience for the most of it, especially playing alone and I consider it to be the worst of the numbered RE games.

The game is 5/10 for me.

At first it feels weird as it's farther away from the regular Resident Evil vibe game play wise but I like that they went back to the "dark", (perhaps too dark), aspect of the Resident Evil franchise. Like Resident Evil 5, the game is very "action" oriented with a lot of quick time events, (qte). What I really loved that at first I didn't was the "action movie" format. So far, I played Leon's campaign on my Steam Deck. Even though it's listed as "verified" the game did kicked me out quite a few times back to the Steam Deck interface. I'm not sure why but the most frustrating part was that it did it always after a boss fight and when it kicked you out, you had to start from the beginning, right before the boss fight, it did not save correctly after the cut scenes. Even though it was very frustrating, I still completed Leon's campaign as it was very fun to play.

Resident Evil 6 definitely gets the most hate out of the franchise, some undeserved and most deserved in my opinion, 
When I played this game I was going through a Resident Evil marathon and I almost dreaded getting to this game because of its reputation but when I got to it I tried to keep an open mind as I am somewhat of an unwilling contrarian and Resident Evil 5 (the closes game to this) is one of my favorite games in the franchise. However I just can't bring myself to like this game.
Defenders of this game will often bring up the mechanics of the game such as the movement, the gunplay and the melee moves (which have been greatly expanded upon since 5) and I agree that the mechanics in this game are really good, the big problem is that the game is often more interested in showing you its lackluster setpieces, drowning you in qte or waiting for something to happen in the game so you can progress and when the game isn't doing this you have to bear its less than stellar level design. 
The enemies is in this game are also much less fun to fight against than the enemies in 4 and 5. Enemies in general feel more tanky and are less responsive to your attacks when compared to 4 and 5 which I feel is a great flaw in this game as the most fun part in those games was settting the enemies up for a melee follow through. Another gripe I have with the enemies in this game is that infected with guns are much more common and they are particularly unfun to go up against. 
Finally, a lot of the boss fights in this game are quite unbereable. To me Resident Evil as a franchise has never had outstanding bossfights but they feel like more of a nuissance here than in other entries as they tend to be very drawn and are particularly bad when it comes to the aforementioned setpieces and quick time events. 
Overall I can't really recommend this game unless you play it with a friend or are a big fan of RE and want to follow the story threads between this and following entries.

RE6 is weird, but overall I really like the game. The mechanics are quite hard to get into, but are incredibly deep and rewarding if you try to master them. This aspect, combined with the co-op makes it genuinely fun most of the time. There are admittedly a few poorly executed sections across its 4 campaigns, but the overall experience is solid if you approach the game with the right mindset. 

This is not a horror game and it was never meant to be, so reel any expectations on that front. Enter with an open mind and take your time learning the complex controls and mechanics, I did and found the game very fun and satisfying.

After finishing Resident Evil 4R I thought, yeah, I might as well play Resident Evil 6 (Initially completed on Playstation 3)

This game already was garbage; ragdolling camera, enemies appearing out of thin air like a random encounter in RPGs, unending QTEs that I stopped doing because they WILL break your controller(s). And of course the partner AI that will lead you to contant instant death moments. This was the Resident Evil game for those that didn't like Resident Evil games. But now add the magnificent glory of contant framedrops. Did I say frames? I mean seconds.

Geforce Experience, as always, puts this game on highest settings but it runs HORRIBLE. I put everything to the lowest settings possible and it still runs horrible. Even though I don't have a "4K" monitor I can run games in "4K" fine, but I can't even run this game on 720p lol. Maybe it's Windows 11, maybe the game has issues with the newest drivers <shrugs>

So if you get the game and you have frame drops, turn OFF Anti Alias as for some THAT worked. If it doesn't work for you.. you probably will stop playing after an hour or 2 because the ragdoll camera REALLY becomes annoying when infected with frame drops.

Bigger isn't always better.

RE6 is basically your average summer blockbuster action movie, but in the worst way possible. There's no substance to any of it, it's just dumb set piece after dumb set piece. It's a trial in seeing just how crazy it can get and what kind of situations it can push the characters into to have them try to survive. It has some good ideas here and there and they clearly PACKED this thing full of content but most agree that the content you get here isn't quite up to par with any of the previous games in the series. RE6 killed the franchise for a reason.

As said before, this game has tons of content. It's easily the longest RE game even now with 4 different campaigns and one of the most extensive Mercenaries modes in the series. Each campaign revolves around different characters and they usually intertwine at certain moments. This sounds pretty awesome on paper but it doesn't feel as developed as say when Leon and Claire meet in RE2 at various points in the campaign. Usually you run into the other characters during a segment and they are just kinda there to help you fight then leave right after. I think Leon and Chris's campaign clearly had the most work done with them with Jake's being slightly worse and Ada being by far the worst of the four. Not all campaigns have the same amount of effort put into them unfortunately.

RE6 doesn't have much in the way of story. Sure there's plenty of cutscenes and attempts at a story but a lot of it feels like rehashes of previous games, there's this dude called Ustanak who is literally a carbon copy of Nemesis in Jake's campaign for example. I think Chris and Piers had a lot of potential though, and Jake as a concept is pretty cool but I think they could have been executed better.

Now there is one thing that RE6 does pretty well, and that's the gameplay. It's definitely a far cry from the Resident Evil that everyone knows but it's a very well made combat system focused around action, doing dodge rolls and performing take downs that feel like something out of a John Wick movie. I find the Mercenaries mode to be especially fun because of this, mainly because it's just pure gameplay without any boring story/annoying set pieces to get in the way.

I don't think RE6 is terrible but by the franchise's standards it's definitely the worst numbered title in the series. If you're looking for some dumb fun with a buddy, RE5 is a lot better for that but this is here as a backup option as well.

I guess you can say it also has the most story related content of any main game of the series but this isn't even the problem with the game.

The problem is the gameplay and the controls. The gameplay just feels like garbage and mostly consists out of button mashing and making stunts. And then the controls, whoever programmed these on PC has NEVER played any PC game. Luckily you can change some of them but others are hardlocked and ultimately the control scheme on Keyboard/Mouse is horrible. But wait, there is more. Sometimes the camera is really annoying and takes the control from the player even to a point where some sections like that boat parcour part in Chris' campaign is one of the most vile Resident Evil parts I remember. They even added annoying enemies that basically block your way but you have to ignore them since the time is REALLY short. If you get stuck once while sprinting or your character makes the wrong move because of the bad control scheme, you can basically redo the parcour because you died. Its just awfully bad game design. Oh, and did I mention you CANNOT skip the credits and are forced to watch them 4 times for each campaign and it always goes like 10 minutes? Even if you watched it already once, you still cant skip it. What were they thinking when they made this game? I guess I dont even need to mention that it has no ultrawide support, like almost all of Capcom's awful PC ports. Oh, there is btw also no pause in this game. If you want to go to toilet or whatever, bad luck, you have to keep the game running or restart from checkpoint. Marvelous game design.

Anyway, if I were you, just skip the game since its easily the worst main Resident Evil game. Story is alright but I wouldn't play it more than once, also because it really drags on with the 4 characters. Maybe they can make a decent game out of it if they remake it in ~10 years lmao.

I bought this game because I wanted to know what happened to Leon and other characters as well, before resident evil 7/8 and in preparation for re 9. 

It features chris, leon, ada, Sherry (from Re2), and new characters helena, jake, piers. 

Just be aware that It's going to be vastly different from all the previous entries. Lots of cinematic scenes, qte and gameplay made with coop in mind, 4 campaigns that are connected. 

Some maps from re6 were copied and used in revelations 2 raid mode, so if you played it first you might experiance deja vu. 

At first this game didn't reel me in, once I completed my first chapter 5 I was hooked. Each campaign ends with an epic boss fight. 

Leon's campaign provides an experiance that is more on the horror side. Has locations like cementary, church, [spoiler] sewers [/spoiler] 

Jake's campaign provides the most challenge. The chemistry between jake and Sherry was wholesome. 

Chris had the best campaign in my opinion. Both in terms of gameplay and story.

Ada's campaign is meant to be played last as it ties all the loose ends together.

Overall it might not be the best resident evil title, and it left me with some mixed feelings, however it was a fun game.

A good game. But so many flaws...
The gameplay it's way much better in Leon's and Ada's stories with puzzles, horror and the return of zombies. The controls are better too, now you can even do melee fighting. I didn't like the new characters: Helena, Jake and Piers. I think they're generic and lack personality. It seems Capcom tried to please every kind of player by making one campaign for horror (Leon's), one for action (Chris - this one looks like Call of Duty) and one mixed (Jake's). If the game was all about Leon campaign's with Claire (maybe?) and only a bonus campaign for Ada, it would be awesome. But even with the flaws, I like this game. For me, Leon, Ada, Sherry and Carla saved it with their stories and gameplays.

A fantastic game, an excellent expansion on the resident evil lore and gameplay.

It's nice to finally be able to move normally, and it lets the enemies have more aggressive tendencies besides "walk at player" and "Walk at player but a little faster." The updated melee system really feels like an evolution of the systems introduced in Resident Evil 4, and the options on offer allow you to change even how bullets are spawned from your position, allowing you to experience the game in a more classic way with a laser that shows you a perfect bullet trajectory and allows for faster followup shots (RE4 and 5) or something more akin to the modern RE-Releases, with a crosshair and center dot, with bullets spawning from the center of your screen rather than your gun's barrel. Each has its own ups and downs, pros and cons, and it can be fun to experience the game with both types of aiming. It's legitimately something really small, but really well implemented that adds extra avenues for replayability, and player comfort.

RE6, and Resident evil Outbreak/File #2 are the only three games that really made me feel like the developers appreciated the players and wanted to make as deep of an experience as mechanically possible, and it shows in the sheer amount of mobility and options the player has at any given time.

Wanted to update this review so that it looks like..ya know... an actual review. 

I hate this game. If you like this game, that's fine, more power to ya, but I don't. Now, I hate this game for one specific reason. If Capcom miraculously fixed this issue, I would rate this game similarly to RE5. 

RE6 LOVES to constantly take control away from the player. 

For example, you'll be playing with a friend in say, Leon's campaign. You'll be fighting monsters, doing your thing, when suddenly the game jumpcuts to a scene of a door opening, or a monster appearing or something flying through a window or a car crashing or a building blowing up. It's constantly doing this, like every few minutes and it unironically gives me a migraine.

I can put up with the dumb story, and the bad voice acting, and the repetitive gameplay, but this seriously is one of the only games in my library that succeeds in making me feel physically ill. I would equate it to the type of nausea people feel when they're having a bad experience in VR. To add insult to injury, the game is LOOOONNNNNG. Like 30 hours long.

To be fair, there's some stuff that's cool here. I like the movement quite a bit. Being able to manually dodge attacks is pretty fun and I wish this feature made its way into other games in the future. But good god, I'm so tired of forcing myself to take a Tylenol before firing this up.

Look closer at the logo of this game. It's literally a giraffe fucking a human in the mouth. And that's how the game will fuck you. Well, I think this game was kinda acceptable at the release time. But now, when remakes of the classic PS1 games are out, it just looks and feels like garbage.

Inventory. It's size is small and this is OK since it's an action game. You don't need to store several key items or burn corpses so they wouldn't revive. But accessing it is inconvenient. When you mix herbs and use them, you create pills. Each one of them restores 1 point of health out of 6. If you want to heal for, let's say, 5 points, you need to push the healing button 5 times and wait for the animation to complete. That's quite annoying, especially in the middle of a fight with a crowd (which happens often in this game). Why couldn't it be like in the earlier games? The only way to restore full health is to use a medical spray. And you have to choose it by scrolling the item menu. The same is with weapons and grenades. You waste too much time while going through all the stuff to choose one specific item. This often gets you damaged and knocked or even killed. I got taken down many times trying to choose a grenade to erase a whole enemy pack. No quick access or at least a pause menu access. No real pause at all because this game is cooperative.

Controls. Camera and movement are clunky. The character turns like he doesn't really want to. It's substantial during some chasing episodes (for example, the one in China with Chris and Piers). When you dodge in the rear direction, you character stays on the ground and doesn't get up automatically which confused shit out of me a couple of times. Dodging is stiff and somewhat hard to use, I don't even know why.

Campaigns. I've seen only two of them and fully completed only the one with Leon and Helena. It's first half feels like an average Resident Evil game with slow zombies, some puzzles here and and there, exploring the laboratoies and traversing the ancient catacombs below the church with a graveyard. Of course it's not like in the earlier games because this is a linear shooter, but it's decent. Then goes the absurd festival. Leon and Helena cannot even take a break during the second half of the campaign. Anytime they try to use an elevator, a transport, anything, it explodes and makes them run. After they escape the danger, there is another rushed segment with crushes and explosions or several stages of a bossfight (and all of that with several annoying QTEs that the most of players will fail multiple times). Yeah, all Resident Evil games ended up with a countdown when everything exploded and the final fight took place, but not in such prolonged and exaggerated manner. The second half of the campaign literally resembles an indian movie.

As for the Chris and Piers campaign, I couldn't endure much of it. It's an utterly boring shooting ground with uninteresting enemies. Some of them are total bullet sponges and the only thing you need to defeat them is to throw your entire inventory at them. This gameplay is repetitive as hell, there is no gunplay like in RE 2 Remake or RE 3 Remake where different enemies are better to kill with one weapon rather than another. Many times the game will make you stay on the position and fight flooding waves of enemies. But it won't give you enough ammo for all of them. I ended up helpless plenty of times during these segments. And even if I managed to find a breakable box, there would be no ammo, only points. Yeah, experience points to buy perks. What is this? A tabletop RPG? These perks contribute almost nothing to your gameplay and it takes huge amount of time to obtain some of them. I don't need those point, I just want to complete the game. But the segment that made me drop the game is the chasing section in China. It was so hard to move there with such clumsy controls. I failed it many times. The one single time I almost succeded, the bot companion failed it LOL. It seems the game itself suffers to pass its own shit LOL.

Is this a good action game? No. Is this a good Resident Evil installment? Well, there's been worse. If you are interested in the plot, just watch it on YouTube. Several times I tried to complete this game and didn't finish it. And I'm not going to. I just wanted to play it while waiting for Resident Evil 4 Remake. But no thanks.

As a Resident Evil fan throughout the years, one who holds OUTBREAK File #2 as the pinnacle of the series, this is what I have to say about Resident Evil 6:

I like this game, the controls feel fantastic, its very responsive and its extremely fun without breaking the flow of the game. As a fan of older titles, the story is.... Its quite funny, it tries so hard to take itself seriously, and expects you to as well, I genuinely cannot, and I don't think you can either, fan or not.

The best way I can describe how the controls feel, is it feels like a mix between Resident Evil and Devil May Cry, I tend to call it Devil May Evil, or Resident May Cry.  Grab this on a sale, well worth the mercenaries experience, and if you have a friend the story is fun to play too.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Resident Evil 6. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Resident Evil 6 is often called the worst of the main series, and that is probably true. Although, I personally believe this game gets more hate than it deserves.

Resident Evil 6 places you in the usual apocalyptic situation our protagonists somehow find themselves in. Unlike previous games, you have four separate stories to play through, all of which are intertwined in some way with each other.

I'll start with the negatives, as there are quite a few. First, the game's story is completely ridiculous at times. It has its good moments every now and then (especially at the end of Chris' campaign), but most of the time it feels confusing and really weird. It can get hard to follow as well. This is most likely because the game attempted to lean on action instead of horror while also trying to do horror, leaving it a muddled mess.

Second, the actual campaign flow for each campaign is horrendous. Large quiet sections often drag the game on while action sections come one after another, never really letting up (this is actually a positive which I will get into later). This is probably because they focused on making four separate campaigns instead of just one really good one, making each campaign feel half-baked in a sense (this is not the fault of the developers, more the fault of the people who actually set the deadlines).

Finally going back to the story, it doesn't really end on a single note. Thanks to it being split into multiple campaigns, the game relies on the final one to tie everything together. This results in the final campaign feeling really awkward and ending on a "okay, so what?" kind of note.

Okay so me saying all of this and still giving it a positive review must tell you that there's something else this game has going for it. And there is.

The gameplay.

Of any Resident Evil game, RE6 has the most engaging combat I've seen. From RE4 and RE5, the characters can still shoot enemies in their weakpoints and use melee attacks to deal extra damage. However there are so many more controls in RE6. You can dash and ram into enemies to stagger them. You can melee enemies to deliver a second blow with a powerful melee attack. You can slide into enemies to stagger them. You can dodge-roll to the side or backwards to evade attacks. You can even counter enemy attacks to deal heavy damage, often out-right killing the enemy. And there are far more controls than that that would take a long time to list out. There's a reason this game is said to have the best mercenaries mode. In fact, the game is best played foregoing your gun in favour of melee attacks against regular enemies (even on the highest difficulty and with infinite ammo).

This is why I believe the best way to play this game is not treat it as a Resident Evil game at all. Sure, as one it's terrible. But as a stand-alone game, it is a fantastic action game with a decent action-based story to go with it. There are still those really slow moments, sure, but when the game gets going, it gets going.

This is especially true on the highest difficulty, where the game pulls no punches. On Professional or No Hope, you are expected to display constant mastery of the game's controls or else you WILL be annihilated. It's an exhilarating experience to complete a chapter on one of the highest difficulties, especially with someone else helping out.

All in all, Resident Evil 6 fails hard as a Resident Evil game. It lacks the horror, resource management, and good story-telling that made the foundations of far better Resident Evil games like RE4 and RE7. However as its own thing, RE6 is a brilliant action game which shows you that when there's a zombie ahead and you have a gun, the best solution is to punch it in the face and break its spine. The game has a semi-decent story, and the difficulties allow both casual and experienced players to have a challenge to measure themselves up to.

Resident Evil 6, a game that's been unfairly maligned by some, but one that I think deserves more credit than it gets. Let's grab a drink and dive into why this game is worth your time.

First off, let's talk about the gameplay. Yes, it's true that Resident Evil 6 is more action-oriented than previous entries in the franchise, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. The combat is fast-paced and satisfying, with a wide variety of weapons and moves at your disposal. Each of the three campaigns has its own unique gameplay style, which keeps things fresh and interesting throughout the game. Now, let's talk about the story. I'll admit, it's not the most coherent or well-written story out there, but it's still a fun ride. The game ties together multiple plotlines and characters in a way that's ambitious and impressive, even if it doesn't always make complete sense. And let's not forget about the iconic Resident Evil villains, who make their return in memorable ways.

One thing that's often overlooked about Resident Evil 6 is its production values. The game looks fantastic, with detailed and immersive environments that are a joy to explore. The voice acting is also top-notch, with some truly standout performances from the cast. But perhaps the most underrated aspect of Resident Evil 6 is its replay value. With multiple campaigns to play through and a wide variety of unlockables and collectibles, there's plenty of content here to keep you coming back for more. And let's not forget about the game's multiplayer modes, which offer even more opportunities for fun and mayhem.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 6 may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I think it's a game that deserves more credit than it gets. With its fast-paced combat, ambitious storyline, and impressive production values, this is a game that's well worth your time. So grab a drink, sit back, and enjoy the ride.

[h1]Resident Evil 6[/h1]

Compared to other RE titles, Resident Evil 6 is the one I have the most mixed feelings with. While RE6 is a [b]highly[/b] entertaining action-based game with high replay value, it is plagued by a mediocre plot, aggravating UI + set pieces, and an overly action-saturated atmosphere with meek attempts at horror in which I would find it hard-pressed to call this game the "dramatic horror experience of 2013."

[u]Story + Characters (Possible Spoilers!)[/u]

Oh man, the story. Resident Evil plots aren't known for being the best, but this has be one of the most convoluted and ridiculous plots I have ever seen.

The entire plotline of RE6 can be described as follows: [spoiler]A leader of an Illuminati-like organization becomes a simp for Ada after a brief business relationship and clones her using one of his staff. Fake Ada is created and gets pissed at him for using her as an experiment, seeking revenge and setting the world on fire as a bonus.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]This entire story is not only generic but it is irrelevant to the entire storyline of Resident Evil. None of the villains, Carla and Simmons, are really mentioned at all before this game and after. They just show up as if we're supposed to know them and care. Regarding the separate campaigns, it's a mixed bag. Leon's campaign is irrelevant, Chris' campaign is okay, Jake's campaign is pretty good, and Ada's campaign feels like it's there to just point out why all this insanity happens. If you wanna understand the whole plot, Ada's story does the best at telling it.[/spoiler]

[u]Gameplay[/u]

RE6's strongest point is definitely the gameplay. Compared to other action titles, RE6 is almost always fun thanks to the amount of fluidity you're given with your movement. Sprinting, dashing, sliding, countering, melee attacks, quick shooting - there are an insane amount of ways to move about and play this game. Capcom really went all out with making as many possible mechanics with how the player can move and attack. It can take a good amount of time to master RE6's movement system, but it's a joy to feel in absolute control when you do. 

Among the three action-era RE games, I would say I have the most fun playing RE6. It's also the best one to play Co-op online or split-screen.

Each character has a unique mechanic they have so none of them feel the same even if it's pretty minor. Leon can dual wield, Helena has a unique shotgun which has unique quick shot animations, Chris has ample firepower at the beginning despite being among the most generic, Piers has the best starting weapon set among everyone with his MP-AF and Anti-Material Rifle, Jake's Hand-to-Hand is among the most fun to use, Sherry has access to a Stun Rod and a burst-fire pistol, and Ada can use her crossbow along with unique dashing and quick shot animations.

There are still some serious problems here though: first, the camera is atrociously bad because not only is it slow and hampered by terrible angles, the game will sometimes wring control of the camera to hyperfocus on an event happening which gets tiring really quick. These moments are most prominent in the Chris and Jake campaigns. Second, the QTEs. It's already been said, but there really are too many of them in this game; it feels like 40% of the game is just QTEs, some of which aren't even deadly if you fail. Third, the design of the set pieces; for some reason, there are so many parts in this game where all you do is run/sprint forward or you die - it happens so often, you will die more from these than actual enemies taking your health down. Again, these are found most in either Chris' or Jake's campaign. Lastly, the UI is not that great since it feels like you're supposed to use the interface while multitasking on the move which adds more burden to the lightning fast pace at which this game makes you play at.

[u]Graphics & Sound[/u]

I found the music in RE6 to be serviceable, but not groundbreaking. It is just there and the differences in music between the campaigns is trivial. They tried to get some kind of horror-like feeling from the main theme but that sort of contradicts with the action-saturated environment of the game. All in all, mildly average.

Comparing this with RE5, it seems like RE6 downgraded in graphics compared to past titles and it's a shame that some of the details of this game are average at best even for a 2013 game. Outside of cutscenes, much of the graphics of the game feel second-rate.

[u]Conclusion[/u]

When it comes to any game, the most important part for me is that it's fun to play. If it's not, what's the point? In that area, RE6 succeeds. It's among the most entertaining Resident Evil games I've played and even more so when you play it with a friend. That being said, the mishmash of problems from the story to some of the gameplay properties mark it as a "black sheep" among Resident Evil major titles.

I would only recommend this game if you're the kind of RE fan who prefers action horror over survival horror and can enjoy the fast-paced gameplay without being ticked off by its flaws.

Resident Evil 6 is a great game plagued by a horrible reputation for no good reason. This isn't a hindsight thing either, I've played this game since it first came out in 2012. I had it on PS3, then on Xbox 360, then finally got it here. I probably have like a thousand hours combined for this game across all platforms. 

This game is insane value from a modern standpoint. This game really has it all, even an actually fun PvP suite. This game got it right a decade ago when Capcom nowadays always fumbles and fails with modern attempts to make a competitive Resident Evil game. Survivors, Onslaught, Siege, and Predator are all dumb fun and none of the RE: Verse or Resistance crap hold a candle to them. 

Do yourself a favor. Buy this game, play it for yourself. Hell, get some of your friends to get it too and I guarantee you all will have so much fun you will keep coming back to this game over the years like I do. Resident Evil 6 is genuinely good, and anyone who says otherwise haven't actually PLAYED the game.

Good co-op game. Mediocre single-player game. TL;DR: buy it for co-op

It's a great co-op game because it handles well; the controls are actually really good in my opinion. Many sections require you to coordinate with your partner, so you have a good amount of interactions that keeps the game entertaining. The plot in general is over-the-top in just the right way so that it's fun to witness its absurdity with someone else. It's true that [i]everything[/i] is more fun with friends, but this is one of the more fun games I've played with friends.

Now, the issue with this game is that it was designed exactly for that: co-op. Single-player turns your partner into an invincible AI that never misses any inputs that otherwise plays decently well. You have to make very few decisions; you get every weapon and the only time you have to do any inventory management is when you have too much ammo. Upgrades are dumbed down to having three level 1-3 skills equipped, with each skill doing something like generally raising the damage with your guns, reduce damage taken, raising damage versus zombies, etc. which is drastically different from even RE5. The plot isn't particularly interesting and gets more confusing than anything; the confusion worked fine in co-op because we're focused on the co-op experience but it's not very entertaining alone (although, I will say that some of the cutscenes are still iconic in a good way)

The flaws that make this a mediocre single-player game at best is also what makes it a good co-op game.

[b]Graphics and story[/b] 7/10

[i]Resident Evil 6[/i] is a shooter action game. To tell the story of this game, we'll assume that the first half of the Jake-Sherry and Chris-Piers campaigns chronicle the incidents of Neo-Umbrella. The plot takes place in Edonia. Sherry Birkin is sent for the extraction of Jake Muller, whose blood from him will grant the preparation of a vaccine against the C virus. Meanwhile, Chris Redfield and Piers Nivans are sent to region where a civil war has broken out, since locals are using bio-organic weapons. For all four characters, Carla Radames —or blue Ada— will be involved in both events: the capture of Jake and Sherry as well as the death of the BSSA members of Chris's team. 

[i]Six months will pass[/i]. Adam Benford, the President of the United States, is infected and becomes a zombie. He wanted to reveal the true events of Raccoon City so The Family conspired against him. Leon S. Kennedy and Helena Harper are blamed for his death. They'll investigate the wrongdoer is Derek Simmons. While the real Ada Wong —or red Ada— will clear her name. Now the conclusion of each of the stories in couples will take place in China. Each one will hand over the antagonist the deserved outcome.

Perhaps combination of parallel stories is not a bad idea. Only screenwriters should know how to weave cross paths applying knowledge of narrative time. This Resident Evil tries to go further in the usual narrative by rummaging for an innovative story. A different way of relating shared events to break the traditional scheme of how to tell a story. On this occasion there are four stories that intertwine with each other. The game's problem was tightly weaving four stories with seven characters: New and well-known, without giving the new ones a possibility to grow narratively. We have that gap of six months, a meaningless abyss. There is an obligation to appear in those moments where stories intersect, it offers a forced scenario for four characters. 

By having that abyss in story, as well as the characters change their temperament due to time elapsed, that's how visual art unfolded. On the one hand, the locations were created before six months. There the urban landscape of Edonia sunk in war and winter predominates. So white scale with illumination is displayed. After a certain time, the locations are opposite, with that impression that something bad happened. The urban landscape is recommenced but is set in the dark. It offers an urban air through common sites that goes to skyscrapers. However, design and photography are poor and vague. Skyscrapers look dull or blurry. It doesn't have a good treatment of textures in the objects. Few places predominate by level of design, quality and appealing detail. Not forgetting the design of the enemies, new and strange, some are colossal.

[b]Playability[/b] 7/10

If narrative wants to break with typical scheme, it happens in same way with the gameplay. The purpose of this game is to keep the player focused on the action without missing a beat. Quick time events will be involved. For those who don't know: it is an interactive cinematic. It consists of pressing certain buttons at a certain time to avoid instant death. Although there are actions with more button combinations. To this is added the change of involuntary camera or involuntary views. The player will look at the scene from a different perspective —although sometimes it tends to confuse perspective for movement, for example, the forward button is overridden to use the walk back button.

The game emphasizes teamwork. It's recommended to play with a friend. There are certain moments in the plot it requires the help of the partner, so we'll temporarily separate into small [i]separate paths[/i]. The purpose: to help each other to continue progressing in story. Something new that is added is stamina for melee attacks. These attacks also allow interaction with the weak points of enemies in order to finish them off. However, depending on our way of playing, the game offers the possibility of choosing skills. We can choose three of them, with which they will give us certain advantages in the game: such as greater stamina, damage, resistance and others. Some skills can be upgraded by points. The enemies will drop [i]chess pieces[/i] — as well herb, ammo, c4 and grenades— that have point value. Finally, each duo- character will find and use different weapons than the other pairs. The combination of herbs prevails. There are constant checkpoints. The player will have more movement options: roll, slide, crouch, cover and the variety of combination melee attack; inasmuch as game is saturated with constant action.

[b]Music and FX[/b] 8/10

The game's soundtrack is interesting, long and distinct. The music reinforces drama of the game. The musical pieces are composed in the form of a suite. What is different is that representative drama of the music expresses action instead of terror. It's a soundtrack with many pieces of music based on melodies and openings of action movies. So we'll listen to musical pieces accentuating the characters and their development in form of clash and raid. Each of them will have a different rhythm and tempo; but in the end, listening to the substance of melody, it becomes continuous whose harmony leans more towards bright tones than rejects dark tones. Although over time it becomes repetitive, exhausting and irksome.

The soundtrack was composed by: Wataru Hachisako, Akihiko Narita, Thomas Parisch, Laurent Zilian, just to mention a few. The main soundtrack that we'll perceive in the story is composed of orchestral music. Although segment of strings, percussions and trumpets frequently stands out. The musical compositions express energy, impetus and vigour. But it lacks emotions and feelings, forcing this music only for the incessant combat. The music avoids sympathy with the characters. Its purpose is to give a shove to continue with the story. Perhaps there are some minimal, barely perceptible contrasts, such as slowness and adagios. Since the rest of the music corresponds to a soundtrack for a movie dominated with verve of action. The music wants to give us a breather in appearance, but suddenly changes to be immersive in action.

[b]Duration[/b] 8/10

As the game seems to have narrative conflicts, one might think that one should start with Leon's campaign. Which offers a tutorial on how to play it. There was no need to add a prologue. It's a good idea start with some introductory steps, but it leads to temporary narrative confusion about how it all started. However, this keeps us tied to the game to learn a little more about the story. It forces us to play each campaign in order to intertwine the narrative.

The game features four campaigns. Each one with 5 chapters. As it is action game, some chapters are played nippily, and others are unappetizing. It's suitable to play it with someone, since that way the game becomes more interactive. It's re-playable, each new game the skills that we choose just like weapons are saved. Or, we can play in different difficulties. The game contains two modes of mercenary. As a rarely played versus mode is also included. If you like action and are curious about this game, I recommend playing it with a friend. That way you will feel constant action at every moment.

In short it sucks, neither fun or enjoyable and either a bore or a chore most of the time. I'm not sure if I'll even bother finishing it.

The UI is terrible, in fact it might be the worst UI I've ever encountered. This is especially true because you can't pause the game when accessing the menu which is moronic. The QTE nonsense quickly becomes tiresome as well as the constant cutscenes.

The controls/gameplay just feel stiff and clunky for the type of game it's trying to be. There are plenty of action FPS games which are far more fluid and enjoyable to play so I'm not sure what they were thinking with this sequel. The camera angles are terrible, the levels linear, and the pacing is awful. Either it's unbearably slow such as in the beginning where you are forced to walk or wait on others, or you're being rushed through area after area.

The artificial difficulty is beyond irritating. The aiming sucks and you have to purchase 'skills' for it as well as weapon damage and other things which cost a lot of skill points and can only be purchased between chapters. There's no reason it should take 10+ headshots to down a normal zombie AFTER I already blew it up with a damn fire extinguisher while others can go down with a few, or that an enemy outside of a building can lunge and instead of hitting the side of the building manage to fly through a window and grab you when you're standing a few feet away. The melee sucks and I got sick of kicking air instead of stomping on a downed zombie's head, and of course afterwards you get grabbed and fall to the ground. Dropped items will disappear on you as well. In the graveyard there are multiple pits dug in the ground and scattered about, if you walk near them you magically slide into them even if you're 1-2 feet away. Granted once you realize that it's not too hard to avoid but that was the final straw for me as I was already irritated. 

The game freezes up when exiting and won't display anything else besides the black screen even when alt+tabing or bringing up the task manager, so you have to blindly use the arrow keys and the delete button to end the task for the game in the task manager after selecting it, while it stays behind the black screen.

Holy cow, what a clunky ass game! The only good thing is the dodge system, but that's it. The game is made like a monkey training program (QTE) where there's a only a very narrow way of doing things and if you don't get it right the first time, well there's always 50 more before you get sick of it. More frustration than fun for sure.

I really enjoy this game and my only guess for the bad rep it gets is because it's just different from other RE games. Which is a completely valid critique, but it doesn't make this game itself a bad game. RE6 is really neat for introducing a more controllable melee mechanic, stamina to go with it, and just a ton of cool stuff for the player to do. Keyboard controls don't feel too great when you sprint around because the camera freaks out with it, but aside from that once you hit the flow with the controls you're all set. There's slightly more analysis on characters and how their past may be affecting them, or how they may be spiraling downwards because of outside forces which is an interesting take and a slight change from what we normally get from RE protags. Leon's campaign is the overarching campaign that fits basically the whole story and the others fill in the gaps. Go into the game thinking that way, not that you're getting four entirely separate stories. I love Helena Harper.

Probably the least enjoyable experience I have had with resident evil.

So me and my friend have pushed ourselves to finish the entirety of the game at the hardest difficulty, we did not play any of the dlc missions or stuff like that just the basic story modes. 

The mechanics of this game is more or less identical to re5, but worse. We had encountered so many problems with doors and the game just shitting itself that we had to reinstall 3 times. There were times when the player hosting had to be the one that opened and interacted with all the objects or else the game would soft lock. An absolutely horrendous experience and these problems caused us to take a month break before completing the game.

Other problems include the default key mapping and the controls. Who in the right mind would put interact and sprint on the same key? The mouse and character movement was also horrible. The overall movement felt clunky even with a controller, mostly due to insanely wide turning radius and extremely slow character movement. And when using mouse there were times where the cursor would snap behind you after an interaction and cause a death.

Next is the story and how fast paced and boring it was. The characters were so flat and predictable and the action sequences was something my 14 year old sister would be able to think up. Me and my friend started betting on what action sequence would happen next and we would get it right every single time. The story was so repetitive and stereotypical that it showcases what little thought was put into these multiple story modes.

The Ada campaign especially was so hastily put together and barley works with co-op play that there were parts where it would literally crash the game due to the second player begin in front of Ada in the load sequences. The Sherry campaign was literally the most boring and contained basically nothing new story or gameplay wise. The Leon campaign wasn't that bad but it felt especially slow, and the Chris campaign (honestly the best one) started off slow and ended way too fast. 

To conclude, the writing is weirdly paced and gameplay is clunky. The only memorable part of the game is the Chris campaign and that is mostly due to the relationship between Piers and Chris which both me and my friend felt was the most genuine and heartfelt. Still a fairly fun game, but its probably not worth completing more than two story lines. And since I didn't play solo I can't imagine how bad the AI partner would be if its anything like re5.

Lot's of console port bullshit.

- Game starts directly without going into the main menu first. I hate that.

- FOV is adjustable (yay!) but the value ranges from 0 to 15. What is that? Can't they write it properly? Presumably it means something like 60-80.

- Brightness adjustment is impossible, since the '6' in the adjustment screen is always visible even when the game itself stops being visible. This setting needs to be maxed. (In all other games the default middle value works best for me.)

- Every action in ingame cutscenes needs to be approved of by pressing a button with the most pointless QTEs (no danger, just opening a door needs timed button press).

- Terrible ingame options menu with non-sense icons where you need to hover over to know what it is. Icons can be clicked but value is only adjustable via keyboard.

- Bright light flashes with cheap SFX when QTE is performed, not very immersive.

- Aiming unprecise and wobbly, mouse acceleration can't be turned off.

- Bad acting, embarrassing writing, non-sense story. (Leon talks to the zombie-president like he doesn't know what a zombie is.)

- Zombies don't die from headshot, Kung-Fu-Fighting is more effective and makes their heads explode. They also side-step to dodge bullets.

It's a mess.

Now people hate this game because it deviated from the horror and gore motives of resident evil. But I hate it for a different reason.

[h1] THE GOOD (BUT NOT THE BEST): [/h1]

- STORY: due to me not interested that much in horror and gore, this is actually okay. Yeah it deviated so much from the RE DNA, but this game is purposely made to continue the story of every character. Maybe u don't agree with me, but that's what I experience for myself. I will hold to an argument that this game is just a carbon copy of Michael Bay films still.

- PERFORMANCE: Game is made in MT Framework, which is a flawed engine from 1990s, texture and env is low-res, but credit to characters textures, bcos that looks good!!! I am able to play this game on AMD Ryzen 6600H, with sometimes small dips in fps, even that is because I'm recording my gameplay.

- TIMELINE: In timeline panel, you can actually see which character and which date in-story is their cutscene, which is GOOD. It's like flowchart but it's linear and character splitted.

[h1] THE BAD: [/h1]

- ACCESSIBILITY: This game is an accessibility NIGHTMARE. Settings DON'T pause the game!!! Who decided to do this crap??? If u want to pause, you need to press START. Like WTH man!!??

- ACCESSIBILITY_2: Settings icon on UI, but description on the subtitle??? I had to move my eyes frequently to see what every settings do. And the icon is not the one which widely used and recognised by the world, its their custom made one, which is BS at its best. A perspectively-PDA style of settings is stylish and all, but it is hard to see. Make UI as plain and easy to see and read PLEASE!!!

- QTE and Interact: QTE UI is bullcrap for this game. Interaction is not shown until you came near interactibles, which is an A-hole design at its best.

- DIRECTIONS: Maps man, maps. People use maps for navigation. Why do it in PDA super hi-tech style??? Make me nauseous and add unnecessary animations.

My review is based on Leon playthrough. This is what I collected. All the bad (and good even) most probably has been solved with their new RE Engine.

Columbo (/kəˈlʌmboʊ/) is an American crime drama television series starring Peter Falk as Lieutenant Columbo, a homicide detective with the Los Angeles Police Department.[2][3] After two pilot episodes in 1968 and 1971, the show originally aired on NBC from 1971 to 1978 as one of the rotating programs of The NBC Mystery Movie. Columbo then aired less frequently on ABC from 1989 to 2003.

Columbo is a shrewd but inelegant blue-collar homicide detective whose trademarks include his rumpled beige raincoat, unassuming demeanor, cigar, old Peugeot 403 car,[4][5][6] love of chili con carne, and unseen wife (whom he mentions frequently). He often leaves a room only to return with the catchphrase "Just one more thing" to ask a critical question.

The character and show, created by Richard Levinson and William Link, popularized the inverted detective story format (sometimes referred to as a "howcatchem"). This genre begins by showing the commission of the crime and its perpetrator; the plot therefore usually has no "whodunit" element of determining which of several suspects committed the crime. It instead revolves around how a perpetrator known to the audience will finally be caught and exposed.

The series' homicide suspects are often affluent members of high society; it has led some critics to see class conflict as an element of each story.[7] Suspects carefully cover their tracks and are initially dismissive of Columbo's circumstantial speech and apparent ineptitude. They become increasingly unsettled as his superficially pestering behavior teases out incriminating evidence.[7] His relentless approach often leads to self-incrimination or outright confession.

Episodes of Columbo are between 70 and 98 minutes long, and have been broadcast in 44 countries. The show has been described by the BBC as "timeless" and remains popular today.[8]

This game gets a lot of hate from die-hard fans for a good reason. no, it doesn't feel like a resident evil game. It's supposed to be dark, a lingering fear of what's around the corner, anxiety inducing from lack of ammunition, and music that makes you feel eerie.

Resident Evil 6 has none of that. The game has 4 total campaigns and Leon's story is the closest you get to that feeling.

However, it's one of my most favorite Co-op experiences that you're gonna make great memories with a friend.

Each story offers a different flavor but ultimately tie into each other:
Leon's campaign: The darkest of the bunch. Offers a great story of finding the cause of the bio-terrorist attack.
Chris's Campaign: Your typical run & gun 3rd-person military shooter. Chris is tasked with eliminating the BOW's of the attack. If you want action, this is it!
Jake's Campaign: This mode is meant for people with Scopophobia (The fear of being stalked). Jake's story takes him on a mission to cure the virus, but is relentlessly hunted by a HULK looking brute monster that's been tasked with killing him.
Ada's Campaign: Unlocked after completing all the campaigns. This story just a filler that ties up unanswered questions gives more back story.

I also wanna mention how awesome the boss fights are in this game. Very intense and cinematic.

The developers tried to satisfy old fans, bring in new fans, and appeal to shooter fanatics. It didn't make a true resident evil game. But if you can get past the RE mindset, your gonna have a fantastic time playing this game with a friend.

Highly recommend. :)

Hilariously overblown, this is what it took for the Resident Evil series to earn a soft reboot but despite the many quicktime events, 0 scares and a somewhat repetitive gameplay, this is a good game, not a good RE, but a fun third person shooter with varied scenarios and cool looking set pieces.

7/10

I bought this game on a steep sale; I like Resident Evil and went into this thinking that it couldn't possibly be as bad as people were making it out to be. The stakes were low and the potential for success was high. This game hard failed. Over the years I've played all but one (until now) mainline RE entry; this is the *only* one of those games were it felt like the developer actively hated me as a player. You can actually catch glimpses of what CAPCOM wanted with this game, and those glimpses are *so* gd good. But the action is bad, and the stealth is bad. Trying to cram survival horror mechanics into those two things makes them that much worse. And that doesn't even address the imprecise controls, the sudden "cinematic" camera shifts that alter said poor controls, and the QTEs. 
TL;DR: I cannot, in any way, recommend this game. Even if you could buy it for a single dollar/pound/euro/money unit. It's not worth it. I've always had a generally positive view of CAPCOM and its games. I came out of this *hating* the company. This game was that rough.

If you’re wondering, like I was, as a fan of the series but a person who doesn’t like the action heavy entries as much, is this game worth playing? This review is for you.

I think the worst Resident Evil game is 5, hands down. If you got through that one, I think this one is better in every way. Better story, better gameplay, and better set pieces for sure.

I played it on Easy to minimize deaths because I hate having to repeat parts in shooters, and for me at least that ended up being a good call.

Pros
- 4 ~5 hour long campaigns that play like self contained stories
- Story is not amazing, but I found it pretty interesting
- Really cool set pieces
- Sections with different styles of gameplay (vehicles, for example)

Cons
- The default FOV made me motion sick (I have only felt this way in playing VR games with low frame rates and don’t normally get motion sick in any other games) and it can only be changed at the main menu, not in-game
- Even with “fixing” the FOV, the camera jerks around quite a bit through each campaign and at times I found myself still feeling a little dizzy
- Some fights feel really long
- Lots of quick time events that will end up killing you if you miss them
- Some segments where you die if you don’t move fast enough, and you end up dying excessively trying to memorize these parts
- Little to know horror or atmospheric stuff
- Very few puzzles (maybe 1 or 2 good ones in 20 hours)

While there is a lot to forgive, and this game doesn’t provide the survival horror that I love about the series, it really has a lot of fun moments. The four campaigns overlap some, which leads to the story being told in fragments which is kind of fun to piece together. It may not be the best Resident Evil game, but it is a good game, and it is definitely fun.

Overall Score: 7.5/10

Resident Evil directed by Michael Bay. The game is dumb fun with a dumb fun story-line. And I gotta say, this is probably the last time the characters were actually great aside from arguably Chris in some moments. Hands down my favorite movement system of any RE game. Love to slide around and be stylish, and the melee and counter system is incredibly satisfying. Gotta mention the best mercenaries too! CDG / Grenade glitch is extremely fun. The modding community for 6 is still alive and well too, very fun to make the game your own with your own picked out cosmetics. The couch coop and online play for the campaign is ridiculous fun, you'll laugh at all the dumb things that happen. My favorite Resident Evil game. I think Capcom secretly hit it out of the ball park with this one and all of the new things they tried to do with it at the time. You get a dumb and cohesive story and arguably the most in-depth gameplay mechanics of any RE game. Kind of a hidden gem in this day of RE games if you let it be. By no means a perfect game but turn your brain off for a bit and you might find yourself enjoying the game.

I initially hesitated to recommend this game because there're things that's really really good and then things that are really terrible. But after finishing all the campaign and definitely not feeling wasted any time, guess it's fair that I give it a praise.
Overall speaking:
Story 9/10
Gameplay 5/10
Control 2.5/10
Music 5/10
Graphic 7/10 

As you may have seen, story is almost the sole reason I recommend this game, but it's really worth it.
I completed the remastered version of RE2 and RE3, watched the gameplay of RE0 and RE1, played RE7 half-way, and I say the story of this is WAY better than any other story experience I have in other games in the same series. In fact it's been a long time since I got really absorbed into a game story.
There are four campaigns, same story from 4 perspective. If you only play one campaign you might feel ah that's how the story plays, but then you play another campaign you're suddenly very puzzled by the apparent total contradiction in the plot. Each story (except Ada's, which you should definitely play last) contains some mysteries and some solutions to the other campaigns, wonderfully fit into each other. Really well written.

Now come the shitty part-the gameplay. I don't know why it makes you so hard to simply save the game. "Checkpoints" save nothing, and you CANNOT pause the game, like wtf. Once I opened the keybind screen, and since the game doesn't stop some monsters came out of nowhere to attack me but I cannot leave the screen because "there are keys not bind yet" like wtf. If I want a game that I simply cannot pause I would find a PvP online game. Despite it's from a 1st person perspective most of the time, sometimes it gets your angle fixed, in order to let you see the stuff in the background--most of the time this happens when you have to RUN AWAY from a threat. So now you have to run for your life, but then the last second you were pressing W to run forward, 5 seconds later you gotta press A to run forward, and then another 5 seconds later you press S---are you fkin kidding me.

Music itself is barely passable, nothing bad but nothing impressive either.
Graphic: not bad by a 2012 standard.

My scores for this game

Story : 9/10
One story and four episodes were great.

Graphics : 7/10
The graphics were good and satisfying.

Musics : 9/10
The soundtracks and situations of the music were great.

Details : 10/10
The details were careful, I did not see any weakness.

Game play : 8/10
The gameplay was very action-packed compared to other Resident Evil
For one thing, I felt like I was playing a game shooter, not Resident Evil.

Variety : 10/10
The variety of stages was great and I did not get bored at all and the online part was a lot of fun.

Characterization : 10/10
It was a pleasure to see the previous Resident Evil characters.

Overall score : 8.5/10

Game was better and worse than I thought at the same time.  Its one of those games that if you go in with low expectations, you'll probably enjoy it. The game feels like it was supposed to be the epic finale of the series as its tie-ing up all the loose ends from prior games, four separate campaigns showing different perspectives and events with fan favorite characters,  a coop experience with your friends or  family,  a revamped inventory system designed for convenience,  cutscenes galore , tons of zombie types,  high stakes action, and also trying to setup a sequel for jake.  And while it does deliver on some of this, all the different elements tend to strech the game and story a bit thin and makes the game a 'on the rails resident evil experience' like you would find at an arcade.  The co-op feature (which is heavily emphasized) is laughably bad as two people need to press 'v' to open a door, or one has to turn a lever while the other runs around, or easy to mess up confusing quick time events ; and while those things aren't all that bad.. the game will also randomly change camera angles causing you to die,  or the areas are so small and limited there isn't much for more than one person to do.  The inventory system is sorta convenient... once you figure out how to use it.  The best elements of the games are the cutscenes, getting to know all the characters a little more with their individual stories, and the over the top corny action.  If you don't mind a janky game,  best way to play this is solo on amateur level (so that your companion ai doesnt die to stupid stuff and it makes the quicktime events easier).   As for the four campaigns  chris's  was the best , leons second (first half was confusing and boring), jakes third  ( lot of 'quick time/maze/puzzle events' that are easy to mess up and die to) , and lastly Adas  campaign ( simply because she is in all the other campaigns so there is not much new and her individual story is pretty short and has some annoying puzzles) . If the game had been more focused on one story line, I think it would have been a lot better and more polished.

This is an absolutely terrible Resident Evil entry, but they're making better games so I'll let it slide. Point aside, still a fun third person shooter, they really wanted to go for it this time around with the movement engine, objectives they'll just throw at you, and skill points mechanics from the very beginning to the game 'til the end. The plot was very hard to follow, and the stereotypical characters and presentation also drain of the otherwise horror experience Resident Evil games are known for. There are a huge variety of gamemodes and content offered however. I had only played Leon's campaign, a small fraction of the content offered. It was fun playing the campaign in co-op, and pretty much all the content is available in co-op as well.

Otherwise, I do not recommend this being your first Resident Evil game. Any other one would do justice if you're looking for the experience.

Resident Evil 6 was built on weak foundations. It took what RE5 already misunderstood about RE4 and then cranked it up to 11. While some redeeming factors still stand, mainly the character movement and the fantastic cast, none of that can save the game from going creatively bankrupt. 8 hours (Leon Campaign) were more than enough for me but the game refused to stop. It went on for another 20 miserable hours that I could not wait to finish.

RESIDENT EVIL 6 is not only a bad game, I consider it a disgrace to the name of Resident Evil, and an absolute spit in the face to fans of this beloved franchise.

RE6 returns absolutely iconic characters Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, and Ada Wong. It also introduces one new main character, Jake Muller, and 2 partner characters to Leon & Chris!

RE6 does an absolutely great job with the characters themselves, which is an amazing thing in this game considering every other thing this game suffers from immensely.

If you've played any other mainline Resident Evil game, you should know the charm & feel that RE Environments give off. They just feel like Resident Evil, y'know? Yeah, well, throw all of that charm out because RE6 does that for you already. Not a single environment in this game gives off that great feel that other entries always do. This game mainly takes place in 2 cities, and it feels as if they dropped Leon or Chris into the environment of an action-zombie movie with tons of neon lights & random explosions. Not only are the environments themselves bad, you ever like that environmental storytelling in other entries? Y'know, the notes and stuff you find lying around when you explore? Yeah, well, say goodbye to that amazing thing too. RE6 rips it away from you. "Hope you're okay with that!", I'm sure Capcom was saying.

RE6 contains 4 campaigns which all round out to about 5 hours long each, and I only played 2. Leon & Chris'. I could not allow myself to play the other 2 (Jake, Ada) as I seriously feel like I would go insane. This game is horrific to play with it's weird obsession of sending unnecessarily long hordes at you that seem like they are never going to end. They send random hordes that last so extremely long you don't think you will see the end of them, and when you finally do reach the end of one, you might as well prepare because another one is right around the corner.

Leon's hordes consist of casual zombies, similar to the Raccoon City Incident of RE2, but also zombies that regenerate into a new form after their death. This wouldn't be so bad, if they weren't constantly in hordes that seem to never end. Oh, yeah, try body-armored zombies too. So you're going against constant hordes with casual zombies, some of which regen into a stronger, new body, and also body-armored zombies. Sick, right?

And if that doesn't sound super bad to you, then I'm sorry if your a Chris Redfield fan who chose to play him first, because instead of that already annoying stuff Leon goes against, Chris is put in literal shootouts. Any encounter you find yourself in, it consists of you firing a gun at your enemy who is also firing a gun. They put that in hordes, too! So, you'll find yourself in a horde but instead of dealing with regeneration or body-armor, you are literally getting hit with gunfire. Fun, right? No. It's not. It sucks.

The stories themselves (atleast Leon & Chris) aren't ... that bad. Leon's is extremely forgettable, I barely remember what his plot even was, to be honest. Chris' on the other hand though, it's not forgettable. It's actually really sad, and it really shows that he has been through some bad stuff, and that doesn't stop as he's constantly going through more stuff during his campaign. It's sad and really gives you a new outlook on the "Great Chris Redfield!".

Other games in RE, such as 5, or even the side-series Revelations are really action-heavy, but somehow managed to hold onto that flare that Resident Evil always gives off. RE6 is action-heavy as well, but on a completely different level and shows no flare of Resident Evil. Such a disappointment.

You like good performance in your games, right? You know, smooth framerates, but also with some good looking graphics. Sorry to tell ya, this game isn't great in that category. Throughout both Leon & Chris' campaigns, I was dealing with constant stutters, and even full-on freezes at times. This game is from 2013.
This means: RE6 is a 2013 game running on a high-end PC from 2020(being mine, of course) and still stuttering to all hell with some actual freezes at times, and the game isn't even graphically insane. It looks okay of course, but it's not anything groundbreaking. Even the games made in RE Engine in recent years don't have this issue, so 6 must have really bad optimization.

The overall events of RE6 aren't very memorable, and it seems Capcom agrees as (atleast afaik) neither 7 or Village mention any of the events that occur in 6, which is a little odd as 6 does have some big events.

It's clear Capcom was trying to go for a big action-zombie movie type feel, and while they may have hit that mark a little bit, it completely ruins Resident Evil and had the franchise continued down this route, I am sure it would have met it's end. Thankfully, RESIDENT EVIL 7 biohazard came and fixed this whole mess and brought the franchise back to it's horror roots.

Capcom made an attempt at making Resident Evil something it's not, and they seem to have succeeded in that with RE6. As a newcomer to RE who has been playing thru all the games in a row, I have enjoyed them all up until this, and I feel this is a big spit in the face to the fans. Whatever this monstrosity was, never do it again Capcom. Thanks.
