Resident Evil 6 is a highly action focused title in the series, attempting to expand itself in all directions with multiple inter-weaving stories, locations, and characters. While the game can be fun, it strays far from the series' survival horror origins, while most other aspects of the game remain, sadly, average. Like with the previous few titles, the game features third-person gunplay combat, peppered with quick time events, mutant creatures, and monster infested locales. While the gameplay appears to be like other third-person entries in the series, it diverges in tone and design. I struggled with whether to give it a thumbs up or down, which is perhaps the most telling.

As a game on its own, RE6 is not terrible. While it has its frustrating aspects, it is not devoid of interesting moments, and entertaining gameplay. However, as a Resident Evil game, RE6 is demonstrably poor, forgetting almost entirely the aspects which made former titles great, and which typified the series as a whole. Resident Evil itself coined the term 'Survival Horror' to describe the nature of its first title in 1996. This game focused on horror, limited resources, fight or flight choices, and a foreboding and mysterious atmosphere which came while investigating. RE6 is a plain action title, with the horror aspect relegated to set dressing. While the series has always had its cheezy moments, with B-movie schlock, RE6 instead feels like it is trying to be like every other action title that came out around the same time.

This trend in the series was already present in RE5, which in turn was responding to the success of RE4, which first introduced the third-person gameplay used in proceeding titles. RE6 triples down on this action aspect, expanding the 'partners co-op' style gameplay of RE5 into an absurd, convoluted, quasi-multiplayer experience. Not only do players have the option of co-op, but they will encounter other teams where missions 'cross'. While interesting theoretically, it further kills much of the horror survival vibe. Further, players can also opt to control a zombie, invading another player's game. If this all seems redolent of Left 4 Dead, you are right, as RE6 had cross over content with that franchise, and obviously took cues from it.

As a long time fan of the series, RE6 is a disappointment to me for all these reasons. But, I feel it would be unfair to wholly damn RE6 simply for being different. Indeed, L4D and the other action style games RE6 draws influence from are not bad games. For those considering playing RE6, just be aware that if you are looking for a survival horror experience or are a returning fan, you will be far better served with any title in the series other than this.

Resident Evil 6 (A Post Rant Review):
Resident Evil 6, it also has a number of smaller changes differentiating it from RE4 and 5. Firstly, all weapons are found in the game world. Weapons cannot be upgraded as in other games, but instead the player buys and equips 'skills'. These range from general damage, to increases drop rates, to more health or stammina.

Skills are bought with 'experience' which is dropped from enemies or found. This is, in esscence, the same as money in 4 & 5, though with more limited uses. With this being the case, I would have preferred if exp was acquired more like other games, given on defeating enemies or completing missions, as opposed to a pick-up. This would also insentivise players to beat levels with speed and flair. This seems to mostly be used to maintain a certain level of player power at all times through out the game.

For those players who do wish to upgrade their skills, they can replay previous missions taking their weapons along with them. There are a total of 4 main stories to play through featuring different characters fighting through a worldwide plot to infect the planet with the C-Virus. Stories 1-3 are done in pairs, each featuring a returning character from previous games. These are Leon, Chris, a grown-up Sherry Birkin, and Ada Wong. Jill is presumably on sabbatical.

Leon, Chris, and Sherry also have a new character to act as their partner. Leon gets Helena, a fellow government Agent who knows more about the outbreak than she lets on. Chris gets Piers, BSAA super sniper, and in some ways a reflection of Chris's early incarnation in STARS. Sherry gets Jake, a mercenary, whose unique genetic origin grants him immunity to the C-Virus. A reasonable effort is made to make each pair have some contrast.

Leon is earnest, but tired of the horror. Helena is desperate and fueled by a need for vengeance. Chris, having fallen into a amnesiac depression, has forgotten that he's a hero, a fact which Piers will try to correct with his own selfless devotion to the cause and to the BSAA. Sherry Birkin takes after Claire, being caring, brave, and determined. She and Jake develop a quick chemistry as Jakes devil-may-care attitude and mercenary position clash against her sincerity. They may honestly be the best pair, if only because they have been given the most space to be individuals, unhindered by previous games. Ada is her usual aloof self.

Each campaign is 5 missions, with each taking just over an hour, rounding out to just over 20 hours total. While some have praised the game's increased length compared to RE5, the split in stories and the multitude of characters makes much of the game a mess. Indeed, everything seems to be a hurry in RE5. The disaster is always in progress, with players desperately trying to act as quickly as possible. While this is not always true, the tone is present, and on many occasions it seems enemies continue to drizzle into the area, preventing the player form feeling safe enough to full explore.

The enemies themselves have some good designs, though I would have like to see more consistency for the C-Virus mutations. While most enemies have fairly solid designs, they feel somewhat inconsistent. Sometimes the C-Virus makes regular zombies, sometimes L4D style mutant infected, sometimes lizards, and sometimes bug mutants. The insectoid mutations really should have been the most prevalent. The game's frequent use of cocoons and other insect imagery would have fit a lot more. But sadly the game want to show you as many designs as it can with little thought, further preventing any consistent design through line.

The stories themselves are half-way self contained. Playing in order, Leo and Helena know the least, with Ada knowing the most about the whole incident. While an interesting concept, I often felt like I was re-treading old ground, and by the second campaign had already guessed one or two of the major secrets revealed in Ada's campaign. Overall, the stories are individually ok, and could even serve as decent RE plotlines on their own, but are ultimately made weaker by placing them interconnectedly in one game.

What remains, after all this, is the gameplay itself which is serviceable. Gun play is fun and fast. Melee is functions while the stamina bar keeps you from simply pounding the enemies into dust. Where it fails, it fails in the details. Small moments where the greater 'coolness' of the moment never gave way to player's perspective. This is where its impossible to tell if your damaging a boss, or where a camera angle gets in the way of the player. I found one of the most frustrating early examples of this was the fact that I could shoot or stab zombies prior to them re-animating, only for them to lunge at me when I passed.

These moments, while small, can add up over 20 or-so hours. Overall the gameplay is serviceable fun, and the plot can be entertaining. In fact, if RE6 were its own game, not part of the series, I would probably have praised it for its ambition. As it stands it is an ok game, and a bad Resident Evil game. It has my recommendation only for the former, and with a heavy grain of salt.

This game has aged horribly. I had played this with a friend on Xbox when it released. A friend wanted to play it as its the only resident evil he hadn't played so I agreed to play it with him.

Pros:
- Game runs fine
- Entire game can be done coop
- I personally like the 4 distinct campaigns each with their own characters / themes and how they overlap with key parts.

Cons:
- Quick Time Events everywhere. Literally opening a door can be a QTE
- It constantly takes control of your camera to make you look at something. 
- - This make it very hard to control if not impossible to fight.
- - It will change from 3rd person  to a remote fixed camera angle like the original RE 1 / 2
- - You'll be in a chase scene and it will have the camera behind you. This is fine and you're holding up to run normally. Suddenly its in front of you and you have to be holding down or you just killed yourself. 5 seconds later you need to be holding left or right. Its seriously infuriating as it will kill you if you don't know the camera change is coming and what direction to hold.
- Controls are janky and tank like. You'll stick to things a lot. The run button is same as vault so sometimes you try and run and they'll just vault over random things, sometimes even in reverse over a table you were trying to run past.

Honestly, while i like the game it honestly made both my friend and I very frustrated regularly due to us dying from camera changes.

Only half-way through Leon's campaign.  Apparently one of four campaigns.  I've been on a Resident Evil sojourn having just completed every prior game.

Prior to playing I was looking forward to writing my 8th straight positive Resident Evil review and calling out the obsessive naysayers for who they are and for being stuck in some Resident Evil template.  I can't do it.  They were right and on multiple fronts.  They deserve your respect.

The story so far is within the bounds of Resident Evil stories and like many of the previous games the story evolves so slowly.  The Resident Evil moniker or any semblance ends there.

The environments are the only redeeming value and the game looks AAA but it's a cluster f**k and I don't use that term lightly.   Horrendous controls to start, ridiculous game mechanics, amateur GUI design, QTE hell and monster closets galore making the game more like Rebellion's Zombie Army series.  

Again, apparently FOV was not a thing in 2013 having to be fixed by community utilities such as Flawless Widescreen saving us from arrogant game designers who adamantly refuse to provide choice and treat consumers as atomic lemmings.  

I approached ready to forgive any Resident Evil transgressions however I just can't do it anymore.   Yes, I've read the game has a boat load of content.  Four campaigns to sail away on.  To immerse yourself in Zombie blood and saliva.  To vomit on the cadaverous odors of the undead.  To experience the tension of what may lurk around the corner.  To see what the creative Capcom minds have unleashed upon unsuspecting players.  No, it wasn't to be.   

Perhaps I'll continue playing just for the story or perhaps not.  Junk doesn't deserve to be experienced, it deserves to be thrown out.  Purgamentum!

Resident Evil 6 is an excellent game marred by a terrible first impression.

The combat system is genuinely deep, with a firearm-melee combination that flows well together once you get used to it. It's a solid evolution of 4 and 5's, as melee can be used anytime instead of exclusively through contextual button prompts. And there are lots of different kill animations depending on the character, the weapon equipped, the type of attack, and the location of the enemy.

The problem is that the game is very light on tutorials and doesn't teach you about the mechanics much at all. I think the idea was that players could discover the combat system for themselves, but what ends up happening is first-timers just get knocked down a hundred times (quite literally because of the new stagger system) before anything seems to click. And even the inventory interface takes some getting used to.

But once it clicks, it's beautiful. I'm glad I stayed with it til the end. Even now, I'm still mastering the counter system, which I discovered by accident only after I completed the story.

Look guys, I'm gonna be honest with you.  This game looks 2013 great and plays 2013 well.  But it has horrible pacing, endless bullet sponge enemies, 2 dimensional characters (any character that had any personality before has had it sucked out of them), and if you don't have a friend to play it with... it will suck.  

The campaigns are awful.  If you liked any of the characters previously, you'll find that they're all hollowed out Hollywood action heroes now.  Even with a friend, I struggled to enjoy this game and I'm glad I never have to play this ever again.

As my buddy and I discussed during our playthrough, this game was made at a time when Capcom leaned WAYYY too hard into Hollywood-ing their stories. Ada's campaign is hilariously awful. All the campaigns are awful. Story-wise. They play fine, but they feel like a chore. Bullet sponge after bullet sponge after bullet sponge. The story makes little sense, and that comes from two long-time RE fans. Do yourself a favor, never speak of this RE game and go straight from a co-op playthrough of RE5 to RE7. Or better yet, go play the Winters' Expansion on RE8. That's where I'm headed. Peace.
Juice

This game made me feel dumber after playing it.  I have to say, to each their own if you like this game but there are fundamentally too many things holding it back for it to be enjoyable.

The camera is an absolute mess.  You'd think that'd be standard for the RE games, but the camera in this game shakes and moves around so much I was legitimately getting sick.

The weapons feel even more limp than RE5.  RE5's weapons were pretty limp in terms of feel, but RE6 takes it to a whole new level.  The skill system basically removes the weapon upgrades from 4 and 5 and makes it so that it lets you *think* there are multiple playstyles.  There aren't.  The game was designed in a way that's so...7th gen.

There's tons of quick time events, tons of walking segments, tons of interruptions, and the gameplay that is there is so unsatisfying outside of a few melee quick kills.

Let's go over the campaigns real quick:

Leon's campaign: If this campaign is supposed to be the best this game has to offer, then I genuinely feel bad for the people defending this game.  Even the Evil Within 1 is more scary, more balanced, smarter, and more fun than Leon's campaign.  This is supposed to be the horror chapter.
Chris's campaign: This is the real reason I played this game.  I wanted to know why he's the way he is in RE7 and 8.  To my lack of surprise, it's never explained.  His campaign is bloated, boring, and very "Gears of War"-lite.  It has the worst final boss of the bunch too.
Jake's campaign: This legitimately should have been a different game.  Jake would also work better if he wasn't a resident evil character and his whole "twist" was predictable since he teams up with barely lega-I mean Sherry.  This is basically the melee part and at times it works fine, but it's wrapped up with enemies that aren't designed very well, don't have interesting or cool designs, boring levels, and and awful QTE's/driving segments.
Ada's campaign: By this point, I was done.  She's the stealth character.  This pales in comparison to the RE4 chapter.  Again, it's bloated and boring.  The "twist" is again predictable.  It's also poorly explained.

I can't with this game.  I gave it a chance in the end after 10 years since it came out.  I figured I might have a different view on it.  Nope.  Not even close.  It's not even fun with Co-Op.  If you want a fun co-op game, there's tons of other options out there.

For every stage that makes me think "wow they really captured the Resident Evil feel with this one!" there's 10 that are light gun level generic zombie shooters, "wait for a door to open while you shoot zombies", if I wanted to play Left 4 Dead, I would have played that. If this game didn't have co-op it would have 0 redeeming qualities. At least playing this bullshit with a friend will give you someone to poke fun at it with. This very well could have killed the entire franchise, so thankful for the reboot with Resi 7/8. I've played every single Resident Evil game in the past 1.5 years for the first time, this is absolutely by far the worst. Resi 5 was like a 6/10 but this is like a 2/10.

And a lot more. A 3/10 game. My only advice is DO NOT BUY THIS.

Resident Evil 6, also known as Biohazard 6, is a survival horror game developed and published by Capcom. The game was released in 2012 for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and PC. It is the ninth main installment in the Resident Evil series, and the sixth to feature a cooperative campaign mode.

The game's story is set in 2013, ten years after the events of Resident Evil 5. The world is facing a new threat in the form of the C-virus, a highly infectious virus that has the ability to mutate its host into powerful monsters. The game follows four different campaigns, each featuring their own protagonists and storylines. The campaigns are:

 1. Leon's Campaign: This campaign follows Leon S. Kennedy, the former Raccoon City police officer who was one of the protagonists of the original Resident Evil game. Leon is now a government agent tasked with investigating a terrorist attack in Tall Oaks, a city in the United States. Along the way, he teams up with Helena Harper, a secret service agent who was with the President when the attack occurred.

 2. Chris' Campaign: This campaign follows Chris Redfield, the former member of the Special Tactics And Rescue Service (S.T.A.R.S.) who was one of the protagonists of the original Resident Evil game. Chris is now a member of the BSAA (Bioterrorism Security Assessment Alliance), a global organization that fights bioterrorism. He is sent to Lanshiang, a city in China, to investigate a bioterrorism incident. Along the way, he teams up with Piers Nivans, a BSAA agent who has experience dealing with bioterrorism.

 3. Jake's Campaign: This campaign follows Jake Muller, a mercenary who is revealed to be the son of Albert Wesker, the primary antagonist of the Resident Evil series. Jake is initially reluctant to get involved in the situation, but is eventually convinced by his partner Sherry Birkin, the daughter of two key Umbrella Corporation researchers, to help her find a cure for the C-virus.

 4. Ada's Campaign: This campaign follows Ada Wong, a mysterious and enigmatic spy who has appeared in several previous Resident Evil games. Ada's campaign is a separate story that intersects with the other campaigns at certain points.

Resident Evil 6 received mixed reviews upon release. Critics praised the game's graphics, voice acting, and variety of gameplay, but criticized its lack of focus, convoluted story, and poor AI. The game was a commercial success, selling over 7 million copies worldwide.

In terms of gameplay, Resident Evil 6 introduces several new elements to the series. The game features a new health system, in which players can no longer heal themselves with herbs, but must instead find health packs scattered throughout the environment. Players can also now move and shoot at the same time, allowing for more fluid combat. The game also introduces the "Partner" system, in which players can team up with an AI partner or another player to tackle the game's challenges together.

One of the key features of Resident Evil 6 is its four campaign modes, each with its own unique protagonist and storyline. The game's story is told through a mixture of cutscenes and in-game dialogue, and features a large cast of characters. The campaigns are interconnected, with events in one campaign often affecting events in the others.

The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed character models and environments. The game's voice acting is also top-notch, with well-known actors like Kevin Dorman and Courtenay Taylor lending their voices to the game's characters.

Overall, Resident Evil 6 is a solid entry in the long-running

After more than 21 hours playing this and just loosing every last bit of patience I had for it in the Ada campaign, I just gotta go and say it: this game f***** sucks. Oh man, where to begin uh? I knew Capcom had a fallout around this time and the RE franchise was one of its victims. If the franchise jumped the shark with its fifth entry then it completely touched rock bottom with this one. The game is full on 2010's action, and while its not true that it doesn't have horror elements, much more than 5 actually, its more of the first than the latter. The best way to talk about the plot is to analyze each campaing on its own, as Capcom tried to appeal to everybody while not appealing to anybody at all and, at the same time, further alienating their fanbase, but first, the gameplay.

Oh man, the gameplay. This continues with the co-op mechanics of the previous one. Make no mistake, this is a co-op online type game they tried to create here, and to a certain extent, they succeeded, but gone are the old isolated and terryfying atmospheres that made the originals, so if you are looking for that then you are gonna hate this more than I did. Luckily, they changed the controls in order to suit better for this type of game, you can move the camera around freely, the ridiculous meelee attacks are back, and you can even walk while aiming or firing, all of which changes the dynamic of the game itself. BUT, they locked on the camera while running, which is annoying and plain idiotic for all the quicktime events going on. Did I mention those? Yes, this game has so many quicktime events that it should be renamed "RE Interactive Movie" and by god I hate any kind of game interrupting when I'm playing. But that's not all, not only the running sections are awful, but every interaction you have with the enviroment is designed to annoy you at best. Your character will trip by just walking over a corpse, hell, Leon will trip into an open grave in Chapter 3 (I think) if you do so much as to go near it. Every single god damn enemy launches at you and triggers some sort of stupid event that just plain interrupts your movement to punch some damn combination with the pad, even bullets will make you fall down on your back. Speaking of which, this is an action game, so you are bound to spend your time shooting but the game is really stingy with the ammo. For some reason, the developers though it was a good idea to keep the low ammunition mechanic from previous games, unfortunately, you need the damn thing to make your way in it, so I ended up most of the time running around boss fights non the less, leaving the AI alone to do the job while I might hit it with the knife once or twice for 30 f***** min. And I know this is probably for the co-op mechanic, but if I'm going solo, give me the damn bullets. Most of the time all your going to find in the crates are those stupid points for the stupid points system, don't even get me started on that. Did I said previously that the controls were ok? Well, I'm sorry to contradict myself but, goddamn, some things make absolutely no sense. The developers decided unexplicably to have two different "action buttons" (perhaps to enhance the QTE), so now you have one to reload and pick items up, and one for running and every other interaction, and that's a problem: if you try to sprint and your character is close to anything that can be interacted with (stairs, crate, table, whatever) you're gonna have a seisure. 600 people participated in the development! How can you f*** something so simple as that so badly?! I have tons of other complaits like the terrible cover system, the changing HUDS, the melee attacks only working whenever they feel like, the items selection screen, the fact that there's NO WAY TO PAUSE THE GAME, not even in single player, the un-remapable controls or the fact that you have to scroll up and down for your weapons inventory, which gets really impossible when you are in a tight situation. F*** I even experienced times when an unconveniently placed cutscene left me completely exposed to enemies attacks and died; I could go on and on but this will never finish. On to the story:

LEON: Ok this episode literally starts with a bang and never stops from there, both characters survive such a ridiculous array of things (bus crashing, helicopter crashing, freaking PLANE CRASH LANDING IN CHINA) that you are gonna be asking to yourself "who wrote this?" more times than necessary. It's RE: Left For Dead because that's exactly how it feels. Leon is as dumb as he'll ever be, constantly approaching danger as if he was a complete rookie, we also take control of Helena or whoever she is, I don't care, she's just a dumb mix of Hollywood clichés. The story is filled with lame one liners and the zombies just lounge at you like kamikazes, which of course, triggers an automatic QTE. If you are quick enough you can dodge them, but other wise it takes like a full damn clip of your gun to stop them. The final boss comes back 5 times, I'm not even kidding, you are gonna be begging to please stop for all the wrong reasons.

CHRIS: Or Call of Duty: Resident Evil, because if Activision was taking a part in the whole zombie deal why not do it opposite also right? This one gotta be the worst in gameplay terms. Chris is now a terribly cliched alcoholic who comes back to his military job for one last mission, after which, of course, we get our obligatory flashback in Estonia or some made up Eastern Europe country (cause the Middle East was unavailable I guess) with full on bio-terrorism plotline ala RE 5. He's teamed up with generic McGuffin' who only seems to talk in full military man macho hollywood lines, although pretty much every male characters seems to be doing some sort of wang measuring when they talk to each other, that's the quality of the dialogue here. I definitively did  not enjoy this. Specially the end with that camera switching running sequence, did I mention the camera locks when you sprint? Well, imagine trying to control that while the angle keeps changing while trying to run away from a gigantic beast (which like many enemies in the game, don't feel like they belong).

JAKE: I admit I did enjoy this one a little better, but it might as well been because I already was tired (the game is overstuffed to the max). This time we take control of Wesker's Son and the girl from RE 2, who now grew to become an obnoxiuos Wolverine like superhero (really). She is a crybaby and he is the typical sarcastic unimaginative antihero, both victims of poor writing, but I did like the chemistry between them if it's worth anything. They are hounded by this absurd "Wrong Turn" like beast who never dies no matter what you do. The final confrontation takes place in a lava filled facility, which only confirms the fact that even at that time, Capcom still had no idea how lava works. He falls into it, yet manages to come back, W-T-F?!?!?!? Even worse, Jake takes him on barehanded... Yeah people, the boulder punching was only the beginning (Chris even stops a full steel door with his arms at one point...)

ADA: Or RE: Arkham Asylum. And you can already see the problem here. THIS IS NOT A STEALTH GAME. So yeah, I got so fed up with this one after being cornered by a bunch of armored zombies with nothing but a damn crossbow, that I just decided to call it quits. This is as far as I go. I am simply not enjoying it.

So yeah, it does has some decent gameplay in between, specially if you play it co-op, but RE 6 is a crummy overbloated badly designed game, not just for the franchise but as a standalone product as well. If it's worth anything, the game does have it's moments of joy, but they are scarce as you are going to be constantly cussing, cursing and screaming to the wind when you get interrupted by its terrible mechanics. All I can say after venting this out is: THANK GOD CAPCOM WENT BACK TO ITS ROOTS AFTER THIS, AND THAT THIS GENERATION OF GAMING IS FINALLY OVER.

The large amount of quicktime events, combined with the worst camera design I've ever seen make this a game you should avoid.

They give enemies guns, and give the player an unusable cover mechanic. Enemies can chain attacks, and there is no soft timer to displace the frequency. So you'll get thrown to the ground from their gunfire, while other enemies pile on, all chaining hits.Gunfire is also not telegraphed, it simply happens. Poor visual design means you are meant to simply be shot from across the room with no way to react until you spot the enemy.

The game is divided into four separately told stories, with Leon's campaign the best of the bunch. Unfortunately, it is nowhere near enough to redeem this game, as all other campaigns will have you screaming obscenities at the failed direction the lead designer championed.

The shining beacon, if nothing else, is the inclusion of The Mercenaries Mode. This time, with an additional "No Mercy" option. Things get wild with a friend, so if you enjoyed Mercenaries in RE4 and RE5, it still is a lot of fun and you'll no doubt get many hours out of playing it here.

[h1] Resident Evil 6, Most Misunderstood Game of the Last Decade? [/h1]

Even if the game has a lot of positive reviews on Steam, it's still one of the most controversial games in the franchise to date, fans & fellow gamers carry a resentful statements when it comes to Resident Evil 6, most of it unjustly so. The complaints regarding the game are primarily centered around the fact that RE6 is a complete betrayal of everything the franchise stood for, which couldn't be farther than the truth. Resident Evil 6 is a love letter to the previous installments with nice little homages and a peak point to getting to see all our beloved characters and adventures we've had the joy experiencing. Yes it's over the top ridiculous, yes it's campy, but that's the nature of Resident Evil, since the Golden Age of Gaming with the PSX and the technological limitations it offered that spawned the Resident Evil games the masses seem to love, were indeed always revolved around muscular meathead mercenaries & tomboy badass females obviously inspired from 80s action movies infused with B-tier horror & sci-fi which created an aesthetic so unique and created an entire universe of its own that was so iconic to spawn countless movies, animations & other miscellaneous works expanding upon it even further. 

Furthermore, do not listen to supposed "fans" discouraging you from checking out Resident Evil 6, it is perhaps one of the most unique co-op experiences you can witness, and even solo, it is a ton of fun, especially having to play around with the unique combat that infuses action & brawler style of gameplay with survival horror third person shooter, which supposedly was formed by the development team responsible for many Clover & Platinium title action games, it all makes perfect sense, get it now, you won't regret it.

Contrary to what fans feel and believe about RE6, IT IS NOT A TERRIBLE GAME. It never was or even close and it's at least scarier than RE5, BAR NONE. But it could've been better in the horror department. I do appreciate the improvements and additions to the controls/movement that lifts the old restrictions of freezing in place when aiming down sights but I miss the old inventory setup which is replaced with live menu pausing that can put you on your toes when enemies are present so do wait until you have a quiet moment to access your inventory. The visuals as well as voice acting are expertly well done. However I do agree with the criticism of the plot being a bit too all over the place as well as being over the top in ridiculous action set pieces that even puts Michael Bay movies on notice. I also like the fact of this game offers diverse range of content and campaign structure/play with up to 7 characters (4 campaigns, 3 with 2 characters while Ada is solo) with alternative plot pathways which is at least consistent when tied together. I'll give it that unlike Sega who keeps stupidly and inconsistently change directions + tones as well as retconning itself every 1-2 installments with Sonic games.

Anyway, I would give this overhated game a fair shot with 8/10 rating since it's clearly a step up from RE5 until RE7 finally goes full horror like the fans wanted. It has plenty of content to enjoy for over 12-20+ hours with vastly improved controls/mechanics, it does have its scary moments (like Ada's opening mission which excellently creeps me out at the start), excellent enemy design as well as engaging boss fights with optional co-op which BTW, THANK GOD the co-op AI partner isn't a complete DUMBASS like Sheva from the previous game so you have nothing to worry about when playing RE6 alone. Unless you go for the highest difficulty settings which I have to say GOOD LUCK.

When this game released, it was polarizing to a lot of people.

A group of people wanted Resident Evil to go back to the puzzle aspect it originally was, in the same vein as Resident Evil 1, 2, and 3.

Another group wanted it to be more action oriented, blazing through the trail that Resident Evil 4, and 5.

Then there was the new group of people whose first experience with the juggernaut franchise was this particular entry.

In a vacuum, RE6 is balls to the wall action, making you feel like you're in a typical Hollywood blockbuster film, filled with explosions, guns, charming if a bit corny dialogue at times, and witty one-liners that only Leon Kennedy can serve up and make you smile. This is the biggest the RE series has gone in terms of scope, both in story and gameplay. 

Gameplay is more responsive than ever before. No longer are you burdened by the tank controls. You can now run, shoot, dash, slide, melee, roll, take cover, and kick ass while doing it. The counter system is one of the most satisfying mechanics ever introduced into the series and mastering it makes you feel like one of the most badass people out there in the world. You've got turret segments, driving sequences, classic RE puzzles, QTEs, it's like a mish-mash of past and then-present gaming trends all blended together to make an action game that others should be compared to.

Story-wise, it's classic RE-schlock and if you haven't checked out by RE5, then RE6 should be a no brainer for you. But much like majority of the franchise, the devil is in the details. Playing through the game lets you get a cursory glance at the plot: a bioterrorist attack that results in zombies, orchestrated by a maniacal villain. But in reality, it's shockingly more fleshed out than the game presents itself to be. It's all in the files, which is a shame because it's a collectible that majority of the people would miss and not bother to collect except for the most diehard of fans.

When I first played this game way back in 2013 on my Xbox 360, I was admittedly confused at what in the world was going on, much like majority of the people that played it. I could follow along, but I could never understand why some characters did what they did, and what happened in between the moments of transition. Only through reading the files did I actually get the whole picture.

RE6's story is surprisingly well though out, though that is my opinion and others may disagree. If anything, the only thing I'm genuinely disappointed about is how some of the interesting developments presented in this mainline entry (Jake being who he is and what he's doing after, Sherry being present, Leon at the aftermath of it all, Ada's next gig) aren't really touched upon in RE7. The only "mainline character" we've seen thus far after RE6's outing is Chris. Hopefully Capcom revisits these interesting characters in a future entry--possible RE9 as of this review's writing.

All in all, Resident Evil 6 is a masterclass on how to make an amazing, responsive, and satisfying action game that was unfortunately marred with the baggage of its extensive franchise history. It had the unfortunate burden of satisfying different demographics that wanted vastly different things from it, 

Some would say it failed to satisfy any of those groups of people. I would have said the same thing. But looking back it now, I think it was alright. It's one of my favorite games in the franchise's every evolving history. No other game comes as close to the action that was presented here in RE6, and it really is a shame that no one else had tried since.

Against popular opinion, I enjoyed this more than I probably should have.... as long as you are not expecting a proper Resident Evil game, and it's much better than RE5. The graphics must have been amazing back in the day and they convey the ludicrous action set pieces very well. Turn off your brain and appreciate some more boulder punching fun with Chris Redfield prior to his appearance in RE7.

RE 6 marks the point when Capcom jumped the shark with the series. While 5 gave us a satisfying co-op mode for the first time, many longtime fans were disappointed with the faster, action arcade-style play. If RE 5 exchanged some of the survival horror elements for pace and action, then RE 6 completely discarded what was left and got very little of value in return. What we got was a direct to DVD playable action movie with all the campy tropes, frustrating controls, and way too many staged sequences.

Probably the most frustrating part for me was unintended actions like mantling up or jumping down a ledge while otherwise running in a straight line. The controls simply don't feel very intuitive. There may have been a few fun fights, but after completing the game on Professional, I can say I won't have the desire to revisit this one.

A good game that I thought was very fun at times, and other times felt it was repeating things. I liked getting back to killing zombies, at least in leon and ada's campaign because it was terrifying and reminded me of the first resident evil games. I really don't even know where to begin. 

Inventory system is garbage and limited, even more limited than your regular systems throughout the other games. There isn't any open inventory, just a bar you scroll through to see ammo and two nearly useless items (incendiary grenade and remote explosive), hardly do anything for you aside from conserving a little ammo, which you'll end up using anyways because rarely do these items actually kill. 

Guns aren't fun anymore. You can't find attachments and upgrades for your weapons in this game, you just find weapons that you need ammo for and that's it. In literally every other game you can get upgrades which do more, expand capacity, fire rate, reload speed, firepower, etc etc. This game just throws weapons at you and hopes the RNG drops you a little bit of ammo for them. 

Story is mediocre and jank. Extremely forgettable and doesn't make hardly any sense. Honestly I wouldn't even canonize this with any other game, the C-Virus doesn't have any depth, there isn't any mention of what researchers did in the creation, just a shitty cutscene in Leon's story, and all you know is "Neo-Umbrella made this." That's literally it. Sure there are some good sections in the cutscenes that make you feel kinda warm. "Hey, this is pretty dope, it's not all bad." and then you get right back into the gameplay that makes you wanna bash your head in between a car door. 

I'd go more into depth, but I just don't feel like it. Bought this with the halloween RE sale, and figured I'd play through it again because I was bored. I'm 6 hours in, finished Leon's campaign, no thanks. I'm sick of the jank controls, garbage story and dialogue, and dogshit "inventory management." 

Just go buy RE2/3 Remastered, or honestly the older games. They're so much better. Camera angles in the older games kinda blow at times but not NEARLY as bad as this game. Plus the controls aren't as bad. You get used to them as you play more. This is just a disgrace of a game and to the RE franchise. Ngl either, I feel like the graphics in RE5 is actually better than in RE6. This was just a cashgrab throwaway the company decided to throw out there back then since everyone wanted another RE game, since RE5 did so well.

People hate on this game a lot, and I get why it's very hit or miss but in my opinion the game is underrated, I get it it's annoying at times, the controls are a bit difficult to adapt to, but the story itself? it's silly and weird at times, but if it got a remake I genuinely think it could be one of the best duo games of all time, if the story took itself more seriously, had better polishing and more of a focus, had more goals and ideas, had a better set-up it would be a masterpiece. As it stands right now I'd rate the game as a 7.5/8.2 but it gets way more hate then it deserves. It's an action packed joke that can't even decide which is which with the story but I still can't hate it, it has a charm and feeling that I love especially in duos, I hate seeing people act like this is one of the worst games ever because it's really not. It needs Love and it needs to be changed but it is not horrible. If capcom remakes this and remakes it well I genuinely believe it will be up there with the best duos games.

I really don't understand why this game always gets so much hate? I frickin' love it!
It has very cool, old school zombie horror story, it has a lot of action, great characters - it's just super fun and interesting. It has 4 different stories, and although third and fourth are a bit short, this game is actually 4 games in one - I mean, come on! How can you not love it? Even the graphics are pretty OK considering it's a bit older game. Only bad thing is that controls are a bit overwhelming from time to time. There is a specific point in the game where you die like 10 times before you manage to finish that stupid part, but if you are patient - it's bearable.
So, each of 4 stories has different set of two characters, but they are all following the same plot, although from different points of view and timelines. Each story has something new to add to unravel the plot and resolve a mystery from previous story. It's such a cool and fresh twist to already seen zombie scenario. My favourites are Leon and Helena, and Jake and Sherry stories. 
You can also play this game alone or with a partner, and although I love playing alone - if you have friends who love RE franchise - team up with them, it's like 1000 times more fun. I played it with my husband who is not the greatest fan of this type of games and he loved it, and we had a lot of fun. We will definitely play it again. 
Way to go Capcom!

I heard this is the worst RE game, and I thought people had to be exaggerating because 5 was so bad. I'm not sure if it's worse than 5, but it's definitely bad. Whoever designed the mechanics in this game deserves to step on a lego. The controls are ridiculous and half of them don't work most of the time. The movement is so janky that if you're slightly off you have to run around in circles to get to the right spot to get the prompt for an interaction. The shooting part isn't bad at all. Inventory system is horrible, no room for anything, and a huge pain to navigate. The buttons make absolutely no sense, and while I understand that it's due to it being a port, if you're going to port a game at least make the controls make even a little sense. 
If you get grabbed by an enemy, there's no cooldown, you'll just keep getting grabbed over and over and over if there's anything else nearby. Sometimes you'll get grabbed by something far away enough that it shouldn't be able to get to you. 
The quick time events are messy, and some of them have no explanation so you're screwed until you mash buttons and get it figured out (the plane).

Not the most positive of the series, and definitely wasn't a huge player pleaser. It is on sale quite frequently for $5-10, and it is well worth it if you like RE games.

But the game is quite fun, with 3 separate campaigns that all intersect through the story, until the finale puts them all together.

Leon's campaign is a bit more survival horror
Chris' campaign is more like RE5, its action and shooty.
Sherry's campaign is like a cat and mouse game with a stalker enemy, and filled with puzzles.

There is also a Mercenaries mode, with plenty of character and costumes to pick from.

This game is easily a good 30 hours or more if you are a completionist.

So much more fun playing co-op.

They game also does what most other RE games didn't and that is really blending gunplay and melee play. You can do some real damage with melee counter attacks, you can pick up melee weapons to bash people with, use the environment to execute people, etc.

Only annoying thing is quick time events, but that a minor inconvenience.

9/10

Resident Evil Marmite edition. 
(For my non-British folk, people either love or hate marmite) 

The reason the game is both loved and hated leans on how you play the game and what you are looking for with a resident evil game. Most of the game falls into being more of a Third Person Action Game rather than a puzzley survival horror. .

What also makes a difference is the campaigns that you play. All the campaigns range from around 4-6 hours and all can be played with a friend or an AI if you hate people.  The campaigns also all intertwine so you'll play some areas a couple of times if you play through each campaign. 

In order from best to worst 

Leon's campaign - This campaign feels more like classic RE. You have more urban settings, a gothic church and a whole lot of zombies. There's some puzzle elements, some big mutated creatures including a literal T-Rex. Overall this campaign feels right. 

Jakes Campaign - This campaign features a new character whom is resistent to the C virus (One day we'll run out of letters) and Sherry from RE2. You travel the world dealing with a good mix of enemies from the other campaigns. Whilst a little disjointed at times, this campaign doesn't feel too out of place and there are some really fun areas and set pieces. 

Adas Campaign - This one should be played last as it generally ties everything together from the other campaigns with a kind of behind the scenes sort of story. This campaign is similar to Jakes in that you get a nice variety but the transitions between each chapter feel quite jarring as Ada just pops up wherever the story needs to be. You also get a lovely co-op partner in this that is incapable of doing anything outside of shooting. For some reason this hasn't been patched or changed so playing this one co-op is a bit lacklustre. 

Chris' campaign - You play as Chris the boulder punching machine as you take down mutant humanoid enemies for practically all of the story. This feels way more actiony and is the least fitting of the game. It's more like Gears of War than anything. This campaign feels like a slog overall. Definitely the least fun for me personally. 
 
Something worth noting is that the movement in this game is actually top notch and makes for some really fun gameplay. You can counter melee attacks, slider, roll and have a lot of manoeuvrability compared to other games in the franchise. The moment to moment gameplay is solid and there's plenty of enemy variety to take this into account. In fact the game overall has quite a bit of content from four campaigns to secrets hidden within the levels to levelling up skills and gunning for the highest ranks. There's a lot of replay value if completionism is your thing. 

Overall the game runs well, co-op works well (Aside from Ada's useless no nmed co-op buddy) and there's a lot of stuff to like here. It's wacky and it's tacky but if you're looking for a competent horror co-op shooter, RE6 is actually quite fun despite it being a bit of a mess.

I never played this game when it originally came out. I heard from friends how much of a departure this game was from the series. So I passed it by. I love the Resident Evil games so much.  I replay RE1 easily once a year.  So when when RE4 Remake was announced I decided that I would replay the entire series 0-8 in order.  I was excited to play RE6  when I got to it since I never played it and I was thinking "It can't be that bad..." I was sorely wrong.  It's absolutely terrible.  I would call it trash but that would a disservice to actual garbage.  This game can't decide what it wants to be.  It has so many gameplay elements that it can't even be good at one of them.  Its a driving game, it's survival horror game, its a gears style game, and its a stealth game.  Thank the lord this all got corrected in RE7.  This game is an absolute blight on the series and needs to be forgotten.  Too many times I was needlessly killed because the game doesn't tell you where to go during a timed sequence, or a driving sequence when the camera pushes to the front or side of the vehicle and you can't see whats in front of you.   

I hoped the story would have made up for the atrocious gameplay, nope! The story is so forgettable and its spread over the course of 4 full length campaigns that all interweave over the course of a 6 month period.  So by the time you finish one campaign and move to the next you've forgotten crossovers cause it happened hours ago in gameplay time. Or it makes you play the entire sequence all over again as different characters. You know whats not fun?  Playing an hour plus long fight twice.

While RE5 was a bit of a departure adding RE4's style of gameplay with more action but at least it was fun.  This game is not fun.  I installed mods just so i could say I finished it and I couldn't even do that with mods.  I got to the final campaign and finally said "F this! It's not worth it." There isn't a single story element that plays into 7 or 8 so why bother. It's painfully frustrating to play. Do yourself a favor and scrub your brain with a rusty SOS pad instead of playing whatever the hell this is.

EPIC!

I'll preface this review by saying I didn't play mercenaries and I played all four campaigns in co-op with a friend of mine. I'll review each campaign individually since my thoughts vary wildly on each one. 

Leon's Campaign: Leon probably has the best campaign in my opinion (which isn't saying much). In Leon's campaign, you and secret service agent Helena Harper go on a journey to expose national security advisor Derek Simmons for his role in the assassination of the U.S. president. The story and writing in general isn't very good in this campaign (just like with most of the campaigns) but in terms of positives this campaign actually has a few. The opening outbreak in Tall Oaks is very reminiscent of Resident Evil 2/3 and the outbreak in Raccoon city, which was really cool to see back in 2012 when this game first came out. However, we now have modern, much better done, versions of said outbreak in the form of Resident Evil 2 and 3 Remake. The zombies, while not as fun to fight as the zombies in re2/3r, are definitely the best enemies to fight in this game, if only for the reason you don't have to worry about them shooting you mid-melee animation. This campaign also didn't have any terrible vehicle sections to pad out time. The set pieces in this campaign didn't feel as ridiculous as the set pieces in the other campaigns either. Finally, this campaign is definitely the most polished. In terms of things that drag this campaign down, the boss fights are pretty bad for the most part, the UI and inventory system in general is the worst in the series (you can't even give your partner items which is really strange since you could in re5). The quick time events are really in your face and annoying, even compared to re5 and especially compared to re4. Overall, I'd probably give this campaign a 6/10 as it wasn't horrible but there isn't really a reason to play it now. If you want to play a modern resident evil with zombies, just play resident evil 2 remake or even resident evil 3 remake. 

Chris' Campaign: When it comes to positives, the only one I can really think of is the writing in this campaign is slightly better than the others. In this campaign, Chris is working for the BSAA (once again) with his partner Piers Nivans trying to stop bioterriorst operations in Edonia and later China. While in Edonia, Chris' entire team is killed by "Ada Wong" and he gets PTSD and tries to drink his feelings away. Piers picks Chris up in a bar and convinces him to come back to the BSAA to help stop a bioterrorist group known as Neo-Umbrella from completely destroying a Chinese city (which later turns out to be a world ending threat). It is also revealed that "Ada Wong" is in charge of said group and Chris has to overcome his need for revenge in order to save the world. Overall, the story of this campaign wasn't great, but it was a lot better than the stories in the other campaigns. The story is also a lot better than the gameplay. Chris' campaign is basically that last 45 minutes of re5 stretched over 6.5 hours. It's basically a glorified cover shooter where you fight j'avo (some of the least fun enemies to fight in any resident evil game) in a bunch of poorly designed arenas for most of the game. Unlike the zombies, j'avo have guns so you'll often be shot down before you can even run up and punch the ever-living shit out of them. Chris' campaign also has one of the worst driving and flying sequence I've ever had the misfortune of playing. Overall, I'd give Chris' campaign a 4/10.

Jake's Campaign: In Jake's campaign, you basically run around and punch j'avo with a really shitty combo system. His story is that he's a Mercenary fighting in Edonia, but for some reason, he's unaffected by the C-virus (the virus that turns people in j'avo). Sherry Birkin shows up and basically says he's the key to making a vaccine for the virus and he needs to come with her. While trying to get out of Edonia, they encounter Ustanak, a tyrant like monster whose goal is to capture Jake for Neo-Umbrella. They end up getting captured by neo-umbrella and sent to China so the rest of the game can happen. The only other thing worth mentioning about Jake is he's apparently the son of Albert Wesker, which feels really stupid and tacked on. In terms of gameplay, this campaign is really bad. The level design, particularly the level where you're escaping the mountain is absolutely atrocious and Jake just isn't fun to play as. Ustanak isn't nearly as memorable as Mr.X or Nemesis and just serves as a quick time event generator for most of this campaign. The vehicle sections in this aren't as bad as Chris' but they're basically on rails and control really poorly. Overall, I'd give this campaign a 3/10.

Ada's Campaign: Finally we get to Ada's campaign. This campaign only really exists to tie up loose ends left over from the other three campaigns and the only positive I can say about it is it's really short, not even three hours long. In terms of polish, it's pretty clear this campaign was basically an afterthought. Ada doesn't even canonically have a co-op partner with her. If you play this campaign in co-op, you play as Ada while the 2nd player gets to play as some generic soldier guy who can't do a damn thing except kill enemies. He can't even open doors or progress through the game really. Just about every single one of Ada's levels is reused from previous campaigns, she has a helicopter flying sequence at the end which is easily the worst vehicle section in the entire game, and this campaign is by far the glitchiest of the four. Overall I'd probably give this campaign a 2/10. 

In conclusion, Re6 isn't nearly as bad as people claimed it was when it launched. This game isn't even as bad as a lot of the later silent hill games. But the I can't help but feel that people who think this game is secretly a masterpiece and always was are just wrong. The amount of bullshit and jank you have to ignore to come to such a conclusion is just way too much in my eyes. This is definitely one of the weakest mainline resident evil games, only beating Re0 and Code Veronica in my eyes. I guess if you're really bored and have nothing else to play you could try this game, for anyone else I'd recommend steering clear.

Resident Evil 6 is not a Resident Evil game. The story travels so far off the tracks that this franchise is hard to save at this point. T-Virus, G-Virus and now the C- Virus, six hundred different kinds of enemies and over the top cut scenes that make the action in the Paul WS Anderson movies look tame. Subplots make little to no sense. Nothing is explained. Villains are just there because the world needs villains. As for gameplay, the co-op element as fine. I'm OK with that existing but why the overuse of cutscenes while your partner opens a door? Or pulls a lever? Is this game trying to compete with Metal Gear Solid IV? Let us play Capcom!  I cannot even recommend this game for the co-op and I definitely would not recommend playing this game solo. Why does the game need to spell out the objective for us? Or where the entrance to the next area is? This is the same developer that gave us Resident Evil, a huge mansion to explore and solve puzzles and this is the best they can do in 2012? Capcom should do us all a favor and reboot the series, start from the ground up because seriously, I couldn't give a shit you're  so desperate to connect the franchise together you feel the need to make Sherry Birkin a playable character.

This is one of the most discussed games in the Resident Evil series and I understand why.
It´s a common fact that this game is the most action-filled main title in the series. But that doesn´t necessarily make it a bad game, as long as the action is fun. Which it is, because it´s ridiculous non-sense you can laugh about. Watching the cutscenes of the game is the same experience as watching the RE movies starring Milla Jovovich. It´s trash, but it´s enjoyable trash. The storylines of the the campaigns are held together by coincidences combined with explosions, crashing helicopters and the extreme mutations of your enemies. 
And while we´re at it, let´s talk about the four campaigns, wich can all be played in co-op.
Each campaign revolves around two heroes, following their own orders and motivations. However, you don´t play four seperate stories, because the storylines of the four campaigns all merge into one. While playing one campaign, you can meet the protagonists of the other campaigns, doing the things you do in their story. This can lead to a bunch of "Oh now I understand"-moments while you puzzle the story of RE VI together. You even have a timeline including all cutscenes from all four campaigns, where you can look up which events happened at the same time or are connected to another. The only downside of this concept is that you sometimes have to do the same battles or boss fights again, but with another character. 
But of course, RE VI has some other problems, too. The savepoints can be very unfriendly, some enemies are very annoying, some death animations are waaayyy to long and some boss fights leave you clueless what you have to do. While the graphics are overall ok, there are points where the game looks like straight from PS1 era, including blurred textures on 2D-houses. Another problem of the game is its action. I know, I´ve said earlier that it´s fun because it´s ridiculous, but sometimes it´s TOO ridiculous, to a point where it destroys immersion and creates plotholes. 
The co-op works very well most of the time, except the last campaign, where the player not hosting the session has to play a nameless agent, who can´t interact with most objects and riddles. So my friend and I decided to play this campaign alone.

Overall, RE VI is a good Resident Evil game to have fun with, and it´s definitely not as bad as its reputation. 
To conclude my review of this game, I once again have to compare it to the Resident Evil movies starring Milla Jovovich. They are fun to watch, but they won´t win an Oscar.

The most grandiose and cinematic RE game out of 4, 5, and 6, with particularly impressive cutscenes and graphics. Unfortunately, the action often amounts to a chaotic, incoherent mess. And with the main characters constantly surviving death-defying scene after death-defying scene, the whole thing loses all semblance of believability, and consequentially, any semblance of horror. The lengthy campaign is divided into 4 separate scenarios, but due to significant overlap between them, much of it feels bloated and repetitive. Fortunately, the bonus Mercenaries mode is fun to play.

The game isn't as bad, as the reviews say it is, I've actually liked Leon's and Ada's campaign, and Sherry's wasn't that bad either (though that one felt more like an action game without enough ammunition, than a survival horror). The part that I did not enjoy  was Chris's campaign, mainly because the chase scenes in that campaign were awful. The problem was the fact, that they - for some reason - did not use the over the shoulder angle with the camera, and tried to make it a bit more movie like, therefore the camera often changed the view angle, sometimes it even spun around, making it quite difficult to control the character as efficiently and swiftly as the game required it (at the end of Chris's campaign, I've died almost 49 times due to the fact that sometimes I could't even see my character in the Haos chase scene). Apparently that chase scene is less difficult if you play with a controller, but it still doesn't quite fit into an AAA game. I would still recommend it though, because apart from the camera angles in the chase scenes, the game, and the story itself is quite enjoyable.
I really do hope that someday they get to this game and rectify it by a remake (granted they would need to scrap most of it), since even though gameplay, and to be honest story wise it is lower mid-range at best, it is the last new mainline Resident Evil game featuring the original characters (Chris does appear in 7 and Village, but it is not the same) for almost 10 years, and it would be a shame if the story of the characters whom fans know and love would and with this game

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I've played through many of the resident evil games (including code veronica) on other platforms and always enjoyed them. They may have always been a bit campy but at least they were enjoyable or scary. In the old games you had to be careful to manage your ammo and healing items since they were very limited and in RE5 you could pretty much just go out guns blazing. RE 6 reminds me very much of RE 5 except over-scripted TO THE EXTREME. The game is drowning in QTE events which like, really Capcom? I thought those went out of fashion in the late aughts? Also, you can't shoot zombies that are obviously going to get up and attack you later UNTIL they get up and attack you which is so incredibly dumb. God forbid the game reward you for taking the initiative to be careful and shoot a zombie corpse that may or may not still be "alive". Also headshots don't seem to do anything, hell you are usually gonna deal more damage by kicking a zombie than shooting it directly in the head. As Leon, I've had regular zombies take 4-5 headshots without dying which is just ridiculous. Once again, it's like the game doesn't want to reward you for playing carefully or precisely. I've seen posts online that say "Oh you just have to level-up your firearm skill or whatever" and it's like lol wut? I should not have to grind skill points just for a headshot on a basic zombie to kill them in 1 or 2 shots. So yeah, unless you love QTE's and games that don't let you do anything until the game says so, then by all means play RE6.

Level design e combate, serio, não da pra nunca ver os inimigos, diferente do re5 que  você sabe onde os inimigos estão e pode se manter alerta e atirar, até nas flechas ou machados q eles jogam, no re6 você nunca sabe onde ta os inimigos, do nada brota um zombie da sombra com um fuzil te da stun e qndo vc levanta acontece a mesma coisa infinitamente, o cenario é confuso e claustrofobico, zombies se camuflam com o ambiente, combate é praticamente pancadaria pura, não da pra usar a arma mais doq 3x por level.

It might not be the most well-received game of the series but it's still a fun co-op shooter at its core. By default, the game comes a load of content: four campaigns, Mercenaries, and PvP--each of which could easily net you a couple hours of enjoyment. Whether you like it or not, this is hands down the most mechanically polished with each character having a fairly large set of melee attacks and weapons in their respective campaigns. There's honestly nothing more satisfying then sliding into an enemy to stagger him, shoot him in the head for a stun, and finishing your combo by throwing him into his friends.

Now lets get into the main content of the game, the campaigns. I would say each of the four range from just okay to pretty good. Leon and Helena have a vaguely classic Resi feel with many of their levels consisting of puzzles, tight corridors, zombies, and dark spaces. Chris and Piers are the military shooter duo packing heavy firepower and easily reaching the highest body count together in the game. Jake and Sherry is very much an action-adventure since a lot of the major set pieces tend to feature a different style of gameplay and location (driving, non-linear exploration, platforming). And Ada, appropriate for the mysterious femme fatale is a stealth-action styled campaign that has her sneaking around behind-the-scenes and subtly helping the other protagonists in various ways.

With a good variety of different flavors, you and your dedicated co-op partner should easily be able to find at least one favorite amongst those four. As long as you keep in mind this is a balls-to-the-wall action game you will get a lot of enjoyment out of it. But if you miss the suspenseful atmosphere and horror of the older titles then it's best you stay away. At the very least, it's a nice way to kick ass as some of our favorite characters of the franchise once more.

RE6 consistently rides the fine line between hilariously janky and just plain painful to play. The entertainment value of the game unintentionally comes from the cooperative struggle to overcome the comically unpolished gameplay, sharing/critiquing the over-the-top cutscenes, and poking fun at the ludicrous plot. This game may be a complete bastardization of the changes, choices, and subtleties that made RE4 so impactful, but damn if RE6 isn't fun to laugh at.

It's worth noting that, whereas RE5 was generally tolerable, RE6 can be truly unbearable at times. Chris's campaign is physically challenging to play and Ada's campaign features clumsily tack-on stealth that doesn’t match the existing gameplay framework or the co-op. So, find someone to join you in the ordeal, have a good chuckle over the Leon campaign, and then jump ship before the tedium of the plot and controls really set in.

A lot of people hate on RE6 because it tries to carry on the cheesy action shooter trope that Capcom was pushing the series in since the success of RE4, some will say "It's not Resident Evil!" because you just run around through 4 guided storylines, except 4, 5, 7 and 8 all follow the same formula.

As a action cover-shooter it's probably one of the best I've played despite the cover system being almost completely pointless. The movement system, CQB and gameplay mechanics all seem alien at first but once you begin to understand them they all perfectly blend together to make the game into a crazy gun-fu simulator, like how the RE: Vendetta movie portrays the series. There's always new tech to learn and you feel like a badass every time you play if you're willing to learn.

The interconnected campaign system is really cool, you can tell they really focused on multiplayer and co-operative play with this entry. There are 4 campaigns and all of them have points where they cross over into the other's campaign. Leon's campaign has large fights where Ada shows up to help him and Helena, if another player is at that section of Ada's campaign at the same time you are they'll actually join into your lobby as Ada temporarily before splitting off again. All of the campaigns seem to overlap story-wise too and there are little tellers to the other campaigns as you play through them. There's a point in Leon's campaign where you take a plane to China, if you look at the TVs on the plane you can see live news feed of an attack in China going on with members of the BSAA fighting them. When you play Chris' campaign you'll actually push aside the guy who was recording that live news feed and experience that fight. There's a couple other points where this happens and if you're a big RE fan you'll love the cross-overs and character reunions, otherwise this system doesn't really work anymore because people are all playing with the feature turned off or more likely you wont be able to find anyone playing at the exact same time as you which sucks because it's a really cool feature that I imagine felt amazing when the game was released.

The game has so much extra-content and honestly most of my hours on the game come from playing through the extra-content. I would go through it all but it's got your standard RE Mercs mode where you have a set limit of enemies and you kill for time and score etc, as well as a handful of other modes that are super fun to play as a group.

HOWEVER, this game does have some pitfalls...
Mainly, I would've liked more DLC that included characters from other RE games, for example RE5 included Rebecca despite her not being in the story. This is just my personal problem I guess because the game does already come with 8 (9 but Carla is just a reskin of Ada) unique characters all with different weapons and take-downs, I just sort of exhausted them and would've liked getting characters like Wesker, Rebecca, Carlos, Jill & HUNK for example.

On the topic of HUNK, Ada's campaign is honestly the worst campaign in the game and Co-Op functionality was clearly implemented last minute, you're better off playing the campaign completely solo because the campaign features Ada and a character added in a free update called "Agent" who serves no purpose other than allowing another player to tag along during Ada's campaign. The worst part about him is that he can't even interact with things and it completely ruins all immersion when Ada grapples somewhere and Agent just pops in out of nowhere because he's not actually supposed to be there. Why didn't they just make HUNK Ada's partner? At this point in the story Umbrella has collapsed and HUNK is supposedly a 'Legendary Merc-for-hire', both of them have had ties with Umbrella and have very notable reputations. Could've done a whole lot more with Ada's campaign instead of making it only about her relationship with Derek Simmons. Would've even allowed for a cool cliche moment where [spoiler] Ada and Carla get into a melee fight and HUNK doesn't know which Ada to shoot [/spoiler] ! Instead it's just about a government official being creepy and stalking Ada because she's hot and destroying most of the world for no real explained reason other than him having an obsession with someone who he's only met in person like twice. Frankly this makes for a terrible villain and highlights how they ran out of ideas on how to continue the story after killing Wesker off. If we had HUNK, the game would've definitely more attractive to a lot of people and we'd have another unique character to play around with in the extra-content.

They've also done the RE Character thing where they introduce these amazing characters only to just make them disappear from existence from every other title in the franchise. Jake Muller, the biological son of Wesker - A pretty big title and name to live up to hasn't been heard from in RE7 or RE8, he just flirts with Sherry and it implies they become close and then he just goes around the world helping people. That's it. Despite him being near superhuman and a carrier of Project W (<- Uncertain but for some reason he has antibodies to the C-Virus so this is the only logical explanation) he just disappears...
Same with his partner Sherry who actually still has the G-Virus in her blood which shows how it allows her to regenerate wounds also disappears throughout RE7 and 8 with no explanation.

Piers Nivans was the Sheva replacement and he was an amazing character, arguably he was a better squadmate for Chris than Jill was in terms of their compatibility and dynamic, Chris being a teacher who fell from grace and Piers being there to pull him back to reality and remember his core values, amazing. Unfortunately Capcom gave us the finger and [spoiler] Killed him as well as gave him an off-screen death [/spoiler] which is such a waste of a great character.

Jill also isn't mentioned at all, she just vanished too.

As someone who's really invested in the lore and story of Resident Evil, for a continuation of the series it adds literally nothing because everything that happens wraps its-self up in the story and writes its-self out. It could've not been made and would've had no effect on the story of RE7 & RE8.

Pitfalls aside, if you're new to Resident Evil I recommend this title as an entry title into the series, it's so dummy simple and entertaining.

TOP 3 FUN THINGS TO DO:
⭐️Playing a wide-range of main characters.
⭐️Using points to upgrade perks.
⭐️Interactive cut-scenes.

THE UNIQUES:
💎Cut-scenes are brilliant!
💎Over the shoulder action.
💎Strong co-op.

PLAYER GAMING REQUIREMENTS:
💼Action.
💼Co-op.
💼Zombies

VERDICT:
After playing this game, I've come to the conclusion that the devs wanted a more action packed game over what they did best, a horror. This started at RE5 and I can't help but feel that they should go back to the original genre, less action and more horrifying scenes! It's also sad to see them remove the item management side.

Now that's out the way, RE6 isn't a terrible game, as much as the die hard fans want it to be. The game play is good and the cut-scenes are brilliant! Theirs plenty to play for, since there's 4 campaigns to choose from, Leon, Chris, Jake and Ada. All of them showing a different side of the whole picture which I think was a great idea. They've stuck with the co-op franchise which is a lot better than the previous RE but I'm more relieved that people are still playing, without you guys, the game would have been a little harder. If you're looking for a story driven game, then look no further because that is the highlight of this game.
Total Score = 83/100.

SIMILAR GAME LIKE THIS? / REVIEWER PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE:
Resident Evil franchise, Days Gone.

GAMEPLAY:
Players control Chris Redfield, Leon S. Kennedy, Jake Muller, and Ada Wong as they confront the force behind a worldwide bio-terrorist attack. The story is centred around their four interwoven campaigns, and every campaign features a unique style in both tone and gameplay.

■■■■■■■■□□ 8 / 10
Item management isn't an issue anymore!

I can’t help but enjoy how idiotic this game is. The unintentional comedic disasters gave me a fright when it happened to me for the first time. 

After chapter 3 in Leon's campaign, I honestly think it's awful. Leon is nearly irrelevant to the plot here. I am pretty sure his obsession was not love but more wanting what he couldn't have. Ada’s involvement in his life has been limited to a single routine and it involves Ada mincing about until Leon shows up, using him, and saving him so she can do it all over again in another game. Love is a strong word, I think she cares about him and doesn’t have romantic feelings for him.

I enjoyed a bit of every single campaign but Chris' is my favorite. Chris’ campaign definitely had the most focus and knew exactly what it wanted to be; an action game with mutant super soldiers. The others had experimental sections, which had me almost yawning. The 'horror' in Leon’s isn't that bad, I guess. However, it does nothing to create tension. Although, Leon’s campaign is the closest to a proper Resident Evil campaign, but it features laughable set pieces that I can’t help but love.

Never knew what it was like to have motion sickness until this game. I've never felt such betrayal from a cast of beloved characters before. What the fuck is this game tho?

I would only recommend this game to people who are huge Resident Evil fans, and even then, it's rough.  When people say it's the worst mainline in the series.  It really is.  The controls and camera are janky, there's a lot of sections where your controls randomly switch and so does you camera and the direction were you go.  The snowmobile section in Jake's campaign is atrocious.  Worst of all.......is if you play co-op (like I am with a friend) then in Chapter 3 of Jake's campaign there is a bug that prevents you from progressing further together because he'll automatically be killed by a tank in a cutscene over and over.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

In certain campaigns the camera is absolutely infuriating, yanking the view away from what you are trying to look at, or locking it into certain angles that make the levels more challenging than they should be.

In all honesty, it's not worth playing, unless you want to experience the entire resident evil series. But of the "crappy trilogy" of 4, 5 and 6, this is the underrated one.

Search behind the back counter for a large diamond ring. This will allow you to propose to my sister Claire. A candle-lit dinner is prepared for you two.
