I'm not even sure where to start with this one... This game has got to be one of the worst pieces of trash I've ever played.

I'll start off with the good:

The sound design and voice acting is fantastic. The sound you hear when the head of an enemy pops is just something else. Similar with the voice acting, all the voice actors did a great job. Unfortunately, that's all the good things I can say about this game.

Now the bad.

The story:

The game is separated into 4 separate campaigns, those being: Leon, Chris, Sherry, and Ada, and in all of these you have a sidekick character with you at all times. The concept that all these campaigns are interconnected and present different perspectives of the overall story is neat, but the execution is atrocious. What really happens is you're forced to replay the same sections as different characters multiple times, for example, instead of giving you to play out two separate ways for separate campaigns, you just repeat the same fights or mechanics in a new campaign as in the previous one. 

Leon's campaign starts off strong and gives you serious classic RE vibes where you're exploring dark cathedrals and empty hallways, however it quickly devolves into a generic action shooter style of game. The stupidity of the characters is insulting. For example, Leon's clearly had a lot of experience with zombies before, yet here, during a cutscene, he will point a gun at the main villain while delivering a spiel of how "we're gonna stop you no matter what", and yet he'll wait for the bastard to fully transform into some eldrich monstrosity instead of, you know, blowing his brains out immediately.

Chris's campaign is just bad. Absolutely thoroughly shit. It doesn't even attempt to resemble something from the RE universe. The whole story is just him running around and shooting everything all the time in a poorly-made Call of Duty-esque fashion. This story can basically be summarized as "Chris makes mistakes because he's an incompetent moron, but somehow he manages to put all the blame on Ada and tries to kill her." This campaign is BY FAR the worst one.

Sherry's campaign is actually quite bearable. The story itself is nothing to write home about, but it's not terrible either. The new character (the sidekick) is actually quite interesting and not entirely cringe, unlike Chris. By the mid point through the campaign, I just couldn't deal with how shit the gameplay was, so I uninstalled this piece of malware and watched the story of the remainder of this and Ada's campaigns on YouTube.

Ada's campaign seems pretty mediocre, too. After the three others, you kinda expect this one to finally tie everything together and explain the motivations of some of the characters, as well as to provide some context to the story, but it barely does any of that.

Now the worst offender of it all, the gameplay:

This game has fuck-all to do with the classic style of RE gameplay. It tries to be a 3rd person action shooter, but it does an incredibly shit job at that. I don't even know where to start with this section.

The movement is pretty bad. Moving over any obstacles requires an interaction with a separate button press. Virtually all enemies use guns, yet the cover mechanics in this game are basically non-existent (you can lean and peek from a wall while your character is standing near a wall, but you can't crouch and hide behind low cover). The camera is inconsistent at best, with the angle being terrible, and the game being riddled with idiotic sections of a fixed camera angle that changes every few seconds.

Enemies don't really respond to being shot. They either stagger slightly or completely ignore being shot entirely. Their AI is completely broken, as sometimes you'll see several enemies just running against an obstacle, or standing next to you, your sidekick, or some other NPC and literally doing nothing.

Speaking of AI, you can play this game with a friend, who controls the sidekick character, or you can play solo with the game's AI controlling them. If you choose to play with the AI, it will choose to either do nothing (as in literally just stand there), or go on a complete murder-rampage. There is no in-between, and unfortunately, 80% of the time, they do nothing. Basically the AI is mentally disabled. You love to see it.

The level design is just crap. Levels are boring and extremely linear. There's no puzzles for you to solve, no documents to find, only some lame collectible emblems.

The game also can't just stick to a single gameplay model. In each campaign, they keep introducing moronic new mechanics that are used once and then never seen again. They keep doing this over, and over, and over again.

The fucking QTEs. God fucking damn idiotic-ass QTEs for every little fucking thing ever. They're not difficult or anything, just pointless and annoying. They do not add anything to the game, just detract from it.

The boss fights are.... I'm really at a lack for words for how bad they are. Aside from the bosses never fucking dying (basically you have a boss fight, you kill the boss, then 5 minutes later SURPRISE!, they're not actually dead, go fight them again! This is usually repeated 5 - 6 times for each boss), there's also fights against goddamn helicopters. And yes, that's a plural "fights", there are at least 4 instances where the boss is a goddamn helicopter. The bosses themselves are just so so soooo shit. Leon gets to fight some big-titty slime spider chick and a grasshopper-ass looking motherfucker, Chris is pinned up against a fetus, Sherry has to deal with a dollar-store knock-off version of Nemesis, and Ada fights a jizz flood. For reference how shit these fights are, in the fetus fight (that's a fuckin' phrase I never thought I'd write), I found that the most efficient strategy to fight on the Professional difficulty was to just do nothing and let your moron teammate do his scripted bullshit, after which you run up to the boss and press a button prompt. Repeat this three times and you win. C A P T I V A T I N G   G A M E P L A Y.

Driving sections and turret sections also exist. They are very bad. Try imagining the worst driving section you can manage. It's still not as bad as the ones in this game. Hell, they even managed to shove one into one of the boss fights. It lasts around 15 seconds before it's over, which makes me question what the fuck the point of it was.

As for the UI, Capcom probably hired a team of scientists to research and develop the worst UI a human could ever experience. It's absolutely idiotic. You don't even have a normal inventory screen. Hell, you CAN'T EVEN PAUSE THE FUCKING GAME. LIKE WHAT THE FUCK???? Who the shit thought THAT was a good idea. If I need to quickly go throw up after playing this shit for 10 minutes, I can't even pause this fucking trainwreck so that my characters don't die while I'm gone.

I'm fuckin' tired of this shit, man. The game broke something in me that I don't think I'll ever get back. If you're thinking of getting this so you can play with a friend just to laugh at how bad this is, just don't. This game goes way past being the level of "so bad it's funny", even "so bad it's tragic". It makes itself at home on the "so bad it's actually offensive" level. It's even worse that RE5, in my opinion, which is an achievement in and of itself.

If you value your time and sanity, skip RE5 and RE6, watch a quick story summary on YouTube, and go play RE7. I hear that one's actually good, unlike this raccoon-shit filled atrocious fucking dumpster fire.

Some of the chapters in this game have the most ridiculous camera angles/tank controls I've ever seen and used. I've died many times due to the camera angle suddenly changing while running from a boss, and I move in the wrong direction due to this change. There are also sections where the game FORCES your camera towards a certain object/objective while enemies are shooting/hitting you, and you can't effectively aim at the enemies to defend yourself. It astounds me how some of the levels made it past QA and into the game itself. There are various areas were enemies can bodyblock you into a corner and essentially stunlock you to death. Add to that enemies that can stagger you from a distance, and you have a game that becomes difficult not because it actually challenges you, but because you have to actively fight the damn camera on top of the gimmicks thrown in. This would be a great game if it weren't for a few very stupid decisions

I just finished Leon's campaign for the first time and would like to give some considerations.

Well, I know many fans don't like this one because it is more like a Michael Bay movie then a survival horror. I don't mind the action turn this game took, I really enjoyed the small amount of suspense at the beginning of this campaign, but I wouldn't say I disliked the parts with more action either. I have played many other games in the series and have come to enjoy them each in their own way.

However, a few things bothered me deeply in this one. First thing to notice was that the inventory management system seemed to be not practical at all, choosing an Item or weapon mid fight was more dangerous than what has been achieved in the dark souls system, for me at least.

Second thing: quicktime events. My 10 years old self might have enjoyed them, but my today self did not. I barely died to enemies or agent hunters, most of my deaths came from the incessant quicktime events that sometimes wouldn't even compute my inputs.

Third thing that comes to mind was having to fight different variations of the same boss. It seemed like lazy writing to just stick the same character over and over as the biggest challenge presented to the player.

Anyway, despite the things I disliked about the game, I am being able to enjoy it. I'm also looking forward to the next campaigns, and maybe going coop again. I had a few players joining in as partners or agent hunters and it was nice to see that this game from 2013 still has an active community.

Terrible RE game, terrible survival horror game, but a really fun third person shooter.

Only play this if you want a coop shooter to play with a friend. It's a painfully average game.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Coop is great.
- The mercenaries mode is the best there is in the Resident Evil series, probably.
- It's a nice idea to divide the campaign into several protags with newcomers and returning characters.
- Piers is great.
- WAY better controls than previous resident evil games, you can move while aiming! Although with some awful flaws (See cons below).
- Sherry is back and better than ever.
- The melee system is great, but... (See cons below).

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- You can't mute yourself in voice chat, so you have to disable your mic... Weirdest part? You can mute OTHERS.
- Windowed mode is hidden, it's not in options, I had to google it (Hint: Alt + Enter).
- Melee combat has a stamina system for whatever fucking reason. The way it was implemented feels more annoying than anything.
- Critical hits feel more like critical misses due to having special recoil and animations.
- The story is... not very good. It feels more narmier than usual. Resident Evil 4, which was cheesy, was so in a good way. I felt myself pulling my hair over some cutscenes... and Jake feels like some strange fanfiction creation.
- For whatever reason, you can't pause.
- Camera angles. Lots of them. Expect to either die or receive damage unfairly in certain moments as you adjust your movement to them.
- The idea of having 4 player coop and agent hunt modes, while cool at the time, is now eh as the game has aged and people don't play it much anymore. This isn't the game's fault however and is just there so you know what to expect.
- Some awful bugs here and there. I've often had my friend disconnect or gotten stuck in a wall. Luckily solved once you reach a checkpoint and restart from there but it's annoying nonetheless.
- For whatever unholy reason, you're gonna have to get used to the god awful interface they have in this game. The one in RE5 was simple, but the one in here is gonna have you get used to it, and when you're done with the campaign, other player characters have other interfaces restarting progress once again.

I loved this game very much, despite how yes the purists will dump on this without hesitation. 
This felt like playing through one of those crazy CGI Resident Evil Movies, It felt amazing to play as beloved characters of the franchise in a way after they've grown and developed skills to handle BOW's and all the crazy stuff that gets thrown out at them. While the story may not be the most amazing, its still a fun game and does a lot of things that were very unique.
The coop element of the game allowing players who are playing different campaigns to band together randomly to fight a boss they've both arrived at in their campaign is ABSOLUTELY COOL, even more so the fact that the boss can be PLAYER CONTROLLED was also in itself an amazing feature even if it was rough around the edges. 
In addition this game has PVPVE in all the campaigns where a player can take control of an enemy character in peoples campaign and try to hinder their progress. 
Your combat ability as all the characters is absolutely astounding as well, being able to roll, jump, dodge, quick fire, remain on your back on the ground firing your weapon from your back while scooting backwards slowly to avoid a zombie from grabbing your legs. 
A lot of very amazing things in this game had been just totally overlooked because of the "This isn't MY ideal Resident Evil game" out look.

I dunno what my entire view on this game is. It's a good game. Story's decent, gameplay's consistent, it controls greatly as well and the music is really nice. I've encountered zero bugs during my playthrough. But there's a massive flaw that can be a dealbreaker for so many people.

Aside from Ada's story, this game is NOT designed for single-player playthroughs. You're gonna end up having a pretty boring time for the most part. I've lost interest of this game as I have nobody to play with. Split-screen is a nice way of giving both you and your partner eye-strain because the screen placement is horrible.

The game has a severe lack of puzzles. I'm fairly sure that only Ada had puzzles and action while everyone else had only action. If you were a fan of puzzle sections in RE, then I'm afraid to tell you that you're gonna be disappointed.

But probably one of the worst parts in my opinion is also what proves that this game isn't designed for single-player playthroughs: there's no fucking pause button. I am not kidding. There's no true pause in the game, I mean you can bring up a menu by pressing start and choose options, quitting the game and shit but the game doesn't even pause. So yeah you can't really take a break unless you are in a safe zone (which is really hard to figure out most of the time) and the checkpoint system doesn't really work so well for you to quit and then resume the game.

I'm recommending this game because it is truly a good game BUT ONLY IF YOU ARE PLANNING ON PLAYING WITH A FRIEND OR SOMEONE WHO'S ALSO INTERESTED IN PLAYING THIS GAME. You will have a good time, but not anywhere NEAR as fun as RE5.

Resident Evil 6 is a deservedly divisive and hated game, and is easily one the worst titles in the Resident Evil series thus far. Completely shedding the Survival-Horror mainstays you've come to expect and reshaping itself into a mediocre Action-Horror blockbuster with a focus on less horror, and more big explosions, rivaling some of the worst B-Movies I've ever watched, even more so than it's predecessor. So you may be asking, why am I recommending this game instead of throwing it into the dirt like many others? Well, in my opinion, behind all of the questionable narrative decisions and janky game design, there is a genuinely entertaining B-Movie schlock fest of a video game that is more than a blast to play with friends. Although, I would hold off on the mere idea of playing this game if you're planning on going in solo, as this game was clearly built with co-op in mind, and playing without another person to help you throughout the 4 separate campaigns this game has to offer is a hell on earth experience I wouldn't wish on my mortal enemy. But, if you have a friend you wanna laugh your ass off with and 8 bucks to spare during a sale, I highly recommend this game. And if your not a masochist or a die hard fan of Resident Evil, avoid it like the plague.

I'm not going to lie: this was an incredible game for me and my older brother, and it was one of the best co-op games we bonded over in my childhood that I'll never forget since it was the game that made me feel close to him despite his detachment from me when I was younger.

We are in good terms now and as I purchased this game when it was on sale, it brought back so many memories for my brother and me when we booted it up and saw the title screen. We genuinely spent a couple of days together playing the various campaigns and enjoying it immensely together as we really felt nostalgic with it.

The storyline was engaging and interesting to play through. It took me some time to get used to the controls again, but after I figured out how everything worked, it wasn't too difficult. Although there were some parts that were so difficult to manage that they required too many tries and attempts to get them right, I'm not sure if I should blame the controls, the game section, or us (I'm more or less specifically talking about Jake's campaign snowmobile section, which has always been annoying to get through and was honestly our hated section together).

People have criticized the game for not being scary enough or being too action-packed, which I respect and understand. After all for almost everyone the main idea behind Resident Evil is that you must survive against dangerous and challenging enemies while dealing with the horror of it all, through various scenarios and locations that are terrifying to traverse, but this game was more or less different from that, and I could say it focused more on the story aspect, which was action-packed rather than the series' actual horror.

For the most part, I was completely enamored with this game. It was enjoyable to play with my brother, and we had an absolute blast with just really going through with one of my favorite childhood classics. We might even play it again in a few years simply to relive the nostalgia.

If you're looking for a game to play with a loved one or a friend, I highly recommend this; it'll be a great bonding experience for even casual players and fans of the franchise.

If you're looking for a game that "should embody the Resident Evil horror experience," look elsewhere because this is certainly not it.

Resident Evil 4 Leon: Sorry, but following a lady's lead just isn't my style.
Resident Evil 6 Leon: *Continuously follows a lady's lead*

CAPCOM, WTF HAPPENED!? 
Furthermore, the tone of this game doesn't make a shred of sense. It tries to take itself seriously while simultaneously relying on absurdity as shown in the use of excessive cutscenes with vehicles and biohazards. There are a lot of anticlimactic moments and punchlines that don't land, but what really seals the nail in the coffin for this game is the gameplay. First of all the camera tricks the player into a false sense of security. You may think you have full control over the camera's movement for a while, that is until you unknowingly initiate a "cinematic" sequence that will subsequently make the camera turn in directions against your will. Combine this with the camera shifting from the typical over the shoulder perspective of your character to a myriad of arbitrary camera angles against your will and you get a migraine-inducing mechanical mess. Second of all, inventory management. There are no attaché cases that progressively increase in size as you get further in the game like in Resident Evil 4 or a passive inventory with 54 slots in addition to an active inventory with 9 slots like in Resident Evil 5. Instead there's a single active inventory with a meagre 9 slots to work with. Nothing is upgradable and the only thing you can buy are skill points which could have been an interesting concept, except there's a caveat in that no more than 3 of them can be equipped at any time. With the number of total skills being around 15x that amount, along with the cost/prevalence ratio of skill points in missions, it's a statistical improbability for the player to ever use the vast majority of these. Picking up too many items will inevitably lead to a situation with no other choice but to discard items as you cannot sell anything in this game either. Lastly there are sections where you are forced to walk at a snail's pace like in chapter 1 of Leon's campaign. Moreover there are sections where nothing is happening and you simply have to wait until the game decides enough time has passed by. There are no ways to speed these up or skip them and it practically kills all remaining replay value that potentially could have lingered within this blight. 

Final verdict: atrocious dumpster fire / 10

I enjoy Resident Evil 6 for what it is. Is it a good Resident Evil game? Absolutely not. However it IS a good Co-op game with a friend and it's the optimal way to play.

Resident Evil 6 has 4 different Campaigns to play through. 
Leon- Without a doubt the best campaign in the game. Leon's chapter is what you would have wanted from a resident evil game. 
Chris- Chris' game is focused primarily on heavy Gears of War combat. It's not bad, it's just not what I want in a Resident Evil game. 
Jake- Jake's gameplay is nothing but hide and seek. It takes the idea of Resident Evil 3's Nemesis hunt and dumb it down to the entire campaign. It's dull and uninspired. 
Ada- Ada's chapter feels like an afterthought. The only reason this Chapter exist is to tell behind the scenes scenarios. 

I recommend this game solely on the fact that it is a good Co-op game.

This game is...fine. It's not your normal Resident Evil game. It's over-the-top action, and there's like four campaigns, and I've played through some of them, but from what I've heard, none are particularly amazing, but it's all up to your own opinion. I played the Leon campaign with my brother, and it's fun. It's not scary, and it's action packed. I loved the action, but it felt less like a RE game and more like a generic action game. The mercenaries mode is fun too. I hate the inventory system though...it really sucks ass. 

You can tell this game was an attempt to try to please everyone. Chris's campaign is more action packed (well they really all are), and Leon's is supposed to be scarier, etc. It has some cool mechanics, like you can shoot on your back, slide, and roll. Your character is quite agile, and can perform some cool melee attacks.

I can understand the hate for this game, especially because they didn't have access to many great RE games that came out like Revelations, or RE7/8/RE2 Remake that honed in heavily on horror. But, if you don't take it too seriously, just try it. The story is fine. It's a cheesy RE story. It's not scary. It's action packed, and it's more nostalgic with zombie and zombie-like enemies. At the time, this might have felt like a disgrace, but now it just seems like a small misstep in the series, but Capcom has regained its footing and has consistently been making quality action packed, but harrowing adventures.

This is a tricky game to recommend. I would only say that if you're a huge fan of the Resident Evil series that you should give this game a try. But tbh, you're not missing much since a lot of people consider this as one of the dumbest/worst resident evil games in the series. 

This is NOT a horror game as much as it tries to advertise it. There is nothing scary and it's just filled with over the top ridiculousness. It doesn't have a theme or identity. It tries to do everything in one package. Which at first sounds good, but it doesn't work. You end getting a subpar experience in the horror, action, story and etc. 

You get 4 campaigns:
- Leon is "horror" focused. 
- Chris is action focused
- Jake is over the top action. 
- and Ada (that ties it all together)  

It tries to please everyone and it doesn't work. Myself who enjoys horror, never felt scared or tense throughout the Leon scenario. Then when came to the other campaigns, I slogged through them and didn't really have a memorable experience. When it came to end of the game and pieced together the plot. I just didn't care. 

For example. In the Chris Campaign. [spoiler] I never felt a connection to him. In the game, he suffers from PTSD when his entire squad gets wiped out. So he goes on this need for revenge. But for me, it never made any sense from his character because of the previous games. He has lost very close S.T.A.R.S team members in the original game. He didn't have this mental breakdown or stop fighting monsters when his closest friend and partner, Jill Valentine was assumed dead in Resident Evil 5. So it feels out of character, or does he care more about strangers than his friends?  [/spoiler] 

In Jake campaign. You will literally not give a toss about anything. Even when they bring characters and plot pieces relating to the previous games. I got this impression that it was poorly tagged in just to have any relevance to Resident Evil timeline. Like, these characters could've been anything or anyone else. But one writer just went; "Oh yeah, he/she is X long-lost family relative that wasn't mentioned or hinted in the past". It makes Sonic fan fiction writing look more appealing than whatever the writers did this.

They didn't keep it simple and tries tackle a lot of elements. But it ruins the flow and again, just get tacky and has a terrible structure in the story.  

The controls is great. I enjoy being able to move and shoot, melee, dive and sprint. But it somewhat backfires even during Leon horror segments. It's okay for an action sequence, but not so great when it's trying build tension. It's fun, but it's far from a resident evil game. What I also noticed is that the character interface is different for each campaign. So after playing several hours on Leon. You'll have get used to the new interface for Chris, Jake and Ada. While it's not a big issue, it can be distracting. 

There is ZERO puzzles, and focuses entirely on the action. Which if you're looking for that experience with a friend. It can be a good experience. It can get comical in a lot of places where the game will get even more ridiculous every chapter. Which if you're with a friend, can be a good laugh. If you felt like the planning and tension in the previous games wasn't your cup of tea. Then you can strap yourself in and enjoy the ride for this fast-faced game. 

The theory behind this is because of the Resident Evil 5. Sadly, despite people saying that the previous titles are miles better. Resident Evil 5 focused more on the action and sold vastly more than any of the other games. I think this made Capcom believe that Resident Evil 6 should be taken in this direction. 

There is only a few good elements in this game. But I can't honestly recommend it even if you pay the discounted price. I can say you should play this if you have friend who is also interested and enjoys Resident Evil...for just one weekend. If you're buying this on a sale and want to play it yourself. You might be able to enjoy some elements. This is not the worst thing or even a terrible game, but it fails to be gripping compared to other games. 

It offers a massive variety and the game gives over +20 hours playtime. But in this game case, more doesn't mean better. I'd say skip it and go play something else.

I've played a lot of these games over the years, but it's been a while. With a quick video refresher on the story, I picked up where I left off with this installment. It was certainly an adjustment from what I'm used to. The areas with endless enemies are quite different from games I had played previously, and when the enemies become more powerful, leaving a zone without exploring an excessive amount was a bummer. This typically doesn't happen though and I was able to clear most areas.

That being said, I found the story to be interesting, and I liked that there were four different arcs that wove together. From what I read, the game seems to get a lot of criticism. I'm not sure why. While certainly not the best installment, it's still a good game. It has plenty of flaws, but the combat is quite fun and ammo drops are frequent. This allowed me to be a bit more aggressive and worry about headshots less. The biggest issue I experienced was an awkward camera that is frequently jittery as it bumps into the floor while running. Some camera switches during boss fights and scenes where I needed to move quickly caused unnecessary deaths. Other than that, not major complaints.

Graphics are good for a game that came out in 2012. Voice acting is good. Music is pretty decent. Even though the game is dated, for the amount of content, the asking price seems far. I got 30 hours out of it just completing the main story. However, this game seems to go on significant sale quite often and I'd recommend picking it up when it does.

Honestly i really tried to like this game. I started playing this after i finished re5 and went in with high expectations and enthusiasm as to how the series will expand after 2 successful action takes on the survival horror genre. It would be an understatement to say i was left feeling sorely disappointed..The horror element is noneexistent and action scenes and qte's are being shoved to your face nonstop. The gameplay mechanics are tedious and needlessly complicated, making the already clunky controls and combat system a chore to operate. Another aspect that really tilted me personally was the save system, which instead of normally saving your current progress even if it says so, it never really does forcing the player to replay massive segments of the story just to get to the point where he exited the game at the time. I can't really say a lot about the enemy variety since i didn't finish the whole game but i've come across a few different enemy types which was a nice surprise at least..weirdly enough the enemies have a certain bullet-sponginess to them, which i quite disliked. In my opinion the only redeeming factor is the cutscene quality, which i found superb along with the online multiplayer where you can progress through the game with another player by your side and lastly the story which seemed serviceable so far. At the end of the day i personally think that this game is a far cry from the rest of the titles in the series in terms of the horror and gameplay aspects and as much as it pains me to say it did not feel like resident evil to me..i might try to finish it with an online partner in the future because im kinda curious about how the story unfolds and because going shooty shooty with zombies is always fun as heck xD

[h1]What I liked: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Still got co-op
[*] Intro chapters
[*] Improved combat
 [/list]
 
[h1]What I didn’t like: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Convoluted story
 	[*] Unpolished gameplay sections
	[*] Most bad design tropes from the 2010’s
 [/list]
[h1]My Score: [/h1]
[b]D[/b]

 [h1]Quick Summary[/h1]
Resident Evil 6 starts with a combat system I love, throwing in a wide variety of enemies that couldn’t keep up with my already high power level, but that’s nothing new to the series. Then, as the game went on, it felt like they forgot what made the game fun. So, they piled on a mixture of shallow and repetitive spectacle bosses, the most QTE’s ever, a lot of varied yet unpolished gameplay “additions”, with a story so long and convoluted that seemed to go nowhere. After 12 hours, we rang the bell and tapped out.

[h1][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31495025/] My Personal Curator List [/url] [/h1]

[h1]Promising Premise[/h1]
RE 6 offers four total campaigns focusing on a single character's perspective of the story, with Leon and Chris being the two I played. Jake’s and Ada’s are the ones I did not attempt, as you hopefully will understand why later. On paper, this idea of a massive interconnected plot, with each one being different, sounds amazing, but in execution not so. Let me start from the beginning and see how I grew to dislike RE 6.

You start with Leon’s campaign mid-story in an odd prologue to tease what is to come later; here, it is mostly QTE prompts to escape a helicopter, open a door, and shoot a zombie. Yes, that should have been a warning of things to come. Once you get past that prologue, which you will replay when it comes up hours later, the game finally lets you enjoy some actually great shooting and improved melee combat.

[h1]The Best Action in the Series[/h1]
The gameplay has changed to allow moving and shooting at the same time, which is nice, even if it’s sad to see the previously unique style gone. Your melee move-sets have been expanded with stamina to manage now, to prevent spamming these new martial art moves to disarm or kill enemies. The best addition is a prone move that allows diving into, sliding, dodging, and shooting enemies like a tactical god. There is an instance with saw blades that you can prone under that is the crowning moment of this new move.

These great new additions are carried into each campaign, with every character having different melee hit combos, stealth, throws, and counter animations that are truly amazing and offer depth for a series that was just simple shooting. These new additions bring RE into its best action feeling, even after RE 8. It’s just a shame the enemy AI and difficulty are not brought up to match this newfound power, think of RE 5 but you are Neo.

This praise and actual enjoyment are mostly from the first 3 chapters of Leon’s campaign. Up to this point, it contains one fun boss(that is just a beefed-up zombie) with cannon fodder helping showcase how fun the combat is when it’s simple. The brisk pace of new zombies, locations, weapons, and the ratio of gameplay to non-gameplay is nicely balanced. This is about the halfway mark, as each campaign is six hours long with five chapters each. So three out of the total ten I played were enjoyable. Then the game takes a slow descent into disaster until we get to Chris’s campaign where it plummets.

[h1]Just Give up on writing, Resident Evil[/h1]
Before that, I need to explain the story: in order to have a story, stuff needs to happen, right? RE 6 has a lot of stuff happen and yet nothing really does. Characters will go places, get betrayed, the villains will die, and then come back to life half a dozen times. They will kill your comrades or entire cities and then you let them go because you don’t have time to explain why and never get any answers. It’s so circular that it felt like after 12 hours nothing happened, you might as well skip the cutscenes, and you will basically get the same idea of what’s happening.

A huge problem that happens here, is that in all the previous games each had a relatively low amount of story and therefore cutscenes, and let you just play the game. Here, it feels like you can’t go five minutes without something to interrupt the core reason you play RE, to the point that it feels like half of the game is non-gameplay.

[h1]A lot but Shallow[/h1]
The game takes you around the globe from a city similar to Raccoon, then to China, and lastly to Europe, in some well-crafted levels that you will revisit with other characters later. Probably the coolest moment was a laser hallway of death leading to explosive Roombas that you had to get rid of. For the most part, I feel the game is afraid to have you just move through a level without something outside of normal combat breaking it up, which rears its ugly head towards the end of Leon’s campaign.

[u]A short list of stuff that breaks the flow of fun[/u]:
[list][*]Boss fights where one person does literally nothing
[*]Turret sections
[*]Bosses that feel like cutscenes instead of playing 
[*]A car chase 
[*]Flying a jet 
[*]The worst and most amount of QTEs in the series
[*]Chris’s clear Call of Duty inspired sections
[*]Sequences that are unskippable gameplay cutscenes
[*]Puzzles that aren’t puzzles
[/list]

With Leon’s main villain, you barely fight him and your co-op partner during one literally can’t. He will transform from a dog to a T-rex, then a fly. These over-the-top boss fights might sound or look cool in a trailer but is terribly boring and tedious when the more simple bosses where you just shoot big zombies were more fun. You “kill” him each time in some explosion or fire to the point that you just give up caring as it overstayed its welcome the first time he wasn’t killed.

The 3rd campaign's character, Jake, who is Wesker’s son, so it’s further tied to the series’ lore. The reason they need him is to end the virus. Just imagine if RE 5 had a separate campaign centered around Sheeva, especially after how bad Chris’s campaign was. 

[h1]The Descent into Despair[/h1]
I can stomach the story because you can skip it, or not pay attention if it’s too long. The same can not be done while playing. You have those “gameplay” sections I mentioned above, which feel like 70% of Chris’s campaign if you also include the cutscenes. They went with an insane amount of variety and yet none of it was enjoyable at all. I would rather have QTE running sections from RE 4 and 5 over actually having to do it. I now understand why they overused them so much, as they have to be inept to screw up running, and yet they did, as platforms are wide and yet so narrow that if one of us made the slightest movement off the path, it resulted in death, so would jumping, or looking around. Also, the car chase and jet flying felt more like a proof of concept that was thrown in, as they sound cooler than they actually play.

Further proof of these half-baked ideas, the inventory is now expanded to allow more items,  an improvement from RE 5, but now it has a carousel format so scrolling takes longer, and removing and managing items is now a pain. The real kicker here is that every new gun takes up a slot and you can’t drop them. Even with the triple inventory space, it somehow feels like less as you will be constantly swapping weapons with how few bullets you will have with grenades and health taking up any free slots as well, fumbling the flow of the fun combat that they seemed to forget they had.

The final change from a system that everyone loved and worked perfectly from RE 4 and 5, the weapon upgrades are gone. Now you get poorly described perks from the score you get after each mission to basically do the same thing but they aren’t needed, as again you are a god with your newfound power.

- due to advance move set controls can be a little confusing

- story or environments sometimes don't make much sense and go out there a couple of times

In an attempt to make RE more like a modern action movie, Capcom succeeds in homogenizing the survival-horror experience and makes each challenge aggravating and downright boring. Waaay too many QTEs, random drops erode the sense of resource limitations, your partner is pretty useless (at least Sheva kicked ass), and the constant inundation of horde-based, stipulation-controlled encounters is noisy and dull. Although RE puzzles have never been too mindbending, the simplifications made in the name of co-op renders exploration nearly pointless. 

Where's the tension and pacing that makes it possible to feel the scares? Where's the learning curve that lets me slowly feel a sense of control? They're gone. Replaced by leaping zombies and Leon doing karate.

I really feel like people give this game a hard time.

I really like this game, and I feel like it had the best combat gameplay out of every single Resident Evil game. Yeah, sure, it isn't scary, but the overall aspect of the game to me feels more intended to be an action game in my opinion.

People apparently bash on this game a lot, and I can understand that, but in my opinion, I love how you could dodge an enemy's attack when you couldn't do that properly before. Counterattacking was added in this game too, which really made it fun to go from enemy to enemy, potentially without losing a single block of health. It felt exhilarating to do that, and it still does.

And don't get me started on the online play. I absolutely loved how a player could join in on you throughout the game. Maybe some other people don't like it, but I really enjoyed that warm feeling in my chest when someone joined my session as a player. It felt like something was missing when I played the campaign, and when somebody joined, it really filled in that missing gap.

And if you can get it, areas where two players' stories intersect are hilarious. I was playing on Chapter 5 - Leon on No Hope with a friend of mine and when we got to the second to last area in the campaign where you fight Simmons alongside Ada, we actually ended up intersecting with a player. I played as Helena and there was actually an Agent character too, and it was absolutely hilarious. That's how we ended up as friends with those other players.

It's great to meet new people in this game, and having to communicate without voice chat, in my opinion, makes it even funnier.

I love this game.

This game is best described as making a big milkshake. You get out your favorite cup, get your ingredients, but find out that you only have two scoops of ice cream left in the carton. You try scraping as much out of the carton as possible, but the drink is mostly just milk. You try spicing it up by adding some chocolate syrup, whipped cream, and sprinkles, but you can't change the fact that it is missing the ice cream.

While 5 was mostly an action game with some big blockbuster moments, it did still have some traces of the original survival horror that the franchise is famous for, especially in Lost in Nightmares. Resident Evil 6 throws away the atmosphere and creative enemies for generic third-person shooter gameplay. The UI has been dumbed down and compressed to having single lines for items/healing/weapons, the guns feel weak and ineffective, and there are a lot of new additions such as dodge and counter which are hardly explained. The best word to describe the whole experience is awkward.

It is an okay action game but it is a terrible Resident Evil game, I would only recommend it if it is on sale since it is a much better experience with friends.

I will explain at toward the end why I recommend this game, but first, I need to get the negatives out of the way! 

Resident Evil 6, what can I say about it.. When I finally got to play it on PS3, I was kinda disappointed by the gameplay.. Yeah, i understand they tried to implement some cool melee sequences, but it felt unnecessary.. I played thru the story campaigns, and when I completed them, I never played the game again. That was back sometime in late 2013 or 2014. This time around, I decided to buy it again for PC (since I've been into gaming on PC for almost a year now due to getting a gaming laptop), because it was on sale for cheap, and give it another chance. It was by playing through it again that I remembered why I never picked it up again back then: The gameplay did not seem as smooth as RE4 and 5 were, and while it helped to be able to shoot WHILE moving (something that wasn't present in RE4 and 5), it seemed the shooting was less consistent. 

I DID see that you could buy skills that could help with aiming, but I personally don't care for the kind of upgrade system Capcom implemented in the game! The upgrade system for weapons in 4 and 5 was MUCH better compared to 6! Not to mention, I think they totally overdid the quick time events in 6! You could be in the middle of a fight with a boss, and it goes to a scripted QTE, and when you complete one, another one pops up 2-3 seconds after, when you're not expecting one to pop up, making you totally miss the timing of the QTE and you get a game over screen! It's quite frustrating at times! The story campaigns are decent, but still leave you with questions! 

However, i would still recommend this game, because it's still a decent time-passer of a game. I just would suggest waiting for a sale before you get it, and be warned, you WILL get frustrated with it at some parts!

HANDS-DOWN, ONE OF THE MOST ABOMINABLE OPENINGS TO A VIDEO GAME...EVER.  
 
   I mean, I do appreciate that some Resident Evil fans actually prefer a zombie-kickboxing simulator to a more atmospheric gaming experience, but seriously, does ANYONE out there actually like all this mechanics-breaking, quick-time-in-lieu-of-a-cutscene HORSESHIT?!  Okay, so maybe The Walking Dead games get away with some degree of it...but if the Resident Evil games are now aspiring to the level of immersion and emotional depth that THOSE games achieve, they may want to start paying some attention to concepts like themes, storytelling, and characterisation, don'tcha think?

   The opening sequence of this game is sooooo painful, they even give you an Achievement for getting through it, appropriately entitled "The Longest Night".  They even have the gall to call it a "tutorial", when it teaches you precious little other than how to die repeatedly because you don't understand the poorly-explained on-screen instructions of how to RUN...in a SINGLE DIRECTION...and then force you to watch the same ten-second snatch of cutscene OVER AND OVER AND OVER AGAIN to atone for your aforementioned sins.  Next time, Capcom, just hawk up a great big loogie and spit it straight in my face, eh?
 
   Things then start to look a TINY bit more hopeful, as Leon and some chick we've never seen before make their slow, moody way through a super-darkened government building, which is seemingly full of spooky noises but no actual undead. It isn't long, however, before we're spin-kicking and pile-driving zombies, and trying to work out just how the hell you even switch from guns to grenades or use health items (all adventures in their own rights, believe me)!  On the whole, there's really nothing terribly intuitive here...not the controls, not trying to estimate how close you can get to a zombie with your flyin' feet before they can get at YOU...the early part of the game is a constant struggle, or at least it was for me, and I played this straight off the back of Resident Evils 4 and 5, and all the DLCS and "bonus episodes" attached to those (undeniably superior) games. 
 
   Overall, there's really not much respect given to long-term fans: this may as well be a big-budget rival company's rip-off of the RE franchise for all the continuity it serves up, both tonally and mechanically.  It's far from the worst game ever made...but it's definitely one of the weakest Resident Evil games, period.  (And I've even played obscure, long-forgotten shit like Dead Aim, the Outbreak series, and the Survivor series, for what it's worth.)
 
    For much of its length, this is barely even a horror game.  It's an action game with unfeasibly dark lighting and horror undertones.  Hell, as zombie-action games go, it's a long way from bad - even slightly "thrilling" upon occasion - but it's hardly honest-to-God HORROR, at least seventy-five per cent of the time.  And for all its attempted surliness, its "grit" never surpasses that of a Michael Bay movie (nice stubble, Leon, but you still have pretty-boy hair); and when all is said and done, it's still every bit as corny as a farmer's field in Summer ("Mr President, please don't make me do this!" blubbers Leon, unwilling to shoot the prez, even though he's clearly turned into a FREAKING ZOMBIE)!
 
   A message to the developers of Resident Evil 7: stop catering to the undiscerning fans of those awful Milla Jovavich movies, and stop pandering to whatever is de rigueur in video games right at this very micro-second in time.  Multiplayer and/or A.I. partners DO NOT MAKE GAMES SCARY.  Quick-time events DO NOT MAKE GAMES SCARY.  Endless kickboxing moves DO NOT MAKE GAMES SCARY.  And making parts of your games so visually dark that you can't even tell what the hell just wounded you, IS JUST FRUSTRATING, NOT SCARY.  

   Pretty pretty please, let's do a little better next time, eh? This series is still pretty good...but it used to be GREAT.  The Revelations games seem to be heading in the right direction...how about lifting the game of the MAIN series, whad'ya say?
 
Verdict: 7.5/10.  
 
(Oh, and PS to the devs: there's this thing they invented a while back, called "save points", and you shouldn't feel obliged to limit yourselves to only one every half-hour or so of gameplay.  Just sayin'...)

Over a year ago I started playing through every Resident Evil game. For a while I was making a pretty good pace since the games aren't that long. Then came Resident Evil 6.

This game took me around half a year to finish solely because playing it actively made me upset. I couldn't stomach doing more than a chapter at a time, and would often take a month long break between them. Playing this game is just so... sad. It's sad seeing everything I love about the series be replaced with quick time events and explosions.

This game is also way, way, way too long. I was ready to be done after the first campaign, but I still had three to go. Every time I played the mechanics which were originally new and fun quickly became more and more dull. I can only perform wrestling moves on monster so many times before it loses its cool. 

If you put these mechanics on another game I might actually like it. It is inherently fun to flip and flop around on the floor guns blazing. That's why I think that the mercenaries is the best thing in the package. Just some arcade fun with intuitive controls. But when you throw these mechanics on a game that is way too long and never switch it up... well it gets stale.

Also Leon is a shell of his former self and it makes me upset.

I'm very excited to move onto Resident Evil Revelations 2 and Resident Evil 7. Both look to be a step in the right direction (especially 7).

A great addition to the franchise, it follows the story really well and while other games tend to lose the grip on the story after a few games this one managed to get a grip on it. At times i felt like they didn't know what to do so they just added another miniboss battle or swarm fight but the story of this game is pretty long and theres not to many of situations like that.

Graphics: 8/10 - While the game looks really beautifull and it isn't verry demanding for what it is some details
                           were just ignored on purpuse to lighten the load on the graphic cards.

Gameplay: 7/10 - Don't fix it if it's not broken, they tried to keep the old over the sholder mechanic but tweak 
                             a bit further which ruined it. Giving someone more options and abilities while also keeping
                             the same limitations as before feels more anyoing then inovative.

Story: 9/10 - As i said i love how they concluded some key parts of the story even though they didn't feel like 
                      they needed it and added new characters to the story as a whole which opens the possibility 
                      for a lot more content (which they didn't make so far) the story of this game is a bit confusing 
                      at times and needs some thinking over after you finish everything to make sense.

Overall: 9/10 - I love the fact that they kept the mercenaries, something they didn't in future games and the 
                        story follows the coop perfectly while also crossing other players coop sessions. The biggest 
                        problem in my opinion would be that the game is massively underrated so there isn't much 
                        interaction with other players.

Resident Evil 6 looks great running at 1080p. Capcom's game comes completely stacked, with all of its content accessible from the beginning, which ensures numerous non-stop hours of fun. Presumably not the best game of the series and it offers no changes other than the visuals, however it offers action and enjoyment without complications, being the most ambitious Resident Evil entry in the franchise, maybe it should not be roasted too hard. It does offer 4 short stories in one game which are told from perspective of different characters, some of which we know from previous games like Chris, Leon and ADA. But to some this is a downer as the developers were not able to focus on one story. And to be honest I also felt a little bored playing kind of same story from different perspectives. I only fully enjoyed Leon's and Chris's story as they were the first I played. After that the other 2 felt quite dull. But nonetheless the game is still good enough to be played at least one time.
I still and will never understand why this game was so hated on, its amaxing, ik its more of an action game but its still worth it espacially if its on sale.

I've recently gotten into playing more scary games lately despite being a big baby and one of the series that I've really fallen in love with has been the Resident Evil series. Having played RE2make and almost finishing RE3make and dabbling in 7 and 8 and watched others play the others I've not played to understand the story, 6 is the weird duck of the long line of games. I wanted to play this mostly because it is co-op and I've roped another friend into playing scary games with me but also to see the wildness that cause Capcom to go 'mmm maybe we take this back to the drawing board' to sort of soft reboot the series with the following 7 and Village games.

Having played the Leon campaign so far (and I doubt stuff changes too drastically gameplay wise in the other campaigns) I can see why this game wasn't as beloved in the franchise known for scares and a creepy atmosphere. A LOT happens at once and you often fights hordes of zombies and other monsters at any one time and so many explosions and slow-mo happens that  you feel like watching an action movie more than playing a tense horror game. However in playing it with a friend, the enjoyment is pretty high and the game doesn't look terrible and everything works so on that front there isn't much to complain about.

The long and short is if you are a RE fan tried and true after so many years this might not be your game but if you also are a fan and want to bring a friend alone for the ride... worse games to play through honestly.

Vastly different than it's predecessor, RE6 is focused on action and combat. You won't get that horror feeling from RE4, but the controls and combat mechanic is miles better, with satisfying gun combat and simplified melee. The graphic looks amazing even in 2022, very impressive given its 10 years old already. 4 different campaign that unfolds the story as you progress through it from a different POV. Absolutely recommended, although the camera work and quick time events can be annoying sometimes.

The years have been kind to "Resident Evil 6". At the time of its release, the game got savaged because of its many issues - which I'll comment about here. But with time, as the game got cheaper and more people where whiling to buy it despite the bad reviews, many players felt that it had positive aspects that weren't appreciated enough at its release. The question then becomes: do its positive aspects compensate for its issues?

After "Resident Evil 5" moved the focus of the franchise from horror to action, Capcom developers wanted the next game to double-down on action, while also having some sober horror elements to apparently appease fans of previous "RE" games - a way maybe to keep some of the franchise's identity in there. They also wanted the game to feel like an epic, with multiple campaigns, and focusing on several franchise favourites like Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield and Ada Wong. It is a game that feels very much like it wanted to be the most "definitive" game in the franchise.

But the final result is an uneven game that can go from pleasant to frustrating very quickly. It's a game that can be clumsy in its attempts to menage both its horror and action elements, and as a consequence, its horror is no longer scary, being more of a restrain on the action. My suggestion is that "Resident Evil 6" should have been an action game all along, scrapping all of its horror elements that just don't click with the overall vibe.

The game has four campaigns: Leon and Helena, Chris and Pears, Jake and Sherry, and then Ada. One thing I really liked about the game is the notion of the stories being interlinked: characters will find each other in their stories and influence them. By playing the game, you'll notice it has a strong focus on the idea of co-op - with the exception of Ada's campaign, all the campaigns can be played by two players. So much so that, like in "Dark Souls", the pause menu doesn't actually pause the game, which is common for online games. But of course you can play the game alone, as your partner will then be controlled by a very competent AI, who can manage itself against enemies and is quick to rescue you when you're down.

Leon's campaign is the most irregular. It starts off as a horror campaign, but it doesn't take long before it picks up and becomes more oriented to action. It has moments when it's not sure what it wants to be, and only at the end it becomes good. Chris' campaign is the most action-grounded of them all: you're a soldier fighting armed zombies. There'll be some annoying bosses, but his campaign overall is actually pretty good. Jake's campaign... I'll just say it's hilarious. Jake is such an edgy character that it feels like a parody of edgy troupes. He feels like a character out of a cartoon; he's just so out there. And what makes it all more fascinating is that it's all taken serious: he wasn't meant to be funny. But anyway, his campaign is actually pretty decent, except at some moments when you have to control vehicles (more on that in a bit). Then there's Ada's campaign, which may be the best - it's the only one properly meant for single-player. Not too frustrating, and with enough action for a good time.

You acquire skill points during the game, which curiously, are not gifted automatically to you as you kill zombies, but you have to manually collect them as drops. With these points, you can unlock new skills for your characters, making things easier. You're never truly lost or confused in the levels, since they tend to be very linear, and even when they're more open-ended, you have this device (the Q key) which will point you where to go next. So the level designs are actually well made. Even key fetching don't feel so annoying due to that.

During the stories, the characters are required to do different things at key moments. Their functions are not interchangeable, tough: what the game delegates to Sherry cannot be done by Jake, for example. At some points the game tries to variate, and to introduce players with different challenges. The issue however is that these challenges can be incredibly annoying: going to the subject of vehicles, you are sometimes asked to pilot something. In Jake's campaign, it is this snowmobile that is incredibly clunky at first, and then there's a motorbike section because, hey, there's gotta be one somewhere. In Chris' campaign, it's a VTOL, but if you're playing with Pears, it becomes much easier, since all you have to do is shoot. In Ada's campaign, it's a helicopter, which is actually decent enough. All of this is to bring some variety to the game, which is understandable, but it doesn't always work.

The main grip I have with the game, however, is the combat. Once again, the game tries to balance between horror and action, and as such, it implements many survivor horror elements that don't work with the action, such as inventory management, bad aiming, fatigue, and being throw out of balance. The game tries to focus on melee combat, which would be a way for players to save up ammo. But you can't just go around kicking enemies since there's so much fatigue you have. Besides, being grabed by zombies can sap your health pretty hard, so maybe it's best to keep your distance.

Each character has its own set of initial guns, and as you progress, you'll also find new guns. But their ammo occupies space in your inventory, and too much items means you won't have room to essential ones: namely healing herbs, which have this disgracefully complicated way to be accessed (apparently, you have to first convert the herbs in your inventory into pills, and then put them in your character). Again, this was all meant for a horror game, but they feel out of place in an action game. There are also numerous QTEs that are just overly present in the game: if we were talking about well placed events, that would be acceptable, but they're just overwhelming as they are.

The bosses are actually tricky, because you don't know when to just fill them with lead and when there's a specific action to do. The zombies come in different shapes and sizes, and at one point you'll face the so-called J'avos: zombies that get an extra mutation when they're harmed. And some of these mutations are incredibly hard to deal with (the swarm of bees being the worst of them all). This is all for the sake of combat variation, so you won't feel like you're fighting the same enemies over and over again.

The four campaigns took me nearly 27 hours to complete, but maybe the game should have been a bit shorter, as it was filled with unnecessary moments. On harder difficulties, it becomes unfairly hard, so swallow your pride and complete the game on normal: it becomes more balanced. Besides, once you beat all campaigns, you'll have the option of infinite ammo, which will make some moments much more pleasant, and will allow you to play at harder difficulties without much issues (but the hardest difficulty lacks the infinite ammo option).

"Resident Evil 6" justifies much of its criticism. But it also justifies much of its praise. You play it and you immediately understand why it's not universally beloved. Once again, developers should have focused more on making an action game, but overall, for all its flaws, it's still a decent game that could have been so much better with so little changes.

For replay experience, this is my favorite Resident Evil game to come back to. I would consider this to be the most arcade-ish experience in the franchise so it would be unfair to hold the expectation of survival horror similar to the original mansion incident. For a game going onto 10 years, it's a solid game.

It is tough to give a recommendation for RE6. As a fan of the series since it's inception, RE6 is one of the worst RE games, definitely the worst mainline title in the series. However, the game isn't that terrible if you view it as a 3rd person action shooter and NOT a Resident Evil game.

The game has it's fun moments but it is unpolished and mechanically messy, many of the mechanics available to the player are cool but poorly thought out and unreliable. Running in this game will often result in your character snapping around instantaneously in the opposite direction and leaping over something, it gets frustrating. Melee attacks are cool but the game forces it too much, resulting in very weak weapons and low ammo.

The 4 main campaigns are a mixed bag in quality. There are some good moments but a lot of rough or even frustrating or dull moments that just get exhausting to play. The game has a lot of QTE's and scripted sequences, which contradicts all the gameplay mechanics. A few turret/vehicle sections that also aren't very fun fill up play time.

There is a lot of variety here but again not all of it is to the game's benefit. While the game's design does get pretty generic for the time it came out, I don't find it as bad as many of it's competitors. For instance, the QTE's aren't any more frequent that RE4/5 for the most part. It's no where near the frequency of Tomb Raider 2013, Uncharted, etc. and it's better integrated into the gameplay.

It's the scripted sequences that get a bit annoying. There are MANY sections of the game where all you have to do is wait for an invisible timer to elapse and combat is optional. Or bosses that you only need to shoot a few times in a specific spot/timing but the overall battle is long and drawn out with numerous scripted encounters that gets frustrating to deal with. (many villains just won't die...)

Anyway, all that being said the core gameplay, when pitted against regular enemies is pretty fun. It is all the other additions and distractions that get in the way. So is the game worth playing? I think so. I think it's entertaining enough to play at least once even for RE fans, but one should go in with low expectations and playing with a friend will help a lot, the game doesn't seem all that well balanced for single player, partner AI is very unreliable.

I will say this though, only pick this game up at a hefty discount. About $5 to $10 USD is the most one should pay for this, though it does come with a lot of content. Also worth mentioning that the Mercenaries mini-game here is great, with many maps, characters and costumes, it may be the best implementation of the mini-game in the series. Almost worth buying the game just for Mercenaries.

Having spent quite a bit of time back on the PS3, this game is ironically one of my favorites of the series. I really like the enhanced movement control options and various features such as the quick shot, melee combat and countering capabilities; however, while the story was neatly layed out from different perspectives, the game lacked everything associated with its survival horror roots.

The lack of weapon customization that was featured in RE4 and 5 was a let down, but was more than compensated with various melee combat options and countering capabilities. The little customization that the player has is in setting up eight different triplets of skill slots that they purchase and upgrade skills throughout multiple runs of the game. These were nice, but I wish there was room for just one more due to the difficulty in escaping from various enemy grab attacks. As far as weapons go, each story includes various weapons that are acquired throughout the first playthrough and remain unlocked after that. The use of grenades has also been mapped much better to quickly and efficiently get to and use than in the other games. Another great enhancement is the dying status being upgraded from the way it was in RE5, that allows the player to defend and escape death without aid, though at a disadvantage.

The overall presentation of the game was very well done and had very good graphics. The levels were in some cases less enjoyable the way they trapped you in a smaller section at a time and blocked the ability to backtrack. One of the most annoying aspects of the game was the interactive movie events or at least some of them that wants to cause great wear and tear to the controller to pull off in the limited time. The last complaint would be in the numerous achievements that are attached to the various verses modes that few likely played to begin with, given that Resident Evil has always been a single-player/ co-op game.

Overall the game is stylish and fun and the PC port seems to run perfectly fine. The gameplay is more action oriented and less survival horror, but the movement and combat options are in my opinion the best this franchise has ever featured in any of their games. If you like these games, then you will likely enjoy this one for the game it is; however, if it must be survival horror, then you may be let down by this one.

Another resident evil title that was released with another strain of virus unleashed, but now the zombies have became smart, and there’s a new character joined the fray: Jack Muller, Albert Wesker’s son. The player will get to experience his story, along with our favorite Chris Redfield, Leon S. Kennedy, and Ada Wong in a story shrouded in mystery, betrayal, and brother-and-sister love. The events of this title goes like this: the president of the United States thanks to a man, who was working for Neo Umbrella called Derek Simmons, where he unleashed a virus with the help of a clone of a character called Ada Wong. Ever felt that someone has been using your loved ones as a collateral for them to get what they want ? Did you ever experience that your best friends always got your back in situations so dire that you don’t wish it would happen to your worst of enemies ? Cause that’s what happened to Leon’s partner, and Chris’s team. Chris’s partner Piers Nivans sacrificed his life to save Chris’s, and Leon’s partner Helena Harper had her sister kidnapped and used as a collateral to kill the president.

Please note: I finished Resident Evil 5 and immediately went to 6 and like RE5, I played this solo.

Resident Evil 6 is a huge improvement to RE5 in every aspect. I made a review for RE5 and in short; the game changed the format of a mainly single-player survival horror series to an over-the-top action multiplayer similar to Left 4 Dead. It gave you the option to play a single-player but the A.I. was horrid. Resident Evil 6 fixed that problem and made companion A.I. more intelligent and gave it infinite ammo. It also felt more like a horror. I had a better experience with this game than RE5, but I did have some issues. Mainly, the controls suck (Which is more of an issue with the series, not just 6) and the story wasn't all good. The story was cheesy as all heck and it took itself way too seriously. I enjoyed the past games (before 5) cheesiness but back then it didn't take itself seriously. That being said I liked multiple campaigns and how they intertwined with each other. I thought that was a nice touch. My last issue with this game is the run time, this is by far the longest Resident Evil game so far. I have no problems a lengthy game but in this case, it kinda dragged on too much,

Overall, I enjoyed this game, much more than 5.

Where do I start.... well, this game is Resident Evil in name only. Second, I was unable to finish the game due to a game breaking bug found in Chapter 3 of Leon's campaign. It's not possible to finish this game single player. Based on what I can find online, this only affects the steam version of the game. Third, the controls are too loose. I'm assuming this was an attempt to make it feel more like an action game than survivor horror.

While the campaigns are decent, leon’s story is the better one followed by Jake and Sherry’s campaign. Chris’ plot is meh at best and feels like rainbow six without the tactical feel. Ada’s is more stealthy and puzzle-based. But honestly the reason i keep coming back to RE6 is The Mercenaries mode. if you wanna unlock all the playable stages you have to beat all four campaigns. Also Resident Evil 6 can run on a Pentium 4 3.0Ghz. very well optimized; surprising considering its Capcom who arent know for their pc ports. realistically i’d give this game a 8.5/10 and an 8 if you don’t plan to play the campaigns.

I am cheating a bit in this review, as I am still waiting to get together with my friend and finish the last campaign, but I’m bored at work, so here we go. I genuinely don’t understand why everyone hated this game. Sure, the characters and dialogue are stupid, but it’s Resident Evil! That’s part of the fun! I really hunk people were unkind to it when it came out because of all the action, but it’s a fun game. The ability to combat roll, crawl on the ground, and do melee combos are a great additions to the over-the-shoulder RE formula and allow for new ways of navigating around and dispatching zombies. I will admit that the campaigns do vary in quality, and Chris’ is not the best, but there are 5 to choose from, so there is a plethora of quality story content. I highly recommend playing with a friend, the game offers both online and local co-op. This makes the experience loads better and there is a lot of fun to be had diving into each other. The mercenaries mode in this game is also excellent, as the new action moves really suit a score-chasing arcade mode, and the crossover with Left 4 Dead 2 made me very happy. Overall, it is a great package with some occasional sour spots. Underrated RE title.

RESIDENT EVIL 6 REVIEW 

Its very well known to anyone who is interested in this game and the Resident Evil series that this game is the most controversial entry, being more action-packed than survival horror. In my opinion this game is great, the story to me is very Resident Evil, though there a lot of action moments that seem to feel out of place, but if you dont mind those type of things then this game is for you.

GAMEPLAY 
Compared to Resident Evil 4 and 5 this game has a lot of controls, a lot of buttons to press and many more, shooting in this game is in my opinion less satisfying than previous entries, weapon upgrades dont exist in this game but there power ups for damage and aiming, when it comes to aiming you are given 2 choices the regular crosshair or the RE4 staple lasersight which can be changed to different colors. To me the biggest problem is the camera, it takes time getting used to it but i was hard at first, being that the camera is so close to the character itself.

OVERALL
 
The game is great for RE fans but know that it is not really a very scary game like the other entries, as a game this is great, it works well but as an RE game maybe not so much. Overall great game has a good and solid story and is pretty enjoyable. I highly suggest this to anyone who is into Resident Evil or just a casual player.

To brutally honest, this is not a horror game. This is an action game. If you are here for scares and spooks, there won't be able to find any here. Which is what the RE franchise is all about (mostly). But if you are looking for a fun third-person shooter campaign with the option to have co-op. You found the right game. 

The good stuff about said game-
Every weapon is fun to shoot. plain and simple, red dot goes on enemy, then bang, all done. 
The new movement mechanics are extremely interesting, cool, fun, and rewarding to master. You can leap backwards, roll forwards, left and right, and if you have good timing, you can duck under leaping zombies or attacks. You can also run and then slide, which is pretty neat.
The new and improved UI. Thew UI is extremely well made and never ever gets in the way. If it somehow does, then you made it to big. Which this perfectly segways into
This game is extremely customizable. Which is awesome. If you don't agree with the games default settings, you can change that! 
Skills. They are an ok addition, I never thought it was the greatest addition, but its something to take note of and advantage of.
Swapping to different items. It is as simple as pressing the buttons d-pad. Left and right for weapons and ordinances for up and down. For healing items they are solely dedicated to the right bumper, which is neat.

But besides all of this there is unfortunately some bad

The bab stuff-
Exploration, there is some exploration. But you can definitely tell it has taken a step back.
This game is LLLLOOOOONNNNNGGGG. I have only beaten Leon's story and it took 8 hours. This game is beefy and if you don't like long games then, oh boy.
It doesn't really tell you how to play the game. This game isn't the greatest teacher, so I recommend a guide or you can figure it out how to play the game yourself. I guess.
No spooks :( I can't really say much about this, this game is honestly just a playable action film where you just blast thousands of zombies. 
Its just shooting zombies. I can't really say much about the gameplay either, its just, blasting zombies for hours on end. Not saying thats necessarily bad. It's just, I can see that getting boring, and then people dropping the game.
The characters. Besides the original characters, they are unfortunately very forgettable. I forgot Helena's name for the majority of Leon's story.
Wait what was the story again? I didn't really pay attention to the story. Like, at all. I could not tell you a second about it. And that is because i did not take this game seriously at all. I don't know why this RE game specifically makes me not take it seriously.  Maybe it is because I had some of my friends watch me play and said their opinions about the game while I was playing it. Or I think its silly that Leon has been blasting zombies and monsters for the past who knows how long, and is still doing it. Or all of my friends making Ashley jokes just to spite me. Who really knows.

But besides all of this, I can only recommend one more thing. Please play with a friend. It will make this game so much better and more enjoyable to have a friend tag along on you're silly quest to shoot zombies from different parts of the world.
Also wait for a Steam sale or a price drop. 
Thats all.
