This game is consistently maligned by most RE fans, and I get it. At the time, it represented the bloated action approach that really took the game far away from what most loved about the original RE. That said, today, with those "expectations" taken out of the equation, I personally think it's a flawed kind of awesome. I love this game. 

I played it on the PS3 years ago when it came out and enjoyed the hell out of it then, too, so after finishing the decent RE 8, I was feeling nostalgic and interested to see how this held up on PC, and I plowed through the entire game again. And once again, I had a great time. 

The creatures/monsters in this game are just fantastic from a design perspective. Some of the best, most varied in the entire series. Truly creative work done here, and it keeps things constantly fresh. The graphics still hold up in 2021 for the most part. Textures are generally crisp and beautiful and it was such a huge step up to play this in 4K from what I remembered on the PS3. 

The four interwoven campaigns was a really interesting approach, and it worked well for the most part, although there were certainly times where it didn't. But the voice acting was generally great (even though the script was not), the action was nonstop (which I know some don't want in a RE game), and the combat was addictive, at least for me. The Leon campaign was especially fun with it's zombie apocalypse setting, but once you get to China and fight those bastards, that was great as well. And watching Ada Wong crawl through tiny corridors on all fours in tight leather pants? Well done, Capcom. Well done. 

I appreciate games that fail because they try too hard vs. games that fail because devs are lazy or greedy or just plain incompetent, and this game is definitely the former. They put an incredible amount of effort into this game to really take the franchise to another level. Sometimes they succeeded wildly. Other times, they failed miserably. 

The skill tree system, for example, is terrible. It takes a ridiculous amount of skill points to level up certain areas, like firearms or defense, so I spent the entire playthrough just concentrating on accumulating enough skill points to raise those. If you were going to play through the campaign multiple times, I guess the system would allow you to explore other skills, but I had no interest in doing that, despite enjoying myself immensely. 

The cover system is also horrible and incredibly awkward. If the could've gotten that down, it would've added a lot to the gameplay, especially in the Chris and Ada campaigns. I did like the new inventory system as far as health tablets go. But the inventory system when changing weapons was terrible. You just have to scroll through your weapons cache, and it's time-consuming and frustrating during a fight. There should've been ways to map certain weapons to specific buttons on the controller. The co-op AI is a step up from RE5, but still not good. I play this single-player, so I was very happy when the Ada Wong campaign allowed me to not have to rely on an AI partner who basically does nothing to really  help you. 

All that said, though, something about this game still manages to really shine through and just be a fun, fun game overall. There's a lot of variety, too, from turret sections to car chases, helicopter battles, fighter jet attacks on an aircraft carrier, etc. I loved it. 

So, despite the flaws, I think this game is a strong entry in the RE collection. It's not going to unseat RE4 for me or even the recent RE2 remake, but I'd put it right alongside, and probably a bit above, RE5 as my third favorite in the franchise after the first. It's really a remarkable achievement in many, many ways. A balls-out approach to game-making where the devs took a ton of chances, some of which failed, but many of which succeeded wildly. Absolutely does not deserve its bad reputation.

This game is a lot better than I thought it would be. Based on what I heard other Resident Evil fans saying over the years, I thought this game would be awful. But I have to say that I enjoyed RE6 more than RE5.

The most pleasant surprise was the length of the game. I thought each campaign would be a lot shorter, but all 4 campaigns are lengthy. However, the game's long length can also be counted as a downside simply because the game has inconsistent quality. Some portions of the game were very memorable and fun, while some portions were quite dull. The game really shined when it wasn't just all about running, having something explode, having the ground fall out from under you, etc. And while there are elements in this game that fans of the classic RE games should enjoy, they feel more like greatest hits being performed by a cover band.

I do prefer the atmosphere and pace of classic Resident Evil games, where you have a lot of slower pace areas to build tension - which results in bigger payoffs when you reach the action-packed sequences. I always loved the relief I felt when I reached a save room with it's calming yet melancholic music. And while those save rooms offered relief, players would also feel dread about what was to come after they left the save room. That feeling is gone in games like RE5 and RE6. 

I do have to give two big thumbs up to the combat in RE6. I wasn't even aware how good it actually was until about 10 hours into the game (due to the lack of tutorials). Not only can we finally move while shooting, but we can do quick-shots, and dodge rolls where we can either choose to stay on our feet or lay on the ground and fire at enemies from there.

You can definitely tell the parts of the game where they cut corners and rushed. The game has plenty of janky crap going on, with numerous cheap deaths and such. And Capcom simply didn't offer enough of what Resident Evil fans like me really enjoy, which are challenging puzzles and environments that are fun to explore and interact with. Instead, the majority of this game consists of one corridor after another without much exploring to be done or interactive elements to be found.

The story is forgettable. I liked Jake and Sherry's campaign the most, because I thought that their characters had great chemistry. [spoiler]Although Wesker having a son sounds like some dumb fan fiction type stuff. And I find the story of Ben making a clone of Ada to be ridiculous and pathetic.[/spoiler]

I could tell that this would have been a much more fun experience if I had a co-op partner to play with. And the Agent Hunt mode sounds really fun too. But alas, I was only able to play solo on the campaigns and the Mercenaries mode. But at least they improved on the AI partner system from RE5 by simply making it so that you don't have to worry about your AI partner dying.

Overall, I would give this game a solid 7 out of 10.

I like to have fun

Resident Evil 6 is an over the top mess, Everything explodes, there's over the top action sequences, turret sections, chase sequences, all the stuff that makes an early 2010's action game. With that being said, there's absolutely fun to be had here. 

If you're like me and was playing this for the Resident Evil story of it, you'll likely be disapointed. There's nothing here that really effects the overall story of any other games and has quite a few one-off characters. But as a game, this is a really fun time for *MOST* of the playtime. 

Leon's Campaign: 

Leon's Campaign is the most resembilant of past Resident Evil titles, relating to RE 4 & RE 5. Helena is a pretty good character but getting stringed along by her in the beginning is pretty frustrating. The action sequences are pretty well done and his combat is great. The hand to hand combat was super fun and intuiative, and helped me save ammo. The boss battles are pretty good and don't drag on. Hunnigan returning is also super fun. Overall this was my favorite campaign

Chris's Campaign:

Chris's campaign is the most action heavy one, but ironically I had the most fun with this one. All the characters in this campaign are super likable and the combat is once again well done. All the different weapons are pretty good too. Some sections of this campaign drag on a bit, such as the car turret section. The boss battles are pretty good too and Piers is a super likable character. Overall this was my second favorite.

Jake's Campaign:

While Jake's campaign doesn't have the most action seqments, it has the worst ones imo. Having to replay sections from Chris and Leon's campaigns was annoying as hell and the snow mobile section is just bad. Jake as a character is unlikable at the beginning but slowly becomes better. Also Sherry being back after so long is really cool. She's great in this. Overall my third favorite. 

Ada's Capmaign:

I didn't play the full campaign. I played the first two chapters and was bored as hell and took to YouTube to finish the story and watch the cutscenes. My part of this campaign was boring as fuck and so slow compared to the "go go go" fast nature of the other campaigns. Overall my least favorite. 

Overall, there's fun to be had here, but 20% of this game could've easily been cut. The combat system is so fun. but sadly is under used. 

Don't play this as your first Resident Evil. It's the only of its kind and is very different than the rest of the series. Fun as a guilty pleasure.

To preface, I am a fan of classic RE. I've been playing it since I was seven years old (24 now), starting on my friend's Sega Saturn. I can't tell you how many times I've played that original bunch of games; probably numbers in the hundreds, and across many copies and platforms. So, as you would expect, like many I used to loathe Resident Evil 6. It was only good to me as a part of my collection. And I thought that this would never change, and that the resentment I held toward it would only grow with time. But, it didn't. Maybe it's because RE has finally started to return to its roots in recent years or perhaps I'm no longer the cynical teenager that I once was or both, but I can honestly say that I have grown fond of RE6 over time, to the point where it's one of the games I reach for when I'm having a bad day. It's by no means one of my favorite entries in the series and it still has plenty of issues, but I choose more often than not to see the good in RE6 now rather than the bad. As a guy who finds Resident Evils 4 and 5 relatively boring affairs past a certain point, RE6 always manages to keep me entertained for hours on end. Yes, it's loud, bombastic, ridiculous and downright bullshit in places, but that's all stuff I've come to expect from this franchise at this point and I can't say I'm ever bored when playing it. No campaign overstays its welcome and they provide enough variety from each other to warrant multiple playthroughs. And say what you will about the gameplay, but I think RE6 may provide some of the best characterization in the whole series. This game is also quite beautiful for 2012, and runs rather smoothly as well. I guess what I'm trying to say is this: If you are expecting Resident Evil 6 to deliver the same chills and thrills as the originals, you'll be disappointed. But if you can appreciate this game for what it is for just a moment, I think you'll have a quite a bit of fun with it. Especially if you bring a friend a long.

--Sincerely, a fellow fan.

I tried my best to like this game. Despite the glaring flaws, I almost recommended this one, but the downsides just kept coming. 

Gameplay wise, RE6 is a pretty big improvement over the last one. This is the part that’s confusing to me, as RE5 gets better reviews overall compared to RE6. I’m here to tell you now that both games are abysmal, but RE6 is the clear winner when you compare the two in a vacuum. The gameplay in 6 is much more fluid than in the last. The QTE sequences still suck, but in general the game is more fun than it’s immediate predecessor, and feels more true to the series.

Graphics are way better too. Of course, you expect the graphics to improve with time, but the art direction of RE5 was absolute trash, and RE6 brings back the traditional RE “feel” with dark, urban environments that look pretty good even 8 years later. 

Controls are still bad, but again, it’s an improvement over the last one.

Story- In RE6 there’s yet another variation of the virus causing chaos. If you thought that ouroboros from RE5 was lame, you’re in for a treat. The first campaign in RE6 (there's 4 in total, all focusing on a different protagonist) culminates in the player facing off against a transforming T-Rex / dog / giant fly monster. The story is comically bad and the monsters are somehow even more lame. Maybe it’s just not made for western audiences at this point, or maybe it’s only made to appeal to children these days, I don’t know… but god, the story is just awful.

At this point the RE team has not only embraced the cheesy-ness of the series, they’ve tripled-down. It seems like they legitimately believe that people enjoy the terrible storytelling and lame twists that have become standard for the franchise.

I’m only playing through these so that I can get to Village, but unless you’re a masochist like I am, you’re going to be better off spending 5 minutes reading the story synopsis on wiki rather than purchasing this and playing it through. In fact, that’s what I had to do after playing through 2 out of 4 of the campaigns in this one. Life is too short to suffer through trash games.

Playing this game made me laugh and cry.

- The cheesy dialogue made me giggle.
- Some of the action sequences are just so ridiculous and over the top, you can't help but laugh in sheer disbelief.
- Redundant QTE that lead to cheap deaths and retries = a lot of frustration.
- Co-op is non-existent in Ada's campaign - You can't even open doors or pull levers!
- Michael Bay would be proud of the amount of explosions in this game.
- So much plot armour! Characters defying death and fatal injuries at every corner, making them seem invincible.
- Clunky controls.
- The camera angles changing in the middle of a chase or escape sequence makes for a disorientating experience - This game tries too hard to be like a cool action movie.
- It lacks the atmosphere and pacing that other RE games excelled in. 
- Badly written characters that were created for the sake of co-op, but they get killed off or are never featured again. The 'Agent' co-op character in Ada's campaign isn't even in the cut scenes, he may as well have been a ghost following Ada around.
- This game hurt my brain. But not in a good way.

Wow. I never thought I would give a Resident Evil game a negative review. I never thought I would be so happy to finish a Resident Evil game, either. I don't know quite where to start, so I'll just say that this unfortunate entry into an otherwise excellent series is incredibly boring, clunky, and utterly devoid of character. I can't say I cared anything at all for the new characters (Helena, Jake or Piers), or for the new stories of the old ones (Leon, Chris, Ada, or even Sherry). None of them had anywhere near enough personality to make themselves worth caring about; very few good one-liners, little interesting character interaction, and...well, I don't really know how to put it, but after watching the characters perform Dumb Impossible Stunt #28 like it was nothing, I just stopped caring. This is the Michael Bay film of Resident Evil.

The game is just non-stop dumb action, but while it was endearing in games like RE5 and, most especially, 3 and 4, here...it's too much. REmake 2 (kinda-sorta), REmake 3, 4, 5 and 8, despite being heavily action-based rather than horror-based, were stellar games because Leon, Claire, Jill, Ethan and Chris were genuinely interesting, fun and often funny characters who, despite being over-the-top action heroes, still kept the games worthy of continued playtime through sheer enjoyability, thanks to their depth and charm. Here, those elements are gone, replaced with nothing but mind-numbing nothingness. RE6 tries to be too many things at once, and fails spectacularly at almost all of them: it's not witty and cool like RE4, it's not grounded like RE2 and 3, it's not a good balance of wacky and entertaining, like 5, and it's CERTAINLY nothing like 8, IMO the best of all of them. Quick-time events are atrocious; they were bad in RE5, but they are GRATING here.

Pretty much the only things I found worth noting were [spoiler]the death of the President[/spoiler], [spoiler]the scene in the warehouse with all the main characters of the game fighting over Ada Wong[/spoiler], and the [spoiler]surprise 'virus bomb' that hits later on in the game[/spoiler]. The controls were somehow worse than RE5, to the point where you can't even manage your AI partner's inventory, for some reason. Inventory management was MUCH worse, removing the easy-to-use grid system and implementing a slider...a f*cking SLIDER. Why?! The only improvement was being able to fire while moving, and that's it. An unfortunate tragedy my time with RE6 was, though at least I can happily say that I will not be playing the game again.

Edit: I played the game again. F*ck this game. F*ck this game. F*ck this f*cking game. F*CK THIS GAME. HOLY SH*T. WORST F*CKING GAME I'VE PLAYED IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. I don't understand. RE5 was stupid, but still enjoyable. This is nothing. I...oh, my god...no words, just no words. I thought RE7 was just OK...I think 1000X more highly of it now, Thank god for RE7, at least it got us away from this f*cking bullsh*t. How this was created, I'll never know or understand. Dumbest bullsh*t I've ever experienced. -100000/10. Don't even play it for fun. Skip entirely if you want to play the entire RE series. I simply could not believe how braindead this sh*t was. F*CK. RESIDENT. EVIL. 6. FOREVER. And f*ck Steam censorship for neutering my f*cking review, you f*cking f*ckwads.

A fun Resident Evil experience. If you enjoyed RE5's Co-Op mode, you'll love this one too. It's lacking in the story department, but the gameplay makes up for it a lot. Chris's scenario is really good. Other than that, I'd recommend doing Ada's story solo since it's insanely worse if you do it through Co-Op, since it was tailored to be a single player scenario in the first place.

Resident Evil 6 is unlike any other Resident Evil game I've ever played. RE games are usually all about survival horror, managing your supplies, ammo and being careful about not spending it all on one section of enemies. However, this game stands out from the other games in the sense that there is no survival horror whatsoever, but rather just pure action. I found myself laughing countless times at how cheesy the dialogue and everything happening story-wise was. It's a good game, don't get me wrong on that, but it simply doesn't feel like a Resident Evil game due to being unlike any other game in the franchise in terms of it's theme. Would I recommend this game? Sure, but definitely not at full price. Don't take the story seriously, and definitely play with a friend to make the most of how fun, cheesy and over the top the game is. I can assure you, you're gonna be laughing your a** off.

Each of RE 6 campaigns tries for a different feel, but overall they're all the same arcadey shooter zombie game. The shooting gameplay is at its best in RE6, but the story is absolute nonsense from start to finish, and really adds nothing to the franchise as it just keeps throwing the same loops where nothing is ever resolved and characters keep doing the same mistakes over and over again.

At least the coop gameplay is good and the horde mode is amazing...

It is really, really hard for me to give this game a fair review. There are mostly two major viewpoints fore RE6. First, it is trash to most hardcore resident evil fans and second, it is really nice adventure action game for non-fan gamers. To say the truth, both ones are correct and true. From old fan perspective it is no more resident evil game, there are no more horror and survival mechanics, which used to be a main focus in classic RE trilogy games. For new players, RE6 is another AAA action game which is good, but not that good to be addictive and likeable like Dying Light or Dead island. Story is simple and straightforward, it is only important for RE lore fans. if you are looking for magnificent storytelling it is not the game you should buy. But, sometimes it's so unusual and exotic, its funny and hilarious in a good way. For example, you are fighting dinosaur like B.O.W monster and then the same monster turns into a big friking mosquito (like wtf, how the hell it is connected to each other). Gameplay isn't too deep as well, but again, it is fun to play. You get massive satisfaction by killing hundreds of thousands of enemies. 

Who should I recommend this game? - to absolutely everyone. As a die hard Re fan, I looked very skeptically at first, but as it finally turned out, RE6 is very fun to play. Is it game bad, which gives you fun? No, it isn't. Just try and embrace massive content which game holds for you. There is something for everyone (no, it is not an IGN joke).
The worst mainline resident evil by miles.

I played this game on launch day on the PS3 back then for almost 100+ hrs. There's a reason why I bought this game again on PC so here are my honest thoughts on Resident Evil 6.

The game would've had less flak if it doesn't have 'Resident Evil' in its name. The bad stuff I can point out on the game is the tedious quick-time events which lead to cheap deaths, sometimes unforgiving enemy damage & the lack of horror. But at the same time the game does a really good job on having an interesting story throughout 4 different campaigns & how well they intersect each other so kudos to the devs for executing this so well. The story is easy to follow so newcomers won't have a hard time catching up. The battle system can be difficult to pick up in the beginning but once you get used to it (especially the melee system), it will get more interesting later on. The campaigns have insane replay value so you might catch yourself playing them again possibly on a higher difficulty. Also, The Mercenaries mode is really fun.

Give this game a chance if you can!

This game is "underrated" in the sense that people act like it's a complete travesty that pales in comparison to other games in the series. In reality it's not far off from RE4 and RE5, and many of the things people complain about here... combat focus, linearity, lack of puzzles, silly story, QTEs... also apply to those games, which have much better reputations.

That said, RE6 is a bit worse mostly because of small annoyances that add up quickly. Enemies are super tanky, your partner AI will often fight when it should run or help you, endless waves of enemies become tedious and weird level design can often confuse or lead to ambushes of trial and error death. The Leon campaign is by far the best and has the least of these issues, to the point where I'd roughly compare it to RE5, but the others suffer so many cuts they bleed out into annoyance way more than fun.

That said, if you're a big RE fan and really loved RE4 and RE5 then I'd say you'll probably enjoy this more than people say you would. The Leon campaign has a decent story that doesn't truly need the others to make sense, and it has the best gameplay. If you're into the series you should at least play that.

For a general audience in 2021 though, this is not a good game and should be ignored.

Resident Evil 6: A Tale of Two Wongs.

Two Wongs don't make it white but that does not keep Capcom from trying. The first story is that of Leon and Helena. Leon helps Helena through her sister complex by helping her kill her sister. The second story is about Chris Redfield a gay military man who reminisces about his past loves while chasing that elusive disappearing snake. When he finds his true love Piers, his partner and is ready to give up the disappearing snake, Piers dies on an underwater base. I am not sure what type of metaphor Capcom was going for there. The third story was Jake and Sherry. Sherry helps Jake beat his heroin addiction by forcing him to run from mutants and people that are trying to shoot him. This unorthodox method works as at the end of the story he is doing what most former junkies do. Ride a motorcycle at top speed down a desert highway. The last story is Ada. Ada is a twenty something Caucasian cos-player who thinks she is the international Chinese spy Ada Wong from the Resident Evil movies and games. Of course she looks too young and white but that doesn't stop her from being obnoxious and having a whole bunch of people shoot at her. I think the real Ada Wong cos-plays as the cos-player and gets her killed at some point. This plot point was too meta for the west so it was left unexplained by Capcom.

Os Resident Evil 4, 5 e 6 são jogos que tiveram uma revolução de jogabilidade, ao comparar com seus antecessores e, também, sucessores.
O Resident Evil 6 é aquele com a melhor mecânica de jogabilidade: muito fluído, com diversos comandos de ação que se encaixam redondinhos para sua proposta.
O seu modo mercenário, até o momento, é aquele que mais gosto e até hoje não cansei de jogá-lo.

Em contrapartida, ele perdeu sua essência de Terror Resident Evil.
A sua história segue uma boa continuidade ao se tratar das armas biológicas, mas sua inovadora e dinâmica jogabilidade fez com grande parte das campanhas virassem histórias de ação; a sua adrenalina sobe mais devido aos constantes e rápidos eventos do que a emanação de terror do ambiente.

This is the worst in the series and one of the worst games I've played. After playing through every mainline RE title, this slog was the last on my list, and unfortunately the longest. It plays itself up too seriously while not having the quality of writing or gameplay to back it up. The pre-existing characters don't feel right and the new ones don't feel like they fit into the game. The writing is hokey but the gameplay is really where it falls on it's face. 

Many times in this game, you'll leave a cutscene to walk a few feet or fire a couple bullets just to be sent directly into another cutscene. The game will constantly take over your camera to make you look at something, veering your character off course. Running past obstacles occasionally results in you flipping a 180 just to jump over the barricade backwards. You are stunned, knocked prone, or set off balance by most hits, allowing you to be hit again. You trip over dead bodies. You can't preemptively shoot some dead bodies which will come to life via the script so bullets will be wasted. To hammer on the script, many sequences in the game will lead you to believe you're supposed to shoot something when in fact, you're just wasting bullets because its a scripted bit. You can't pause the game to change the settings, instead having to do it live. There's a ton more problems I don't feel like going into. 

I know it's 8 years later but jeeze. I can't believe this game has "Very Positive" reviews. It's absolute trash and not even worth a laugh. Honestly, if you're exploring the series for lore, just watch the cutscenes online. That was 20 hours I'll never get back.

P.S. Disgusting of you, Capcom, to sexualize Sherry of all people.

Resident Evil 6 is one-of-a-kind.  Over 200 developers specifically worked on this game, not counting live orchestras, motion and facial capture, full teams for multiple mechanics and minor details.  If I remember correctly at the time this was one of the most expensive games ever produced.  

It is an absolute shitshow.

Graphically all over the place.  Wide open snowy fields, crowded downtown alleys and streets, underground biological research facilities, abandoned east European villages, dungeons and churches, an aircraft carrier, caves.  You're never in the same place for more than two levels in a row, and it really doesn't look that bad.  Main character models are detailed enough and there's some interesting enemy variety (for the most part) at least until you start getting into zombie dinosaurs and "Mutated Derek".  No real complaints here until you realize that almost every segment of these levels is simultaneously too linear and completely cluttered for a free-form style of combat that is completely unusable because of it.

RE6's combat is it's main strength. The biggest problem is that it explains nothing at all.  Did you know taking cover regenerates your stamina almost immediately?  Neither did I for 50 hours.  It doesn't help that there's no clear indication as to what you can and can't take cover on, and that the system for taking cover is unreasonably complicated.  Clearly designed for a controller (the ideal way to play the game, don't even bother with M+KB because you'll be using almost the entirety of the alphabet), you must approach an object and pull the left trigger/right click, then you're locked in cover.  After that the only way to peek out and fire is by using the left stick/WASD in the direction you want to look out at, then use the right stick/mouse to aim, and right trigger/left click to fire.  The *only* reason to take cover in this game is to recover stamina, which is used for ridiculous actions.

Stamina is used for melee and takedowns.  There are contextual melee takedowns, takedowns to steal enemy weapons (and kill them with the weapon if you do a QTE), melee combos that take down multiple enemies contextually, you can stunlock/combo enemies infinitely if you time your hits right.  You can use a Quickshot (L+R trigger/mouse click) which immediately spins your character to the closest enemy with your chosen weapon and fires, stunning them and opening them for a melee takedown.  You can do this multiple times in a row while changing targets, you can do this playing as Jake and literally bounce off of enemies, you can do this as Chris and throw enemies at each other, you can do this as Leon and JUGGLE ENEMIES WITH DUAL PISTOLS LIKE FUCKING DEVIL MAY CRY.  If it wasn't for the clunky cover system and the fact that the level design does not facilitate any of this RE6 would be considering a pretty damn good character action game.

I'm not a Resident Evil fanboy but I'm aware of most of the franchise and characters.  6 is clearly designed as fan service all the way through, which old characters clashing with new constantly.  The problem is that the story is played so straight-faced and so self-serious, with NONE of the previous RE's campy self-awareness, that you objectively can not take this thing serious.  It's so bad it's good, but bad in a good way.  It's a parody of every 7th gen trope smashed into a single package.  It's hard to take anything in this game seriously when you're doing literal midair noscope collateral headshots off cliffs with Chris Redfield, suplexing enemies as Jake, or juggling multiple enemies in midair as Leon.  

I could go on about how RE6 is the best example of "less is more" in a game.  The massive development budget combined with the absolutely insane amount of people who worked on the game obviously crushed any real chance of the unique mechanics being fully fleshed out.  Did I mention that there's like 9 different asymmetrical multiplayer modes?  How about Left 4 Dead 2 cameos?  There's an "Agent Hunt" mode which lets you INVADE OTHER PLAYER'S GAMES AS A REGULAR ENEMY.  Did you play RE1 and think "Wow, I wish I could play as the first zombie you encounter and kill Jill"?  Guess what, you can!  You can play as a slow moving zombie with it's own moveset, unique UI, miserably slow controls coupled with attack animations that take up to 10+ seconds to fully complete.  It's pretty fun jumping into someone else's coop match and killing them as the equivalent of a RE4 villager, and you gain ingame currency for doing so.

This game deserves to be played simply because we will never get another title like it.  It revels in itself, takes itself too seriously, and throws a fat middle finger to the concept of basic gaming mechanics.  What the hell were they thinking?  Buy this shit immediately.

Oh yeah, there's an achievement for playing 10/20/50 levels as a female character too.

I would like to start right away with the plot of the game. The range of events taken and even the distance is longer than in the fourth and fifth parts, but there are still many non-isolated and undisclosed moments. The height was taken decent, but the behavior and general prerequisites did not work out perfectly. But for the sake of fairness, I note that, to the conscience of the developers, there are a large number of videos explaining the general alignment and elaborated aspects of the intersection of the main characters, and also we must not forget about the dynamism and a decent variety of parts of the chronology of the game. The gameplay is also not entirely unambiguous. There are many pluses, the overwhelming majority. Taken on a wide scale and interestingly worked out fighting game, you also have to get used to the specifics of the game and start combining melee and ranged actions. In addition to all this, one must be able to assess the overall situation and plan ahead. But you can count a dozen game flaws of which, half of which can seriously affect the game. In addition, such negative negative situations with an unpleasant sight on the part of the characters. Which is just disgusting. And of course the developers fanatically cannot move away from their idea with the seemingly endless resurrection of bosses. Sometimes it looks extremely boring and extremely unreasonable. Chris Redfield's battle with the giant B.O.O. at the end of the company, it could enter the top for irrationality and exhausting. When you need to run for about 15 minutes and wait for the right moment due to the lack of ammunition. The latter, by the way, is also a separate topic during the first playthrough, but in most cases it is not fatal. The visual design is very diverse, it seems that it was created by means of graphic elements of different generations. Why an impression? This is true. If the beginning is reflected by exponential detail and color. In the second chapter, it drops in places to the level of Resident Evil 4. All this is in the system of versions of both games. Many graphic elements are clearly from the first half of the 2000s. But the videos are very effective, I must admit. However, in certain chapters, there is again a high contrast and variety of structure in the environment. The characters are very well worked out. Leon Kennedy is still the most stylish hero in the gaming industry. And the figures of the female protagonists are mesmerizing. In terms of sound equipment, there is harmony and everything falls into those notes. Starting with the manifestation of the sound of weapons and ending with professional dialogues. The background music is used in the additional content and fits quite thematically.
Bottom line. Plot - 7.5. Gameplay - 7.5. Graphics - 7.5. Sound - 9. Average rating 7.8.

One of the best resident evil games

Leon's campaign was tolerable, specially when played Co-Op (though I'm sure a lot of the fun there was unintentional), it sure lacks the charm and polish that was present in RE4, but it was at times fairly entertaining and varied, the levels sure lack the creativity and energy present in that game, often frustratingly relying in gimmicky sections instead of finding compelling ways to best utilize its decent sandbox. 
Speaking of which, I think the best part about RE6 is its foundation. Once you get past the fact that they completely abandoned the RE4&5 formula, the base mechanics are, while clunky at first, quite a lot of fun, it's oddly satisfying once you get the hang of them, it's clear that Capcom put a ton of time into refining the specific contextual animations, even if some of the hit registration and target selection is shoddy. 
Enemy design is a massive downgrade, they are all bullet sponges and lack their resposiveness and fun unique interactions present in the prior over-the-shoulder RE games. You'll be begging for more variety until you actually get to fight the other Zombie types.

Overall, my first impressions weren't great, but I was still looking foward to what the rest of the campaigns had to offer, until I found out what the game had in store.

Chris' and Jake's campaign are actual geniune garbage, they are merely generic military cover shooters with 0 inspiration with even more scripted events and QTEs. I have nothing to say about them, I couldn't bring myself to finish them, you'd have to force me into finishing them.

The main problem is not that it's not similar to a certain Resident Evil game that came before, but that it utterly fails at bringing a new compelling direction to the series, specially when RE has no shortage of untapped potential in its old formulas, so to utterly abandon them in favor of CoD sales feels insulting. Resident Evil 4 may play nothing like the old classic games, but it's one of the most commercially successful and critically acclaimed games of all times, it brought (though unfortunately short-lived) a completely new life to the franchise

Such lazy writing. Also, there are so many bugs. The view, movement, and controls are SO BAD for PC. Stressing out for some running parts and failed so many times just because of the shitty controls. Not worth buying except if you buy it from the sale.

Played two campaigns and cannot stand to play any more. Basically, instant kill events suck and they are the only difficult part of the game.

This design is repeated over and over: go through some very easy combat, occasionally the game will yank control of your camera away or shove you into a cutscene to completely disorient you. Typically you will lose 0 health for the entire level. EVERY level ends in a situation where you can be killed instantly either by a QTE or environmental hazard. Example: running from a helicopter across some boats, but the controls constantly get you stuck against walls or vaulting obstacles in the wrong direction, resulting in a game over.

None of the weapon upgrading mechanics from RE5, and instead you collect points to just buff overall damage and other (less useful) things. None of the upgrades matter though, as the QTEs will be the only thing killing you.

And the story is zombies + arguments between edgy fan-service characters.

It is an okayish game. 
Plot is good, I love how Chris acts in this game, as well as his partner. To be honest, I really love the duo Chris-Nivan's story. The opposite goes to Leon's overwhelmingly simping attitude in this game. 
Okay, now the gameplay, Leon's Story shines best in this case, and the opposite goes to the rest. I've played through RE 4 and 5, and am completely fine with shooting people with guns, but it just feels super frustating, annoying and boring against these guys in this game. 
And the item management, I just wish they at least brought RE5's item gameplay back. They removed the gun buying / upgrade shop, they force you to carry every single weapon you've unlocked so you don't have enough spaces to keep much of your favorite ammo type, and takes decade to scroll through the weapons when you need to switch. Meanwhile I could press 1 for a handgun, shoot once, press 3 to quickly use a shotgun and bam in Re 5. The item menu also feels sluggish when you need to discard a thing for space. Big nope. Yeah they added in skills, but their effect is just not that various to entertain me.

TLDR: Good plot, but the way they execute it is terrible. Gameplay is worse than RE 5 imo. Buy it for Chris.

It gets messy when you get to the Ada campaign, it feels so rushed and unfinished and the Co-op in it was added in later so player 2 can't really do anything. Mercs is also in this game. You need to accept the fact that this is not a traditional Resident Evil game but instead a stupid but fun action game. All in all I enjoyed this game.

I've seen a lot of people defend this one recently as the dumb fun one that got a bad wrap. Make no mistake, this is the most agonizing game of all time even after you get a handle on the controls. Stilted and weightless gun-fu is stacked on top of some of gaming's most boring setpieces and boss fights. I went into this one ready to like it as a silly over-the-top action adventure, but I'm not even halfway and I feel like I need an IV drip.

Only the campaign for Leon and Ada somehow make it to a decent level. The rest is just a waste of time. Stupid controls, "shooter" mechanics combined with survival(part of the whole game player walks around without ammo), the game constantly requires player to run ahead, leave intetesting stuff behind.
I've played all re games, from first to fifth, and I've never encountered a situation where I was left unarmed in scripted section, where player have to beat something. 
Even putting the game into "easy mode" doesn't fix anything.

Resident Evil 6 is the most complete character's stories (unfortunately there's no Jill story) and also all controlling that more realistic than other series. You can crouch, slide, defend with coup de grâce, hide behind table or wall before you shoot enemies, and also the AI will help you more without worrying their health or ammo (if you play offline) so you don't need to struggle by keeping them alive like Sheva on RE 5 or Ashley on RE 4 since you hit all QTE (quick time event) quickly and correctly.

I've been playing this game for a long time, and yeah I must say I love and enjoy it. Extra content is part of the game that makes us want to play this game everyday, especially Mercenaries. So far, Resident Evil 6 has the best mercenaries system in my opinion, supported by advanced controlling system and attack/defend mechanics. Extra content also gives players to choose their main skill, so ether you love to shoot or use physical attacks, you can adjust it just how you like to play the game. All DLC are seriously fun, especially onslaught and predator. But as long as time goes by, well, now online mode has been dead and you won't find any players easily to play together.

Resident Evil 6 has many features that players will like to play, but also there's a thing that makes me struggle to play it. Like I've said, this game has more advanced and complete controlling system, but well, it also makes players getting stress to control characters. If you are a new player from previous franchise like RE 4 or RE 5, yup you will feel uncomfortable by all controls method that RE 6 has, basically when you play campaign mode, you may have to look notice "YOU ARE DEAD' or "MISSION FAILED" for many times just because of it. But if you curious like me, you can learn all controls method slowly until you know how to do and what buttons you should hit every position of camera changes or also when quick time event appears.

My rating for every characters story: 8.5/10
My rating for controlling system: 7/10
My rating for Mercenaries mode: 9.5/10

This game is ... Oh boy. 
[h1]It's the perfect sequel to Resident Evil 5[/h1]
The Campaigns are hilarious; the unbeaten comedy of the decade. It's [i]The Fast and the Furious 7[/i] of the Resident Evil series. Co-op is mandatory. The utter lack of plot stability and complete seriousness of the whole thing make it an absolute joy to play. 

Mercenaries mode is [i]Time Crisis[/i] that you can play in the comfort of your own home without paying for continues. It's the best arcade shooter I've played since Resident Evil 5. It's worth buying this game for this mode alone. 

This game is technically stable, with strong visual design, good music and amazing motion captured cut-scenes. Combat is a smooth 3rd person horde shooter with kill chains and melee combos.

However, the worst enemies in this game are forced camera angles, quick-time events, timed set-pieces, co-op disconnections and the control scheme. [b]DO NOT ALT+TAB IN CO-OP, IT DISCONNECTS YOU![/b]
Menuing is confusing, and the loss of the grid inventory system is sad, but the system is still usable. 

A must-have for any fan of the RE series.
The only reason I would recommend this is because the story of the Chris campaign with Piers Nivans is very good. Other than that the game is hot garbage and a disgrace to the Resident Evil series.

- Zombie shooter game. As an action game, it’s a good game…but as a survival horror game (such as Resident Evil), it’s too action oriented with a very linear map for each campaign.
- Very slow pace for some part of the game, Leon’s first chapter for example. And waiting your partner just to open a door was pretty annoying
- No freedom to explore, just follow the guide and it’s done (sometimes there’s a puzzle to solve, but literally very easy one). The game tells you where to go, where to obtain the key item, etc... 
- Poor camera angle and control, especially during chasing scene. 
- Bad saving mechanic. There’s no manual save, this game using an auto-save and it saves only at the beginning of each chapter. If you quit the game in the middle of the chapter, you have to restart that chapter.
- This game is full of QTE and BUTTON MASHING

Jake & Ada's campaign are broken in Co-op.  If you're not the host in Jake's campaign some run sequences are literally unwinnable. Because there's a weird time delay between the host and player 2 you lose instantly or there's about 0.3 seconds of leeway.  For the part where we were running from the Ustanak in the cave i died 27 times before we found out we had to perfectly sync our framerates and vsync settings and match speeds to get past it. The next level, where you run from a tank was completely impossible and i'd get run over instantly no matter what i did. Your only choice is to replay it on single player. 


In Ada's campaign, if you play co-op player 2 can't interact with or help with any of the puzzles or story items. She has a grappling hook they were too lazy to implement for player 2 so you just teleport. There's a part where you fall through the floor and ada has to crawl away from saw blades that my host kept instantly dying at for no reason, just like my tank experience.

I wanted to believe that I had better things to be doing with my time than reminisce about the brain cells I wasted years ago, slogging through this Gerrard Butler-ass Netflix Special focus group abortion. I wanted to believe a lot of things.

Please, I implore you to waste your money and time on Resident Evil 6 so that you will know my folly and indignant piss.

Y'all want the god honest opinion i got you .... take 7.49 $(or whatever it's worth after the sale is over) and instead of buying this game go getchu a cheap hooker to give you the clap and once you have that start biting people .......it would be a more fun "zombie experience" then this abomination to the RE name. There's 4 campaigns i am through 2 and i feel like i'm Micheal J Fox and my parkinson's is acting up..... like ya boi legit has spaghetti for hands in every other RE you get something to either help ya aim or a steady red dot sight cause you know everybody is a trained solider..... not a person picking up a fire arm for the first time in their life. I would however forgive the more intense enemy placement if they gave you the bullets or teammates to match in the second campaign ( chris redfields) i've resorted to not fighting anything until i have to and it forces you often. 
        They have a garbage pail leveling system. In which they give you 50 experience points in some drops and 100 in other drops most of the upgrades you would want are 20k and above. the worst part about it is you can't spend Skill points in game you have to  end the chapter or quit out...... the worst part about this system is that it makes most of the drops the piss puddle of points instead of ammo , heals or anything of use. This makes the game hard ....for no reason... by the way the skill point upgrades feel like they do nothing. They recycle cut scenes cause the end of each characters campaign i guess they just meet up or whatever. 
        The game looks fine for an early 2010 until you look at the muddy pixelated walls....they look awful and so does the skybox background of the china level(don't actually know but it said china at some point so i assume thats where we are). for context when i play RE5 on the comp or even on a ps3 or 360 it looks vastly better ....that was made during the same gen HOW DO YOU GET IT WRONG LITERALLY JUST COPY AND PASTE IF YOU SUCK AT MAKING LEVEL. 
       With that being said the last thing i want to touch on is the absolute nonsense this game goes through it throws "zombies with guns" at you way to much and it turns this game more into a 3rd person COD then an RE game. The feel of RE is lost and honestly makes for a sour experience.....

In Short i give the game a 4/10 it's a game sure it functions sure..... it has a structure sure...... but it's like the guy who goes tango dancing and instead of actually dancing he falls hits the waiter and the bottle of 1934 wine on his tray flies right into your dates neck and kills her. Is it a great game? Probably not. Was it the right direction for the series? No. Do I respect the hell out of it for being the most actiony, explodoningy, soap opera drenched, apologetically over-the-top entry in the series? You betcha.

The game isn't perfect. Some chapters are leagues better than others, and the controls manage to be both clunky but also...kinda nice? Like, the movement options in this game is impressive. Pulling off [i]coup de grace[i] is fun as hell. (I've always been a sucker for the post RE4 melee attacks as they feel so...satisfying.) Taking cover sucks ass though. The story is absolutely, almost comically dramatic and it seems like they just kept adding more explosions to spice it up and you either love it or hate it.

All in all, not a bad game at all. Weaker entry in the series, but you get quite a bit of content for what you pay for these days. It's not all great, but it ain't as bad as everyone remembers.

i just wanna start off the bat and say this is one of my favorite resident evil games. my 1# is RE8 and 2nd is RE2 remake. i've played RE7 and RE4 so im here to tell you if this is a good game. now i wanna say if you are a hardcore RE fan, this is not for you, this game still has viruses, zombies and all the wacky fun a resident evil game can have. but this is probably the most action Resident evil game from the franchise because while somewhat has horror elements, its not focused on it. this game just goes nuts to butts with the action which was really fun. another bonus is that you get to play as four main characters, Leon, jake, chris and Ada. leon of course was a blast, chris as well, havent done jake or ada. while i dont think this game has the best plot, its still good and keeps you entertained as you go through this action filled game. i would 100% recommend this for anyone who just wants a fun action zombie game, 9/10

This is the game that made me never trust the "general consensus" ever again. 

It is no exaggeration when I say that I believe the hatred for this game is in fact an observable case of mass hysteria.

The only olive branch I will offer is I understand that classic RE1 fans were likely quite upset that this game is the ultimate departure from its roots, and it is likely that dissatisfaction that incandesced the bandwagon of hatred for this game.

With that out of the way, regardless of expectation it is insanity to imply that RE6 is bad, let alone terrible as most people imply, I can fully see why someone might dislike it, but I think it is impossible to call it objectively bad. 

Why am I writing this? Because I have seen so many people call this game bad, and then when I ask them what they think about the slide tackle reversal they answer: "The what?"

That's right, RE6 has probably some of most in-depth movement systems of ANY over the shoulder shooter on the market, this is a TEN year old game at the time of writing and I cannot think of a single game that comes close. And though the game doesn't teach you it, and you can beat the game without using much of it. 

You can duck, you can roll in all directions, you can slide tackle off a sprint, you can REVERSE that slide tackle to face the way you came. You can choose to stay on the ground, from which you can roll left or right, or jut back and forth, as well as crawl, you can however stand instantly instead. You can shoot while sliding, reverse sliding, while on your back.

These aren't even all the moves, there's way more, I'm not going to drone on, though, you get the point.

What matters is that this system exists, now, I know that's not enough to make a game good. That's where the: Shooting, Enemy Design, Level Design, Quick Shot and Melee come into play.

All these mechanics mentioned above are a balanced gestalt of gameplay. They complement and layer each other near flawlessly. 

The shooting is well tuned and satisfying

The enemies are interactive and varied in many ways from having objects you can shoot on(or off) them, weak spots, unique mechanics with the player/melee system/terrain and all kinda of insanity I won't spoil.

The Level Design promotes using the movement system by having hazards, shortcuts, holes you can slide trough or objects you can vault over.

Quick shot allows you to instantly fire your weapon accurately at the nearest enemy, every weapon has a unique animation for this, effectively serving as the third layer of combat.

Melee allows you to preform environment-aware attacks of opportunity to staggered or otherwise available enemies. This fourth layer of combat ties all the other mechanics together, there are so many of these. Throwing enemies off ledges, pulling their feet while you're below them so they hit their head on the edge, or dropping down on them and push their head to the ground, or slam them into a railing, or a wall. Or snap their neck from behind. Or PARRY them, take their weapon, use them against them.  FLIP a zombie that is LEAPING AT YOU and STOMP on them.

Calling RE6 just an over the shoulder shooter isn't quite enough, it's very nearly an over the shoulder shooter/fighter.

[Did I mention every single character has a unique melee moveset?]

So that's my argument for the gameplay and why you should play it.

Is the story amazing? No... But I thought it was good, campy, but touching at times. Fun

The environments are varied and fun, the pacing is good.

The amount of content is good, Co-op is an amazing way to play this game

Is it scary? No, but it IS fun. 

Give it an honest try. USE the movement system, you'll not find another like it for a long time.

Don't give in to the hate.

I played this initially on Xbox360, and now I'm playing it here; I don't regret having purchased it twice. This game is one of my favorite REs, CAPCOM really outdid themselves with the four campaigns and the mercenaries mode on this one; it is truly a surprising milestone, considering its predecessors were RE4 and RE5. If you haven't already done so, go ahead and buy this game; rest assured, you will not regret it.

If you are playing through the RE series and this is your next game all I have to say is good luck, however if you are interested in playing this game for what ever reason save your money.

This game is a mess, the story is clunky and boring, the controls are awful and are possibly one of the worst in   any triple A game, the overall gameplay itself is by far the worst in this franchise and no matter what i did the game is so dark meaning i couldn't see anything for most of the game even in brightly lit outdoor areas.

The game presents you with 4 separate and different campaigns that all weave between the same narrative which in concept is a pretty cool idea as it allows you to see the same story from different perspectives and means that you can play as more fan favorite characters, however in RE6 case it means that story feels bloated and moments are contrived just so that characters can meet and tease their own storyline. This also means that each campaign has different play styles ranging from average to god awful and once you have played one campaign you know the overall story with one interesting twist added into the final half of the final campaign.

The controls and gameplay are also awful as sometimes you may press a button and either the input isn't registered or it does something completely different, the amount of times i have opened the menu when i pressed reload during a boss fight and have died as a result is ridiculous, there are also many instances where ill die even though ill be on full health because ill be grabbed by one enemy and thrown into another enemy who will grab me and then im grabbed during the previous animation and so on until i lose all my health, and the checkpoints don't always work so you could be put back to where you were 20 minutes ago. There is also an ungodly amount of screen tearing during every pre rendered cut scene making some moments nauseating to watch.

Don't pick this up unless you are playing through the RE games but even then I doubt this game will be a fun experience.

4/10

I convinced a dear friend of mine to do a completion run of this game with me. It's a beautiful INCREDIBLY buggy and stupid mess that I genuinely treasure. Don't play solo- bring a equally foolish friend along for the ride.
Campaign greatness :
[b]1. Sherry and Jake.[/b] Easily the best one. Their mechanics are fun, the chemistry they create is believable. Jake as a really O.P mercenary suits the 'cool-line jokester' leagues better then Leon in this game. Leons feel forced, where Jake feels like a cocky prick. And that's perfect- he is. Some of their story is aggravating though: the snow sequence makes you wanna pull your hair out all the way until the end, and Jakes emotions kinda don't make sense. Spoilers here -- > [spoiler]Jake doesn't know his dad is Wesker (also, like, when did he even get the baby shot in? Wesker ain't the one-night screw y'know?)but agrees to help Sherry for money since they need his blood. He implores that he doesn't like/want to know his father, that he doesn't want to be like him or what he did. Then Chris rolls around with Piers and admits he killed Wesker, and Jake gets all uppity about it? It doesn't make sense to me, but it's cool anyways.[/spoiler] Anyways, screw the story. Do Jake/Sherry first it's so much fun.
[b]2. Leon and Helena.[/b] The beef of the story for this game, as is obvious. They grow the desire to slap them both outside the back of the head and move on. If I didn't play this with a good friend where we could goof off, it'd be annoying. But with a friend, it's just stupid hilarity we can enjoy together. Like the lovestory triangle with Helena being a voyeur. It's lovingly buggy and clearly unpolished, but at this point I find it endearing. You couldn't count the amount of times they should be dead on four sets of hands. We tried. They should be dead chief.  The reason they're not my favorite is, as I stated with Jake, Leon has his typical one liners like from RE4. They're just INCREDIBLY FORCED. Like he's giving a punch line to a really long joke and the entire crowd is just crickets levels of forced. The friggin' intro sequence they both pull their guns on a mysterious figure, he cocks a eyebrow and just says "So, back for more?" and I wanna scream. They just squabbled what they could of a personality from RE4 and slapped it into his entire story. Helena isn't any better either- friggin' sis con for the MAJORITY of her story. I get it, worry about your sister, that's family. But it's just SO. MUCH. There are a few glitchy moments that really grate my gears, namely the segment at the end [spoiler] where Simmons becomes this crazy four-legged beast who shoots like bullets in a circle from his head IDK. At that segment there I kid you not we crashed maybe five different times. And it was PER playthrough. We're still in the process of doing all the game on the hardest difficulties, and each time through we crash at that train part CONSISTENTLY. IDK what it is about it, but it's a nightmare. You can easily get glitched in that spot too : if you shoot Simmons on the roof and then don't run past him? You're fucked.[/spoiler] Anyways, a decent time.
[b]3. Chris and Piers.[/b] Quite painful at times. I'd say it's on par with Leon/Helena story, but eh. It's a bit less fun more focus gameplay. It's very strictly not puzzles, it's a active shooter. Which is fine. The controls are kind of janky and their story is kind of plain. The whole premise is Chris has temporary memory loss since he let his teammates die to [spoiler]the fake Ada replica that Simmons made using his wifes body. Y'know, the usual foe.[/spoiler] Anyways, they all die and he represses the memory. Piers rolls up, calls him a wuss, and basically drags him back to the military still with memory loss. He retains his physical memory and just brings a damn pistol and knife. PIERS RUNS A MACHINE GUN AND [b] ANTI-MATERIAL THERMAL SNIPER RIFLE.[/b] Anyway, his team dies again and Chris remembers. The entire rest of the time he seeks revenge, even at the loss of the remainder of his team. Piers just joins him around, making sure he doesn't get himself killed doing stupid things. And they do MANY stupid things. Anyways, they're story is meh, the combat is meh, the ammo drop is CRUEL. It's perhaps one of the more annoying stories, but it's not all bad honestly. 
[b] Ada and Agent.[/b] Here, however, on the other end of the spectrum we have the assitry. People screamed joyously about there being online co-op and then pointed an accusatory finger at Ada's campaign that was strictly solo. So the improvised and added a literally unkillable, unvoiced, unnamed agent that can do nothing but shoot. He cannot open doors, he cannot activate puzzles, he doesn't even get any partaking in the cutscenes. Ada opens a door wide, shuts it, he just appears behind her. Ada grapples up to a balcony and he just MATERIALIZES. Her story is all around the place, which I suppose makes sense cause she's a busy girl and has to interact with all the different stories at some point or another. But her whole situation with Simmons bothers me. Her whole combat system is INFURIATING. Some segments feel far too difficult given other parts of the game. Ada's campaign isn't fun; at best, it's fanservice.

Do I recommend this game? Only if you have a good friend who doesn't take things too seriously. Don't get this game if you're one of those people who does complete achievement hunting. I was skimming the achievements myself and realized I couldn't do a few and the slew of others mostly pertaining to the side hunting jobs were agonizingly not worth my time. Otherwise, decent. A 'get on 50% off sale' kind of game.

RE6 is a pretty good 3rd person horror action game.
However, it is not a very good Resident Evil game. Even though there are nuggets of decent resi story the story arcs and dialogues can be quite poor (which is somewhat faithful to the 'Jill Sandwich' franchise I suppose) and the ridiculous level of explosions and dead "not really dead" bosses is just head shakingly stupid.

In terms of gameplay, sometimes the buttons on controller, occasional camera angle, and flow of combat can be infuriating along with some stupid instant quick time deaths but overall I quite enjoyed the gun play and co-op combat. So think it is worth picking up when on a sale, especially if you can find a friend to play with. The main campaign is around 4 x 5 hours (4 different characters) and it was able to keep my attention long enough to complete them all and even go back for some collectables. So a bit of a mixed bag but overall on the recommended side.

I remember the reviews for this game when it originally came out. I wasn't a fan of RE 5 when I played it with a friend, and the reviews made this game sound truly awful. It's actually not too bad. It definitely has flaws. A ton of them. I wouldn't recommend this as a game to start the series with either. Heck even if you are looking for a multiplayer RE game look at 5 or the Revelations series. This game doesn't deserve the hate it gets though, and it's worth a play through if you're a fan of the bonkers plot.

The biggest flaw in this game is the game play. If you ever played RE 4 or RE 5 and thought to yourself that you would love to play a version that has all of the slow bits taken out and just have combat (sometimes infinitely spawning enemy closet combat) you'll be right at home. There are barely any puzzles in this game. Even when they do show up it would be generous to call them a puzzle. More like momentary diversions before getting back to the shooty shooty bits. Really Ada's play through it the only one I can think of that had puzzles that took more than two minutes. Personally I really missed better puzzles and needing to plan where items need to be used. Those are some of my favorite parts of RE games and it gets kind of exhausting without them. The combat in the game isn't bad. It's very similar to playing RE 5. On higher difficulties it will push you and it would be good to get a human friend to help. On lower difficulties the AI partners are okay enough. The guns all act differently, but only kind of. I mostly just used the same one until I ran out, switched to the next, and just kept repeating that until stuff died. 

The other big thing with this is that it is an ugly game. Really ugly in fact. A lot of the background textures look like old PS3 assets. The movies look good, but the second you are back in a game play section you know. I played on the highest graphics settings and it still looked bad. The environments are so boring that there were a good amount of times I got turned around for no reason. Every angle pretty much looked the same so I just kept running back to the same place over an over again. Pretty annoying. On top of that most of the chapters are stupid long. I could literally clear one of the original PS1 RE games in the time it takes to beat the average RE 6 chapter. There's quite a bit that could be cut from the levels and if some genius modder figures out a way to cut the fluff from this game I bet it would be 1,000% better.

In the long run though the biggest flaw here is the scope they tried to reach with this game. One of those Icarus reaching for the sun kinds of things. I appreciate what they were trying to do here. They were trying to tell an interconnected story like they did with RE2. It almost works. The problem is that they didn't seem to have the time to really flesh it out and having to make SO many separate environments probably set them back a bit too much. I would guess that is why the environments are so ugly and the game play is so stripped down. They just stretched themselves too thin. If they had more time or cut down two of the stories to focus on the main ones it probably would have been much better for it. 

Here I am recommending a game and I've done nothing but whine about it. Here's the thing, I have been playing RE games since '96-'97. I remember the days when RE1 had a very poorly acted live action intro. When the voice acting was barely passable. I loved that stuff. It was SO cheesy that it made this series one of my favorite video game series. When this game came out I remember seeing and reading a bunch of reviews that complained about the plot. It's like people forgot that this is a series where a slug queen hive convinces itself that it is the 80 year old creator of the T virus. A series where the captain of a special forces cop team is also some how a mad scientist as a side gig and just happens to be really into doing all the evil. When I look at the plot of this game next to those things it's really fun. I can see why people don't like it, but really if you just sit back and enjoy it for the shlocky horror/sci-fi/spy weirdness that it is the plot of this game is pretty fun.

If you are a fan of the series this can be worth it. I would wait for a major sale. It's probably the longest game in the series, but full price is still a bit much. If it is ever on sale for like $10-$15 I would say it is worth it. If you don't have patience for weird plots and janky backgrounds maybe give this one a pass and just look up the plot on YouTube or something. I'm glad I played this. It probably sounds like I'm not, but I am.

Esse é difícil, é um jogo legal e tals, mas tem muitos defeitos na minha opinião, e aquele tipo de jogo que quando funciona, funciona bem, mas quando não funciona pqp que pariu.

-O que eu gostei foi do modelo de várias campanhas, tem bastante coisa pra fazer e as campanhas são bem diferenciadas, fora que cada campanha tem 2 personagens jogáveis (tirando a da Ada), não muda muito no geral, mas é o suficiente pra valer a pena rejogar com o outro personagem.

-Os gráficos são bonitos pra época, a jogabilidade é média pra mim, funciona bem até, mas é muito travadona (sei lá se é porque eu joguei no teclado).

-Gostei bastante das armas também, tem até uma variedade boa, e cada personagem tem uma arma que é exclusiva dele.

-Tem um sistema de loot e upgrades também mas nada de excepcional, tem que dar uma farmada mas dá pra coletar moeda o suficiente pra pegar os upgrades importantes em cada campanha.



-A parte ruim foi mais no "balanceamento" do jogo, os inimigos são muito esponja de bala, demora muito pra morrer, mesmo acertando só headshot, isso se o cara não se transformar umas 5 vezes e na última virar um casulo e simplesmente ficar lá paradão, fazendo você perder loot e ter gasto um monte de balas a toa, os inimigos são bem mais rápidos e ágeis que seu personagem, isso cria várias situações onde você leva hit sem nem ter tempo de reagir.

-Talvez isso conte como Spoiler sei lá, mas fica o aviso, porque outro negócio que eu não gostei foram as "boss fights", quase todos os grandes bosses são mortos em cutscene, tu vai la descarrega tudo no cara, ai ele "morre", dali dois capítulos, opa, tinha morrido não, voltei, ai vai lá, "mata" de novo, dali dois capítulos, "olha eu de novo aqui", ai o cara finalmente é morto, em uma cutscene, muito tosco kkk. Os bosses em si são bem legais e bem feitos, mas as lutas são bem meh.

-QTE, QTE a rodo, pqp, nunca vi tanto Quick Time Event na vida, é o pior aspecto desse jogo, e uma das piores coisas já criada no mundo dos jogos lol, claro, não são impossíveis de fazer, dá pra passar tudo de boa, mas exageraram demais na quantidade, fica chato.

Enfim é um jogo legal de jogar, além de barato, mas vai ter aspectos que vão incomodar bastante, aquele tipo de coisa que você fala "meu, quem achou que isso aqui ia ser legal", "quem deixou isso aqui passar no QA", etc, mesmo assim vale a pena, melhor que o 5 pelo menos.

Best way to describe this game is that it's like playing a mashup between RE:4 and RE:5 with incredibly low brightness on your monitor. Combine sheer darkness with a camera that doesn't know where it is supposed to be looking, and you'll be playing a game where you can't see what the bleedin' hell is going on. Mix in an obtuse user interface and you have a recipe for frustration.

It's even more action than horror - or any exploration and adventuring at this point. This has been a progression of the series with has now reached it's nadir. You just have to try and shoot as many zombies as you can and then just go toe-to-toe with the rest! It just looks very silly. The story has huge problems with pacing - essentially it's non-stop balls-to-the-wall action. There's no real horror of which to speak because the game can't find time to slow down and build anticipation. It tries too hard to jump-scare you every minute, and when it's not doing that the vehicle or elevator the players are in are guaranteed to explode. It doesn't take long until you more or less are expecting something to go wrong at every corner - and you won't be wrong either. Comparisons of "Call of Duty - but you have to pick up ammo" are accurate.

Unlike most survival games, there's zero reason to conserve ammo. Dead zombies give you more - you just have to pick it up. Out of ammo? Just kick them all to bits! The game is marred with many quicktime events until the game becomes a mere test of your reactions. Very little thought or strategy is needed to work your way through the very linearly designed levels, party because it's an experience of pure chaos in near darkness. It couldn't be more further removed and dumbed down from the adventuring and puzzle solving of the very early Resident Evil games. To top it all off, it doesn't even save the game properly between checkpoints and you have to often retread earlier sections.

If a manic over-the-top action movie with zombie elements is your thing then you might like it. There's four campaigns so there is actually loads of content. However, I was pretty much over it from the first few levels. It just gets more comical the more you play into it. It's only saving grace is the mercenaries mode - which is unashamedly a survival mode with an annoying timer - and is pretty fun once you get into it. Playing with a friend could be fun. It's just not enough to save the whole game from my thumbs down.

I wouldn’t recommend RE6. I bought it specifically to play with a friend, but we lost motivation halfway through the final character campaign. It wasn’t even much fun, because the second player was a dispensable mob character with no bearing on the RE universe. RE5 gets a bad rap, but aside from its terrible camera, the game is a blast in co-op. Thus, I will compare the two and discuss key points that come to mind.

Bugs. RE6 seemed buggy and not well-coded. There were a couple time times in which events simply wouldn't trigger even though we figured out what we had to do in order to progress a boss fight or checkpoint.

Gameplay. Fewer puzzles than RE5, more standard objectives like survive within a time limit, kill all enemies, etc. They also removed shared inventory. Overall, there is less of a feeling that you need to depend on your partner to survive. I did not like this. However, I enjoyed the skill tree system in which you upgrade your hero (not the weapons themselves, as was the case in RE5).

Camera angles. I died more to the sudden irreversible changes in camera angles than to final bosses. After a cutscene ends and a chase + QTE sequence begins, you may have to hold backward to go forward. The timing is tight, so one of us would frequently get caught and killed. It was really frustrating to see our score go down because of this. You didn't have to worry about this in RE5.

Gamma. Holy hera! The gamma calibration was so off in comparison to other RE games. At first, I followed the instructions to turn it down until you could barely see the symbol. However, I literally could not see anything around my character. I was constantly stumbling into things and getting attacked from my periphery. The game was not remotely enjoyable until I cranked gamma up to 20.

QTEs. Strict timing like in RE5, but manageable. There were actually fewer QTEs during cutscenes than I would have liked. It was a bit boring to sit through them, because I don't know anyone who actually watches RE cutscenes for the story. A plus is that the QTE inputs were more consistent, whereas RE5 gave me PTSD by switching it up between left + right, action button, and crouch.

Driving sequences. These were the death of me.  I never want to see a snowmobile ever again. I crashed and died 10-11 times each time we had to navigate a vehicle. You have to drive so fast that you can’t even see the obstacles, but you can’t slow down either. Otherwise, you’ll get caught by enemies from behind, or the target you’re chasing gets away and you fail the checkpoint.
