It's funny, because on my first playthrough I hated Resident Evil 6 so much I uninstalled it and I wasn't even half way through Leon Chapter 1. After sitting down and be patient enough to finish all the campaigns, my opinions changed: It's a damn fine co-op action game. I went in expecting a Resident Evil game which I shouldn't have, that was probably why I despised it a lot in the first place.

[u][b]Things that Resident Evil 6 did well[/b][/u]

• [b]Well paced for an action game.[/b] After fights you get room to breathe before facing other waves of enemies.
• [b]The story is decent.[/b] This may be controversial but I quite enjoyed the story despise the criticism it has. It might not be as good as other Resident Evil games but still pretty fun on its own.
• [b]The characters.[/b] After finishing the game I appreciate so much more of Leon, Chris and Ada. The new characters such as Jake and grown-up Sherry are pretty interesting as well (except for Helena, she's kinda meh but I don't hate her). I feel like they've done a really good job writing them in this game.
• [b]You can finally run![/b] No more of that Resident Evil 4 and 5 trotting.
• [b]Level design is pretty well done for an action game.[/b] It's easy to follow and there are extra stuffs to find along the way as well.
• [b]The game's length.[/b] Resident Evil 6 is the longest game of the franchise, so if you enjoy games that run for more than 20 hours, this is for you.
• [b]Co-op is fun with friends.[/b] Remember to bring some friends with you, because randoms might try to friendly fire you (this happened to me, yup).

[u][b]Things that Resident Evil 6 did not so well[/b][/u]

• [b]Inventory management.[/b] This is the biggest con of Resident Evil 6 for me. Inventory feels clunky, you can basically see it as non-existent. It's just downright horrendous, even Resident Evil 5 did a better job with this.
• [b]Identity.[/b] The developers tried so hard to please every fans that they ended up disappointing everyone. It clearly does not feel like a Resident Evil game, and the horror that I loved in the older titles was never found in this title.
• [b]The atrocity of quick time events made its return![/b] They really prove time and time again that QTEs are really the worst thing that ever happened to this franchise. Thankfully this game has more tolerable QTEs than RE4 or RE5 but everytime you come across one you just wanna rip your head out.
• [b]Sudden camera angle changes in some segments.[/b] You cannot believe how many times I have died because this game decides to bring back fixed camera angle during tense moments?? It's a really annoying and pesky feature, and it's frequent enough to drive you mad.

[u][b]Every Resident Evil 6's campaign[/b][/u]

You can skip this part if you don't want any spoilers.

• [b]Leon's campaign[/b] is targeted to the zombie fans and the likes. This is supposed to please the Resident Evil fans who love the older titles but it was done rather... poorly. Zombies can use weapons and it looks goofy as hell. Generally, this campaign is okay and the final chapter is kinda epic. 
• [b]Chris' campaign[/b] is for Resident Evil 5 lovers. They feature the same-ish enemies from RE5 (called the J'avo). The combat/melee attacks feel really satisfying with Chris (don't know if it's the same for Piers but it probably is). Overall, I like the story side better than the gameplay side, but it's a decent campaign.
• [b]Jake's campaign[/b] is kinda a mix of Leon and Chris? It's hard to explain, but apparently Jake can do really good melee attacks (I didn't know, I was playing as Sherry). But otherwise, the story and the gameplay is fine on this one.
• [b]Ada's campaign[/b] is for the puzzle suckers from the older RE games. Features plenty of puzzle, and you get the choice of doing the campaign alone or multiplayer which is pretty cool. Ada's coolness is on point, the gameplay and plot is pretty a-okay as well.

[b]Resident Evil 6 is like what others said, a good action game but a terrible Resident Evil game.[/b] Luckily, this marks the end of the 4-5-6 trilogy and the series would turn back to its original horror roots with Resident Evil 7. Although an end to quite a controversial era, Resident Evil 6 is still a fun game, even more fun if you have friends to play it with. It's a pretty cheap time-killing game when it's on sale, and you get to dive more into the Resident Evil universe.

[b]Score:[/b] 7/10 [i](Decent and fun action game, not a good Resident Evil title, get it on sale!)[/i]

Imo the worst Resident Evil game. Can't say it's a bad game but as a Resident Evil it's really bad. It's fun playing it with friends though.Things I didn't like in general are the inventory (you can carry 6+ guns, there is no inventory management), "No Hope" difficult was the the as the Normal difficulty in other RE titles, too much action (relevant, some players may like it), the skills in general, there is a bug or whatever that is that all the saves on each chapter are unlocked so you can play the last save before finishing the whole chapter, most places etc

I can't recommend this game. The main reason for that is because it does a lot of things wrong which Resident Evil 5 did right. RE games are not narrative masterpieces by any stretch of the imagination but RE5 provided nontheless a fun third person coop experience. RE6 doesn't.

The main issues compared to RE5 are:
1) Terrible camera perspectives during action sequences and quick time events: The camera focuses on being cinematic but this often means you don't even see where you are going with your character. Sometimes you don't even see your own character while you are supposed to move around and evade dangers
2) Clumsy inventory interface: I don't understand what was wrong with the previous interation. But in this game inventory management is poorly implemented at least for a PC game. Hotkey assignment are impossible. You have to scroll through inventory through combination of button presses and mousewheel. You also can't choose your weapon layout anymore, meaning you will block a significact amount of your inventory space with ammunition wether you want to or not.
3) The progression system is unengaging. Instead of upgrading weapons you pick a set of three perks which you can upgrade from level one to three. Consequently you have very little meaningful choice. While in RE5 you could chosse from a variety of weapons and upgrade them, most perks in RE6 are only useful in niche circumstances. Generally you pick firearm damage, melee damage and health because they are always useful, reducing the effective amount of player choice to practically nothing.
4) No item swapping in coop. 
5) No shared progression in coop. If you find emblems or collectibles every coop partner has to pick them up seperatly for some unknown reason
6) Areas are extremly cramped with doors requiring both players interact carefully gating the players from area to area. These "two players doors" are extremly ubiquitous. A coop game has to do something like that in order to keep players from straying too far. RE6 is just extremly uncreative when it comes to accomplishing that goal. This gives the game an "on-the-rails" feeling that is only seldomly interrupted by open areas.

None of these issues are by themselves gamebreaking. However, in combination they make for a frustrating and lackluster experience. I can't give an impression on the multiplayer since I only played the main campaigns in coop. If you are looking for a coop game I suggest you try RE5 first. In addition to the aformentioned issues you should also have a high tolerance for quick time events, since they are pretty much everywhere.

There is some really great stuff buried in this game, but it's surrounded by repetitive mechanics, tiring setpieces, hit-or-miss stories, and a complete betrayal of everything that made the series great.
If you're a Resident Evil fan who wants to experience all the games, play it with a friend, you'll probably have a good time. I recommend starting with the Chris campaign. It's easily the best so do know that it'll all be downhill from there, but if you dont like Chris' campaign, you will hate the rest of the game.
If you're a newcomer to the series... Maybe pass on this one.

Generally buggy with poor controls, poor level design, bad voice acting and a boring story, but it loops back around to being hilarious since it sucks so hard. You would have to be a moron to play it alone. The only way to enjoy this generally terrible game is to laugh at it with a buddy.

Edit: After finishing the game, I can say without a doubt the following about Resident Evil 6:
1. The gameplay is horrible and it backtracks on everything that made RE4 and RE5 fun.
2. The story is nonsensical, poorly executed and explained even worse.
3. The voice acting ranges from alright at best to atrocious at worst.
4. The game is CONSTANTLY interrupted by quicktime events and cutscenes. I would honestly wager that I spent about half my time playing this game in either a quicktime or a cutscene instead of controlling my character.
5. There is no semblance of difficulty even on the hardest setting, No Hope, which only marginally reduces the amount of ammo you get.
6. The pacing of the game is some of the worse I have ever experienced.
7. The game overall is a total shit-show packed with terrible action movie tropes that would make Michael Bay blush.
8. The game is incredibly glitchy and broken. Enemies are constantly teleporting around, appearing and disappearing, and the collision of the game areas are generally subpar at best.
9. The music is bland and forgettable.
10. And finally, the controls. The controls in RE6 are some of the most obtuse, unresponsive and actively unfun I have ever had the displeasure of experiencing in a video game. The camera jitters rapidly and uncontrollably while running if you try to change directions with the mouse, to the point of inducing motion sickness. The game also is CONSTANTLY ripping control of your camera away from you to show you something inconsequential, which destroys whatever semblance of flow was left after the constant quicktime events and cutscenes. Your character enters a lengthy, uncontrollable falling animation that lasts about 6 seconds after being shot more than once, which also makes trying to play agonizing and constantly disrupts gameplay.

Overall I have no idea how or why this game was made. It's so universally bad by every metric that me and my brother had numerous moments of gut-busting laughter at the absurdity and general atrociousness of the game, so I guess it has that going for it. Play it with a friend for giggles, or don't play it at all.
story feel like a spiderman 3 movie on who to focus on

This is the first game in the series left I hadn't yet played, and is also the worst.   Damn shame,  as I was very much looking forward to it. NOTE: Campaign play only!

THE GOOD:
[list]
[*]4 Campaigns with crossovers
[*]FANTASTIC animation
[*]The action gets your blood pumping in the first few moments
[/list]
THE BAD:
[list]
[*]The action is all there is.  There's no exploration, no reward for being extra diligent beyond the typical out-of-play extras.  [*]It makes the action lose all meaning
[*]THE CAMERA. GOD, THE CAMERA.  It feels like an old PS1 game. 
[*]You see how in the promo video characters sometimes move around in circles to do something?  That's not a nifty dodge.  It's how you move.  The movement controls are kind of hit and miss. 
[*]The key mapping, by default, is nothing like the previous games.   This makes sense only in as much as neither are the controls.  Remember tabbing into your inventory to pause the action?  NOPE.   You'll be holding ALT and scrolling with your mouse, or hitting a key that brings up an item menu with NO CLUE how to use it.   I know, you're thinking, "ti's just an inventory", but imagine playing old Zelda and having to hold the Select key white twisting the controller sideways and holding A plus the directional pad to select the flute. 
[*]The QTEs are back and man are they awkward.   You're either rolling WASD keys in order or rapidly tapping the key you mapped to actions.
[*]Back to that inventory.  Not only is there no pause, but you have to seelct every item previous to the one you want to get to the one you want. 
[*] The HUD is confusing; it resembles old arcade rifle shooters, with a bullet count in little  bullet icons and a number indicating all of the shells in your inventory.   Health is a large series of blocks, while combat energy is in a little bar. 
[*] Gone are the onscreen prompts like blood around the edges to tll you that our health is low.  Your only indicator is your nearly transparent HUD. 
[*] Herbs shake into pills, and pills only restore one point of health.  Found a red herb?  Mix it to get 5 green pills basically.  
[*] Bosses often lack visible weak spots and the "difficulty" is bullet sponge elimination. 
[*]You can't carry ammo for every weapons, and ive found no inventory expansion item
[*] The level design is atrocious.   You're often running or driving in scripted events and the controls are sluggish and bad.  The developers appear to have looked up "levels players hate" because you WILL have sewer levels and there IS an underwater level where you have to hunt air pockets like Sonic the Hedgehog. Unfortunately, you can't see most of the things you need to save your life or to avoid getting killed until they've killed you already. 
[*]NOTHING is scary about this, other than the damage it does tot he franchise.  The constant threats completely eliminate the sense of tension and foreboding that made the games great
[*] Companion AI always gets the easy job while you're stuck with your back to the wall, no ammo, no health items. 
[*] Those health items are so rare they are almost pointless
[*] Prior games rewarded identifying a sleeping zombie and killing it.  In this game, unless a script has run to make it attack you AND it's been put on its feet, bullets *pass through* the target, so you have to piss it off and risk injury to kill it. 
[*] You MUST master the dodge mechanic, because once a zombie begins its attack, it is invincible until it lands it.
[*] Campaigns spoil each other due to them not being in chronological  order. 
[*] Most bosses are killed by a scripted event, and some you may as well not even shoot. 
[*] Companions can't share loot
[*] Game is so totally on rails that if you see a place to explore, it's really just where it was going to send you next. 
[*] Even a successful QTE can be ignored and you'll get hurt anyway
[*] Some QTEs chain in a way that if you fail the first, the next one coming up will hurt you
[*] Most of the time, running from zombies isn't an option.   You absolutely must kill everyone on the field. 
[/list]

Edit: Since my last attempt, i tried playing the game again, but with a setting that ostensibly disables the QTEs.  It doesn't, actually, except for certain QTEs that would prevent you from watching the story unfold because you have to do the QTE to not die.  However, this did make enough of a difference to enjoy it, and I happily played through Leon's campaign and started into the others.   I'll update this list as I go, but here's what to expect:

[Prologue] - Easy peasy.   Just shoot zombies when you see them, though one or two can be evaded.   

[Leon Campaign] - The nerfed QTEs from the setting toggle helped a lot here.   I enjoyed most of the playthrough, and most enemies were zombies, as one might expect from a zombie game. 

[Chris Campaign] - Chris's campaign starts out more militaristic, but play focused a lot more on weak point discovery.  This had more "first run traps", such as a hall where if you go for ammo before you chase off an invisible snake monster, it will yank you up into the vents and you get a game over screen.  I ran out of ammunition more often here, but Chris is a dynamo with a combat knife.   Unfortunately, this campaign also introduced the dreaded "running in reverse" that no gamer enjoys, where you have to run toward the screen from something that kills you if you slow down or stop at all, but also have to climb or slide under things as if you were playing Crash Bandicoot backward.   The final boss for the campaign even has this feature, with the camera angle becoming your worst enemy as it flips around and messes with your running direction. 

[Jake Campaign] - This campaign has been hell so far.   It starts with some passable combat moments and story tension, but whoever designed these levels thinks that turning the environment against the player in a Nintendohard fashion is fun, especially combined with the 'Ustanak'. That word means "uprising", but in this case, it's Nemesis from RE:3 but without random appearance, with a multipurpose arm that seems to change function as easily as MegaMan selecting a weapon.  He's in every mission so far that doesn't involve you driving a sluggish snowmobile at breakneck speeds to escape an avalanche, and im stuck on the ultimate crap combo: a stealth mission where if you step on ice or shoot a gun or otherwise make noise, Ustanak busts through a wall and kills you almost instantly.   If your'e seen by his pet fireflies, he does it as well.  Then, you have to use bombs to distract him while your partner gets a card key, and then do ->8<- QTEs in rapid succession using the movement keys or again, instant death.   You have to run between those QTEs as well, so if you happen to hit a movement button as the QTE finishes, you lose half a second and die to the Ustanak. 
[Ada Campaign] let you know after I finish the Jake campaign....if I can stomach it.

I know what my major issue is.   if you've ever played D&D or another tabletop game with a bad DM, that's how this feels.   Innovation isn't rewarded.  You aren't allowed to outsmart the design, but instead must follow tightly on the rails. QTEs arefrequent and sometimes even success equates to failure.   Particularly in the Jake campaign, I feel less like I'm playing a game and more like I'm going through  level design that was put together specifically to make sure players ragequit.

It has some cool boss fights.  But other than that... It's really not worth it unless you're a huge Resident Evil fan who has to play the whole series.  Because this is not a Resident Evil game.  

During one single hour of gameplay during Leon's story, Leon crash-landed an airliner, his partner (Helena) drove a bus through a barricade, he fought a boss on top of high speed passenger trains (trains.  Yes.  Plural trains) which all derailed in the process, and he piloted a helicopter which he also crashed.  

Michael Bay would think that this video game has too many explosions.  Because it does.  

And instead of a virus that mutates spiders into giant monster spiders, this time the writers decided it would be a good idea if the virus mutated humans into many different kinds of bugs and animals.  So you will, if you play this game, have to shoot at human torsos with spider legs that are carrying machine guns and shooting at you.  What?  How did this game get published?  Capcom, what were you thinking?

All action.  No horror.  The only horror is in the monsters' looks.  But it never unsettles you.  It doesn't benefit from playing late at night with the lights off.  It's just a shoot em up, third person shooter, that just so happens to have Leon, Chris, Ada, Sherry (as an adult now), and reference to Wesker & Umbrella.  

It will make you want to play RE4 and RE5 again.

Def Recommend.

-Money well spent
-Obviously Co-op, better with friends!
-Well placed over-the-top theatrics
-Appropriately delivered cliches and stereotypes
-Can push obstacles the size of boulders, but cant move a lawn chair blocking your path
-If it looks like a trap/boss room it probably is
-Plenty of unique boss fights and usual variety of enemies with some additions
-Usual level of unnecessary boob physics (Since RE5)

My only complaint is that, with the story it is fairly easy to find what 'should be a twist':
-You kinda know who your villain is immediately
-You kinda figure out how a mysterious figure fits into the story before you're 4 of 20 chapters in
-By the time you begin the 2nd story, you pretty much have everything figured out and there's not really any more mystery/plot unless you're terrible at missing hints so the rest feels like 'filler'

Tip: Play through the whole game. Plenty of content with 20 chapters and 4 stories alongside each other.

This has got to be the worst video game I have ever played in my life. As a Resident Evil game it fails horribly - as if Capcom forgot what made their previous titles successful by slapping new-age garbage mechanics and dramatic tension to meet the 2012 trend requirements, and as a triple A game it is a slap to the face.

The countless bugs and glitches were the only thing in the game that put a smile on my face, such as a helicopter clipping through the buildings and shooting missiles directly at me. The combat system adds "cool" combo moves, but in doing so the game lacks critical feedback that tells the player what state the enemy is in. Headshots practically mean nothing and ammo conservation is useless. Any ammo that is obtained is immediately spent afterwards. The only way to keep ammo is to overuse the melee attacks which becomes repetitive very quickly.

Guns and characters look really nice but the texture quality in the environment are 144p MS paint graphics anti-aliased to hell. I only looked forward to playing each chapter for the cutscenes at the end to get a grasp of the story which was convoluted to follow, so much so that everything in this game was never mentioned in subsequent titles. I have no reason to replay the campaign more than once and the mercenaries gamemode was pretty much the only challenge but boring to play for more than an hour at most. I wish I refunded this game when I accidentally clipped through the table in the first chapter by vaulting over a pot, but I gave it a chance to only disappoint me. Definitely not worth the price.

Despite being a main entry in the Resident Evil franchise, Resident Evil 6 is noticeably different compared to its predecessors. It's even more action-oriented, to the point that many fans, myself included, said it's more like a shooter game with scary enemies compared to horror. Like RE5, this game is co-op friendly, where every mission is playable with a partner. There are 4 separate campaigns which sometimes intersect, and the playable characters are Leon/Helena, Chris/Piers, Jake/Sherry, and Ada. You can co-op on Ada's campaign, a non-canon character named Agent will appear during gameplay, but disappear in cutscenes.

Combat gameplay is similar, but also has a lot of new features. The most noticeable and important for me was the ability to move around while aiming, something RE4 and 5 doesn't have. There's also the ability to slide, roll, dodge, and quickshot. While RE6 has a lot more combat moves, honestly I prefer RE5's simpler combat. There's a lot more action scenes, like where you run away while being chased or the place falling apart, and quite plenty vehicle driving/combat scenarios. To be honest I'm not a fan of the amount of running scenes, there's just to many. And outside the helicopter combat moments, which is fun and still feels "in tone" with the game, vehicle scenes just feels jarring and very unlike a RE game.

Due to having 4 campaigns, RE6's story is quite long, it can be 5-7 hours each. Each campaign explores different areas, so it's not repeating the same levels 4 times. Although some levels use the same map or with minor differences, usually story intersection levels. All campaigns (except Ada) explore one character's relationship with their partner, giving a lot of time for development. They also have unique weapons and melee finisher moves. With many playable characters and their unique combat strategies, gameplay becomes a lot more fun and varied. It's actually a strong point for this game, like Separate Ways in RE4. It also has a Mercenaries mode, score attack levels like the ones in RE4 and 5, and Mercenaries No Mercy, a crossover with Left 4 Dead featuring characters from there and weaker, but more numerous zombies.

Remember how I said RE6 is really action-oriented and co-op friendly? It is also a major weakness for menu and inventory management. The in-game menu (Esc) where you can change settings and controls, are made in-game. That means you cannot open the menu in combat since you'll get attacked. I know it's preferable for co-op, but not everyone has friends or motivation to play that way. If you play offline there is a pause button, but you still cannot view the menu while the game pauses. Opening inventory also plays in real-time, making combining items or switching weapons difficult and stressful especially when you're in a pinch. You also cannot trade items or use your partner's inventory as an extra storage like in RE5, and the inventory is quite small. In short, it's way too co-op friendly, even if you play alone.

Despite the action direction the story takes, lore-wise I think it still makes sense. Since the use of bioweapons became more prevalent, it makes sense that zombies and the creatures here appear, and in large numbers. And of course the virus can be modified by scientists, creating the gun-using zombies who still have some intelligence. Resident Evil 6 is a good game, but comparing it to other titles it makes this game feel weird and out of place. However, with the return of many likeable characters, horror RE fans still should play this game despite the large difference in its tone and atmosphere. If you're new to the franchise, however, do not use this game as your first entry, get RE2 remake instead.

Ugly, tedious, and bloated. The motivation for the changes made to Resident Evil 7 make so much more sense once you've experienced this game. 

The original RE games were, in my opinion, confusing, frustrating, and clunky. I was 12 when it was genre defining and it was too hard and complicated for me then - I had no particular love for the 'traditional' formula and no reason to care about where the series went. But at least then the Resident Evil games were a unique property - something that did what they did better than the imitators around them. So where RE 4 hit a precious middle-ground in increasing the pace of the action without losing sight of what made the series enjoyable (a lucky shot that could just have easily missed the mark), RE 5 began emitting the whiff of corporate mandating as pilfered gameplay elements from other properties and genres began to creep into the series to draw in a larger player base. 

In Resident Evil 6 we see the natural end-point of swapping creative design for profit-motive. This game reeks of gimmicky excess standing in for a desperate lack of inspiration - the kind of creative bankruptcy that stained so many games of the 20-teens and rendered them utterly forgettable amongst the quagmire of conceptual plagiarism they all engaged in as they scrabbled for shreds of consumer attention like rats in a dumpster. 

If you want a bombastic 3rd-person shooter made in Japan play Binary Domain. It shares many frustrations with RE 6, but is better than you expect it to be. At least that game throws itself entirely in the direction it's leaning rather than trying to keep one foot in two worlds that are diametrically opposed in terms of tone and pace. RE 6 wants to be a high-octane action shooter while also forcing dated and annoying gameplay mechanics onto the player to simulate tension it can't organically manufacture when the narrative arc is 'kill zombie' and the entire game can be played by pressing one button at a time. 

I don't have any great investment in the series' creative direction. Who gives a sh*t what a game does mechanically if it does it well? But they say that if a book doesn't grab you in the opening chapter, then it hasn't earned your time. Resident Evil 6 throws a lot at you in its opening chapter and like so many that tried this same tactic, it fails to pull it off better than the games its aping. It's enjoyed something of a critical resurgence as expectations have boiled down and while I can appreciate that it's some mindless, functional fun with a solid amount of content on offer, I've played far too many milquetoast rip-offs trying to snatch some of Gears of War's success to endure this without a very stale taste in my mouth. 

Resident Evil 6 is the point a creative, innovative property truly buckled and became a cowed plagiarist desperate for attention. Capcom came around and closed the circle with its 7th release, but I cannot imagine a scenario in which 4 separate campaigns built on the paltry foundations of this game can provide something worth the time it would take to explore them.

Horrifically underrated and absolutely worth your time. The dialogue feels cheesy and canned, but when has resident evil voice acting ever been good? The shooting feels responsive and well put, the quick time events keep you engaged regardless of the situation, and even something as simple as dodging and sliding feels badass and fun. Sure Helena serves no purpose, Sherry is about as reasonable as the deeper lore of this series, and you could completely remove Ada's campaign and nothing  would change, but is that a bad thing? RE4 was a masterpiece, RE5 kinda sucked, and this game feels like a worthy successor to RE4.

How to not make a Resident Evil game: the game. Do you like watching constant cutscenes? Do you like being unable to move and still lose HP and die while said cutscenes are going on? Do you like when a game takes control of your point of view while said cutscenes are still going on and give a chance to let you die and restart the fun all over again? Do you like stupid stories, tropes and generic monsters? If you said Yes to all or any of the above, this game is for you.

This is far from the best Resident Evil game, but it's actually really fun to play with a close friend or family member. There are many difficulties to select from, so pretty much anyone can play it. There were times when the game was insanely frustrating, my brother and I got super mad at the game and each other when we played Chris and Piers on Professional (the part where you had to escape the giant BOW). Even after changing on Normal it was still challenging, so keep that in mind. There were a few parts like that, but overall the game's pretty easy.

As I've mentioned before, this game is fun to play with someone close, EXCEPT for the Ada campaign. Neither of us wanted to play as Agent because he's literally non-existent in the story. I don't see why they would even add him in the game at all, because the only purpose he serves is killing enemies, or dying if P2 isn't skilled enough. He can't open doors, he doesn't appear in the cutscenes, etc. I'm not saying that it'd be much better if he could, I'm just saying that since Ada works alone, he shouldn't even exist in the game. Maybe it was just for the sake of being able to play co-op in Ada's campaign, but it's pointless 'cause it isn't enjoyable.

Overall, Resident Evil 6 is an okay game. I'd say it was 7.3/10 for me. Buy it if you have someone to play with and if you think it's satisfying to shoot zombie heads, NOT if you're a fan of RE classics.
idk man it's bad even with a friend. Just play RE5 again

No. RE6 is where we legitimately find the franchise losing its way. Trying to pull in way too many directions with multiple stories trying to extend the game, the product as a whole is a mess. There are some good ideas in this game, I must admit, but the execution is botched. Quick time events return on steriods, punishing you to a ridiculous degree at times regardless of which story you play. Animation hitboxes for hazards or even enemy attacks so big they have their own zip code, (getting smeared by an oncoming train despite being on the opposite track) you rely even more than ever on invincibility frames and quick time animations. Gone is any merchant or upgrading system from 4 and 5, what you find and hold on to is what you get with an unremarkable skill system to augment your gameplay. If there is any saving grace, is that Mercenaries mode is still fun with a friend but honestly that's a hard game type to legitimately screw up. Combined with a story that demands you to play every pair in order to make sense of it, campaign as a whole can be ridiculously long even with a coop partner. Overall this game is a discount buy if you absolutely must have it for your collection.

There are so many issues in this "port" that its impossible to mention all of them. 
You have zero control over the character. He, she is all over the place. And when you have a straight path and actually gets forward you run into a door where you and your partner have do open... press V for "wait on your partner". You open the door into a cutscene only to be greeted with another door just as the cutscene ends. You press V for "wait" and you get into a room. Filled with enemies, about 5 of them, and after you have been running around in circles looking at the ceiling, the floor and every wall 54 times back and forth, you have killed the enemies (god forbid you get hit, cause then you'll rolling around on the floor for an extended period of time, with no guarantee that you dont get hit again on your way up). This leads up to a door, press V... 
Time and time again you get truly amazed how bad this game is.

This game is a hot pile of garbage for the Resident Evil series.

TL;DR play RE5 instead.

RE6 has a long list of sins that really impede the fun:
- Unskippable cutscenes
- Cutscenes regularly breaking up action (10+ during boss fights!)
- You can take damage during cutscenes (I've died several times to this)
- Frequent loss of camera control during gameplay (to look at some stupid thing while you take damage)
- Quick-time event boss battles
- Slow-walking sequences
- Tripping over corpses and objects
- Character turns like a boat, enjoy falling into pits
- First campaign with Leon and Helena casually drops all the plot twists in the other character's campaigns. Why the heck would I slog through another 8 hours of campaign just to see the same "twist"?

Did I have some laughs playing coop with a bud? Absolutely because this game is so bad sometimes it's good. Was it worth $40? No, no it wasn't.

For anyone looking for an entry into the more "action" games from RE series, play RE5 and you won't be disappointed. It's tastefully campy, with decent progression and good continuous action sequences. RE5 I enjoyed playing through the campaign multiple times. RE6 I can't be arsed to replay the campaign with the other characters because it feels like such a slog.
I have no idea why there's a mechanic where you trip over dead bodies when you run over them, but you do.
Perhaps I judged you too harshly.

Oh boy, I really wish I could review this better, I loved this game forever ago when it first came out and I played it on Xbox, did not realize just how bad this is. Gameplay wise, it is fairly decent apart from the strange new inventory system, and the actual in game inventory system is really just not that good. Also having the run and interact button be the same led to a solid 3 deaths because of my person deciding to climb up a ledge and then immediately climb back down the ledge to only get hit with my next complaint, falling. If an enemy snipes you, you fall, if an enemy coughs next to you, you will fall and have to get up faster than they can attack, if you don't, you will be stuck on the ground like a newborn baby wearing a BSAA uniform. Not the boulder punching Chris Redfield I seem to remember. The amount of quicktime events that are found in this game are another area that I feel it would have been better off without, watching what seems like a transition only to be hit with a sudden "press space + R" led to an exasperated sigh and another try so that I can pick up a bit before only to hyper focus on every transition scene for the next hour of gameplay. The story is fairly alright and I do have to admit I like the tie-in's from each character's story into the other ones. It was definitely unique and felt new but honestly this game definitely needed something better than that to keep it alive. If you can get this game on sale, I would recommend, but honestly this game is best described in a single word: yikes.

Resident Evil 6 is not good. nut it souldn't have been this way. On paper, this should've been the slam-dunk and the magnum opus of the action RE games. The problem is, the game is a bloated, ugly and unfocused mess. 

The story of the game s broken up into four separate campaigns, where you play as different characters in different places. Each of the campaigns tells it's own story, but fits into larger narrative and each serve as a piece of the puzzle that connects the main mystery of the game. You can play any campaign in any order you want, but to actually understand the story as a whole, you have to play them all.
The story of the game is very convoluted and bloated beyond any strectch. Not only you have to follow 7 different characters in their own stories, the game itself is full of filler, while not even explaining what the hell is going on. The gameplay is just constantly interrupted with cutscenes of people talking what they need to do to poceed, which annoying, and most of the cutscenes you can't even skip. 
There are some good moments in tehre, but there are two main issues. First, the game takes itself way too seriously, constantly talking about how fate of the entire world is on the line. There is not a trace of some kind of jokiness and lighthearted fun in any situation, everyone is super-serious and doesn't want to make or take jokes at all. Second, the characters are actually unbearable, they are either stupid, act like a-holes, or bland and boring as a piece of wood. leon most of the game just follows around and does what everyone else tells him to do. Chris was completely butchered, erasing progress of his character from RE5 completely, and making him petty whiny b*tch. Jake, while being the son of one the most charismatic characters in the series, acts like an ididot, a-hole and he is bland uninteresting all at the same time. 
And at the same time, the ideas presented here are worth explorring. it is definetely interesting to explore Chris' inner psyche after so much war and fighting, because he probably would suffer from some kind of PTSD. Jake and Sherry beign kids of the biological war are actually worth talking about in the context of RE, two characters who's parents were responsible for so much horror and tragedy, using their gifts to fight for the good of the world is intriguing. But why in this game? Why Jake has to be the most awful character written in RE series? Why Chris has to suffer right after the game he got his closure with Jill and Wesker?  Why Leon does nothing but simping over Ada?

Then there are graphivs. The game actually looks ugly. There is this blue/grey filter over everything at all times. The textures are low-resolution and blurry, it's like they took 144p picture and streched into FullHD. The particle effects look cheap. The game actually looks like a remaster of a PS2 title. the only good part of the games visuals are character modles. There is certainly a lot of love and care put into them But there rest of the game is just unpleasant to look at. 

But how the game actually plays? Well, RE6 tries to be this action game, with big and crazy setpieces, loud combat and cool moves. The blueprint of RE4 is here, third-person camera, manual aiming and shooting, butnow movement is no longer tank-control based, characters can freely strafe around and even move while aiming. The game also borrows a lot of the mechanics from it's contemporaries, like cover system, sprinting and dodge-rolls. The game tries to blend RE stuff, with something like Uncharted, maybe a little bit of Call of Duty Modern Warfare, it tries to be as much of spectacle as possible, while provifing tight gameplay in combat.
But everything feels sloppy and weird. The movement has so much lag. Incredible combat of Re4 is gone, because there is no actual combat sandbox, the game just throws enemies at you and you just shoot them. new melee moves look cool, but rely too muvh on context sensitive inputs and require you tyo manage this new stamina gauge, which is probably was put there for you to not abuse powerful melee attacks, but in the end just punishes you for having fun. There is this weird new quick-shot mechanic, whioch probably should be used to interrupt attacks and stagger enemies, but sometimes enemies can decide to not react to it at all. 
Also, what is worng with this UI? Instead of classic grid based inventory, you get this weird wheel that looks different on each character. In older games you just pick the grid you want and do whatever you want with it. Here you have to actaully sroll to the thing you want to use, and then press a button to use it. The herbs are reworked that now they act as some sort of pills, and if you mix herbs you just get more pills that you can swallow. and tose pills have their own separate space when stored. so there is no reason to hold your herbs and they waste space in your inventory until you find red herb to mis them with. There is also problem with ammo. The game either showers you with it so much you don'e know what to do with it, or doesn't give you any at all, instead giving you new points for the awful skill system.
the skill system should be a replacement for buying new weapons and upgrades. Some skills give you more damage, some improve you defence, some can even spice up your gameplay with something unique. But the price on those skills are just outrageous. You would have to grind hard until you get skills you want leveled up. The game is long, but even then, at the end you would have only a couple of skills leveled up to maximum. 
But the biggest problem with the game is how much it tislef stops you from laying. The game constatly eitehr stuns you, you shakes the cameera around, or locks you into a QTE section, or just straight up takes control away from you, especially in sequences where you have to run in the crumbling facility and sking ships, where there is an earthquake every 30 seconds that shakes everything and doesn't let you control anything until it decides to stop. The game relies so hard on QTEs, that everything you do would be a QTE. Brreak away from enemy, turn a valve, press a button, hit an enemy. Everything is QTE., and the kind of QTE that people bullied so hard it was deleted from gaming last console generation. 
And there is still forced co-op even if you play solo. Thankfully, unlike RE5, now your AI companion is invincible, has unlimited ammo, and you don't need to manage it's inventory. The only function it has is to assist you in scritpted sequences and help you get up after you lose all of your HP. But now you can't even pause the game. Even if you disconnect from the internet, you can not stop it.Just why you would fix one thing and then completely break the other?

All of this piles up into very annoying and unpleasant experience. I know there are still people that enjoy this game and it's own brand of action. it's now in thephase where people can even nostalgic about it. But it should've ben a lot better. The series desrves better, the fans deserve better. As big blockbuster action game, it severely lacks polish of AAA game and is too clunky to be a glorious action experience it wants to give you. Even budge ttitle such as Devil May Cry 4, despite reusing assets and having troubled development from the same company, just focused on what matters and made the game really good. And that is probably what RE6 lacks the most, focus. It tries to be too many things at once, trying to please fans and new comers, trying to be both RE and not RE. This is a failure that could put any other franchise into the grave. Good thing Re is an everchanging frachise at this point. And it always deserved a second chance.

I love this game!

I regret buying this game, even though it was on sale. If you're looking for a co-op game in the vein of RE 5, you will be let down sorely by this game. It's hard to understand how a game so flashy can be so monotonous. It lacks the campy elements that redeemed the over-the-top narrative of the 5th game. Resident evil 5 managed to satirize Hollywood films of its era (inadvertently or not) whereas this one failed to understand the aesthetic draw of its previous success. The combat is a genuine chore and it doesn't make use of any of the elements in previous games that added tension or a challenge to the player (resource management, inventory management, etc.) and opted to make a mediocre 3rd person shooter. It's a sad devolution that's even worse in the context of playing the games in sequential order.
This game is trash, but its very entertaining trash when played with a friend. I would recommend it to any group of 2 looking for something to play on sale.

Thought I've had a bad experience with this in 2013, since I find an abomination to play fps-like games on console, and decided to give it a try on pc with 80% off on sales. Just ended up playing an even worse version of it, everyone know that Capcom sucks at porting to pc, but this game is the top of the cake. While the original looks poorly tested, I'm pretty sure this port itself wasn't even tested at all. It's just a straight port, and the devs doens't even bothered adding a proper key setup for pc. Controls were always bad, and this version has even worse default configuration that you can't even fix because some commands are still tied to the same keys and there's no alternate keys setup. Just try reloading your gun when there's loot dropped close to you to see what happens. You can only change weapons through the mouse wheel (enough said, you got CONSOLIZED), and the weapon HUD is giant covering the center of the screen, meaning that changing weapons will either cause you to miss your aim, getting damaged or having to sit still till it disappear. The mouse look causes even more bugs than the console version already has, just check the forum for Chris's pier section: I died 3 times there without even knowing what happened and came straight to the forum completely convinced it was a glitch. Bingo. 
Not like this is the only issue, the design itself is poor and irritating in every way possible and makes you just want to finish the game fast. Playing this game is an absolute torment that I would just recommend if you're a RE fan and needs to know the plot, and with 80% off at least. Thought about dropping it at several moments, so painful it was, and I never did it before unless the game wasn't even worth to be called a game. Enemy placement is just irritating (like placing an enemy on top of you when you can't aim straight upwards, or spawning an enemy with a gun shooting your face when your char calmly finishes climbing a ladder where you couldn't see upwards), enemies are boring (you fight enemies with guns 80% of the game, wich makes the game looks a generic shooter, and enemy design itself it not attractive), zombie mutations makes it look like you're playing L2D (wich makes the game lose it's identity and looks like a generic zombie game), and some boss fights have so terrible and ridiculous fighting scenes that will make you miss Chris punching a boulder.  
There's no pause for enemies in cutscenes: they will keep walking and surrounding you and when you regain control they will instantly attack/damage you.  Same will happen when you need to wait for your dumb AI partner to open a door.
I can barely call it a game, actually, seem fanmade stuff far better than this, actual players wouldn't do this crap. Looks like the devs just randomly popped enemies around the map to reach the quota. They don't even know the difference between challenging & irritating, between scare jump & a monster that bursts from the wall instantly damaging you.
Vertical Sync doens't work. 
I don't even remember dying to enemies, but must've died like 50 times on instant death events due to the camera angle (there's even a record for it, died past 50). That same camera angle mess with your directions when kicks in (always in the moments you need to run), causing the direction keys to change directions, causing you to walk down a pit or just get stuck running into a wall. Not to mention the weird angle choices, like focusing on a monster while you can't see the next obstacle that will kill you.
Some QTE scenes makes you fell you're playing a buttom masher (smash to swim or you die...).
Hitting item boxes is harder and slower than hitting enemies.
There's empty sections for absolutely nothing - level start, you walk down a hallway and have to wait for a CUTSCENE to open a simple door. Shouldn't even have a door in there.
There's a few good sequences, such as the invisible snake boss and the plane crash sequence, wich are really good from the start till the end, and you will surelly have fun seeing some character's meetings. You will not want to miss those if you're a fan and gonna buy the game anyway, just be ready for the absolute torment that is playing 90% of this game. This could easily be the worse RE game ever, if that ridiculous excuse of an FPS for PS1 never existed.
This game is a disaster in every way. Stay away from it, people thumbs it up cause it has "RE" on title. I can play RE4 with the weird old school controls and have fun, but this is just an absolute torment.

This is the first game in the series I do not recommend.

Pros.:
- Some storylines like love line between Jake and Sherry.
- Some old characters like Sherry.
- Certain cross plot moments.
- The idea of exploring the game through different characters.

Cons.:
- Redesign of Leon and Ada. It's just an epic fail. Ada was flawless in RE4. Why the hell did they redesign her? Also, you play and just watch her ass in leather trousers. I don't mind that but I would rather see old Ada's design with modern graphics than her ass. There was so much chemistry between her and Leon before. And now it's gone. Dialogues, all bland.
- The main villain. Bland. Just a waste.
- The whole game became something like Call of Duty. Humvee race with the sport car? You kidding me? I'm playing NFS now?
- The plot is just boring. They tried to exploit old ideas like RE2 and RE5 but it's a failure, it's not convincing at all.
- QTE stuff. Another fail. It's annoying to play this way.
- The most important thing - the spirit of RE is gone. Suspense, horror, fear, mystery. It's just a blockbuster now.

If you want to watch what's up - just watch the game in youtube. It's better to see the most memorable parts there (including Joanna or what the hell was the name of Leon's partner's sister, touching herself in the middle of the fight).
better with a friend.

I am 31.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I just could NOT get into this. I think maybe they were being too ambitious with this one. They were trying to make it too much like an over-the-top action horror flick experiment. The story was very bland. I don't think I can get back into it.

This is some kind of postmodern Rashomon. There a war in eastern Europe, a bio-attack at a US college, and a bio-attack in China. The player will witness these events in non-chronological order. The player will witness these events from four different perspectives. No insight will ever really be gained. No new understanding. Who the actual terrorists are is never clear. All that is known is they work for neo-umbrella. 

The originally secret Ada campaign also doesn't really clear anything up. Her campaign starts in the middle of the story and she has to piece together what she can just like everyone else. 

The gameplay is fun enough in coop but I do not recommend playing through to completion. Once you start to feel tired just stop. There is no narrative reward.

To put it simply, this game sucks ass.

I here a lot of "Oh well it's not a great RE game, but it's a pretty good game."
This is not true, it's bullshit.

I played all of Leon, Chris, and Jake's campaigns, before I finally had enough of this heap of smoldering dog shit.
Jake's campaign is the closest this gets to being "good", Leon's felt like a weird mediocre mish-mash of Left 4 Dead and RE4, and Chris' felt like 3rd person COD. 

I'm only reviewing it now because some weird part of me, after beating RE4 on Pro, decided "hEy, I'm GoNnA gO dO aDa'S cAmPaIgN aNd HaVe ThEm AlL dOnE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! iT cAn'T bE tHaT bAd, RiGhT?????????????"

How wrong I was, you get some familiar weapons from Ada's Separate Ways arsenal, TMP and Crossbow to begin with, not bad, right? The beautiful machine pistol that never runs out of usefulness, and the explosive crowd control device known as the Bowgun. Hard to fuck up something that's already been done well, wouldn't you think? Capcom managed it! The TMP feels terrible, it is so incredibly weak it hurts, and the Crossbow is reduced to a pitiful shell of it's former self. 

I'd recommend just avoiding the game completely, but if you absolutely MUST play RE6, play through Jake's campaign, maybe Leon's if you're feeling a bit dangerous, then drop it, never come back. It's not like anything that happens in this matters in series canon anymore.

I recently completed this 'game' with a buddy in co-op. It is by far the worst Resident Evil game I have ever played and one of the most painful video game experiences I have had in my almost nineteen years on this sweet planet. 

Pros:
- Some over the top moments (like a tower exploding four times in a row) made me laugh
- There was a fistfight between a human and a literal fucking Tyrant that was kinda funny
- Zombie T-Rex boss
- Lighting was ok
- Actually a solid amount of content, providing me with over 20 hours of game time across the four campaigns
- Mercenaries is pretty fun, probably the best part of the game
- Co-op is easy to set up and get into

Cons:
- Story is batshit stupid and not in a funny over-the-top RE4 way but in a just straight up TERRIBLE way
- Most of the new side characters are boring (barring Agent) or frustrated me beyond belief (Jake Mueller)
- The enemies are either uninspired (Javo) or have been done better in previous games
- CONSTANT Quick Time Events that disrupt the flow of gameplay and make for shoddy game design
- Multiple frustrating moments that almost made my friend and I outright quit multiple times (e.g. terrible defend your position segments or one where you much search for keys or some other item)
- A plethora of bugs, glitches, and crashes, in fact causing my friend to crash several times (some soft crashes, some hard) despite his PC being well above the game requirements
- Agent, as a character in Ada's campaign, is almost completely worthless as he cannot open doors, pick up key items or interact with any key parts of the environment. FFS he isn't even in the cutscenes 
- Snow level was soul crushing 
- Turret section that made me want to throw my computer out the window
- Chris' entire fucking campaign (felt more like Gears of War than Resident Evil)
- Almost zero horror to speak of, almost completely action, and not good action at that
- "More like an ex girlfriend" and "Always something with women" CRINGE QUOTES from Jake Mueller
- Jake Mueller 
- Game expects you to feel attached to characters that you literally got introduced to about 10 minutes ago if even that
- Inventory system that is clunky and contrived 
- Healing system that does not work well with the series formula in comparison to previous entries 
- Skill system that essentially has little impact
- Ranking system that makes no fucking sense (my friend multiple times got a lower accuracy, more deaths, and less kills than me, yet still came out with an S rank, whereas I was stuck with an A or a B in certain cases)
- Simmons was one of the weakest villains the series has come across yet even worse than the boring main villain of RE4 and the fucking leech opera man from RE0
- Cover system is complete ass, having one of the worst control schemes I've ever seen (having to aim while next to cover and then press the spacebar, whilst still holding the aim button otherwise you leave cover or vault over it)

Conclusion:
This game is an insult to the series and I can assure you if I had not been co-oping with a buddy, I would've quit after Leon's campaign. It is no wonder why the series began to bomb after this game. Thank god RE7 was actually good.

Final Verdict: NOT recommended (DO NOT BUY)

A resident evil where you don't spend hours going back and forth solving weird puzzles.

[h1] Story [/h1]

In 2013 (ingame) a new funky virus has emerged. The C Virus! It originated from a research facility in China. (Ingame) Gotta tell you this game was way ahead of its time.  ┐(͠≖ ͜ʖ͠≖)┌

You play the campaign from 3 different perspectives. Leon, Chris, and the newcomer. Jake. Said perspectives have their fair share of diverse enemy types. 

Like for Leon, you encounter the mutant shark, mummy zombies, Spider-Woman-Thing? And the triple changer Simmons. 
Chris, you encounter soldiers that mutate in response to physical trauma. They become very insect-like. Possessing, maggot heads, and mantis arms, tarantula torsos, flying torsos, etc. Invisible Snek, 2 armored helicopters. And that skeleton fetus thing at the end.
Jake's enemies are that he encounters nemesis 2.0 and some mutant soldiers. So......
Regardless I like all three campaigns. Despite how dated this game is, I adore the action-packed, atmosphere. I also adore how creepy, grey, and unnerving some aspects of the game are. I like the dialogue. Acting. Troy Baker, and Roger Craig Smith. Is always great.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Gameplay? Leaps and bounds from Re 4 & 5. You can jump on your back with "X" once your laying on your back, you can roll from left to right. When using "A" and "D".  You can dodge left with "Z" and right with "C".  I am easily amused, I just which more third-person shooters would implement an evading mechanic, as elaborate as this.

Unlike any other RE game from the fixed camera angle days to RE 5. You can run while holding "Spacebar" not awkwardly speedwalk. Unlike other games. 

The UI is funky. I wish it was like RE4 where you would organize and click tab and select the items and the herbs you want. You know basic stuff. Some weapons in my opinion are trash. Or have weird double standards. Like the grenade launcher can delete J'avos from existences. Yet they can't do significant damage to those regenerator, frog things. Or bosses in general. As you can see, I essentially speed ran the game. I just did the campaigns in one sitting, frankly.

This game is more of an arcade game for some reason. It's the type of game, where you and your friends can pick up the game and well play. It is fun, 8/10.

[h1] Enviroment and Atmosphere [/h1]

Like other RE games I played, the environment, dungeons, are decrepit. Rusty, old. Cold, unnerving. I adore the spookiness. It really puts me on edge. The enemies complement said spookiness. 

[h1] A small note [/h1]

I am relatively new to the RE franchise. In my opinion, I have seen a lot of hatred for this game. Talking about how it strives too far from the RE formula. Now I understand how during a certain period of time, every game company, under the sun, decided to copy the "warzone" formula due to its popularity. Just an industry trend. Like how every first-person shooter incorporated wall-running, after titan fall. I like the action RE games. I believe it is a logical and natural evolution for a series such as this. Concerning its lore and overall legacy of said series.

Think about it, if bio-terror was real, like in the RE series, then is accepted task forces like the BSAA. Would emerge. Military, action dudes, would show up to save the day. They are more prepared and well trained. No need to be restricted to ridiculous situations for artificial horror. Now I understand most of the arguments on how certain elements lack horror. Which I do agree with, to a certain extent. Like how you must be resourceful, feel claustrophobic, feel vulnerable, etc. But I am saying I think, we should have two categories for RE games. The action-packed line-up. And the horror side. Where you have stuff like Ethan and his first-person view. While you got my boulder punchers saving the day. You know? There is nothing wrong with having a little both. That is why RE 4 is loved by so many. It is an action game, with horror element.

You may like it or not but the game has a good story, gameplay and of course a coop mode. What is different from the other RE games is that you can beat the opponent with bare fists and instead of horror you actually have a lot more action here.

Being a fan of the series, it is painful to write a negative review of this game. Allow me to preface it by saying that a lot of things can be forgiven, if it's played with other players in co-op mode. The single-player walkthrough, however, is a painful experience.

So much of the game sounds amazing on paper: several story campaigns with returning fan-favorite and original characters spanning all over the globe, a few dozen of unique enemy types, improved combat mechanics with proper abilities to take cover and dodge attacks etc. But any improvement from previous games is coupled with severe signs that the game was rushed and ran out of budget: clunky controls, inconsistent level design (pacing is all over the place), terrible graphics (worse than Resident Evil 5 and some textures and models are straight from the 90s) and the story that relies a lot on re-used levels and assets.

Speaking of the story, it is horrendous. Without revealing spoilers, while actors try their best with terrible dialogue, the main story is a combination of things that we have seen before, but dialed to 11. If you thought Leon being a Secret Service agent saving the President's daughter in Spain was cheesy in RE4, you should be scared of how pulpy the story becomes in 6, but only this time it is not charming, but exhausting. Another power-hungry villain who comes out of nowhere with character depth of a shallow pond, even more crashing helicopters, exploding vehicles, bike chases and a non-ending stream of cheesy one-liners that would make Arnold proud. It is an absolute opposite of the first three games, and if 4 and 5 were a signal for you that the series was going the wrong way, Resident Evil 6 is an exclamation point to that idea, gleefully embracing its own stupidity and proudly flaunting its well-deserved label of being the worst game of the series.

P.S. This game is so bad, Capcom soft-rebooted the entire franchise after this.

Verdict: If you like Resident Evil franchise, maybe just avoid this game. It does not finish storylines from previous games, it's mostly self-contained. If you start RE7 immediately after RE5, you probably will not even know that something else happened between the two games.
If you want a fun co-op experience with a buddy, it's not so bad. Co-op mode is the only redeeming quality feature of this game, but there is also Resident Evil 5 that has co-op too, but is not a pile of trash at the same time. There is Resident Evil Revelations 2 which is excellent and is built around co-op, so maybe grab that instead.
If you like horror, definitely avoid this, the horror-roots of the franchise were pretty much buried in a cemetery. 

P.S. 2: By the way, this game forces you to chase a dog around the cemetery in a dark environment, because the dog has a key. This is the game's definition of fun and it explains everything about its design.

DO NOT TRUST POSITIVE REVIEWS, Resident Evil is a terrible mess of nonsensical story, boring and convoluted gameplay and TERRIBLE camera design. I honestly never saw a worse camera in any games I ever played. 

This game is just a complete mess that can only offers solace if you play it to laugh at how terrible it is. 

And to site a review by Gamespot which sum it all:

"Resident Evil 6 is constantly (and annoyingly) playing with camera angles, even outside of the running sections. The worst moments are those that yank control from you and force you to stare at a growling behemoth's dramatic entrance, or a helicopter's flyover, even when you're in the middle of a quick-time event, or engaged in a shoot-out. Smart games either have you hold a button if you want to witness a major incident, or simply allow the incident to happen. Resident Evil 6 is not a smart game. It doesn't care what you're doing: that monster is big, and the game forces the bigness upon you. (And when the sequence is done, the camera may not be in the position in which it started.) Such occurrences are, every time, detrimental to gameplay, and it's shocking how many of them there are."

"But while you won't often die due to the level of challenge (unless you crank up the difficulty, of course), you might not be able to escape a few of the game's "gotcha" deaths. With little warning, a vehicle might crash through a barricade, and if you happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time, you're dead."

"Its problem is that it throws a bunch of action game mechanics at the screen and expects them to all work well together. Instead, Resident Evil is sloppy and random. You've never quite seen a mess like this."

Honestly, if you treat it like a standalone action game. It's ok. The QTE is honestly disgusting and breaks the whole immersion (or what is left of it honestly). That said, if you want [b][i][u]ACTION[/u][/i][/b] in a RE game, 6 actually is your best bet. If you are looking for a Resident Evil game, which you most likely are, this is not it.

That being said, this is the "John Wick vs Zombies" Game You Never Knew Existed, most specifically RE6 Mercenaries Mode. 

Released in 2012, this game preceded the 2014 John Wick movie. It meshes both zombie shooter and stylish combat quite well - allowing for cover maneuvers, sleek takedowns, boulder-crushing punches, and other serotonin/adrenaline-pumping moves. More action than horror (which most RE fans understandably didn't like), wish Capcom took this winning formula and made a separate action-horror spin-off.

The game is impressively long (could be easliy divided into a few separate Resident Evil titles), fast paced and compelling at the same time with startlingly fun and well made coop and deathmatch variations modes ([b]pity that multiplayer is barely populated though[/b]). Besides, apart from the low quality textures, RE6 looks decent even by modern day standards (especially the main cast models and their mo-cap animations), it's perfectly optimised and the gameplay mechanics are so complex and solid ([b]an amazing variety of character move sets and their interactions for example[/b]), it could  put to shame most of the third person action games recently released. Well Japanese craftsmanship after all. 
 
Really why did this game get so much hate is a mystery to me.

[h1][b]Devo's Seal of Approval?:[/b][/h1]

If you've got a mate like mine to do co-op with ("Daemonicrazor")...THEN YES. Cooperative campaign gameplay makes this title worth the asking price. It's a casual & entertaining 3rd person shooter set in the "Resident Evil" universe...nough said.



[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
[list]
    [*]Cooperative campaigns...FOUR OF THEM!,
    [*]Entertaining enemies & interesting weapons,
    [*]An "over-the-top" story line set in the "Resident Evil" universe,
    [*]The graphics have held up well considering this was released back in 2012,
[/list]

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
[list]
    [*]Some frustrating sections in some of the campaigns which can only be put down to poor game design,
    [*]While the "over-the-top" story line is entertaining, it can drag on a little at times,
    [*]A "tacked-on" Ada Wong campaign...wait...is this a pro because its laughable how "tacked-on" it is,
    [*]Really poor sniping mechanics,
    [*]A confusing inventory system...at first,
[/list]


[b][h1]CONCLUSIONS...[/h1][/b]
I played through this title with my online BFF "Daemonicrazor", and let me tell you, WE HAD A BLAST. It was so entertaining that it even got us talking about which coop title we could jam out next.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1684529098
There's not much to say about this title; it's a pretty solid, entertaining and casual cooperative game, set in an amazing universe that i'm a big fan of. More accurately described as a 3rd Person Action Adventure Shooter, it's not the traditional "Resident Evil" survival horror genre.

Cooperative gameplay (with a funny friend) is what makes this title great. Coupled with hilariously outlandish story elements and "logic defying" gameplay design decisions and you have a recipe for ROFL'ing. But like I said, cooperative play is what makes this title great, and this day-and-age I wouldn't recommend you to play this title alone.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1684528951
I'll remember playing this title for a long time; messing about with "jiggle" physics, getting our characters into compromising positions for a well-timed screenshot or two, and making fun of the some of the story plot-points.

In short, if you've got some spare money and time, and have a good mate to jam out on this title with; give it a go. "Daemonic" and I had a ball of a time.

NOTA: Esta reseña se basa en el tiempo personal dedicado y no en comentarios inutiles donde se critica sin saber que es lo que critica.

Resident Evil 6 Review

Este Resident no es apto para el publico que viene acostumbrado. Esta entrega tiene mucha acción y por momentos deja de ser Resident Evil. Es interesante que las 4 campañas esten unidas. El problema esta en las medallas finales. La clasificacion va por historias, capitulos, dificultades y personajes. Lo cual por historia hay 10 medallas las cuales 5 son de cada personaje. (PROMEDIO POR CAPITULO 50 MINUTOS) Lo cual es sumamente estresante hacerlo al 100%.

RESUMEN GENERAL DE CAMPAÑAS.
Como antes mencione el promedio. El juego tiene una durabilidad de 20 horas aproximadamente. 5 horas por campaña.

Leon / Helena
Es la historia más parecida a la de un Resident Evil.

Chris / Piers
La historia es como si fuera esa tipica pelicula SUPER EXAGERADA de Acción.

Jake / Sherry
Pasa algo similar como con la de Chris y Piers. Es como si fuera tipica pelicula en la cual aparecen los mismos 2 protagonistas y el mismo antagonista de principio a fin.

Ada / Agent
Es la más complicadas en cuanto a introducción. Luego se vuelve más sencillo pero aun asi sigue siendo complicada.

Conclusión: Recomiendo las historias de Leon y Ada.

PROS
•Multiple Historias
•Variedad de dificultades
•Sistema de habilidades (Puede ayudar dependiendo tu manera de jugar pero no te genera un GRAAN cambio)

CONS
•Jugabilidad (El Sprint, los saltos no deseados, el movimiento estando agachado o cuando esquivas para los costados) 
•Pesima camara (En algunas campañas dificulta la visibilidad del jugador o hace Zooms cuando esta en lugares un poco cerrados)
•El lado del apuntado se reinicia a cada rato cuando jugas con personajes secundarios.
•Inventario muy limitado

DLC: PROXIMAMENTE

RECOMENDADO SI:
►Sos un jugador dedicado y jugas los juegos por orden
►No tenes una mejor oferta y ya compraste todos los juegos que querías
►Te gusta conocer grandes cambios (por mas que no sean positivos)

8/10
By far the worst Resident Evil Game

Pros:
- Story is actually really good and actually has some good character development; (especially for Chris, finally) each characters story has a distinct flavour to it and the narrative flows naturally with some overlap. Leon definitely had the best campaign out of all of them, the game felt like it was mostly his story and the other three campaigns were just added for the sake of it. The voice acting is also the best it has ever been despite the still occasionally cringey B-movie dialogue
- Game play is the best its ever been for a Resident Evil title; it's nice being able to shoot and move and the diving and dodging aspect really improves everything and makes the combat more seamless; I also really liked the melee system, it's nice being able to hit enemies without them being staggered (like previous games) and you can chain your attacks together 
- The sound design is excellent, everything comes through flawlessly on my 5.1 system and the music and sound effects are really well designed

Cons:
- Too many qte's; I know they were going for the whole cinematic aspect but the amount of them was just way overboard, it creates too much of a disconnect in the game play
- The controls on m+k are abysmal and take a fair bit of time getting used to, I recommend rebinding some of the keys
- Whilst I really loved the overall story Jake's campaign felt completely unnecessary in the grand scheme of the game, it felt like he was jut there to have a "twist" added to the story. It also would have been nice to have the campaigns over lap more seamlessly instead of having them separated for each character

I can see why fans of RE don't like this one but I really had fun with it, definitely one of the best action games I've played. But ofcourse there are problems with it, like:
-UI and inventory system are really bad.
-AI partner system is still as bad as it was in RE5 so play CO-OP if you can. (As a side note, each character 
 having a different UI style is a nice touch.)
-Perk system that replaced weapon upgrades doesn't hold up to it and there is nothing more frustrating than 
 having no ammo, breaking something and getting 50 skill points instead of ammo.
-In game menu not pausing the game is annoying.

But positives like:
+''Four stories that are mostly different but sometimes cross ways with eachother'' is a really good and fun way to experience the story.
+Over the top action scenes and boss fights are really fun to play.
+Controls and overall gameplay are smooth and fun.
way outweigh the negatives for me.

Make no mistake, Resident Evil 6 is a mess. Its story is nonsense (even by the series standard) and paced like a runaway train, its gameplay and level design is a mash of cliched cinematic action mechanics, it manages to both look and control worse than RE5, and the horror elements are paper-thin. Yet I'll still recommend it because it's the kind of mess that's an absolute riot in co-op. A top-notch Mercenaries mode also helps push it into a guilty pleasure. With Capcom getting the series back on track with RE7 and the RE2 remake, RE6 can be safely appreciated as a "So Bad, It's Good" compilation of everything wrong with action/horror games of its era, rather than the franchise killer it was dreaded to be.

95% 

"Resident Evil 6" is a 3rd person, over-the-shoulder, adventure zombie shooter. The graphics are generally good and the sound is built beautifully. It's also very very long (almost 50 hours played and I'm still not sure if the thing is going to end...). Overall, I like this game a lot.

RE 6 feels exactly like a Resident Evil game in that we can play multiple characters through a variety of maps, skill upgrades are funded by collectable artifacts, boss battles are fun yet long winded, the movement system is consistently inconsistent (by now I have to wonder whether Capcom thinks poor movement makes things scarier?), and the story follows a convoluted plot about human experiments that spawn zombies. What makes it feel unlike most Resident Evil games, is the satisfying Fun of it all.

This is the most complete of the Resident Evil games, without daring to reinvent anything at all. Not quite as swift and addictive to play through as RE 5, but definitely a well built and functional adventure.

Does Resident Evil 6 have an annoying amount of flash at times? Yes, it does. And does the game not let you quit because re-starting will load a Chapter rather than a Checkpoint? Why, yes it does. But the flash can be turned off honestly and replaying chunks isn't a problem, because this action adventure's primary gameplay is so creepy, sleek, fast-paced, and thrilling that we forgive the sins. The puzzles throughout are clear and engaging, battles in general are a blast, and the skill tree can actually change things specifically for your unique gaming style. Even though the game maybe overstays its welcome because it's so darn long, I would be ashamed to complain about getting more for your buck in this day and age.

A lot of good in RE 6 makes the bad feel nitpicky.

Not only is "Resident Evil 6" arguably the most playable and engaging of the entire series, but it's a good game by any standard.
