7/10

I've played 1 - 6 and Code Veronica X and I gotta say that this one is my favorite of the bunch. I really don't understand the hate that this game historically had. It's true that out of the series that this is the Michael Bay Resident Evil, but that's what makes it so fun. The fact that when it came out (and had the player base to support it) you could have intersecting campaigns online and play with two other people across the net in real time was amazing. I've played this one the most out of all of them (5 being a close second) and it's just fun. I didn't really like the original trilogy, for me they were a chore I had to power through to get the story I needed to play 5 and 6. I will say that Code Veronica X for me was a far more enjoyable experience than 1 - 3. I have not played 0 or 7 or the Revelations games.  Maybe in the future or if 0 gets a PC port. I think all of the negativity this game got was unfair and undue and exposed how toxic the gaming community can be sometimes. The bad reviews were completely unjustified. The fact that dogshit like TLOU 2 can get overwhelmingly positive scores and this blockbuster blast of a game can be so widely panned just shows that the gaming media is not only clueless, but possibly even corrupt.

That being said, there are some issues. Some of the dialog is corny, some of the decisions made by characters in the game make absolutely no sense, and there are still some bugs that require a restart from time to time. There are times where it is completely over the top (perhaps even exceeding punching boulders) but I maintain that this is a personal preference and not an aspect of the game to be critiqued. I myself am a fan of machismo, actions movies, and 80s tough guys (for all three, check out Far Cry Blood Dragon, an incredible homage to the era) so boulder punching for me isn't lame or silly, it's something to get pumped over.

If you enjoy fun shoot em ups, like the Resident Evil universe, or just want a good time with friends, I highly recommend it. These days more than ever we could use a fun popcorn flick (or game) to distract us from all of the silliness in the world, and I think RE6 fits the bill.

I'm going to be direct. Resident Evil 6 tries to be the modern inheritor of resident evil 4. It fails, the camera controls are wonky, its attempts to get you to engage in melee are a trap that just leads to lost health from grapples that enemies often get to do for free, its story is the usual RE camp but with the added annoyance of attempts to be an action game that are undercut by the frayed ribbons of survival horror left inside.

The characters are too vulnerable, the gunplay is anemic, your actions as 'heroes' often lead to the deaths of civilians because the dramatic story is forced to share the same space as an arcade game. You have zombies spitting acid as hordes while crawling around underneath traps left over from an indiana jones set but aren't granted the courtesy of one shot kills or even a guarantee that your bullets will hit your target.

This is a shame because its full of fan service for long time RE fans. There's the skeleton of a good idea here but its left languishing under a multiplayer mode that's honestly not worth using, strange attempts left over from five where the game tries to pair you up with a brain dead NPC, and lackluster combat mechanics.

don't buy for full price, and only if you're here for ridiculous RE lore nonsense.

I remember buying this game years ago on the XBOX 360 and then stopping playing.  With the announcement of a new RE 8, I decided to go back and play through all the REs, doing 5 and 6 coop with a friend.

About 2 hours into this playthrough of 6, I started to remember why I stopped playing this one years ago.  The controls in 6 are not very good.  When playing coop, the gameplay seems very jarring having the action interrupted constantly by mini-cutscenes and whatnot.  This game also has many "no warning" instant death action scenes which seem a bit unfair.

Overall this one feels like a chore to playthrough.  Yes, it's designed more like an action movie, but I feel more modern titles have done this style of run-n-gun action way better. 

If you're a fan of the series and want the lore, backstory, etc, by all means play this.  Just be prepared for a lot of noticeable frustrations.

Super fun shooter/action game, that has little to do with Resident Evil gameplay, but has tons of content, huge production value and a really stupid story line and writing. 

Setting is closer to Call of Duty, but with mutants and zombies -taking you all over the globe on ridiculous missions to save the world. 

As an action game it's quite fun, especially in Co-Op, with probably 15 hours to get through the story with a great variety of environments and levels, plus Mercenaries: the endless survival mode which is possibly the best part of any Resident Evil since Code Veronica.

Highly recommend for a fun coop romp or if you are tired of the more traditional gameplay of RE2 and RE3 remakes.
Worst of the series. Controls are so annoying. The part with Chris that run on boats against the helicopter is demented gameplay. Autosave is the worst ever seen.

I went into RE 6 hoping for more RE 5.

I did not get that. You only have one gun of each type per campaign (down from the 5 of each type in RE 5). Your inventory is a mess, and the controls are terribly convoluted even for a PC port. I found myself accidentally using things all the time since the use item button and the kick the zombie in the face button are the same button for some reason.

The real no no is how choppy and disjointed the boss fights are. There is a stupid amount of quicktime events in this game. The boss fights are literally 5-10 seconds of game play and 20 seconds of cutscenes. Some of the bosses we killed by letting the AI kill them we didn't even touch them.

On top of that the game has this annoying thing with zombies playing dead, corpses you know are zombies but the game renders them invincible till you get close enough for them to grab you. If you aren't aiming at the thing you have zero chance of avoiding it. We also noticed that for some reason the zombies seem to exclusively target player 1 and almost entirely ignore player 2. Unless they had no actual path to attack me, they never attacked my friend. We could have ten of them there and they would dog pile me and just totally ignore player 2. This is especially bad when you do Chris's story because most of the enemies have guns. In the first mission I'd been downed four times (we played on professional) and I'd used every single healing item we both had. My buddy was in front of me for half the mission. He was shot once. One time. The entire mission. I was lit up like a christmas tree hiding behind a wall and he's just walking around behind the zombies shooting them all to death while they hyper focus on killing me.

Then you have the skill system that replaced the shop in RE 5. This system is bad. What's the point in having a billion skills if you can only use three? Who is going to take "increased melee damage" over "take 75% less damage"? Who would take "Reduced recoil" over "Do more damage with ALL guns?". Basically every skill set turns into "more damage with guns" "reduced damage taken" and then "extra damage to (insert primary enemy type of the mode here)." With no reason to ever change it.

Worst official RE ever made. All the good elements of past parts are gone. Terrible camera angles, terrible aiming, and terrible controls. Loads of bad, overlong quick-time events. Without a controller its imposible to enjoy the gameplay experience.

There are also some good stuff in the game though like the graphics for an example. They are very nice with loads of gameplay elements not found in older titles. Melee combat is more fluid and meaningful. Gameplay is more dynamic than RE4 and RE5. You can also play co-op and co-op is kinda fun if you are playing with a friend.

Although there is a tremendous amount of content, much of the experience is either an incoherent mess or just repetitive and boring. And with the main characters surviving death-defying scene after death-defying scene, the whole thing loses all semblance of believability, and consequentially, any semblance of horror. 

Final Verdict: [b]5.5/10[/b]

Resident Evil 6 is probably the least favorite Resident Evil among fans, for it abandoned all the iconic Resident Evil designs and embraced over-the-top blockbuster action to be an action (not horror) third-person shooter. But to me, Resident Evil 6 always has a spot in my heart for being my first Resident Evil game. To be fair, it is not regarded as a good Resident Evil, but still is a very decent third-person shooter. So far I’ve done five playthroughs (not all on Steam), two of which are done cooperatively with friends. Co-op is way more fun than playing solo. That said, solo is not bad either. It is harder, but AI is decent and would not drag you down like in Operation Raccoon City or some sessions in Resident Evil 5.

The story took a very dramatic tone to accommodate the action, which some fans dislike. The protagonists do not die no matter it is an explosion or a high falling, even people around all die or turn into zombies. These dramatic scenes are probably just slightly better than Chris “Boulder Puncher” Redfield in Resident Evil 5. I think they are too much, but I won’t bother myself picking out all the dramatic yet unreasonable stuff. Just enjoy it for what it is, it is a little cliché but still very entertaining. On the other hand, character building is pretty good though. In my regard, Ada Wong is probably the best of all, with her unspoken affection for Leon. Sherry is my second favorite with her cute voice and clumsiness as a rookie agent. Characters in this game have certain personalities and some very good moments.

As for the storytelling, this game has four storylines going on at the same time, given the event in the game is on a global scale. This approach is very unique among video games and a brave trial in the narrative. I appreciate it for being able to present a full picture of a biological terror event, from the start to the climax and to the end. On the flip side, you will experience some scenarios twice when you play different roles. Capcom tried to minimize the repetition in these scenarios by offering different viewpoints for different characters, yet I still find it somewhat redundant and uninteresting because on the gameplay side you just do the same thing again. Four storylines also have certain different play styles. Leon’s questline has more of a traditional Resident Evil vibe, Chris’s and Jade’s are full-on gun-blazing and very action-packed, while Ada’s questline has some stealth elements and puzzle-solving. It is very dynamic, to say the least, but unfortunately, none of them nail the horror apartment.

The presentation itself is not bad. Surely it is a 2013 game so it doesn’t have good textures, lighting and other visual stuff like today’s game, it is still very decent. Character models are eye candy, not only better than counterparts at that time but also many games later on. I also like its music and I still listen to some of them from time to time.

The gameplay of Resident Evil consists of shooting, action, QTE and some light puzzles. There is no inventory management or any complex map design from the classical Resident Evil. Shooting is much faster-paced than previous games, it feels good, accurate and responsive. To compensate for the fast pacing, the game introduced a fairly complex dodge mechanic, which is quite in-depth for a shooter and very useful if you can master it. Puzzle session is too few to talk about and as for QTE and action, they are not a hurdle but I hold negative opinion towards these two. 

QTE is a popular game design at that period and I hate it because it is a very lazy design trying to engage players in the current event. This game has too many, to the point it kind of exhausts you out. As for the action, this game has quite some escape sessions which themselves are not the problem. The problem is this game has a very stiff keyboard and mouse control for movement because it was transplanted from the console, and the fixed camera angle during escape made the matter worse. I remember back in 2013 when I first played the game, in the last chapter of Chris where he has to flee from the giant monster, I could not make the escape no matter how many times I tried, not until I bought an Xbox controller just for this session. Also in other escape scenes and even normal sessions, you can feel the stiffness and unresponsiveness of movement from the poor keyboard and mouse control. It can be frustrating from time to time.

To sum it up, I don’t think Resident Evil 6 is a bad game. It surely has its problem and is not a Resident Evil that fans hope for. But if you just treat it as a normal third-person shooter, you can still have some good experience.

Resident Evil 6 is strange action game in a strange horror action franchise, which at times can be quite enjoyable to play.

RE6 has a pretty robust combat system which has the serious drawback of not using enough buttons, as it is a console game at it's core, though technically it is a very solid port with the kind of functionality you'd expect from modern capcom PC release.

Examples of the button problem is: 
Reload and pick up item drop is both R by default, meaning pressing R will have you pick up an item drop at your feet, good if it's the ammo you need to reload, less good if you need your gun reloaded without mashing reload key at that moment.
Dashing by holding space and vaulting over obstacles/leaping of edges/over pits without slowing feels good, until you try to dash a few centimeters to close to the edge of a table and getting a tactical sliding across going 160 degrees opposite of the way you were going.
Counter attacks on mutated J'avo and killing them with their own mutated limbs feels great, unless you press M1 next to another enemy in a vulnerable state, which triggers an attack which might not have enough knockback and/or invincibility frames to knock the first one back and instead leave you open to attack, though one could argue spacing to avoid such interactions is a skill that on the players responsibility.

Story is... Okay the story is some of the dumbest shit I know and I love it.
Spoilers, I'll even try using the tags.
[spoiler]So this high ranking US security official, Derek Simmons, is actually also working for the secret underground organisation, that isn't called the illuminati but it is basically that, called the family.
So Derek had some super secret mission taken care of by everyone's favorite super spy for hire, Ada Wong, and seeing her in her new tight leather pants and cleavaged red shirt got him head over heels, so he did the only sensible thing a man with an unhealthy obsession for a coworker and access to research by at this point defunct bio weapon companies and the seemingly endless funding by a secret society.
He cloned his crush onto his girlfriend, Carla Radames, by giving her an injection that causes a cocoon based mutation, modified to mutate her into a near perfect clone of Ada Wong, which is successful and he got his hot asian spy gf.
Carla isn't super hyped about having forcefully been turned into her boyfriend's waifu and as one might gather neither of them is all there mentally. So she decides to destroy the world by getting meanest fucking virus and flushing an gelatinous human reaper from mass effect 3 into the ocean(called Haos) into the ocean, assuring complete global devastation or something.

Separate from this, the current president of the USA has decided to step forward as a whistle blower on the Raccoon City cover up, at this point(this story taking place in 2013) an event from 15 years or almost 4 presidential terms ago, meaning he is basically going to expose the US government, or something.

Derek doesn't like that at all since, idrk why he's weird, so he orchestrates another virus outbreak, using US security agent Helena Harper's sister Deborah as leverage to get it going, when the president is about to appear at Ivy University in Tall Oaks, the zombie outbreak starts, claiming his life and assuring the secret of raccoon city remains a while longer, maybe forever. 
However it turns out Leon S. Kennedy, a survivor from raccoon city, has some experience surviving and escaping cities full of zombies, and Helena and Leon escape Tall Oaks, though not before being declared rogue agent by Derek who then immediately board a plane to China, like all non suspicious government employees after making accusations of treason against federal agents would do.
They follow, crash a plane into a populated chinese city center and track him down and kill him, then expose the US government about raccoon city.

Meanwhile Carla has been selling super performance enhancers(the C-virus, which is T+G+Plagas stuff+idk gene magic) to insurgents in [NONDESCRIPT EASTERN EUROPEAN COUNTRY] which gives them super powers like growing extra eyes and spontaneous mutations in response to damage. However Jake Muller, secret son of Albert Wesker, is among the insurgents taking this injection, though he is immune to all viruses since he has strong genes on his dad's side.
He gets picked up by orphan turned government agent, Sherry Birkin, who gets him to agree to sell his blood to make super vaccines for the whole world against all the wacky viruses Derek and Carla are dropping unbeknownst to both the world at large and themselves.
They get captured by nemesis 5.0 after some hijinks and a taken to china for researching by the baddies, though later escape and beat him up, and then bail, Jake gives Sherry a friend discount on his special blood sample.

Chris and Piers don't really matter that much, they do their job(to fight bio terrorism(ie zombies and stuff)), one of them dies and RE7/8 takes place after this and features Chris so guess who dies. Though he seems even more traumatized that time around than in this one where he becomes and alcoholic.

Ada does spy stuff, finding out the stuff I mentioned in the start of the spoiler, then helps Leon kill an US government official and destroys the backup clones of her Derek was keeping in some underground lab, presumably made from homeless chinese people grabbed of the street.
It is the funniest campaign in coop since it's not designed to be(patched in after release) and player two just plays a teleporting faceless Agent.

The story in summary, the world is almost consumed by an apocalyptic infectious zombie virus because some illuminati guy had a crush on/boner for Ada Wong.[/spoiler]

Like I said, while gameplay is solid with some core flaws, these flaws are enhanced and expanded in the story mode, as movement is camera based with the camera sometimes being wrestled to highlight certain elements(leading to awkward movement/unintentional inputs), enemies are not generally frozen for cinematic highlights(leading to cheap hits) and certain events that should really should have been pure qtes/cutscenes mix it up in a pseudo controlled environment that displays the worst features of the controls(often leading to frustrating instant deaths).

Each chapter is rather lengthy at around an hour to 40 minutes, with 5 chapters for each of the 4 campaigns, so if you only play it through once you got a pretty decent bit of content. 
Though each character plays mostly the same, learning their unique quirks and weapons traits is quite fun and mastering them even more so, like Helena [spoiler]automatically reloading her hydra shotgun upon making a quickshot wth the last shot[/spoiler] or Jake [spoiler]having a unique man-toss move that's great for crowds on enemies on the ground by equipping hand-to-hand and standing by their feet[/spoiler].

Multiplayer as of right now, is surprisingly filled and there is almost always a story mode game available with at least decent connection(I'm in northern europe, so that mileage may vary).
Getting a buddy for some mercenaries is great fun, and almost required as you cannot play while waiting for someone to join, a problem shared with all the extra multiplayer modes, so they are all basically dead outside of organizing something through the steam forums or other outside the game means, which is a shame as some of them are quite fun.

The game, in summary is a great bit of stupid, rather unique fun, if you can overlook it's many flaws, or just play mercenaries until your eyes bleed.

Also, there is modding functionality, look it up, it's not officially supported but there is lots of stuff and not the most difficult thing to get into if you want a custom mercenaries music track or something. Anything more complicated you probs wanna get a mod manager, I used Fluffy mod manager last time I did some modding, should still work fine.
Leon's campaign is good. Literally all the others are utterly horrid. Some of the worst design I have ever seen in any game.

Resident evil 6, in my opinion the most underrated installment in the series.

If you are looking for challenging puzzle's, counting your ammo and planning ahead your next steps carefully like you might have come to expect from the previous Resident Evil games then this game is not for you and you will be dissapointed.

If you like a fun action packed game in the Resident Evil universe with great co-op capabilities you have come to the right place! 

You could compare Resident Evil 6 to a rollercoaster, it's fun its thrilling but there is no freedom to go off track.
You pick a character you will play their story and you have no other choice than the follow the directions given to you. Which sounds boring but for a co-op game this is the only way the game will work and I am afraid this is the reason for some of the negative reviews.

Still I had a wonderful time playing this game Solo and Co-op and as you can see by my hours played even after finishing the game I still come back to it once in a while since the replayability of the game and the graphics hold up great.
After finishing the story mode there are multiple other multiplayer modes that are more arcade based if you are looking for a quick 10/20 minutes of fun playtime.

At the moment the game is heavily discounted, if you are reading this and there is still a discount available I highly recommend trying it out.

There is a benchmark tool available on Steam if you are not sure if your PC can run the game properly, but I am sure any PC built after 2012 is able to run this game.

It's not an horror game, but it is an amazing multiplayer game.
It's also fun, like, a lot. You're gonna laugh your ass off when you see yourself in situations that even a trained agent would have died, like more than five minutes underwater with a giant fish swimming while holding you into him and you fight him off like you're using some cool underwater equipment, but you're not.
Or, a fucking plane falling off the sky and destroying half of the city, but you're alive without any scratch (Well, RE5 did this too).

It's fun, because it's dumb.
But for a dumb silly story that competes with Bollywood on how crazy and silly it can get, it has a fluit gameplay, controls that would make lots of shooters jeallous of it and if you take it as an action game where you shoot zombies and infected people, and everything and everyone gives you bullets, with a cool soundtrack and a high-tech HUD system, for the time this was released, this game aged pretty well.

The mercenaries here is easier to get on in single player for example, and it's fun to play too. Actually while Resident Evil 5 has the best multi player mercenaries, Resident Evil 6 has the best single player one.
The game runs flawless and is very optimized, I have no complaints about it. It's from a time where Capcom wanted to grab the name of big franchises and switch to a genre that were giving tons of money to them and they hit their face on the wall with it, everyone were mad because at least RE4 had a little of horror in it. The game is NOT perfect, but it's pretty damn fun to play if y ou remember that untill 2014, QTE's were a thing and this game is full of them. XD

Play it, you gonna like it. Just don't play it thinking it's an horror game, or a survivor horror. It's just a fun single or multiplayer game (Sometimes I feel it's easier to play this one single player).

This game is the peak of how NOT to make a Resident Evil game. (Not that this is WITH a friend playing as your partner)
- Action takes the front seat with the only survival horror being starved for ammo or the controls
- Enemies move around during scripted events giving you no chance to react to them
- Enemies move around while the camera is stolen from you to watch your partner being knocked on their ass
- Many enemies animations line perfectly up to kill you the moment you stand up
- The controls will have you sprinting and then vault over an obstacle BEHIND you
- Enemy behaviour is completely erratic, newer following any kind of proper system ie. a sniper needing to take aim anywhere between 0 seconds and 3 seconds before shooting
- Absolutely boring music
- Multiple campaigns with the substance of 3/4 of ONE
- While Resident Evil certainly is no bestseller in terms of story, often being laughably silly, this game manages to be neither good, funny or campy enough to garner any kind of interest

One plus side
- The alternate game modes circumvents all of this, by only focusing on the thing it managed to do right, action.

Ignore people that say this is a bad game, it's very enjoyable, especially with multiplayer. You get a serious bang for your buck here, buy it on sale for $6.99 and you'll get at least 22 or so hours out of this, and that's without collecting emblems or playing bonus game modes.

The Resident Evil franchise has had some legendary entries and some forgettable ones, and RE6 falls somewhere in the middle. Largely a mediocre experience, this entry relies heavily on action-based combat and largely improves on RE5 in that respect. However, the areas in this game are just not that interesting; this is the only game in the series which I just didn't bother finishing because I got bored with it halfway through. Go for it if you liked RE5's action, but if you're looking for proper survival horror or a quality gaming experience, leave this one alone.

Resident Evil 6 is a silly and bloated action game which I do find better than Resident Evil 5.  The partner AI is much better and you do not have to worry about item management for them,  The game has four campaigns which feature Leon, Chris, Jake, and Ada Wong, each campaign will take five hours to complete each one so that can equal to about twenty hours of game.  I do find it interesting to play the game from many perspectives but it can get a little long winded and feel like a chore to play through.  My favorite campaign is Leon and my least favorite is Chris's since his levels can be frustrating at times.  My biggest critique is that there is not enough ammo sometimes in the level, this has been the case since the original Resident Evil but since this is mostly an action game it gets old running out of ammo so many times.  The enemies feel like an AI is just placing them in the level with no rhyme or reason and they can respawn endlessly unless you move on.  The AI is bad and I found the enemy and friendly AI running in circles and just freezing at times.  I do recommend this game but it is a guilty pleasure, and I have to be in a specific mood to play it.

I have mixed feelings with this game, it's an action oriented game rather than survival horror. To make this review quick I'll rate every campaign with some commentary. 

Leon: the best out of the bunch, fair difficulty, it's playable, awesome cutscenes and action sequences, but with flaws here and there surrounding the gameplay. Leon Kennedy is awesome, enough said, 7.5/10

Chris: a more annoying and more difficult campaign, lots of enemies and an annoying final boss, i hope you saved some bullets cause i beat it with merely ten shots left, whoever thought it was a good idea to screw around with the camera angles can die in a ditch, 6/10

Jake: i'd like to point out that the timeline is inconsistent, lots of enemies, little fun. A really bland attempt, and nothing new to offer. Ustanak is basically another version of Nemesis and the fights against him have unresponsive controls and the giants in the game are basically another form of El Gigante. Didn't really enjoy this one. 5/10

Ada: were they on heroin when they made this? Too many enemies for the amount of bullets they give you, for a more action oriented gameplay, conserving ammo is not something that you should worry about, so why the overwhelming amount of enemies. Carla was a pain to beat and the chainsaw dude can go to hell. I did not enjoy this one and found it painfull and agonizing, 2/10

They should have just focused on making one awesome campaign instead of making four different ones that just suck harder than the last. I say skip this one or just get to play Leon's campaign.

Sigh... It's like a Holywood movie in every respect. Well composed, high production standards, yet boring and tedious story full of cliches.

It feels very cinematic, it's the quintessential action movie experience full of insane stunts, explosions, and chaos, but really that's all it is- a sequence of action scenes. Sure there is a story, but it's entirely composed of cliches. No new ideas, single dimensional characters, a plot that has zero depth to it beyond 'the world is in danger and we're going to shoot our way to saving it'. I'm really not sure I want to finish it.

If you take a look at my profile you'll see I'm a big RE fan, though most of my playtime is in Playstation consoles (played the series since the PS1). I love RE. However, I simply cannot recommend this game. As a RE fan, or even as a normal gamer, it doesn't matter. RE6 is just...bad. I don't even know where to begin since pretty much all of it is quite flawed but I'll try my best to give this some structure and explain why I don't think anyone should get this game *except maybe coop players starved for games*

First off, this game isn't entirely without merit. It tries some new things to varying degrees of success. For example, the movement. This game handles differently to 4 and 5. 4 feels kind of floaty to control and 5 feels more grounded. 6 would be the next step in this evolution. For example, they made it possible for you to run into objects and physically "crash" on them or trip over bodies. While I think this is neat and adds to immersion, it can also become pretty annoying quite fast. So I consider this change more of a side grade rather than positive or negative. On that same note, lots of new actions were added like sliding around or dodge rolling, which allow you to maneuver way more than ever before. They're not entirely flawless and can feel pretty janky, but hey at least they work most of the time and serve their purpose.

Now, what about the mechanics/aspects that are indeed negative? Well... I have to talk about the UI first, who in their right mind thought that making the interface for each character different was gonna be cool? It's not, and it can be jarring if you're constantly switching between campaigns and characters but that's the smallest issue of all. It's the actual icons and the inventory itself that are absolutely terrible and one of my major gripes with this game. RE5 had a very simple but very intuitive and fast inventory, as well as potential for higher level play with it. RE6 on the other hand has a very cluttered inventory that is visually unappealing and too distracting. 5's inventory was more ergonomically designed, allowing you for quicker inputs whereas 6's feels clunky and sluggish. It's just a step back unfortunately.

Now here's another issue that is more of a bunch of systems with 1 common flaw: the camera. The camera in this game can be pretty unruly. To point some of these instances, take dashing for example. When you dash in this game, you pretty much can't move the camera at all. Why? Because doing so will make reset its position for no reason, try looking down or up while dashing and it'll start the rebound process. Which is especially aggravating when going up some steps or anything that involves changing elevation (because those make it bounce naturally already). Dashing by itself already feels bad considering there's severe understeer but with this annoying camera "feature", it gets really annoying. Another time when the camera can royally screw you over is when the game decides to show you "this event is happening, look at it!". So what does the game do? It takes total control of the camera over you, often times mid fight! So there you are trying to make sense of what's happening while getting your centre of attention elsewhere, often times not even on the enemies you're supposed to be fighting. What's even funnier is that aiming during these forced cameras makes it return to normal, but only while aiming. Games taking control away from you in such an intrusive and random way is a problem that in this day and age shouldn't be a thing, but it seems like this focus on "cinematic pieces" rather than actual gameplay and player input are even more common now. There's even some instances where you're viewing a cutscene and immediately after it's over you've been grabbed or attacked by an enemy that wasn't even there before. Don't know if that's a bug but it's certainly annoying, especially when playing in the higher difficulties where your health gets deleted by these cheap moves. Also speaking of these, there's plenty of times where the game autoaims for you after opening a door or watching the characters interact. Why? Does the game think players are too stupid to ADS for themselves? Sometimes there's no immediate threat yet the game still aims for you for a couple of seconds (without letting you do anything else).

Lets take cover shooting, since it's also affected by this in a sense. In this game you take cover automatically *sometimes*. Other times it doesn't. I have no idea what makes it apply auto cover since in previous games, there would be context sensitive button prompts to take cover, which makes sense and isn't intrusive or disrupting to the gameplay. But this game doesn't have such logic (RE6 even has those prompts, yet it still included an autocover!). It feels poorly implemented like most of the game, and it just pains me to see and experience considering all they had to do was keep the mechanics the same as previous games. To add insult to injury, I had times where my laser and the dot were lined up on enemies while shooting from cover...then as I fire I notice I'm actually hitting the cover. One time, this hitbox was literally on thin air. I had a clear shot, yet pieces of rubble fell from an invisible extension of a wall rather than blood pouring from the enemy's bullet wounds. Did they even playtest this game?

I guess they didn't because the game is buggy. During Jake's campaign, there's a section where you get chased by a tank. Yet the second the cutscene ends you get squished. No matter which keys or direction of thumbstick you use, you die. Probably because you don't get any input at all, the moment the cutscene ends you die. Look it up if you don't believe me, hell the friend I was playing with even stayed behind on purpose without pressing anything yet I still got killed. We tried many things but what ultimately fixed it was restarting the game, reloading that checkpoint with reversed roles as host and (oddly enough) moving left instead of away from the tank. And no, just pressing left wasn't the solution since I tried that before we restarted the game and I still instadied. We had to quit, reload and switch as well as press something that doesn't even make sense just to get past it. Also had instances where some context sensitive actions don't even show up, causing more resets. Maybe this PC version is buggier but that's still no excuse.

Now to end on a positive, I have to say the melee system is actually pretty fun. And overpowered! Honestly, you're better off using melee attacks than guns most of the time. Guns feel like they tickle enemies whereas melee staggers them and lets you finish them in one combo quite often. Probably dependent on difficulties (we played on Veteran) but this just highlights yet another problem with the game. Guns feel less viable than melee, on a third person shooter lol. As a related side note, there's many sections in the game where the whole camera/world shake tremendously and it makes precise aiming unnecessarily more annoying. The worst is when you're trying to snipe during these, because scope sway is already quite high so it's a nightmare.

This didn't even touch on the absolutely nonsensical story, or how Michael Bay-ish the game is where things explode for literally no reason every 10 seconds, or how each chapter long overstays its welcome and ends up feeling repetitive and tedious (the gimmicks that would be cool if they lasted 5 minutes, instead last triple that). I wanted to focus more on the gameplay side of things because I can't stress this enough, the game just doesn't feel good to control or play. It had some neat ideas, but it bit way more than it could chew and instead of delivering a fun, tight experience like most other games in the series it ended up a mess in every single aspect. I played this when it came out way back and didn't really enjoy it. Now that I got it again and tried giving it another shot, it feels even worse.

For a game that the community has dubbed "the franchise killer" this is a shockingly solid game.

Let's get the boring stuff out of the way: Yes this is as far removed from original Resident Evil mechanics as you can get. No this game isn't even remotely scary and no this game isn't going to win any awards or beat out the old, beloved games that we all know and adore.

Got it all out? Great let's keep moving.

This game has an incredible amount of content and passion put into it. 4 long and complex campaigns with a star roster of Resident Evil characters ranging from Leon to Chris to Sherry and even Ada, all while throwing in some new faces that helps spice things up.

The game is just a joy to play with it's incredible combat and varied enemy types. While the game is far removed from it's survival horror roots it is still very much Resident Evil. It has all the insanity that you come to expect from a title in this genre what with it's grotesque monster designs, wild explosive weapons and out of this world insane cutscenes and stunts that will make you go "How the fuck is any of these characters still alive and breathing!?"

It was the same deal in Resident Evil 5 and it was the same deal in Resident Evil 4. Even in 4 which, to many, is considered the best entry to the series has some really insane and wacky stuff you wouldn't see from it's Playstation 1 origins.

The series soon came around with Resident Evil 7 and it's return to survival horror but even that entry has some insanity thrown into the mix.

What I'm trying to get at here is that it's unfair to say that Resident Evil 6 is a bad game because it's more action oriented compared to it's predecessors because even the older games had that same flair of crazy action horror. Resident Evil 6 just steps it up a notch by throwing in some fun combat and shooting mechanics that leaves you curious how far you can stretch it's mechanics for the joy of taking down monsters in an almost Devil May Cry like fashion.

The story itself is also fairly deep and you can tell Capcom was passionate about creating a complex and intertwining story. At key moments in the 4 campaigns the characters collide and it's fun to explore the different campaigns perspectives for the overall narrative and how it all ties together at the end.

Finally it's coop allows you to experience this joy ride alongside a friend while you laugh at it's batshit crazyness. It will never live up to it's predecessors but it doesn't have to. Resident Evil 6 stands on it's own and if you can accept that it's not a survival horror then you got a really great Resident Evil worthy experience on your hands.

Oh and give Mercenary mode a try while you're at it. I'd argue it's the best entry of Mercenary we have seen in the franchise so far.

Resident Evil 6 HAD to happen in order for series to be actually good again. I don't hate it necessarily and I do have some fun playing it, but it is so far removed from anything I played RE for, it could easily be called a different name entirely.

And yes, while the game is not "scary", there is plenty of horror in this game... story/theme/general goal of the game is to tell a horror story... but it also wants to offer an action adventure, and a war story... all at once. Can you see the problem? So you play through a campaign of your choosing, let's say Jake, and it goes like this...

You start on a battlefield, lots of enemies, explosions, cool macho posturing. After 15 minutes you end up in a horror scenario locked in a warehouse with an invincible monster, then you go through a creepy blink-and-you-miss-it manequin factory, then there is a layered battle sequence against a giant angry monster, then you are shooting down helicopters and incoming rackets. END Chapter 1.

EVERY chapter does this. Every 10-15 minutes you get thrown into a different style of gameplay and the game wants you to feel something different. But NONE of it works, because everything is so over-producer and over-eager to please everyone. Nothing sticks with you. This is a horror story of epic proportions as told by Michael Bay. Lots of explosions and cleavages, lots of macho posturing, lots of slow motion and "epic" setpieces.

I love Resident Evil and I have a strong tolerance for bullshit as far as this series go. However I cannot recommend Resident Evil 6 to anyone, unless they are a complete newcomer to the series and have never played a 3rd person over the shoulder shooter in their life.

I have played through RE6 several times back when it came out on PS3, completed all the campaigns and let me tell you, the dissapointment with this game only grows stronger every time I return to it.

Almost every thing that could have gone wrong did, in fact, go wrong. This game is a prime example of bloated budget, overblown development and wrongheaded executive decisions. There are TONS of content in this game but none of it works as it should.

It was a slog to play all those years ago and it is still slog to play now. It is not fun, the story is a complete pointlessly complicated yet extremely dumb bullshit. The game takes itself way too seriously to be in any way enjoyable at least on that level.

Let me list some points...

+ Excellent soundtrack and presentation.

- The game is emotionaly empty. It is not scary, funny, thrilling, tense or anything... it is so terribly univolving and dull it hurts.

- The atmosphere is non-existent. You have several cities thrown into chaos, numerous viral outbreaks etc. but it just leaves you cold. You don't care about anything happening on screen.

- The gameplay is just a rehash of RE5, but with the fun sucked out of it completely. More of everything does not make a great game. There are more enemies, more combos, more scenarios, more main characters, more on-rails shooter segments, more giant boss fights, more mounted weapons etc.. And nothing of it is done correctly or interestingly in any way, shape or form. There IS some fun  to be had (mainly in co-op) but it is buried under tons of bizzare choices.

Let me start by saying I have over 1000 hours in the series and easily +20k in games in general. 
I play games for fun even when they're bad, sometimes they are fun because they're bad.

This isn't one of those games.

RE6 is both a bad Resident Evil as well as a bad game in general.

Some games lure you in by giving you a grand opening followed by falling off rapidly. Thankfully, RE6 is horrible from the very first second.

You start by only being able to move forward. No matter which button you press. Same speed, same animation. You can either move forward like a slug or stand still. 
There is no penalty and nothing to see. This should be a cutscene. Instead it's a mix of cutscenes, quicktime events and holding down a button.
The quicktime events are especially egregious. None of them have to be one. At one point you have to press a button to hold your partner's hand.

Next scene is the same. You walk, your input gets interrupted by a short cutscene, you press a button, you get a cutscene yada yada yada. Some cutscenes stutter to interrupt the monotony. I haven't found a game I couldn't play on highest settings and this isn't even gameplay, it's a cutscene. There is no reason for it to stutter. 

You learn how to handle the menu and oh boy if that's not the point where you quit then hats off to you. 
If you put a gun to my head and tell me to navigate through this atrocity to find a specific item I'd tell you to pull the trigger.

By the way, throughout all cutscenes and interactions neither Leon nor Hannigan speak and act like Leon or Hannigan.
Don't worry if you don't know either. They are still horrible.

You get a few more sets of cutscenes, buttons to press and whatnot (engaging gameplay!) and get to the scene where you're literally told to run throughout the whole scene.
You can't fail. There's not quicktime event to du. No buttons to smash. You press move+shift and hold it. Again, no reason for any of this to exist.

Your escape runs into trouble because someone on your helicopter randomly turns into a zombie. Were they bit? No.
Why do they turn? Who cares. Here, have a crashing helicopter and some fiery explosion. Micheal Bay would be proud.

The following area is a bit darker, which is a horrible thing because you finally realize that Leon's hair wasn't just shining because of the fire around him. It always is.
Apparently he grabbed chrome instead of shampoo. Lighting also changes randomly in certain spots.

Speaking of Leon, he's a massive pussy.
Here's a things your character will be scared of visibly:
- Thunder
- Noise
- Running into a chair

You think I'm exaggerating? Try running into a chair. Nothing else is going on. No cutscene or anything. This is part of his gameplay. Any chair you run into will scare you.
Speaking of running, this is the part where you're randomly unable, able and forced to run.
Sometimes you can't, sometimes you can, sometimes you have to because normal movement is disabled. No cutscenes inbetween, it just randomly switches.

Why? For the glory of satan of course.

On the topic of being scared: Our hero Leon S. Kennedy is letting a random university staff member go ahead and clear debris.
You couldn't even do it if you wanted. You have to let a civilian go ahead during a zombie apocalypse.

You know, like a true hero.

Speaking of true hero, he is at least a true gentleman. Should you decide to want to move on to the next area you will wait for your partner, no matter what happens.
There is no way to end waiting prematurely. Enemies coming closer? Tough luck, you're waiting. Shouldn't have tried to assume your AI partner is competent enough to run straight towards you.

At this point you've barely played a little more than the tutorial.

This game is utter garbage and unlike many games, which get tolerable if you love the series, it actually gets worse if you played any other part.

It's a bad resident evil and a bad game in general.

But after that, you're in for hell of a ride!

The Resident Evil series is knowingly a long-running franchise and it's still relevant due to the way it keeps reinventing itself, often to controversial results.

One of these reinventions was the series actionized escalation, which started becomeing evident in RE4 and reached its apex here in Resident Evil 6, before critical mass'ing and returning to its pure horror roots in RE7.

Resident Evil 6 is divided into 4 scenarios, each with different characters, parallel stories that connect and different playstyles.
- Leon and Helena have a more classically-bent, RE4 inspired campaign facing mostly zombies.
- Chris and Piers have a very actionized story facing against the more intelligent J'avos, infected "half-zombies".
- Jake and Sherry also follow an action-heavy story that has elements of a Mr. X / Nemesis like entity thoughout the plot.
- Ada goes back to a more puzzle-focused campaign that is reminiscent of older titles.

All in all, I really enjoyed this game. The action scenes, plot and sheer impressive moments are incredible, and voice acting is top-notch delivered by greats such as Matthew Mercer, Laura Bailey, Roger C. Smith and Troy Baker.

It may not be the best one in the series and too actionized for fans of the classical survival-horror titles, but RE6 is a very fine all action game with horror aesthetics.

Best played in Co-op with a friend for the full experience~

TL;DR, only buy it if you love bad games
First and foremost, this is a bad game. But I love it.
If you're into bad games, play this. Try it. Play it on easy, don't take it seriously. 
if you play the game on normal or higher, too many of the enemies are just bullet sponges that show no reaction to being shot. I remember 5 different times while playing through the first chapter, I had to stop and google if a mini boss was un-killable because I really could not tell if I was making any impact.. There's no cry of pain, hardly even a flinch. And several times through the end boss of chapter one, I ran out of Ammo and had to just stand around until Someone came to help me. There was no way to melee the boss, I had to just wait until more ammo dropped then run out of that and wait again.
If you play this game on normal, you will have a bad time. It will feel like playing catch with your older cousin but they're all twice your size and you can't catch the ball and they don't even try to make it easy for you. It's punishing and upsetting. 
If you play it on Easy, you will have a great time. The story is so over the top bad and stupid and just weird. and the mechanics are so laughably bad too. You never feel like you have control of Leon or Helena or Sherry or whoever, it always feels like they're some klutzy idiot who got stuck in a children's playhouse and you're shouting instructions from outside to help them get out but they keep bumping into things and making things worse for themselves.
The ambition is so well intentioned but misplaced. they tried to make three different campaign styles, it basically boils down to having different weapons. The "classic Resident evil horror side" for Helena and Leon is the exact same as Chris's story except you get a pistol instead of a rifle as your primary. Sherry and Jake's unique "nemesis style" gameplay boils down to brief running and puzzle segments against this unkillable enemy. It's not worth getting excited over
Now for the truly bad parts that no one will enjoy, even if you like bad games.
The bosses at the end of every campaign are terrible. Chris probably has the most interesting as he fights a titan sized mutant that's essentially an aborted BOW that survived. It's confusing and hard to figure out how you actually do damage. Leon and Helena fight a politician turned Mutant BOW and I swear you fight and "kill" him 9 different times. You'll be begging for it to be over, you just get tired of him and wish he'd just be gone. Sherry and Jake just off the "nemesis" that's been chasing them.
Worst resident evil game ever! Killed my family out of rage.

[b]Disclaimer [/b]: Although it says I've played over 36 hours of this game, there's a chunk of it that was just spent with me AFK. This review was also posted as of finishing the campaigns of Leon (veteran & professional difficulty), Chris (veteran difficulty), and Jake (veteran difficulty). I just started Ada's campaign on veteran and I'm almost frustrated enough to uninstall rather than finish it.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Four separate campaigns, each with several difficulty levels, that provide plenty of play time, provided you're not frustrated by the cons that I'll be mentioning below.
+ Leon's campaign is very reminiscent of older Resident Evil games, since you've got traditional RE zombies in there. The nostalgia kinda falls off once the action and story just get ridiculous, like [spoiler] fighting the big bad of Leon's campaign who transforms into a zombie centaur,  then a zombie dinosaur, and then a Godzilla-sized zombie fly. [/spoiler] The early parts of his campaign do have a nice horror feel to it, though. I definitely enjoyed that.
+ Somewhat decent AI partner if you decide to play single-player. It's not great, but not terrible either.
+ Wide selection of weapons to use, ranging from pistols to shotties, automatics, explosives, and more.
+ Skill system that encourages replaying the game to unlock more skills.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- The camera angles can be a worse enemy than bosses or even regular enemies and turns even mundane fights into a struggle; it feels like they took the worst parts of the original RE camera angles and slapped it onto RE4's over-the-shoulder tank controls, so suddenly switching from over-the-shoulder to fixed camera angles throws off your direction/movement flow. It's janky as hell.
- Very limited inventory space; it's hard to hold more than one stack of each ammo and throwable type together with herbs and first aid sprays.
- Too many quick-time events. It's easy to tell that the game isn't modern at all based on the sheer number of QTEs the game throws at you. It's also incredibly frustrating when failing a QTE just instantly results in a mild case of death. Combined with the janky controls and bad camera angles, it's sometimes already a challenge just to start the QTE, then a horror story when you actually have to punch in all those QTEs once they've started.
- The camera angles are just so bad.
- Story-wise, [spoiler] the whole background can be summed up as "guy gets too horny for some woman in red and starts a bioterrorism crisis." [/spoiler] The RE franchise's story is generally cheesy, but this one's less cheesy and more just bad. It even gets to the point that the big bad goes on a full mustache-twirling let-me-tell-you-what-evil-things-I've-done monologue at some point.
- Dying multiple times to a forced POV/camera angle switch isn't fun at all.
- Not a fan of how hitting Esc to open the menu in single-player mode doesn't pause the game at all. You have to press the dedicated pause button to do that, and you can't access the menu to change up any settings while the game's paused. When a zone was too dark and I needed to brighten it up a bit, I had to raise the brightness while hiding behind cover, only to get killed by an ambush.
- The game isn't well-optimized for PC. I'm a bit over the minimum requirements and running everything on the lowest graphics settings, yet I'm seeing sudden framerate drops on occasion that turn it into a slideshow or just outright freeze the screen for a moment and result in me dying/failing the objective. The same goes for cutscenes; most of them end up have desynchronized audio and video, with the cutscene stuttering for a moment and the audio lagging behind once it resumes.
- Did I mention how much I dislike or even outright hate the forced camera angles?
- Considering how long ago this game was released, I didn't have any expectations for online multiplayer. Tried it out anyway and it's pretty much dead. If you're really looking for a proper multiplayer experience with this, bring a friend along with you. Public lobbies/matchmaking isn't happening here.
- Speaking of multiplayer, game modes like Siege are locked behind DLC. On top of buying the game, you gotta pay for that feature too.
- To whoever decided to put forced camera angles and janky tank controls together, who hurt you so badly that you had to take it out on everyone who decided to play this game? After playing this, I'm glad camera angles and controls got overhauled for the Resident Evil 2 remake.

Edited for formatting and the disclaimer up top.

[b]TL;DR[/b]: not a good Resident Evil game at all, but could've been a half-decent action game. However, it's completely ruined by forced camera angles with janky tank controls, and a worse-than-average-for-a-videogame story. [b] Would NOT recommend. [/b]

The worst game I've played in years.
Not since the Wii eras shovelware have I experienced a game this poor. I was dead set on playing all of the RE games, but I can't stand a game which makes me feel physically ill after a 1 hour session.

This is where the series finally took the jump in the chaotic, filthy cesspit of over-the-top, dumb action, taking all of the bad things that characterizes what I like to call the "AI Trilogy": RE4-5-6, three games in which you're stuck with a dumb AI companion that hinders more than it helps you. Now, I agree that RE4 was a good turn for the series and it has its iconic moments but it set a very bad trend for the series with a focus on action that doesn't always work right. I enjoyed RE4 because it tried something new while keeping some of the classic DNA. It did just enough to be fun without being ridiculously frustrating. RE5 was an annnoying but decent experience with its moments and I respect the bold decision to make a RE game set during daytime. RE6, though, was an exercise in frustration with a pacing that's constantly crippled by scripted events and QTEs. 

RE6 tried to be that epic blockbusters that brings well-known heroes of the RE universe in an epic multi-layered fight to save the world, much like most Hollywood action movies with shared universes. In Capcom's mind, it meant explosions and self-destruct sequences, tense chase scenes and incredibly tough bosses who only drag the fight on for the sake of spectacle. You could argue it would work for an actual action movie but even so, a good action movie doesn't drag things for too long. And RE6 likes to overstay its welcome with pathetic attempts at padding with QTEs you barely have any time to react to and that kills you instantly. These doesn't serve the game at all, it's just an half-assed attempt to keep players on their toes, not because of surprise attacks from monsters but because at aty time the game might plop you in front of the jaws of some annoying trap that will immediately kill you should you fail to press the buttons quick enough.

This game should be called "RE6: Wigglesticks" because wiggling the joystick and mashing buttons is what you do the most often in this game, wheter it's to shake off an enemy or avoiding a cheap death trap. QTE to avoid a blade sticking out of the wall, QTE to not get your head stuck in a grinder because of a monster popping out of nowhere, QTE for this, QTE for that. Even combat has QTEs to kill or push a zombie who grabbed you, this I could forgive more easily, but the rest are just scripted bullshit that just slow the game.

And you have four bad campaigns to get through, three of which must be completed to unlock the fourth one and they're all mostly forgettable. Leon's campaign is supposed to be the most "survival horror" of the four but this is where you get most of the annoying QTEs and insta-kill traps. Chris' campaign turns the game into a cover-shooter with most setpieces being shooting gallery that has you fight gun-toting terrorists that can mutate into half-monster creatures. And Jake's campaign is the most laughable of all, it puts you up against a gimmicky monstrosity called the Ustanak, who's basically a discount Nemesis. Between uninspired boss fights and chase scenes, you have a dumb stealth section in which you have to avoid some kind of insects who warns the Ustanak of your presence and you get insta-killed if you don't hide before he gets you. Finally, you get Ada's campaign, which is a subpar attempt at stealth, putting you in tight corridors where you have to takedown enemies to avoid alerting everyone around and getting overwhelmed. These four campaigns are easily the weakest part of the game and they're a proof that quantity over quality is no way to make a memorable experience.

As for the story well, it makes no sense, as expected. With each new game since RE4, the series jumped the shark to ridiculous extent. Here you have a virus that has little to no explanation and only seems to infect anyone who doesn't wear plot armor and the games enjoyes cliché'd tropes way too much, like the big tough hero Chris turning in an alcoholic asshole because his men died during a mission or Helena trying to reason with a too-far-gone, mutated sister or the bad guy Simmons going on about bringing order to the world through viral warfare. The game is shock-full of bad clichés and predictable twists without even the slightest attempt at surprising the player. If this was a bad Hollywood action movie, nobody would bat an eye but unfortunately, this is a bad action movie you have to PLAY.

Sadly, the most fun I've had with the game is its Mercenaries mode, in which the game's combat truly shines. Unlike the main campaigns, here you actually need to use all kinds of combat moves and strategies to stay on top since you can't rely on an AI partner to save your butt once you go down. You can use slides, tackles and follow-ups to bring enmies down and you have to prioritizes threats to avoid taking an attack that can damage you hard or worse, insta-kill you. You can unlock characters and costumes through playing the mode and it'll keep you busy in a much more satisfying way that the campaign ever will. To be honest, Mercenaries should have been the whole game; a spin-off title with heavy focus on action, pulling monsters and stages from the entire RE universe, a bit like Mercenaries 3D on 3DS did but with much better technology and more content. 

And this might be the reason I would recommend getting this game on sale for a low-low price because the best part of RE6 is an extra mode where the action focus actually works. But even so, there are other action games that might scratch that shooting gallery itch a lot more for the price, even though, in my opinion, the "shoot-enemy > Follow-up attack" of post-4 Resident Evil games is so satisfying. If you really want to get this, keep your expectations very, very low for the campaigns and don't expect anything groundbreaking for the Mercenaries mode. As far as Resident Evil games go, its overall mediocrity is only outdone by the likes of Operation Raccoon City and Revelations 2.

I love this game so much :) I know everyone else hate this game

Here is the problem. If you set aside the fact that there is nothing scary about this game, that it doesn't even resemble classic resident evil, you are still more or less left with a half assed action game. 

First of all, the game is entirely too long. Like, I actually would really enjoy the multiple campaigns with interweaving stories... if they actually told a story. Seriously, the story in this game felt the most jarring and incoherent. At least with Resident Evil 5 shit kind of made sense, at least there were notes and things that you could read here and there. This game has none of that. You get virtually no in game notes. I think the game mentioned that you can shoot these blue medallion things to get access to the files, but honestly is that even storytelling at that point? I'm going to go into more spoiler heavy stuff here:  [spoiler]So the game has 4 campaigns, you can play through leon, chris, and jake in any order, but you get ada after you beat the other three. You can more or less play them in any order, but be warned that there is a lot of overlap sometimes. In fact, I feel like the game could have done more to make the experience slighly more linear and skip sections you have already played. For example: There are two boss fights in Jake's campaign that (assuming you've played Leon or Chris) that you end up doing again. A whole two ass boss fights that the game just MAKES you replay.  Anyways, as far as the story is concerned this game has the depth of a mud puddle. None of the characters are interesting, none of their objectives are complex, and the virus just makes no sense and is never explained. It just is.[/spoiler]

Gameplay wise this game is all over the damn place. The gunplay is alright, however most of the guns feel like they are lacking in power. Enemies will sometimes just flat out ignore the fact that they've just been shot, and this is wildly inconsistent. Sometimes the enemies fly back and recoil after taking a buckshot, other times they just keep charging you. The game gives ample resources, but then throws you into boss fights where you will drain through resources like crazy because the bosses are either complete bullet sponges or they go down in two hits once you find the right way to defeat them. There is no consistency with that. The game also likes to throw you into situations where you will die instantly if you don't press a certain button or move fast enough. 

The level structure is boring. The game consists of shooting galleries. There are a few unique segments where you get to drive vehicles, but these are mainly on-a-rail sections that last a whole 2 seconds. There also seems to be in every chapter a section where you collect 3 keys, which are honestly the worst sections. They serve no purpose but to extend an already bloated game. 

The enemies in this game suck. I swear those black goop guys are really annoying, and the fly things are the worst. The enemies aren't fun or exciting. They fall into three categories: 1. Fodder enemies 2. Bullet Sponge enemies 3. Bullet sponges that instant kill. Also the game has enemies with guns, and they knock you over constantly, which would be no big deal if I was fighting a boss, but these dudes are legit the standard enemy.

Last but not least, the camera gave me motion sickness. Idk who thought it would be a good idea to make the screen violently shake up and down when you try to adjust the camera while running, but they should be fired.

Basically, this game sucks. I don't know why I finished it. I thought maybe i'd be paid back in some way. I wasn't. Honestly, just watch all the cut scenes for this game and you'll be fine.

This game is perhaps one of the most poorly thought out and executed games I have ever played. Capcom has zero idea of who their audience was for this one. They have combined all of the worst parts of all the previous games into a bloated monstrosity. 

The controls are abysmal. The UI and inventory management are the most unintuitive systems I have ever used. The game actively fights you at every turn to merely try to walk along and try to enjoy yourself. It constantly interrupts the action to draw your attention to the thousandth building on fire while you slowly amble along while things are trying to kill you. During one fight there were 4 cutscenes that took control away from you in the span of 20 seconds. It switches to fixed camera angles abruptly but doesn't compensate for the current inputs so you are left spinning in circles or facing the wrong way during difficult or timed encounters. The biggest sin of this game is how much control it takes away from the player. It is more frustrating than enjoyable. RE6 can be used as a guide of what not to do in a game for almost every single design choice.

There is almost no puzzle solving or exploration of any sort in Leon and Chris's campaign (disclaimer: I haven't played the other two yet). You pick up all these weapons that you can barely use because you can't carry much ammo at all and the tablet system for healing is absolutely ridiculous. There is no combining or examining items in the inventory. It feels like they wanted to make an action movie and completely forgot what fans like about the series. None of the weapons feel satisfying to use since non-basic enemies are extreme bullet sponges. I will say the visualization of headshot damage on basic zombies is good.

The writing is atrocious even for the usually cheesy dialogue of the series. The characters are completely out of character and make the worst possible decision at every opportunity. They constantly lament their comrades/civilians who were killed but are causing large scale devastation and collateral damage. Resident Evil 5 looks like a masterpiece next to this game.

The quick time events are perhaps the most annoying ones I have ever encountered in a game. They add nothing. You could be walking down a hallway with a bunch of bodies on the floor. You can't shoot the enemies ahead of time and instead you have to let them grab you and mash buttons while they damage you.

This game completely jumps the shark. There are a bunch of giant, towering enemies that just have no place in the universe. We've switched back to a virus after the parasite in 4 and 5. The virus is airborne yet the characters walk through virus clouds constantly without any effects except when the story makes it dangerous. I'd gladly punch 10 boulders over the stupid set pieces in this game.

I'm happy that Capcom found its way after this complete pile of garbage with 7. A soft reboot was the only way to fix this travesty. I sincerely hope that whoever thought this game was fun and in a state to be released    no longer works in game development.

As somebody who is not a long-time Resident Evil fan, I´m comfortable to make the following statement, after finishing RE 2 Remastered and finishing RE 6 Chapter 1:
Resident Evil is... evolving.
Like Assassin´s Creed, they are taking out the boring stuff and leaving only what really matters. (in AC, I never liked to lose a mission merely by being spotted; they took that away and it got so much better - my opinion)
In RE 2 Remastered, there was a lot of secrets, hidden things, annoying puzzles, a humongous amount of backtracking. So, more often than not, I was forced to look into the internet for walkthroughs, hints, etc. The remastered game was gorgeous to look at, but the hindrances and time-consuming little tasks and mini-quests took away from the experience.
And this is the word: experience.
Resident Evil 6 is waaay more straighforward. You have somewhere to go, you know the general direction you must go,  you have to free yourself from grappling zombies by means of manageable quicktime events, deal with zombies by shooting them (of course) or barehanded beat them, open doors, jump fences, climb stairs... nothing too fancy or mysterious. Even when a key is needed to open a door, the key is nearby. 
So you must just... go on, and keep going.
So you can really focus on and feel the experience of fighting for your life in a zombie hellish mayhem, a dark, confusing, chaotic, flaming nightmare, beautifully rendered, as the story progresses at every checkpoint. (oh, and the checkpoints are always ahead of you, not behind you - you really move FORWARD in this game, you don´t run in circles like a lab rat)
This games really provides you the experience of being in a zombie apocalypse. Nothing more, nothing less.
So far, this is the zombie apocalypse game I´ve been looking for for so long.

UPDATE: I´m on Chapter 6 (of 20...) The game is throwing an almost impossible to beat boss at me, right after having me play a sequence of actions that were almost identical to the ones on Chapter 1. The developers forgot Bauhaus motto, "less is more". In this case, more is just more. If I wanted to fight boss after boss, I´d go to Dark Souls. This game is getting less fun by the minute. I still recommend it, though, because there´s quality gaming content here, although right now it is distancing itself from my preferred taste.

UPDATE 2: Turns out the impossible-to-beat monster was the final boss of Leon´s campaign. I´m satisfied, because I had the good feeling of accomplishing an ending right after defeating the final boss. I had closure. Now I´m starting Chris´campaign. I will refrain from commenting it. I´ll just say it´s quite different from Leon´s, and you can carry the skills you got from the previous campaign to this one.

Resident Evil Six is one of the worst Resident Evil Games ever made, ranking slightly better then ORC or Gun Survivor, but this is sadly less the fault of the game and more of a fault of Capcom itself.  Resident Evil 6 was released during the "Call of Duty Action" and QTE Crazes in gaming, back when every game had to be a heavy action shooter like CoD and or have Quick Time, of which Resident Evil 6 has both and of which dramatically hurt the overall gameplay.

The Gameplay itself is decent enough, its rather mundane but as good as any coop shooter at the time.. It could have been better if the upgrades were good. Overall, if you're going to play Resident Evil 6 you're going to want to play with a friend, and the movie action like gameplay is going to be constantly fighting your ability to enjoy the game.  The 4 campaigns are overall passable, if not mundane.. but they would have been far better served as actual movies.

Oh man...this game....this game...I have a love/hate relationship with.

On the good side, great fun with friends, they give variety to the game play with vehicle missions, and I love the whole separate story lines coming together into one main story line gimmick.

Now the bad side, the Jake and Sherry game play sucked! Cheap deaths, confusing levels and frustrating sections. Now I love being chased by a huge tyrant along with the next guy but when you get a death cutscene when you are miles away from him is a whole different matter all together. You can just tell it was not programmed well with camera whiplash during chase sequences. It almost killed the whole game for me.

Also, Ada's story seems to kind of be tacked on but it is enjoyable and it gives an outside looking in perspective of every  other character's play through. I think my friend and I died laughing because everyone ignores the second player character known only as "Agent." He does not exist in the story but it is comical to see this character just be "there." with no other purpose but to be Player 2.

I would recommend playing Leon or Chris' campaign first then Jake followed by Ada.

To start this off this was the last of all of the mainline Resident Evil games I played. Many of the games in the series are up there with some of my favourite games of all time. I came into this game expecting a game in the vein of Resident Evil 5 but attempting to cater more to the action crowd with a bit more of an action centric game. It was much worse than what I came to expect. I went in with middling expectations and came out having played a game that I can easily list with the worst games I've ever played.

Cons:
- Playing the same segments multiple times to pad out content because "two characters were there"
- Weapon accuracy is all over the place due to the erratic laser pointers
- The movement controls. Getting characters to accurately move to where you want to go is so much harder than it should be and makes for a frustrating experience trying to interact with things.
- The map design is occasionally so unreadable there had to be a button to point the player in the right direction.
- Almost everything in the game stun locks you constantly taking control away from the player 24/7 which is incredibly frustrating.
- Almost the entire game is non stop action with tedious enemies that weren't fun to fight without any breaks.
- A lot of the story threads in the game went nowhere and there were some laughably bad moments thrown in there. Chris' story was somewhat interesting but the military focus lead to the majority of the gameplay feeling incredibly generic and tedious.
- The coop. It might as well not exist. If you need to do something in coop it usually involves both players doing the same puzzle individually or being an assistant to killing enemies. (In the 4th campaign your coop partner can't even interact with the world)
- The inventory system. Seeing as the game made the effort of streamlining it out I'm not sure why it still exists just to mix herbs. Having it there just to have to fumble with the single row inventory during the hectic combat scenes does not work well.
- Constant quick time events for everything you do doesn't make for engaging game play. The analogue wobble ones are just ridiculous.
- The in game menu's were a bit of a mess mainly due to the fact all of the options were only icons so many of the options require you to scan over them to know what they are.
- The camera is thrown to different locations quite often making playing those sections even more difficult along with the dodgy movement systems. A lot of the times they'll just get you killed.
- The game occasionally changes the aiming methods of your character from keeping the crosshair in the centre to moving the crosshair around the screen. Why?
- Everything that made Resident Evil what it was is gone in this game.

Pros:
- There are a few decent story cut scenes.
- There were a couple of basic puzzles in two of the campaigns which were alright.
- The attempt at interweaving story lines was an interesting idea and  it was cool to see an alternate story line playing in the background of a few segments.
- The character models look pretty good graphically for the time it came out.
- The dive mechanic is pretty fun.
- It can be so ridiculous at times that it can crack you up

RE6 has a half baked story that tried to do way too much to please everyone but ended up being... Just kinda boring on all fronts. It felt more fun when it came out on the PS3 back in 2012, whether that's due to the more intuitive controls, the new-game hype, having more people to play with online, or some combination of the three, I don't know.

For fans of the older Resident Evils, you'll notice that RE6 shoves (or rather, drop kicks) some of your favourite characters towards the "anime protagonist" side of the spectrum, they definitely aren't just survivors anymore. This was the turning point that made Capcom backtrack towards a more subtle gameplay style for a reason. You get to see Chris and Leon together for the first time in-game though, so that's pretty neat.

Overall, there are worse ways to spend $8, but if you buy this for full price then I have no sympathy for you when you end up disappointed.
