I first wrote a much more negative review about 14 hours into the game, but now after having beaten the main 3 campaigns, my opinion has changed a lot, mostly because I played what I think is the most fun campaign (Jake and Sherry's) last. 

Graphically I think this game looks great, and still holds up well today despite originally being an Xbox 360 title. I love how almost all of the areas look.

Plot wise, there's a lot going on, but I do really enjoy how as you play each campaign you get a much fuller piece of the picture. It's a story told from 3 perspectives, but at the end of the day it's pretty simple, there's a zombie virus that lots of people have and some dummy wants to use the virus to make a bunch of money. It's what you would expect after resident evil 5. I did end up really caring about some of the characters, and one campaign's ending specifically was incredibly sad to me, despite me at first not really caring about the characters.

Gameplay wise, it is great! There sadly aren't many puzzles and for most of the game everything is pretty linear, but it's still fun. It's a very mindless resident evil, something you play to turn off your brain, but that can be good and relaxing. Again I do think that Jake's campaign is the best, so if you're looking for a smaller expierence I'd say to play that one.

Wow. It started out okay but then it just jumps the shark and goes in Michael Bay mode on steroids. There are way too many QTEs, worse than in RE5. And even then, the response is horrid. Also, the camera position is horrible. It's WAY too close and difficult to see what's around. AI is better in what it does in taking out enemies, but SO many times I've had them jump on top of me when I'm climbing ladders and they knock me down, making me lose time in many instances. Other times, they just sit there, blocking your path as the areas can become quite tight in places. Yet as you try to push your way through, they just stand there, oblivious of your intentions and not moving at all. I had to restart many levels because of this.

It started out almost like the scary REs before RE4, but definitely, they've ratcheted up the action beyond what RE5 was. And this is just into the first 4 chapters of the Leon campaign. It still has it's fun moments, but at times, especially into chapter 3, there's a lot of scripted QTE events that just seem to go on and on. Exploration is mainly for the Serpent emblems but that's it. Chapters 1 and 2 started out slowly, appearing to increase the tension then all of sudden, it's just non-stop action with some breathers here and there. It almost seems imbalanced possibly? It goes from one extreme to the other (nothing going on seemingly to build up the tension) then it just does a 180 and it's action, action, action. Still, it's RE right? So you have to play it and you can get enjoyment out of it, but for me, it just seemed to go too far in the action if that's even possible. 

The Chris campaign was nothing but action and way too many QTEs and scripted scenes. It just feels like the control has been taken away from us and we're just watching it rather than actually doing anything. This is RE's path to COD I guess. 

Jake and Sherry's mission is even more over the top than Chris' and there are so many "come on" moments that even Jake says that one point. I had to laugh as if even Capcom had to admit this was too much. 

It could have been so much better but then maybe we never would have gotten RE7 because of it, nor RE Village when it comes out.

Before I started Resident Evil 6, I had only heard about how bad of a game it was. However, to my surprise, RE6 is a really fun game. Now, while it is a pretty bad Resident Evil game, for an action game, it is quite solid. In fact, even though it isn't a very good RE game, I enjoyed it more than RE5. Along with this, I enjoyed the multiple stories, even if it overstays its welcome. Yet, even though I enjoyed my time in RE5, I completely understand why others dislike it; the controls are somewhat janky, the camera can be hit or miss, and the game is very linear. However, if you go into RE6 with the mindset that this is an action game, I think that you'll have a good time.

Personally
I prefer both Jake and Ada's campaign (mostly Ada's)

PROS
1) Fun multiplayer experience, connects easily with friends.

2) Controls are fine

3) Many characters involved in the campaign and playable too. 

4) Long gameplay which is fun

5) Beautiful graphics

6) Loving the location, more outdoor than indoor


CONS
1) The whole game felt rushed, inaccurate object size for example,  The styrofoam boxes for food and the chopstick on top is huge also the campus plates and etc. 80% of the time i yelled wtf?? 

2) QTE that is faster than sonic and unnecessary stuff like when Leon taking control of the plane, wanting players to look around to search for the button is annoying and can be avoided by just simply let the players flying it. 

3) On the other hand, the game makes no sense, I know games doesn't make sense but the law of physics does not apply here. Characters survived all the way from critical attacks and crashes like really?? Maybe a little is acceptable but way too much. For instance, Leon and Helena can stand steadily while the enemy flew away from the open plane with strong force and also managed to stand on top of the train while going fast. Just seems very scripted.

4) Boss defeated by QTE which is boring and lame unlike Resident Evil 5 and 4. 

5) The skill points wise, I preferred upgrading the guns which is again like previous RE game.

6) Bad camera angles, switching to fixed angle randomly while being chased, causing confusion and died instantly.This can be avoided again.

7) Odd low angle behind when running which is frustrating again why?

CONCLUSION,
Not bad but can be better. Overall, enjoyable

[SERIOUS REVIEW, PLEASE READ!!]

I have a been a big fan of the Resident Evil series ever since RE2 (1998), I was now once again reintroduced to the franchise as a teenager around the time RE2 remake was released. I heard Resident Evil 6 was the most hated game of the franchise because it diverted itself from the usual survival horror, to a co-op third person shooter game. I played this on the Switch, and I have to say that this game HAD a lot of potential. In some parts of the game, I remember or I am reminded of how similar the gameplay mechanics were to L4D2, the AI is also smart this time, so none of your partners will die and they actually respond really fast when you get downed! 

If only critics and fans of the game weren't so harsh, this game had the chance to become the next L4D2 game or replacement. The idea of having all of the characters in one game (Except Jake and Piers of course) sounds really cool, think of it as a reunion party.

Leon and Helena's campaign was really interesting, I felt connected to some of the background characters and I felt bad for them. Chris' campaign is like a warzone, fighting with big monsters and men with guns and tanks. Sherry's was okay, and felt more like survival. 

My only complaint was how bad the GUI or inventory system is, I have no idea how to bring out grenades and sometimes even trash herbs by accident! I guess I got too used to the switch version.

If you are ever getting this game, please do get it with a friend. It's such a fun game, and I recommend it alot.

ALSO THE SEXUAL TENSION BETWEEN PIERS AND CHRIS IS SO HOOOTTT

Honestly, I never cared about all the negative reviews this game received. I never understood the need to crap on it sooo much. This is one of the most fun games I ever played. Since the moment I saw the trailer I knew it was going to be a memorable experience. 

The gameplay is really simple if you play it with a controller (using a keyboard and a mouse is easy too, but it can get confusing sometimes), the graphics are not top notch, but for the year this game came out it is really beautiful. ( Also I never really care for the graphics too much. It's not a crucial element of an enjoyable game.) The story is so ridiculous and over the top, a true Japanese writing that is so engaging and fun to watch even if they only released the cutscenes and made a movie instead of a whole game. The characters are all unique - the old ones, the new ones. They are actually written very well and made very sympathetic. Not to talk about how much the voice actors really enjoyed making the characters sound believable. All the kudos to them. The co-op is the best part, more so if you play with a friend.

Anyway, I've already played this game like a dozen times, and It's actually so big that I'm still learning things about it. I plan to re-play it a lot more in years to come. All I can say is, if you still haven't played RE6, this game is ridiculous in it's own way, definitely flawed, but it's an experience for a life-time. :)

Overall I think the game is pretty good and fun to play with friends.

Unlike its predecessor, The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt doesn't exactly come screaming off the starting line. Compared to The Witcher 2, where you're immediately plunged headlong into a sexy story of intrigue and betrayal, this main quest can seem mundane, even perfunctory at times. But each time I stepped off the well-beaten path to blaze my own trail, it turned into a wild, open, exhilarating fantasy roleplaying experience, rife with opportunities to make use of its excellent combat. Even after over 100 hours with The Witcher 3, it still tempts me to press on – there’s so much more I want to learn, and hunt.


The Witcher 3 is as dense and deep as the other two games in the series in terms of RPG mechanics, and the overwhelmingly massive open-world environment has at once made that depth more intimidating, and in the long run, more rewarding. It’s difficult to express just how huge and open this world is: verdant, rolling fields liberally dotted with swaying foliage of every shape and size fill the space between loosely connected, ramshackle townships where people struggle to scrape by. A full day/night cycle and dynamic weather pull it all together, cementing The Witcher 3’s landscape as one of the most authentic-feeling open worlds I’ve ever seen. A handy minimap points you where you want to go, which might seem like a crutch, but honestly, without it, I’d have been hopelessly lost. That a world this size still feels so purposeful, and full of things to do is quite an achievement.

The one caveat on all that though, is the technical performance on the PS4 version I played for review. 30 frames per second was sometimes too much to ask, transitions between The Witcher 3’s two main maps are just a bit too long, and minor glitches do pop up from time to time. None of it ever impacted gameplay in any meaningful way, thought it did compromise the beauty of the experience ever so slightly.

This new open-world map obviously has ramifications for the structure of the story, and though there are flashes of greatness, the main story is ultimately the least fulfilling part of The Witcher 3. You might call it another case of The Elder Scrolls Syndrome. Our tale begins as a multi-continent search for Geralt’s long-lost lover Yennifer, and Ciri, his surrogate daughter. My single biggest issue though, is that it never becomes much more: the overly long main story is essentially just Geralt running errands for people in exchange for information on Ciri’s whereabouts. It effectively maintains focus and momentum, but it feels more like a wild goose chase than an intriguing mystery to unravel, like the one we got in Assassins of Kings.

Thanks to lots of excellent dialogue and voice acting there is some emotional payoff along the way, but it’s mixed in with too much padding in the form of meaningless fetch quests and collectathons. Every time I felt like I was on the verge of an interesting revelation, I’d have to suddenly stop to escort a goat, or search for a lost, narcoleptic dwarf. Heck, even Geralt can barely hide his frustration with the constant parade of menial tasks at times.

It’s also worth noting that though you will get along fine without playing the first two games in the series, without the context provided by the Witcher novels, Ciri is more or less a complete stranger until the last quarter of the journey, which made it difficult to care about finding her as much as The Witcher 3 expected me to – especially given the slew of intriguing characters who are relegated to supportive background roles.


Thankfully, they all get chances to shine once you venture off the beaten path, and that’s where The Witcher 3 gets nearly everything incredibly right. Depending on your decisions in The Witcher 2 (which can be handily recreated via some dialogue early in the game), you’ll see lots of familiar faces returning to play a role in Geralt’s search, and once they have, they offer you a secondary line of quests that typically provide far more interesting scenarios to dabble in. Underground turf wars, assassination plots, love triangles, and unexpected alliances are all part of these optional romps. They’re all so meaty and full of rich story content that they feel like they should have been part of the main story.

The same can be said for a lot of the side quests you pick up in the field as well. Aside from the bevy of standard side-quests, monster lairs, and bandit camps generously littered about The Witcher 3’s gargantuan land mass, you also get a bunch of monster-hunting Witcher contracts to persue. Geralt's quarry ranges from ethereal wraiths that need to be made tangible before you can harm them, to Foglets who conceal themselves in thick smog, waiting for a chance to strike. The payoff here is twofold: in keeping with the lore, these represent your most reliable stream of income, which is refreshingly significant due to an appropriately stingy in-game economy.

The other upside is that, more often than not, these hunts and other side activities provide interesting insights into a land being destroyed by war, and the many forces that play a role in shaping it. Best of all, you’re one of those forces. It may not shift the main story’s conclusion in monumental ways, but I often returned to places I’d visited earlier to find that a seemingly small decision played out in a very big way. There is no morality meter, no paragon or renegade rating. In the grayscale world of The Witcher 3, there is only cause and effect; the decisions you make, both big and small, can legitimately change the world around you – far more so than most games that make similar claims.

Character progression and equipment choices are equally impactful. Relative to The Witcher 2, I found that Witcher 3’s RPG systems have been streamlined in some ways, and made more complex in others. In both cases though, the result is the same: a better experience. Simplifications to how you restock and use potions and oils makes them feel more practical and immediately useful, as you no longer need to meditate to do any of it. Sure, the old way was more in keeping with Witcher lore, but in a wide open world, it makes less sense to expect players to predict and prepare for everything they might come across in advance. On the flip side, there’s a wider variety of powerful, interesting potions than ever, including those that greatly enhance mounted combat, and others that restore health as you cast spells (or Signs as Witchers call them).


Speaking of Signs, they’ve been improved across the board with alternate casting modes, and a wider variety of upgrades, making them impactful in every fight. It’s actually entirely viable to build a sign-focused Geralt. I played him a lot like a Jedi actually, able to influence people’s minds in conversation, a powerful long range “force” push, and the ability to reflect crossbow bolts back to the sender (a returning ability that’s been made far more usable). The new skill system provides a good deal of flexibility while still rewarding players who want min/max for the best builds, and weapon and armor crafting is as deep and nuanced as ever, if not more so.

All of this shines through in The Witcher 3’s responsive, brutal real-time combat. Where combat in this series has up until this point felt vague and even a bit clunky, here it’s so fluid and satisfying that I walk around hoping for bandits to jump me just so I can repel their attacks with magical barriers, parry their blows with uncanny precision, and relieve them of life and/or limb with the occasional gory flourish. The Witcher has always done a great job of making me feel that I’ve outsmarted my foes, but for the first time here, controlling Geralt feels tangibly badass with every successful fight.

while RE6 failed at being a Resident evil game i do still considered it somehow a decent game so that's my short review of it :)
the campaigns: RE6 is splitted into four campaigns that are connected to each other and you get to play as familiar favourite characters and some are new to the fans (leon s kennedy and helena harper , jake muller and sherry birkin, chris redfield and piers nivans, ada wong)
and with that being said the focusing on making it co-op playable and having a non-controlled partner covering your back and too much action totally eliminated the horror aspect that the series is known for, perhaps it would have worked better
the story may not be the best but it's still good and interesting and it has it's emotional moments 
the gameplay: decent and enjoyable, every character has his own unique weapons and play style and upgradable skills there's as well few puzzles here and there which is nice, and let's not forget the QTE which is not everyone is a fan of, but I heard it can be turned off in the options
multiplayer: there are some fun game modes like the mercenaries and pvp modes some are only included when getting the complete pack edition which I wouldn't really suggest it because the multiplayer is dead but the price difference isn't big so it's up to you, my advice is look for the steam game groups to find people who still play them since it doesn't take so many players to full a lobby
the controls: I found them easy to forget sometimes especially if I haven't played it in a while but they're good once you get used to them again
graphics and optimization: it seems like capcom didn't focus on that aspect much, there are some spots and objects that have a really terrible looking textures even when all the settings are maxed out but they can be easily ignored, the optimization is great and it isn't really demanding so I believe most of the low end PC's would be able to run it just fine
conclusion: even with it's flaws it's still a fun game if you don't treat it like a RE game and I recommend it for players who are looking for a nice story co-op experience!

Nude mod.

***First, I would like to thank my dear friend, Bachito, as he was the reason that motivated me to buy this game***

[I AM ONLY TALKING ABOUT MERCENARIES MOD]

Game Mechanics & Ideas:
The game allows you to move and shoot at the same time. You can also evade enemy attacks & best of all counter them. The weapon switching is also done very fast & efficient. They also allow you to press buttons or move analog sticks (Controller users) to get out of sub-bosses which put you in instant dying mod which is pretty creative & fair. The Weapons' mechanics, sound, & power are all very balanced. The inventory was unique & while it was hard to understand at first, when's I got to understand it, it became fun to use. I would still say that RE5 inventory was better in a way though RE6 inventory does have some better things than RE5's inventory. 

Graphics: 
The graphics are very nice & detailed. They did NOT put a filter that removes away the true colours which is a good idea because they kind of made everything darker and balanced it with lightning visual effects. The visuals & mapping design is very creative & it can easily be said that they put in a lot of effort which is why you don't see a lot of RE6 modded stages simply because it won't be easy modding these type of stages. For me, I really liked it as it seemed to have a unique theme for the RE franchise. The glow, colour saturation, details, shadows, lighting, environments (Ground/Tunnels/Inside/outside/Houses/Sewage), are all PERFECTLY well made!

CONS:
- Game uses microphone & finding the option to disable it is very complicated for some people.
- Accessing the inventory can cause you to slow down or sometimes disable your character's movement.  
- Regular Mercenaries has too little enemies & it's very boring to play. 
- Servers still have a very bad netcode & lag for P2, P3, P4, P5, & P6. 
- A lot of times when you do melee, you are not invincible & you can take damage from enemies. 
- The inventory for some of the characters in No Mercy Mercenaries is very badly put & it doesn't fit the style or theme of this game at all. 

Overall, it's a good game & I bought it exclusively for it's mercenaries mode & I wasn't disappointed as it has a speedy fast paste mercenaries mode & one of the best soundtrack out of all the other RE mercenaries.
